title: DOB Safety Violations
ufd: This dataset contains information on safety violations issued by the NYC Department of Buildings (DOB) that are payable in DOB NOW. It includes details about the violation, such as the issue date, type, and status, as well as the location of the violation, including borough, block, lot, house number, street, city, state, and zip code. A key column is `violation_remarks`, which describes the specific reason for the violation, such as failure to file required inspections. The `violation_type` column categorizes the violation as either HBLVIO or LBLVIO, potentially indicating high or low-pressure boiler violations. The `violation_status` column indicates whether the violation is active. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in safety violations across different boroughs or to identify properties with recurring violations. It can also be used to understand the types of safety violations that are most common in the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details safety violations issued by the NYC Department of Buildings (DOB) that are payable through DOB NOW. It includes comprehensive information about each violation, such as the date, type (HBLVIO or LBLVIO), status, and specific remarks describing the reason for the violation. Location data is also provided, including borough, block, lot, and address details.

title: Street Hail Livery (SHL) Permits
ufd: This dataset contains information on active Street Hail Livery (SHL) permits authorized by the NYC Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC). Each row represents a unique permit, identified by its license number, and includes details about the licensee, such as their name and the license type. The dataset also provides information on the vehicle associated with the permit, including the DMV license plate number, VIN, and vehicle year. Key columns include 'active', indicating whether the permit is currently valid, 'license_status', 'suspension_reason', and the 'date_updated' and 'time_updated' fields, which show when the data was last refreshed. Researchers, transportation analysts, and the general public can use this dataset to understand the current landscape of SHL permits in NYC, track permit status, and analyze trends in vehicle types and associated bases. The dataset also includes contact information of the base, such as name, telephone number, address and website.
sfd:

title: DOB NOW: Electrical Permit Applications
ufd: This dataset contains information on electrical permit applications filed with the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB). It includes details about the job, such as the job filing number, address (house number, street name, borough, and zip code), and job status. The dataset also provides information on the applicant, including license type and number, firm name, and contact information. Key dates include the filing date, job start date, and completion date. You can use this data to track electrical work being performed in the city, analyze trends in electrical permit applications, or examine the distribution of work across different boroughs. The dataset also includes information on insurance policies related to the electrical work, such as general liability and worker's compensation.

title: DOF Parking Violation Codes
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive list of parking violation codes in New York City, along with their corresponding fine amounts. Each entry includes a unique code and a clear definition of the violation, such as "FAILURE TO DISPLAY BUS PERMIT" or "BUS LANE VIOLATION." The fine amounts are broken down by location: "manhattan_96th_st_below" and "all_other_areas," with each fine including a $15 New York State Criminal Justice surcharge. Researchers, urban planners, and transportation enthusiasts can use this data to analyze parking violation patterns, understand the cost associated with different violations, and potentially inform policy decisions related to traffic management and parking enforcement. The dataset contains 97 unique violation codes and their associated fine amounts for different areas of the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details parking violation codes and associated fines in New York City. It includes a comprehensive list of violation codes, their descriptions, and corresponding fine amounts for Manhattan (below 96th St) and all other areas. The dataset is valuable for understanding parking regulations and their financial implications in NYC.

Related Topics:

Applications and Use Cases:

title: Medallion Vehicles - Inactive
ufd: This dataset provides information on inactive medallion vehicles, offering insights into the status and reasons for their inactivity. Key columns include the license number, the name of the licensee, the date of the license, and the current status of the medallion. The dataset also specifies the DMV license plate number, vehicle identification number (VIN), vehicle type (e.g., HYB, WAV, BEV), and the model year of the vehicle. Furthermore, it details the medallion type (either "Named Driver" or "Owner Must Drive"), the agent number, suspension date, and the reason for suspension. This data can be used to analyze trends in medallion vehicle inactivity, understand the common reasons for suspension, and track vehicle characteristics associated with inactive medallions. The dataset is updated daily and includes the last updated date and time for accuracy.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: SARS-CoV-2 concentrations measured in NYC Wastewater
ufd: This dataset contains information about SARS-CoV-2 N gene levels in New York City's Wastewater Resource Recovery Facilities (WRRF). It includes data disaggregated by WRRF, sample collection date, and test date. Key columns include `wrrf_name` (the name of the wastewater treatment plant), `sample_date` and `test_date` (the dates of sample collection and testing), `population_served` (the population served by the WRRF), and `copies_l` (SARS-CoV-2 concentration). The `technology` column specifies the type of digital PCR used for the analysis. Note that the RT-qPCR was changed to digital PCR in April 2023, resulting in values that are about 10-20 times higher than those of RT-qPCR. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to track trends in SARS-CoV-2 concentrations in NYC WRRF influent.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset provides SARS-CoV-2 N gene concentration levels detected in influent wastewater samples collected from New York City's Wastewater Resource Recovery Facilities (WRRFs). The data is organized by WRRF, sample date, and test date, and includes information on the population served by each facility. The dataset also specifies the digital PCR technology used for analysis, noting a change from RT-qPCR in April 2023 that resulted in higher concentration values.

**Related Topics:**
- Wastewater Surveillance
- SARS-CoV-2
- Public Health
- Epidemiology
- Viral Load
- Environmental Monitoring
- New York City

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- SARS-CoV-2 N gene: Coronavirus nucleocapsid gene, COVID-19 marker
- Wastewater Resource Recovery Facility (WRRF): Wastewater treatment plant, sewage treatment plant
- Copies/L (copies_l): Viral concentration, viral load, gene copies per liter
- Sample Date: Collection date, date of sample
- Test Date: Analysis date, date of testing
- Digital PCR: dPCR, Polymerase Chain Reaction
- RT-qPCR: Reverse transcription quantitative PCR, Real-time PCR

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Tracking trends in SARS-CoV-2 prevalence in NYC communities.
- Monitoring the effectiveness of public health interventions.
- Predicting potential surges in COVID-19 cases.
- Comparing viral loads across different WRRFs and neighborhoods.
- Assessing the impact of new variants on wastewater concentrations.
- Evaluating the performance of different PCR technologies for wastewater surveillance.

title: Electronics Drop Off Locations in NYC
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive list of electronics drop-off locations across New York City, essential for residents looking to responsibly dispose of unwanted electronic devices in compliance with New York State law. The dataset includes key details such as the borough, neighborhood (ntaname), and name of the drop-off site (dropoff_sitename), along with the address and zip code for easy navigation. You can use this dataset to find the nearest and most convenient electronics recycling location. Additionally, the dataset incorporates geographic information like community district, census tract, council district, and other political districts, enabling analysis of recycling accessibility across different areas. The inclusion of latitude and longitude coordinates allows for mapping and spatial analysis of drop-off locations. This dataset can be valuable for city planners, environmental organizations, and residents interested in promoting responsible e-waste disposal and understanding resource distribution.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset catalogs electronics drop-off locations throughout New York City. It includes details such as location name, address, borough, and neighborhood, along with geographic information like latitude, longitude, and political districts. This data is useful for locating e-waste recycling centers and analyzing recycling accessibility across different areas of NYC.

  - New York City: NYC, New York, boroughs (Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island)

title: Census Demographics at the Neighborhood Tabulation Area (NTA) level
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at population changes in New York City at the neighborhood level between the years 2000 and 2010. It includes demographic information aggregated to Neighborhood Tabulation Areas (NTAs), which are groupings of census tracts within the city. Key columns include the borough and NTA name, allowing users to analyze population trends in specific geographic areas. The dataset also contains the FIPS county code for each area. Population figures are provided for both 2000 and 2010, along with the numerical and percentage change over that decade. Researchers, city planners, and community organizations can use this data to understand population shifts, identify areas of growth or decline, and inform policy decisions. The data spans across the Bronx, Brooklyn, and Manhattan boroughs.

title: Energy and Water Data Disclosure for Local Law 84 2021 (Data for Calendar Year 2020)
ufd: This dataset contains energy and water consumption data for large privately-owned and City-owned buildings in New York City for the year 2020. It includes property-specific information such as `property_id`, `property_name`, address details (`address_1`, `city`, `postcode`), and building characteristics like `year_built` and `primary_property_type`. Key metrics include energy usage intensity (`site_eui_kbtu_ft`, `source_eui_kbtu_ft`), greenhouse gas emissions (`total_ghg_emissions_metric_tons_co2e`), and water consumption (`water_use_all_water_sources_kgal`). The dataset also provides information on Energy Star scores and certifications. Researchers, policymakers, and building managers can use this data to benchmark building performance, identify energy and water efficiency opportunities, and track progress towards sustainability goals. The dataset includes location information to allow for spatial analysis of energy and water usage.
sfd:

title: OpenRecords FOIL Requests
ufd: This dataset provides information on Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) requests submitted to the Department of City Planning. Each row represents a single request, identified by a unique `request_id`. Key details include the `request_created_date` and `request_submitted_date`, indicating when the request was initiated and formally submitted, respectively. The `request_due_date` specifies the deadline for the response, while the `request_close_date` marks when the request was resolved. All requests in this sample were submitted via `Mail` and have a `Closed` status. Researchers and the public can use this dataset to analyze the efficiency and timeliness of the Department of City Planning's response to FOIL requests. It could also be used to understand trends in information requests over time.
sfd:

title: Energy and Water Data Disclosure for Local Law 84 2022 (Data for Calendar Year 2021)
ufd: This dataset contains energy and water consumption data for buildings in New York City, collected annually via EPA Portfolio Manager as part of Local Law 84. It offers insights into the environmental performance of individual properties, including energy star scores, site energy use, and greenhouse gas emissions. Key columns include `property_name`, `year_ending`, `energy_star_score`, `site_eui_kbtu_ft` (site energy use intensity), and `total_ghg_emissions_metric` (total greenhouse gas emissions). The dataset also provides location information such as `city` and `postal_code`, as well as property type classifications. Researchers and policy analysts can use this data to benchmark building performance, track progress towards sustainability goals, and identify opportunities for energy and water efficiency improvements. The data allows for comparisons against similar buildings both within the city and nationally.

  - Analyzing the impact of energy efficiency improvements over time.
  - Comparing building performance across different property types and locations.
  - Developing predictive models for energy consumption and GHG emissions.
  - Evaluating the effectiveness of energy efficiency policies and programs.

title: Metal Content of Consumer Products Tested by the NYC Health Department
ufd: This dataset contains results from the NYC Health Department's testing of consumer products for metals like lead, arsenic, cadmium, and mercury. It includes the product type and name, such as food spices, candies, or jewelry, along with the concentration of the metal found in parts per million (ppm). The dataset also specifies the manufacturer and the country where the product was made and purchased. The collection date of the sample is recorded. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to identify potentially hazardous products, track trends in metal contamination, and inform public safety measures. The investigation type is also included, providing context for the testing.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the New York City Health Department's testing of consumer products for heavy metal contamination. It includes measurements of lead, arsenic, cadmium, and mercury in various products like food, spices, candies, and jewelry. Information on product origin, manufacturer, and sample collection date is also provided, enabling analysis of potential health risks.

title: Recognized Shop Healthy Stores
ufd: This dataset contains a list of bodegas and grocery stores in the Bronx and Brooklyn that have been recognized for their efforts to promote healthy food choices. These stores participated in the Shop Healthy NYC program and implemented changes such as increasing the availability of healthier foods, promoting them with marketing materials, and placing them in more visible locations. The dataset includes the store name, street address, borough, and zip code, as well as the year the store was awarded and the program wave. Location data is provided through latitude and longitude coordinates, community board, council district, census tract, and neighborhood tabulation area (NTA). Researchers and public health officials can use this data to identify and analyze the impact of the Shop Healthy NYC program on participating stores and their communities. The dataset can also be used to map the locations of recognized stores and assess the geographic distribution of healthy food options.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details grocery stores and bodegas in the Bronx and Brooklyn recognized for promoting healthy food choices through the Shop Healthy NYC program. It includes store locations, award year, and program wave, along with geographic information like latitude/longitude, community board, and census tract. The data allows for analysis of the program's impact and the geographic distribution of healthy food options.

title: Voting/Poll Sites
ufd: This dataset provides information on voting and poll site locations throughout New York City. Each row represents a specific site, identified by its name (`site_name`) and number (`site_number`). Key details include the borough (`borough`), city (`city`), street address (street number and name), and zip code (`zip_code`) of each location. The dataset also specifies voter and handicap entrances. Additional columns such as community board (`community_board`) and council district (`council_district`) provide further administrative context. Location is provided as latitude/longitude coordinates. Researchers, city planners, and voters can use this dataset to identify polling locations, analyze their distribution across the city, and understand the accessibility of voting sites.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details voting and poll site locations in New York City. It includes information such as site name, address, borough, zip code, and accessibility features for each location. Geographic coordinates (latitude/longitude) and administrative district information (community board, council district) are also provided.

Related Topics:
- Elections

Applications and Use Cases:
- Mapping polling locations across NYC.
- Analyzing the distribution of polling places relative to population density.
- Identifying areas with limited access to voting sites.
- Assessing the accessibility of polling places for voters with disabilities.

title: 2017 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records from yellow taxis in 2017. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including details about the pick-up and drop-off times, locations, trip distance, and passenger count. The dataset also provides information on fare amounts, payment types, and vendor IDs. Key columns include `tpep_pickup_datetime` and `tpep_dropoff_datetime` for trip timing, `pulocationid` and `dolocationid` for locations, and `trip_distance` for the length of the trip. Researchers and analysts can use this dataset to study taxi usage patterns, analyze fare structures, or investigate the impact of location on trip characteristics. The `payment_type` column allows for analysis of payment preferences, while the `passenger_count` can be used to understand ridership trends. This data offers valuable insights into transportation patterns within the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed trip records for yellow taxis in 2017. Each record includes information on pickup and drop-off times and locations, trip distance, passenger count, fare amounts, payment types, and vendor IDs. This data allows for analysis of taxi usage patterns and transportation trends.

- Payment type: payment method, credit card, cash

Applications and Use Cases:

- Study fare structures and pricing models.

- Understand ridership patterns based on passenger count.

title: Forestry Work Orders
ufd: This dataset contains records of forestry work orders managed by NYC Parks & Recreation. Each row represents a specific work order, detailing activities performed by parks staff, contractors, or other entities. Key columns include `wotype` which specifies the type of work being done (e.g., Block Pruning, Stump Removal), `wostatus` indicating the current status of the work order (e.g., Open, Closed, Alternate), and `boroughcode` which identifies the borough where the work is taking place. The `communityboard` column provides a more granular location identifier. Additional details include the presence of wood debris (`wowoodremains`) and potential wire conflicts (`wowireconflict`). Researchers and urban planners can use this dataset to analyze forestry activities across the city, track work order progress, and understand resource allocation in different boroughs and community districts. The dataset can be joined to the Forestry Planting Spaces dataset using the `PlantingSpaceGlobalID` and `GLOBALID` columns.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains records of forestry work orders managed by NYC Parks & Recreation. Each record details specific activities performed, including the type of work, status, and location (borough and community board). It includes information on wood debris and wire conflicts, allowing for analysis of forestry activities, work order progress, and resource allocation.

Related Topics:

- Wostatus: Work status, job status, completion status
- Wowoodremains: Wood debris, tree waste, organic material
- Wowireconflict: Wire conflict, utility interference, overhead obstruction

Applications and Use Cases:

- Optimize resource allocation for forestry activities.
- Identify areas with high demand for specific types of forestry work.
- Join with other datasets (e.g., Forestry Planting Spaces) to analyze the relationship between work orders and planting locations.

title: NYC Wi-Fi Hotspot Locations
ufd: This dataset provides locations of public Wi-Fi hotspots across New York City. It includes details such as the borough, type of access (free or limited free), and the provider offering the service (e.g., LinkNYC, Transit Wireless, SPECTRUM). The dataset also contains location information, including latitude, longitude, and specific locations like parks or subway stations. Key columns for analysis include 'borough' to understand Wi-Fi availability across different areas, 'type' to differentiate between free and limited free options, and 'provider' to identify the organizations offering the service. You can use this dataset to find free Wi-Fi hotspots, analyze Wi-Fi coverage in different neighborhoods ('ntaname'), or compare services offered by different providers. The 'activated' column shows when a hotspot was put into service.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations of public Wi-Fi hotspots throughout New York City. It includes information on the borough, access type (free or limited free), provider, and precise location coordinates (latitude and longitude). The dataset also specifies the activation date of each hotspot and the neighborhood it serves.

- Wi-Fi Hotspot: Wireless internet access point, WLAN access point

- Access Type: Free Wi-Fi, Limited Free Wi-Fi

Applications and Use Cases:

title: NYPD Calls for Service (Historic)
ufd: This dataset contains historic records of calls for service to the NYPD's 911 system. Each row represents an entry into the ICAD system, used by call takers and dispatchers. The data includes information on incidents reported by the public and self-initiated entries by NYPD personnel. Key columns include `incident_date` and `incident_time`, detailing when the incident occurred, `nypd_pct_cd`, indicating the police precinct, and `boro_nm`, specifying the borough. The `typ_desc` column provides a description of the incident type, while geographic coordinates (`latitude`, `longitude`) pinpoint the location. Researchers and analysts can use this dataset to study crime patterns, response times, and resource allocation within the NYPD. The data also includes several computed region columns that can be used to analyze incidents by geographic area.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides a historical record of 911 calls for service received by the New York City Police Department (NYPD). Each entry represents an incident logged in the ICAD system, including details on the incident type, location, time, and responding precinct. The data encompasses both public-reported incidents and self-initiated entries by NYPD personnel, offering a comprehensive view of police activity across New York City.

Related Topics:
- Crime statistics
- Emergency response
- Law enforcement
- Public safety
- Geographic analysis
- Urban planning

Concepts and Synonyms:
- 911 calls: emergency calls, calls for service, police dispatches
- Incident: event, occurrence, report, complaint
- NYPD: New York City Police Department, police precinct
- ICAD: Incident Command and Control System
- Borough: district, region, area
- Typ_desc: incident type, description of incident, event category

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze crime trends and patterns across different boroughs and precincts.
- Evaluate NYPD response times to different types of incidents.
- Optimize resource allocation based on incident frequency and severity.
- Identify high-crime areas and develop targeted intervention strategies.
- Study the relationship between environmental factors and crime rates.
- Create visualizations and dashboards to communicate crime statistics to the public.

title: Asbestos Control Program (ACP7)
ufd: This dataset contains information on asbestos control projects in New York City, as reported to the Department of Environmental Protection (DEP). Each row represents an asbestos project notification (ACP7 form) filed with the DEP Asbestos Control Program. Key details include the project's start and end dates, its current status (e.g., Closed, Submitted, Postponed), and the location of the project, specified by borough, zip code, street address, and building identification number (BIN). The data also describes the type and amount of asbestos-containing material (ACM) being abated, the abatement type (e.g., Removal, Repair), and the names of the building owner, contractor, and air monitor involved. Researchers and environmental professionals can use this data to analyze asbestos abatement trends, identify areas with high asbestos activity, and track the progress of asbestos control efforts across the city. The dataset also includes spatial information like latitude, longitude, community board, and council district for location-based analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes information on project start and end dates, status, location (borough, zip code, address, BIN), and details about the asbestos-containing material (ACM) being abated. The data also contains information on the building owner, contractor, and air monitor involved in each project.

title: NYC Citywide Annualized Calendar Sales Update
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of property sales in New York City, offering insights into the real estate landscape. Each row represents a property sale and includes details about the property's location, classification, and sale price. Key columns include 'borough' and 'neighborhood' for location, 'building_class_category' and 'building_class_as_of_final' for property type, and 'sale_price' and 'sale_date' for transaction information. The dataset also contains identifiers such as 'block', 'lot', and 'zip_code' to pinpoint specific properties. Researchers, real estate professionals, and city planners can use this data to analyze sales trends, assess property values, and understand the dynamics of the NYC real estate market. Additional details like 'residential_units', 'commercial_units', and 'total_units' offer insights into the composition of properties. Information regarding tax classes, land and gross square footage, and year built are also included.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains detailed records of property sales in New York City. It includes information on property location, classification, sale price, and sale date. The data allows for analysis of real estate trends, property values, and market dynamics within NYC.

Related Topics:

  - Property Valuation

title: DOF: Property Charges Balance
ufd: This dataset, titled "DOF: Property Charges Balance," provides information on property-related charges for a given period. It includes details such as the parcel ID (`parid`), which uniquely identifies a property, and a product code (`code`) associated with the charge. The dataset also specifies the start (`dt_pd_begin`) and end (`dt_pd_end`) dates for the period the charge is applicable. Key financial columns include the sum of liabilities (`sum_liab`) and collections (`sum_coll`) related to the property.  A transaction counter (`trans_ctr`) is provided, along with flags indicating prior ownership and whether the property is city-owned. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze property charge trends, assess liabilities, and understand property ownership patterns within the city. The `luc` column may provide insights into land use categories.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
The "DOF: Property Charges Balance" dataset contains detailed information on property-related charges, liabilities, and collections. It includes parcel IDs, product codes, and the period for which charges apply. Key data points include sums of liabilities and collections, transaction counters, and flags for prior and city ownership.

**Related Topics:**
- Property Assessment
- Municipal Finance
- Urban Planning
- Tax Collection
- Real Estate
- Land Use

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Parcel ID: Property Identification Number, Unique Property Identifier, PARID
- Liabilities: Debts, Outstanding Charges, Owed Amounts, SUM_LIAB
- Collections: Payments Received, Revenue Collected, SUM_COLL
- Product Code: Charge Type, Fee Code, CODE
- Land Use Category: LUC, Zoning Classification, Property Type
- City-Owned Property: Municipal Property, Government-Owned Land

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Analyze property tax delinquency rates.
- Identify properties with high outstanding liabilities.
- Track trends in property charge collections over time.
- Assess the financial impact of city-owned properties.

- Predict future revenue based on historical collection data.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of property tax enforcement strategies.

title: Neighborhood Financial Health Digital Mapping and Data Tool
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive look at neighborhood financial health indicators across New York City. It includes data for the year 2020, broken down by borough, neighborhood, and community district. Key columns include poverty rate, median income, and demographic percentages (White, Black, Asian, Hispanic). The dataset also features a series of financial health goals and associated indicators, such as access to financial services, affordable goods, quality jobs, and opportunities for building assets. Each goal has an overall outcome score and rank, along with individual indicator outcomes, ranks, and definitions. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze financial disparities between neighborhoods, identify areas needing intervention, and understand the relationship between financial health indicators and demographic factors. The data can also be used to track progress on financial health goals and evaluate the effectiveness of financial empowerment programs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains financial health indicators for New York City neighborhoods in 2020, broken down by borough, neighborhood, and community district. It includes metrics like poverty rate, median income, demographic percentages, and scores related to financial health goals. The data allows for analysis of financial disparities and identification of areas needing intervention.

title: Historical DOB Permit Issuance
ufd: This dataset contains historical records of permits issued by the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB) between 1989 and 2013. Each row represents a single permit and includes information about the property, the type of job being performed, and the parties involved. Key columns include `borough`, `bin` (Building Identification Number), `house` number, `street_name`, `job_type`, and permit details such as `permit_status`, `filing_date`, and `expiration_date`. The dataset also provides details about the permittee and owner, including names, contact information, and license details. Researchers and analysts can use this dataset to study trends in construction and development activity across the city, examine the types of permits being issued in different areas, and analyze the characteristics of permittees and property owners. The data can also be used to understand the distribution of different building types (`bldg_type`) and the prevalence of residential construction (`residential`).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains historical building permit records issued by the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB) from 1989 to 2013. Each record details a specific permit, including property information, job type, permit status, and details about the permittee and property owner. The data allows for analysis of construction and development trends in NYC.

title: DOB After Hour Variance Permits
ufd: This dataset contains information on After Hour Variance (AHV) permits issued by the NYC Department of Buildings (DOB). Each row represents a specific permit granted for work outside of normal working hours. Key details include the address (house number, street name, and borough) where the permitted work is taking place, the AHV permit number, and the reason for the variance, such as public safety or construction activities with minimal noise impact. The dataset also specifies the start and end date/time for the variance. You can use this data to analyze trends in after-hours construction, understand the reasons variances are granted, and identify areas with frequent after-hours work. Additional fields indicate whether the work is enclosed, involves demolition or crane use, or is near a residence. The permit status (issued or rejected) and the type of variance (initial or renewal) are also provided.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details After Hour Variance (AHV) permits issued by the NYC Department of Buildings (DOB) for work conducted outside of standard business hours. Each record represents a unique permit, specifying the location, reason for the variance, and the approved timeframe. The data includes information on the type of work, potential impact (e.g., noise, demolition), and the status of the permit.

title: Housing Litigations
ufd: This dataset provides insights into housing litigations initiated by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) in New York City. It contains information on cases brought against owners of privately-owned buildings to enforce housing quality standards. Key details include the `casetype` (e.g., "Heat and Hot Water", "Tenant Action"), `caseopendate`, `casestatus`, and `casejudgement`. The dataset also includes location information such as `housenumber`, `streetname`, `zip`, `community_district`, `council_district`, `census_tract`, and `nta` (neighborhood tabulation area). You can use this data to analyze trends in housing code violations, identify problematic buildings or landlords, and assess the effectiveness of HPD's enforcement efforts. The `respondent` column lists the parties involved in the litigation. Note that the `findingofharassment` column has mostly null values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details housing litigation cases initiated by New York City's Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) against owners of private buildings. It includes information on the type of case, dates, status, judgement, and location details for each litigation. This data can be used to analyze housing code enforcement trends and identify buildings with frequent violations.

title: Registration Contacts
ufd: This dataset provides details on contacts associated with multiple dwelling registrations. It includes information on individuals and organizations involved, such as corporate owners, agents, and officers. Key columns include `registrationid`, a unique identifier for each registration, `type`, which specifies the contact's role (e.g., CorporateOwner, Agent), and contact details like `corporationname`, `firstname`, `lastname`, and business address information (`businesshousenumber`, `businessstreetname`, `businesscity`, `businessstate`, `businesszip`). The dataset also contains a `contactdescription` field that further describes the contact type. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the network of contacts associated with housing registrations, identify key stakeholders, and understand property management structures. The data can also be used to ensure compliance with registration requirements and improve communication with property owners and managers.
sfd:

title: New York City Climate Projections: Extreme Events and Sea Level Rise
ufd: This dataset contains climate projections for New York City, focusing on extreme weather events and sea level rise. It includes projections for the 2030s, 2050s, and 2080s, as well as sea level rise estimates up to 2150. Key columns include 'period', indicating the time frame of the projection, 'sea_level_rise' which estimates the rise in inches, and several columns detailing the 'number_of_days_year_with' specific conditions, such as extreme temperatures or heavy rainfall. The dataset also provides information on heatwaves, including their frequency and average length. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to understand the potential impacts of climate change on New York City and to develop adaptation strategies. The data is based on the IPCC 6th Assessment report and incorporates advanced climate modeling techniques. Note that a large fraction of the numerical columns have missing values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides climate projections for New York City, focusing on extreme weather events and sea level rise. It includes projections for the 2030s, 2050s, and 2080s, with sea level rise estimates extending to 2150. The data covers metrics like the number of days with extreme temperatures, heavy rainfall, and heatwave characteristics. This information can be used to assess the potential impacts of climate change on New York City.

title: Civilian Complaint Review Board: Complaints Against Police Officers
ufd: This dataset contains information on complaints against New York City police officers, as received and processed by the Civilian Complaint Review Board (CCRB). It includes details on the incident date and time, the borough and precinct where the incident occurred, and the reason for police contact. You can use this data to analyze trends in complaints, identify potential problem areas within the NYPD, and assess the outcomes of police encounters. The dataset also provides information on whether body-worn camera (BWC) or other video evidence was available. Key columns include `complaint_id` for unique identification, `borough_of_incident_occurrence` to understand geographic distribution, `reason_for_police_contact` to categorize the nature of the incident, and `ccrb_complaint_disposition` to see the outcome of the CCRB's review. This information can be valuable for researchers, policymakers, and community members interested in police accountability and transparency.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details complaints filed against New York City Police Department (NYPD) officers, as investigated by the Civilian Complaint Review Board (CCRB). It includes incident details such as date, time, borough, precinct, and reason for police contact. The data also indicates the availability of video evidence and the final disposition of the complaint by the CCRB.

title: Bicycle Counts
ufd: This dataset contains bicycle counts recorded at various locations around New York City. Each row represents a 15-minute interval of bicycle traffic at a specific counter location. The key columns include `id`, which identifies the counter location (refer to the linked Bicycle Counters dataset for details), `date`, which indicates the timestamp of the count, and `counts`, which represents the number of bicycles recorded during that interval. The `status` column indicates the status of the counter, with a value of 0 suggesting normal operation. Researchers and urban planners can use this data to analyze bicycle traffic patterns, identify peak usage times, and assess the impact of infrastructure changes on cycling behavior. Please note that the data may have occasional lapses due to technical issues. The timestamps are recorded in GMT/UTC timezone.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed bicycle traffic counts in New York City, recorded in 15-minute intervals. It includes the location ID, timestamp, bicycle count, and counter status for each interval. This data is valuable for understanding cycling trends and infrastructure performance.

Applications and Use Cases:

- Support urban planning initiatives related to sustainable transportation.

title: Privately Owned Public Spaces (POPS)
ufd: This dataset provides detailed information about Privately Owned Public Spaces (POPS) in New York City. POPS are public spaces provided by private owners in exchange for zoning incentives. The dataset includes location information such as borough name, community district, address, and zip code, as well as geographic coordinates. Key details about each POPS include its type (e.g., plaza, arcade), required size, hours of access, and amenities. You can use this dataset to find POPS locations, understand the types of public spaces available, and assess their accessibility and amenities. Researchers and urban planners can use this data to analyze the distribution and characteristics of POPS across the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset catalogs Privately Owned Public Spaces (POPS) throughout New York City. It includes location details like address, borough, and coordinates, alongside information on the type, size, accessibility, and amenities of each POPS. This data allows users to understand the distribution and characteristics of these publicly accessible spaces within the city.

title: Clean Air Tracking System (CATS) Permits
ufd: This dataset contains information on Clean Air Tracking System (CATS) permits in New York City. It includes details on boiler registrations, renewals, work permits, and inspection requests submitted by NYC residents. Key columns include `requestid` and `applicationid` for unique identification, `requesttype` to categorize the type of request, and location information such as `house`, `street`, and `borough`. The dataset also provides specifics on the equipment involved, such as the `make` and `model` of the boiler and burner, as well as the `primaryfuel` and `secondaryfuel` used. You can use this data to analyze trends in air quality permit applications, understand the distribution of different request types across boroughs, or examine the types of equipment and fuels being used in NYC. The `issuedate` and `status` columns allow for tracking the lifecycle and current state of each permit.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed information on Clean Air Tracking System (CATS) permits issued in New York City. It encompasses boiler registrations, renewals, work permits, and inspection requests submitted by NYC residents. Key details include request types, location information, equipment specifics, fuel types, and permit status.

- Investigate potential correlations between permit activity and air quality measurements.

title: NYPD Criminal Court Summons (Historic)
ufd: This dataset provides a breakdown of criminal summonses issued by the NYPD in New York City. Each row represents a single summons and includes details about the offense, such as "PUBLIC URINATION" or "RECKLESS DRIVING," along with the corresponding law section number and a more general law description. The data also captures demographic information about the individuals receiving the summons, including their age group, sex, and race. Location information is provided through borough, precinct, x/y coordinates, latitude, and longitude. Researchers and the public can use this dataset to analyze trends in police enforcement, understand the types of offenses being summonsed, and examine potential disparities in enforcement across different demographic groups and geographic areas. The `summons_date` column indicates when the summons was issued, and the `summons_key` serves as a unique identifier for each record.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains records of criminal summonses issued by the NYPD in New York City. Each record details the offense, relevant law information, and demographic data of the individual receiving the summons. Location details, including borough, precinct, and coordinates, are also included, enabling spatial analysis of summons activity.

- Investigate the relationship between summonses and other crime statistics.

title: NYCEM Emergency Notifications
ufd: This dataset contains a collection of emergency notifications issued by NYCEM, providing valuable insights into public safety events and important city services. Each record includes a unique ID, the date and time of the notification, the notification type (e.g., Transportation, Public Health, Emergency Activity), a brief title, and the full email body containing detailed information. The 'notificationtype' column categorizes the alerts, allowing users to filter and analyze specific types of events. The 'email_body' column provides detailed descriptions of the events, including locations, times, and recommended actions. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze trends in emergency events, improve resource allocation, and enhance public communication strategies. The data can also be used by the public to stay informed about potential disruptions and safety concerns in their area. With 100 rows and spanning various notification types, this dataset offers a comprehensive snapshot of emergency communication in New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset comprises emergency notifications issued by NYCEM, offering insights into public safety events and city services. title: School Zones 2024-2025 (Elementary School)
ufd: This dataset provides information on elementary school zones for the 2024-2025 school year. It includes geographic boundaries of school zones, represented by the `the_geom` column, and the corresponding school district (`schooldist`). The borough in which the school zone is located is indicated by the `boro` and `boro_num` columns. The `initials` column may provide abbreviated identifiers for the school zone. The `label` column offers a user-friendly identifier, and the `dbn` column contains the official school district number. This dataset can be used to determine the elementary school zoning for a specific location, understand school district boundaries, and analyze the geographic distribution of school zones within a borough. Additional details or exceptions regarding zoning can be found in the `remarks` column.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details elementary school zones for the 2024-2025 school year, including geographic boundaries and school district information. It provides details such as school district number, borough, and user-friendly identifiers for each zone. The dataset allows users to understand school zoning boundaries and analyze the geographic distribution of school zones.

title: Local Law 251 of 2017: Published Data Asset Inventory
ufd: This dataset, titled "Local Law 251 of 2017: Published Data Asset Inventory," provides a comprehensive inventory of datasets available on the NYC Open Data portal. It includes key information about each dataset, such as the responsible agency (`datasetinformation_agency`), a unique identifier (`uid`), its name, and a descriptive summary. The dataset also tracks compliance with data retention standards, the presence of a data dictionary, and whether the data is geocoded. Users can leverage this inventory to understand the breadth of data available, assess compliance with open data policies, and identify relevant datasets for their specific needs. Additional columns provide insights into update frequency (`update_updatefrequency`), automation status, and whether records have been removed for compliance reasons. This information helps users understand the maintenance and quality of the datasets.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The "Local Law 251 of 2017: Published Data Asset Inventory" dataset catalogs datasets published on the NYC Open Data portal. It provides details like agency responsible, unique dataset ID, dataset name, and a descriptive summary. The dataset also tracks compliance with data retention standards, data dictionary availability, and geocoding status, offering insights into dataset maintenance and quality.

title: NYCHA Public Housing Developments
ufd: This dataset contains the locations of New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) public housing developments. Each row represents a single development. The `the_geom` column provides the geographical coordinates defining the boundaries of the development. The `developmen` column gives the address of the development, while `tds_num` is a unique identifier. The `borough` column indicates the borough in which the development is located. This dataset could be used to analyze the geographic distribution of public housing across the city, to study the relationship between public housing and other urban characteristics, or to support community planning efforts. Note that the Borough column has some missing values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations and attributes of New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) public housing developments. It includes geographic coordinates, addresses, unique identifiers, and borough information for each development. The dataset provides a spatial representation of public housing across NYC, enabling geographic analysis and urban planning applications.

title: Police Precincts
ufd: This dataset contains geographic boundaries and identifying information for police precincts in New York City. Each precinct is uniquely identified by its 'precinct' number, ranging from 1 to 123. The 'the_geom' column provides the geospatial data defining the precinct's boundaries as a MultiPolygon. 'shape_leng' and 'shape_area' represent the length and area of the precinct's boundary. Researchers, city planners, and the public can use this dataset to visualize police precinct locations, analyze spatial relationships between precincts and other city features, or calculate precinct-specific statistics. The dataset includes 78 police precincts. This data is updated and previous versions are available on the DCP Website.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides geographic boundaries and identifying information for New York City police precincts. Each precinct is uniquely identified by its number, with geospatial data defining its boundaries as a MultiPolygon. The dataset includes attributes like precinct number, geometry, shape length, and shape area, enabling spatial analysis and visualization.

title: Pregnancy-Associated Mortality
ufd: This dataset provides information on pregnancy-associated deaths in New York City, offering insights into maternal mortality trends and contributing factors. It includes data from vital records and the Maternal Mortality and Morbidity Review Committee (M3RC) review process. The dataset spans from 2016 to 2018 and allows users to explore deaths categorized by their relationship to pregnancy, underlying cause, race/ethnicity, and borough of residence. Key columns include 'year', 'related' (pregnancy-related, associated, or undetermined), 'underlying_cause' of death, 'race_ethnicity', 'borough', and the number of 'deaths'. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to analyze disparities in maternal mortality, identify key risk factors, and inform interventions aimed at improving maternal health outcomes. The data are not cross-classified on all variables.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on pregnancy-associated deaths in New York City from 2016 to 2018. It includes details on the relationship of the death to pregnancy, underlying cause, race/ethnicity, and borough of residence. The data is sourced from vital records and the Maternal Mortality and Morbidity Review Committee (M3RC) review process.

title: 2019 - 2020 School Locations
ufd: This dataset provides information on school locations for the 2019-2020 fiscal year. It includes details such as location name, address, grades served, and the administrative district. The dataset also specifies the type and category of each location, such as "General Academic" or "Elementary." Key columns include `location_name`, `grades_final_text` which specifies the final grades served at the location, `location_type_description`, and geographic information like `community_district` and `state_code`. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze the distribution of school types across different districts, understand the range of grades offered at various locations, or map school locations within specific communities. The `managed_by_name` column indicates whether a school is managed by the DOE or is a charter school. The `open_date` and `status_descriptions` columns provide insights into the history and current operational status of each location.

title: Buildings Selected for the Alternative Enforcement Program (AEP)
ufd: This dataset provides information on buildings in New York City that have been selected for the Alternative Enforcement Program (AEP). The AEP, run by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD), focuses on severely distressed multiple dwellings. Key details include the building's address, represented by street address, boro (borough), postcode, latitude, and longitude, as well as identifiers like building_id, BIN, and BBL. The dataset tracks the building's progress in the AEP, including the aep_start_date, current_status (AEP Active or Discharged), discharge_date, and aep_round. You can also find the total_units in each building and the number of open building code violations at the start of the program. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the effectiveness of the AEP, identify areas with distressed housing, and track changes in building conditions over time.
sfd:

It includes building addresses, identifiers, AEP status and dates, total units, and initial open building code violations. title: NYC Permitted Event Information - Historical
ufd: This dataset contains historical information on permitted events in New York City. Each row represents a specific event, identified by a unique `event_id` and described by its `event_name`. The dataset includes the `start_date_time` and `end_date_time` of the event, as well as the `event_agency` responsible for the permit. You can find out what `event_type` it is, such as a "Special Event", "Farmers Market", or "Construction". The `event_borough` and `event_location` provide spatial context, while `community_board` and `police_precinct` offer administrative details. The `street_closure_type` indicates if there were any street closures associated with the event. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in event types, locations, and agencies over time, or to understand the impact of events on different communities.
sfd:

Each entry includes the event's name, start and end times, responsible agency, type, borough, location, and related administrative details like community board and police precinct. title: Tobacco Retail Dealer and Electronic Cigarette Retail Dealer Caps by Community District
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the regulation of tobacco and electronic cigarette retail within New York City. It details the maximum number of Tobacco Retail Dealer (TRD) and Electronic Cigarette Retail Dealer (ECD) licenses allowed in each community district, alongside the current number of active licenses. Key columns include 'borough' and 'community_district_name' for location, 'tobacco_retail_dealer_cap' and 'electronic_cigarette_retail' for license limits, and 'active_tobacco_retail_dealer' and 'active_electronic_cigarette' for the number of active licenses. The 'trd_available_under_cap' and 'ecd_available_under_cap' columns indicate the number of licenses still available in each district. This data can be used to analyze the density of tobacco and e-cigarette retailers across different communities, assess the potential for new businesses, and understand the regulatory landscape. Researchers, policymakers, and business owners can leverage this information for market analysis, regulatory compliance, and public health initiatives. The dataset is updated periodically, as indicated by the 'data_as_of' column.
sfd:

The data enables analysis of retailer density, potential business opportunities, and the regulatory environment across different communities.

- Researching the impact of regulations on the retail landscape.

title: DOB Stalled Construction Sites
ufd: This dataset provides information on stalled construction sites in New York City, as reported to the Department of Buildings (DOB). It includes details on the location of the stalled sites, such as the borough, community board, house number, and street name. Each entry represents a complaint made about construction activity that has stopped abruptly. The `date_complaint_received` column indicates when the complaint was filed, while the `dobrundate` column shows the date of the last update for the stalled status. The `complaint_number` serves as a unique identifier for each complaint. This dataset could be used to analyze the geographic distribution of stalled construction projects, track complaint resolution times, or identify trends in construction activity across different boroughs and community boards. It offers insights into potential issues affecting development and construction progress in the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains records of stalled construction site complaints reported to the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB). It includes details such as the location of the stalled sites (borough, address), complaint date, and last update date. The data can be used to understand the distribution and characteristics of stalled construction projects across NYC.

Related Topics:
- Construction
- Real Estate Development
- Urban Planning
- New York City
- Building Permits
- Department of Buildings (DOB)
- Complaint Management

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Stalled Construction: Inactive construction, stopped construction, delayed construction, abandoned construction
- Complaint: Grievance, report, issue, concern
- DOB: Department of Buildings, NYC DOB
- Borough: County, district, area
- Construction Site: Building site, development site, project site
- DOB Run Date: Last updated date, update date

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the geographic distribution of stalled construction sites across NYC.
- Track complaint resolution times for stalled construction projects.
- Identify trends in construction activity and potential development issues.
- Investigate the impact of stalled construction on property values.
- Monitor construction progress and identify potential delays.
- Predict future construction slowdowns based on historical data.

title: FHV Base Aggregate Report
ufd: This dataset provides a monthly overview of For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) activity in New York City, as reported by licensed bases to the NYC Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC). It includes key metrics such as the total number of dispatched trips, the number of shared trips, and the count of unique vehicles dispatched by each base. Each record details the activity for a specific base, identified by its license number and name, for a given month and year. The "DBA" column, if populated, indicates the "doing business as" name of the base. Researchers, city planners, and transportation analysts can use this data to understand trends in FHV usage, shared mobility adoption, and the operational scale of different bases. Please note that data accuracy depends on the completeness and accuracy of submissions from the bases.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains monthly statistics on For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) trips in New York City, as reported to the NYC Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC). It includes information on dispatched trips, shared trips, and unique vehicles dispatched by FHV bases. The data is organized by base license number and name, providing a detailed view of individual base activity each month.

Related Topics:
- Transportation
- Urban Planning
- Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC)
- For-Hire Vehicles (FHV)
- New York City
- Mobility
- Shared Mobility
- Vehicle Dispatch

- Base: Dispatch Company, FHV Company, Licensed Operator

- Shared Trips: Pool Rides, Shared Rides, Multi-Passenger Trips

title: Protected Streets Map - Block (Dataset)
ufd: This dataset provides information on protected streets in New York City. Each row represents a block of protected street, identified by its geographic coordinates (`the_geom`) and a unique code (`oftcode`). The dataset includes the borough (`geoborough`) where the street is located, the name of the street (`onstreetna`), and the cross streets defining the block (`fromstreet`, `tostreetna`). You can also find the start and end dates of the street protection (`dateprotec`, `dateprot_1`). This data could be used to analyze the distribution of protected streets across the city, plan routes considering street protection measures, or assess the impact of these measures over time. The `shape_stle` column likely represents the length of the street segment.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details protected streets within New York City, offering a block-by-block view. Each entry includes geographic coordinates, borough, street names, and the start/end dates of protection. The data allows for analysis of protected street distribution and planning around these measures.

**Related Topics:**
- Urban Planning
- Transportation Infrastructure
- Street Safety
- Geographic Data
- New York City
- Public Works

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Protected Streets: Bike lanes, pedestrian zones, traffic calming measures, safe streets
- Geographic Coordinates: Latitude, Longitude, `the_geom`
- Street Block: Street segment, block face
- Borough: Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island, `geoborough`
- Street Names: `onstreetna`, `fromstreet`, `tostreetna`
- Protection Dates: Implementation dates, start date, end date, `dateprotec`, `dateprot_1`

**Applications and Use Cases:**

title: 2016 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip details from yellow taxis in 2016. Each row corresponds to a single taxi trip, including pickup and drop-off times, locations (longitude and latitude), and trip distance. Key columns include `vendorid` identifying the taxi company, `passenger_count`, and `trip_distance`. The dataset also provides a breakdown of fares, including `fare_amount`, `extra` charges, `mta_tax`, `tip_amount`, `tolls_amount`, `improvement_surcharge`, and the `total_amount` paid.  `ratecodeid` offers information about the rate type, and `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip record was temporarily stored in the vehicle before being sent to the vendor. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi usage patterns, analyze fare structures, or build predictive models for trip demand. The `payment_type` column allows for analysis of payment method preferences.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed information on individual taxi trips in 2016, specifically focusing on yellow taxis. It includes trip characteristics such as pickup and drop-off locations and times, distance traveled, passenger count, and a comprehensive breakdown of fares and charges. The data allows for analysis of taxi usage patterns and fare structures.

Related Topics:
- Taxi trips
- Transportation data
- Fare analysis
- Geographic data
- Time series analysis
- Urban mobility

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Taxi trip: ride, journey, cab ride
- Fare amount: trip cost, price, charge
- Pickup location: origin, start point
- Drop-off location: destination, end point
- Trip distance: mileage, travel length
- Passenger count: number of riders, occupancy

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze taxi ridership patterns and trends.

- Study the impact of pricing on taxi usage.
- Develop fare estimation models.

- Analyze payment method preferences among taxi riders.

title: Housing Maintenance Code Violations NYCHA properties
ufd: This dataset contains records of Housing Maintenance Code violations issued in New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) properties. Each row represents a specific violation identified during an inspection, often prompted by NYC Housing Court requests. Key details include the `viol_desc` which describes the violation, location information such as `boro_nm` (borough name), `str_nm` (street name), and `zip` code, as well as the `development_name` of the NYCHA property. The `bldg_id` and `stairhall_no` help pinpoint the specific building and stairwell where the violation occurred. Inspection and approval dates (`insp_dt`, `viol_appr_dt`) provide a timeline for the violation. Researchers, housing advocates, and city planners can use this data to analyze housing quality trends in NYCHA properties, identify areas with frequent violations, and assess the effectiveness of code enforcement. The `hzrd_clas` column indicates the hazard class associated with the violation.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details Housing Maintenance Code violations recorded in New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) properties. Each entry represents a specific violation, including its description, location within the NYCHA development, and dates related to inspection and approval. The data allows for analysis of housing quality and code enforcement within NYCHA properties.

Related Topics:
- Housing Quality
- Code Enforcement
- Public Housing
- Urban Development
- NYC Open Data
- Property Maintenance

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Housing Maintenance Code Violations: Housing code violations, property violations, building code violations
- NYCHA: New York City Housing Authority, public housing, housing developments
- `viol_desc`: Violation description, violation details, code violation type
- `boro_nm`: Borough name, NYC borough, county
- `development_name`: Housing development, property name, NYCHA complex
- `insp_dt`: Inspection date, violation date, date of inspection
- `hzrd_clas`: Hazard class, violation severity, risk level

Applications and Use Cases:

- Investigate the relationship between violation types and hazard classes.

- Support research on housing quality and living conditions in public housing.

title: Incidents Responded to by Fire Companies
ufd: This dataset provides details on incidents responded to by fire companies, including fire, medical, and non-fire emergencies. Each row represents a unique incident, identified by `im_incident_key`. Key details include the `incident_type_desc`, describing the nature of the incident (e.g., "Passenger vehicle fire," "Rescue, EMS incident"), and the `incident_date_time`, `arrival_date_time`, and `last_unit_cleared_date_time`, indicating the timeline of the response. The `fire_box` and location details like `street_highway`, `zip_code`, and `borough_desc` specify where the incident occurred. The `action_taken1_desc`, `action_taken2_desc`, and `action_taken3_desc` columns describe the actions taken by the fire service personnel. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this dataset to analyze incident types, response times, and actions taken in different locations. The `total_incident_duration` column allows for analysis of the time spent on different types of incidents. Information about `property_use_desc` may be used to understand the types of properties where incidents occur.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains detailed information on fire department responses to various incidents, including fires, medical emergencies, and other non-fire events. Each record represents a unique incident and includes details about the incident type, location, response timeline, and actions taken by fire service personnel. The data spans various locations identified by fire box, street, zip code, and borough.

Related Topics:
- Fire Department
- Emergency Medical Services (EMS)
- Public Safety
- Incident Response

- Actions Taken: Fire service actions, interventions, procedures

Applications and Use Cases:

title: DOHMH Indoor Environmental Complaints
ufd: This dataset contains information about indoor environmental complaints reported to the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH). Each record represents a single complaint, often received through the 311 system. Key details include the complaint number, date received, incident address (including street address, zip code, and borough), and the status of the complaint. The dataset also specifies the type of complaint, such as asbestos, indoor air quality, or mold, along with a more detailed descriptor. Location information, including latitude, longitude, community board, and council district, is available for some complaints. Researchers and the public can use this data to understand the types and locations of indoor environmental concerns reported in NYC, although the presence of an address does not indicate a violation was found, only that a complaint was made.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains records of indoor environmental complaints reported to the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH), primarily through the 311 system. Each entry includes details such as complaint number, date received, incident address, complaint type (e.g., asbestos, mold), and complaint status. Location information like latitude, longitude, and borough are also provided for some records.

Related Topics:

title: NYCHA Residential Addresses
ufd: This dataset provides a list of NYCHA (New York City Housing Authority) residential addresses, offering insights into public housing locations across the city. Each record includes detailed address information, such as the development name, house number, street, city, state, and zip code, along with geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude). The dataset also contains administrative information, including borough, community district, city council district, and various state and federal legislative districts. Key columns like "development" and "address" pinpoint the specific location, while "borough" and "city" provide broader geographic context. Researchers, urban planners, and community organizations can use this data to analyze the distribution of public housing, understand its relationship to surrounding neighborhoods, and assess the needs of NYCHA residents. The "building" and "stairhall_" columns offer a more granular view within each development.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a comprehensive list of NYCHA (New York City Housing Authority) residential addresses, including geographic coordinates and administrative district information. It provides detailed location data for public housing developments across New York City. The dataset includes address components like development name, house number, street, city, state, and zip code, as well as borough, community district, and legislative districts.

title: 2020 - 2021 Diversity Report
ufd: This dataset provides information on admissions methods and diversity initiatives in New York City public schools for the 2020-2021 school year. Each row represents a specific program within a school, detailing the admissions process, program name (e.g., Kindergarten, Gifted & Talented), and any diversity considerations used in admissions. Key columns include 'school_name', 'program_name', 'admissions_method_for_students', and 'diversity_in_admissions'. The 'diversity_in_admissions' column describes priorities given to specific groups of applicants, such as those eligible for free or reduced-price lunch. Researchers, parents, and education advocates can use this data to understand how different schools and programs approach admissions and promote diversity. The 'selection_criteria_for' column offers insights into the academic and non-academic factors considered for screened programs. Note that a large fraction of values for 'diversity_in_admissions' and 'selection_criteria_for' are missing.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details admissions methods and diversity initiatives in New York City public schools for the 2020-2021 school year. It provides information on specific programs within schools, including the admissions process, program name, and diversity considerations. The data can be used to understand how schools and programs approach admissions and promote diversity.

Related Topics:

title: Drinking Water Quality Distribution Monitoring Data
ufd: This dataset contains drinking water quality monitoring data, providing a snapshot of water quality at various distribution sites. Each row represents a sample taken at a specific location and time, with the `sample_date` and `sample_time` columns indicating when the sample was collected, and `sample_site` identifying the location. Key measurements include `residual_free_chlorine_mg_l`, `turbidity_ntu`, `coliform_quanti_tray_mpn_100ml`, `e_coli_quanti_tray_mpn_100ml`, and `fluoride_mg_l`, which are all indicators of water quality. The `sample_class` column indicates whether the sample was taken for compliance or operational purposes. This data could be used to assess the overall quality of drinking water, identify potential contamination issues, or track changes in water quality over time. Researchers and water quality professionals can use this information to ensure public health and safety. Note that fluoride measurements are missing for a large portion of the samples.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides drinking water quality measurements collected from various distribution sites. Each record represents a water sample taken at a specific date, time, and location. Key measurements include chlorine levels, turbidity, coliform bacteria counts, E. coli bacteria counts, and fluoride levels, providing a comprehensive overview of water quality.

Related Topics:
- Water Quality
- Environmental Monitoring
- Public Health
- Water Resources
- Drinking Water Standards
- Water Treatment

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Drinking Water Quality: Potable water quality, tap water quality
- Water Quality Parameters: Water quality indicators, water quality metrics
- Residual Free Chlorine: Chlorine residual, free chlorine concentration
- Turbidity: Water clarity, cloudiness
- Coliform Bacteria: Total coliforms, bacterial contamination
- E. coli: Escherichia coli, fecal coliforms
- Fluoride: Fluoridation, fluoride concentration
- Sample Site: Water distribution point, sampling location

Applications and Use Cases:
- Assessing drinking water quality compliance with regulatory standards.
- Identifying potential sources of water contamination.
- Tracking changes in water quality over time.
- Developing predictive models for water quality parameters.

- Investigating the relationship between water quality and public health outcomes.

title: ACRIS - Personal Property Master
ufd: This dataset contains details on personal property-related documents recorded in the Automated City Register Information System (ACRIS). Each row represents a specific document, identified by a unique document ID and CRFN. Key details include the borough where the document was recorded, the type of document (e.g., TERM, INIT, CONT), and the document amount, if applicable. The dataset also provides the recording date and modification date of the document. Additional columns like UCC collateral type and federal tax information are included, though some may have missing values. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze trends in personal property transactions, understand the distribution of document types across boroughs, and potentially assess the financial activity related to these records. The `good_through_date` indicates the expiration date of the document, while `reel_yr`, `reel_nbr`, and `reel_pg` appear to be related to film or microfilm indexing, though their values are consistently zero in this sample.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed information on personal property documents recorded in the Automated City Register Information System (ACRIS). Each record represents a specific document, identified by a unique ID and CRFN, and includes details such as borough, document type, document amount, and recording dates. The data allows for analysis of personal property transactions and trends within the city.

Related Topics:

title: 2023 For Hire Vehicles Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains information about For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) trips in 2023, as reported by livery, luxury, and black car bases. Each row represents a single trip and includes details about the dispatching base, pickup and dropoff times, and affiliated base number. The `dispatching_base_num` and `affiliated_base_number` columns identify the bases involved in the trip. Location information is provided through `dolocationid` and `pulocationid`, representing drop-off and pick-up taxi zones, respectively. While location IDs are included, note that `pulocationid` has a high percentage of missing values. Researchers and transportation planners can use this data to analyze FHV trip patterns, understand base operations, and potentially link trips to specific geographic areas using the taxi zone IDs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) trips in New York City during 2023. It includes information on trip origins and destinations via location IDs, dispatching and affiliated bases, and timestamps. The data allows for analysis of FHV trip patterns and base operations.

title: NYC Open Data Release Tracker
ufd: This dataset tracks the release status of datasets planned for publication on the NYC Open Data portal. It provides a comprehensive list of datasets, the agency responsible for them, and a description of each dataset's contents. Key columns include "agency," indicating the government organization managing the data, "dataset," the name of the dataset, "dataset_description," which offers a summary of the data, and "update_frequency," detailing how often the dataset is refreshed. The "original_plan_date" and "latest_plan_date" columns show the planned and most recent target release dates, while "release_status" indicates the current status (e.g., "Scheduled for release"). Researchers, journalists, and the public can use this dataset to monitor the progress of open data initiatives in New York City. It allows users to identify upcoming datasets of interest and understand any delays or changes in release schedules, as well as agency notes that provide additional context. This information promotes transparency and accountability in city government.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset provides a comprehensive view of planned dataset releases on the NYC Open Data portal. It tracks key information such as the responsible agency, dataset name and description, release status, and planned release dates. This allows users to monitor the progress of open data initiatives and identify datasets of interest.
