title: 311 Call Center Inquiry
ufd: This dataset contains information about inquiries made to the City's 311 call center. Each row represents a single call, with details about the date and time of the call, the agency involved, and the nature of the inquiry. Key columns include "date," "time," "agency" (the responsible agency), "agency_name" (the full name of the agency), "inquiry_name" (the topic of the call), "brief_description" (a short description of the inquiry), and "call_resolution" (the outcome of the call). You can use this data to analyze trends in citizen requests, identify common issues reported to the city, and assess the efficiency of different agencies in resolving inquiries. For example, you could analyze the most frequent inquiry types or the average resolution time for different agencies. Note that due to pandemic call handling modifications, the activity data since March 2020 may not fully represent the agent-handled calls to 311.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details inquiries made to a city's 311 call center, with each record representing a single call. It includes information on the date and time of the call, the responsible city agency, and the specific nature of the inquiry. The data allows for analysis of citizen requests, identification of common issues, and assessment of agency efficiency in resolving inquiries.

title: New York City Climate Projections: Temperature and Precipitation
ufd: This dataset contains temperature and precipitation projections for New York City, as reported by the New York City Panel on Climate Change (NPCC). It includes historical baseline data as well as projections for future years like the 2030s, 2040s, and beyond. The dataset provides both annual and monthly data. Key columns include 'year' and 'month_period' for the time frame, 'mean_temperature' (in °F), and 'mean_precipitation' (in inches). Additionally, the dataset includes several columns ('ensemble_average_mean_changes', etc.) that represent ensemble average mean changes in temperature and precipitation, offering different model projections. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to understand potential climate change impacts on New York City and to inform adaptation and mitigation strategies. The data allows for analysis of both temperature and precipitation trends over time.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes historical data and future projections, covering annual and monthly timeframes. The data allows for analysis of climate trends and potential impacts on New York City.

title: Trade Waste Hauler Licensees
ufd: This dataset provides information on companies licensed to collect and remove trade waste in New York City. Each row represents a licensed entity, identified by a unique BIC Number and Account Name. Key details include the business address (address, city, state, postcode), contact information (phone, email), and license specifics such as effective and expiration dates. The dataset also indicates whether the license is a renewal and the type of authorized recycling collection. Location data, including latitude, longitude, community board, and council district, is available for some entries. This data can be used to identify licensed waste haulers in specific areas of the city, track license status, and analyze recycling practices within the industry. The Application Type field confirms that all entries are for "License" applications.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on businesses licensed to collect trade waste in New York City. It includes details such as business addresses, contact information, license effective and expiration dates, and location data where available. The data can be used to identify licensed waste haulers, track license status, and analyze recycling practices.

Related Topics:
- Waste Management
- Business Licensing
- New York City
- Environmental Regulations
- Recycling

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Trade Waste: Commercial waste, business waste, industrial waste
- BIC Number: Business Integrity Commission Number, License Number, ID
- License: Permit, Authorization, Certification
- Waste Hauler: Waste Collector, Refuse Company, Garbage Company
- Recycling Collection: Recyclables, Sorted Waste, Recoverable Materials

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identifying licensed waste haulers in specific NYC neighborhoods.
- Tracking the renewal status of trade waste collection licenses.
- Analyzing the geographic distribution of licensed waste haulers.
- Investigating recycling practices among licensed companies.
- Mapping licensed waste collection businesses by community board or council district.

title: Storefronts Reported Vacant or Not
ufd: This dataset contains information on storefront vacancies in New York City, collected to comply with Local Law 157 of 2019. It includes data on ground and second-floor storefronts, reported by property owners through an online portal. Each entry represents a storefront registered as of December 31st of the reporting year, with updates provided by June 30th of the following year. Key columns include the `borough_block_lot` and `property_street_address_or` which can be used to identify specific storefronts. The dataset also provides the `borough`, `zip_code`, and `primary_business_activity` for each storefront. Researchers, city planners, and business analysts can use this data to analyze vacancy trends, understand the types of businesses present in different neighborhoods, and assess the economic health of commercial areas. The `vacant_on_12_31` column indicates whether the storefront was vacant at the end of the reporting year.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides details on storefront vacancies in New York City, as reported by property owners to comply with Local Law 157. The data covers ground and second-floor storefronts, including information on their location, business activity, and vacancy status as of December 31st of each reporting year. This resource is valuable for understanding commercial real estate trends and economic activity across NYC neighborhoods.

Related Topics:
- Commercial Real Estate
- Urban Planning
- Economic Development
- Vacancy Rates
- New York City

- Business Activity

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Storefront Vacancy: Empty storefront, vacant commercial space, retail vacancy
- Borough Block Lot (BBL): Property identifier, parcel number
- Primary Business Activity: Business type, industry sector, NAICS code (implied)
- Property Street Address: Storefront address, location
- Local Law 157: NYC storefront registry law, vacancy reporting requirement

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze storefront vacancy rates by borough and zip code.
- Identify areas with high concentrations of vacant storefronts.
- Track changes in vacancy rates over time.
- Understand the types of businesses occupying storefronts in different neighborhoods.
- Assess the impact of Local Law 157 on vacancy reporting.
- Support urban planning and economic development initiatives.
- Provide data for commercial real estate market analysis.

title: NYC Parks Forever Wild
ufd: This dataset delineates the location of ecologically important natural resources within NYC Parks property, known as Forever Wild areas. Each row represents a specific Forever Wild site. Key columns include `gispropnum`, a unique identifier for the property; `propertyname`, the name of the park or area; and `acres`, the size of the area in acres. The `shape` column contains the geographic coordinates defining the boundaries of each Forever Wild area. The `forverwildid` column provides a unique ID for each Forever Wild designated area. Researchers, urban planners, and conservationists can use this data to analyze the distribution, size, and location of protected natural resources within New York City's park system. This information can support conservation efforts, inform land management decisions, and facilitate studies on urban ecology.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the location and characteristics of Forever Wild areas within NYC Parks properties. Each entry represents a specific Forever Wild site, identified by unique identifiers and geographic coordinates. The dataset includes information on the property name, size in acres, and a unique Forever Wild ID, providing a comprehensive overview of protected natural resources within New York City parks.

Related Topics:
- Urban Ecology
- Conservation
- Land Management
- GIS (Geographic Information Systems)
- NYC Parks
- Natural Resources

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Forever Wild: Protected natural areas, conservation zones, ecological preserves
- GISPropNum: Property identifier, unique property ID, park ID
- PropertyName: Park name, area name, location name
- Acres: Area size, land area, property size
- Shape: Geographic boundaries, spatial data, coordinates, polygon
- ForverWildID: Forever Wild identifier, unique area ID, conservation site ID

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyzing the spatial distribution of protected natural resources in NYC.
- Assessing the size and characteristics of Forever Wild areas.
- Supporting conservation planning and land management decisions.
- Conducting research on urban ecology and biodiversity.
- Mapping and visualizing Forever Wild areas within NYC Parks.
- Identifying potential areas for future conservation efforts.

title: Borough Boundaries
ufd: This dataset contains the boundaries for each of the five boroughs in New York City, excluding water areas. Each borough is represented by its unique code (`borocode`) and name (`boroname`). The dataset also provides the area (`shape_area`) and length (`shape_leng`) of each borough's shape. The `the_geom` column contains the geometric representation of each borough's boundary in a MultiPolygon format, which can be used for spatial analysis and mapping. This dataset is useful for urban planning, geographic analysis, and visualization of borough-level data in New York City. Researchers, city planners, and developers can use this data to understand the spatial characteristics of each borough and integrate it with other datasets for comprehensive analysis. The dataset offers a foundational layer for various applications related to New York City's geography and governance.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset delineates the boundaries of the five boroughs of New York City, excluding water areas. It includes a unique code and name for each borough, along with its area and length. The dataset also provides the geometric representation of each borough's boundary in a MultiPolygon format, enabling spatial analysis.

title: Parks Permit Areas
ufd: This dataset contains information about areas within Brooklyn parks that can be permitted for events. Each row represents a specific geographic area, such as a lawn, picnic area, or whole park, identified by a unique CEMS ID. Key columns include `acres`, representing the size of the area, `areatype`, describing the type of park feature, and `name`, providing the name of the park or area. The dataset also includes administrative information like `communityboard` and `councildistrict`. You can use this dataset to identify suitable locations for events within Brooklyn parks, understand the types and sizes of available spaces, and gather relevant location and administrative details. This data is used by the Citywide Event Management System (CEMS) to manage permit requests.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details permitable event spaces within Brooklyn parks, providing information on location, size (acres), and type of area (areatype). Each entry is uniquely identified by a CEMS ID and includes administrative details like community board and council district. The data is used by the Citywide Event Management System (CEMS) for managing permit requests.

Related Topics:

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Permit Areas: event spaces, reservable locations, bookable areas

- Acres: area size, land size, square footage (implied)
- CEMS ID: unique identifier, location ID, permit ID
- Community Board: local government, district board
- Council District: political district, ward

Applications and Use Cases:

title: Certification of No Harassment (CONH) Pilot Building List
ufd: This dataset contains a list of buildings in Manhattan subject to the Certification of No Harassment (CONH) Pilot Program. Each row represents a unique building, identified by its building ID, BIN (Building Identification Number), street address, block, and lot. The dataset includes information on whether a building has a Building Quality Index (BQI) designation, an AEP order (presumably related to environmental protection), or any vacate orders from HPD (Housing Preservation and Development) or DOB (Department of Buildings). It also indicates whether there has been a finding of harassment at the building. Key geographic information includes the borough code (which is consistently 1 for Manhattan), zipcode, latitude, longitude, community board, and council district. This data can be used to identify buildings potentially at risk of tenant harassment, assess the prevalence of vacate orders, or analyze the geographic distribution of buildings under the CONH program. The `date_added` column indicates when the building was added to this list.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details buildings in Manhattan participating in the Certification of No Harassment (CONH) Pilot Program. It provides building-specific information including address, identification numbers (BIN), and geographic coordinates. Key indicators such as Building Quality Index (BQI) designation, AEP orders, vacate orders (HPD/DOB), and harassment findings are included, enabling analysis of building conditions and potential tenant harassment risks.

title: Bicycle Counters
ufd: This dataset provides information about bicycle counters in New York City, detailing their locations and operational parameters. Each row represents a specific bicycle counter, identified by a unique ID and name, such as "Staten Island Ferry" or "Broadway at 50th St." The dataset includes the latitude and longitude coordinates for each counter, allowing for spatial analysis and mapping. Additional details include the data collection interval (in minutes), the timezone, and a counter identifier. The 'domain' column indicates that the data is managed by the New York City DOT. Researchers and urban planners can use this dataset to understand the distribution of bicycle counters across the city and potentially correlate their placement with bicycle traffic patterns (refer to the Bicycle Counts dataset for the actual counts). This information can be valuable for infrastructure planning and promoting cycling as a mode of transportation.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset catalogs bicycle counter locations in New York City, providing details such as their names, unique IDs, and geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude). It includes operational parameters like data collection interval and timezone. The data is managed by the New York City DOT and can be used to understand the spatial distribution of bicycle counters.

Related Topics:

- NYC DOT: New York City Department of Transportation
- Spatial Distribution: Geographic distribution, placement, location pattern

Applications and Use Cases:

- Analyzing the spatial distribution of counters in relation to bicycle traffic patterns (when combined with traffic data).
- Identifying areas with high or low counter density.
- Planning new bicycle infrastructure based on counter placement.
- Correlating counter locations with demographic or socioeconomic data.

title: HIV/AIDS Diagnoses by Neighborhood, Sex, and Race/Ethnicity
ufd: This dataset provides insights into HIV and AIDS diagnoses in New York City, specifically for the year 2021. It breaks down the number of diagnoses and rates per 100,000 people by borough, neighborhood, sex, and race/ethnicity. Key columns include `hiv_diagnoses_num` and `aids_diagnoses_num`, representing the number of new HIV and AIDS diagnoses, respectively. The `hiv_diagnoses_num_per_100k` and `aids_diagnoses_num_per_100k` columns offer standardized rates for comparison across different populations. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to identify trends, disparities, and high-risk areas for targeted interventions. The dataset also includes information on concurrent HIV/AIDS diagnoses, providing a more comprehensive picture of the epidemic. This information can be valuable for resource allocation and prevention efforts.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on HIV and AIDS diagnoses in New York City during 2021. It provides counts and rates of diagnoses, broken down by borough, neighborhood, sex, and race/ethnicity. The data allows for analysis of trends and disparities in HIV/AIDS incidence across different populations within NYC.

title: Building Elevation and Subgrade (BES)
ufd: This dataset provides information on building elevations and subgrade details for New York City, derived from building footprints. Each record represents a building centroid with its location (latitude, longitude) and measurements related to grade and first-floor elevation above sea level. Key columns include `borough` indicating the borough the building is located in, `block` and `lot` which are unique identifiers for the property, `z_grade` representing the building's grade elevation, and `z_floor` representing the first floor elevation. The `subgrade` column indicates whether the building has a subgrade space. Additionally, `notes1` provides context on how the measurements were taken. This dataset can be used to analyze building heights, assess potential flood risks based on elevation, or understand the prevalence of subgrade spaces in different areas of the city. Researchers, city planners, and real estate professionals can leverage this data for various urban planning and development purposes.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains building elevation and subgrade information for New York City, based on building footprints. It includes the location of building centroids (latitude/longitude), grade elevation, first floor elevation, and subgrade presence. The data also provides borough, block, and lot identifiers for each building.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- Real Estate

- Flood Risk Assessment
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Building Elevation: Height above sea level, building height, vertical measurement
- Subgrade: Basement, cellar, underground space
- Z_grade: Grade elevation, ground level, base elevation
- Z_floor: First floor elevation, floor level, entry level
- Building Footprint: Building outline, property boundary
- Borough: NYC borough, district, county

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze building heights across different boroughs of New York City.
- Assess flood risk based on building elevation data.
- Identify areas with a high concentration of buildings with subgrades.
- Support urban planning initiatives related to building development and infrastructure.
- Visualize building elevation data on a map using latitude and longitude coordinates.
- Estimate the cost of construction projects based on elevation and subgrade requirements.

title: DCLA Cultural Organizations
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of cultural organizations in New York City, as listed by the Department of Cultural Affairs (DCLA). Each row represents a unique organization, identified by its name and contact information, including address, city, state, and phone number. Location information is further specified by postcode, council district, borough, latitude, and longitude. You can use this dataset to locate cultural organizations in specific areas of New York City, identify organizations by discipline (e.g., theater, music, dance), or analyze the distribution of cultural resources across different neighborhoods. Additional geographic information is provided through census tract, building identification number (BIN), borough, block, and lot (BBL), and neighborhood tabulation area (NTA). This information could be valuable for researchers, city planners, or anyone interested in exploring the cultural landscape of New York City.
sfd:

title: NYPD Criminal Court Summons Incident Level Data (Year To Date)
ufd: This dataset contains information on criminal court summonses issued by the NYPD in New York City. Each record represents a single summons and includes details about the offense, such as the offense description (e.g., reckless driving, trespass) and the relevant law section number and description. The data also provides demographic information about the individuals receiving the summons, including age group, sex, and race. Location information is included, specifying the borough and precinct where the offense occurred. Researchers and the public can use this dataset to analyze patterns in police enforcement, explore the types of offenses leading to summonses, and examine potential disparities in summons issuance across different demographic groups and locations within New York City. The summons date indicates when the summons was issued. The jurisdiction code specifies the legal jurisdiction applicable to the summons.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: New York City's Flood Vulnerability Index
ufd: This dataset provides insights into flood vulnerability across New York City, aiming to inform resilience policies and programs. It includes a Flood Vulnerability Index (FVI) for different flood hazard scenarios, considering both storm surge and tidal flooding. The key columns include `the_geom`, which contains the geographic boundaries of the analyzed areas, and `fshri`, representing the Flood Susceptibility to Harm and Recovery Index. Other columns like `ss_cur`, `ss_50s`, and `ss_80s` likely represent storm surge scenarios for current conditions, the 2050s, and the 2080s, respectively, while `tid_80s`, `tid_20s`, and `tid_50s` may represent tidal flooding scenarios. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to identify areas most vulnerable to flooding, assess the impact of future climate scenarios, and prioritize resources for flood mitigation and recovery efforts. The `geoid` column likely serves as a unique identifier for each geographic area.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details flood vulnerability in New York City, offering a Flood Vulnerability Index (FVI) across various flood hazard scenarios. It incorporates both storm surge and tidal flooding projections to assess risk. The data includes geographic boundaries (`the_geom`), a Flood Susceptibility to Harm and Recovery Index (`fshri`), and projections for storm surge and tidal flooding under different climate scenarios.

- Tidal Flooding (High Tide Flooding, Nuisance Flooding)

- Geographic Boundaries (Spatial Data, Polygons, `the_geom`)
- Geoid (Unique Identifier, Geographic Identifier)

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identifying areas in NYC most vulnerable to flooding under different climate scenarios.
- Assessing the impact of future climate change on flood risk in specific neighborhoods.
- Prioritizing resources for flood mitigation and recovery efforts based on vulnerability.

- Visualizing flood risk using GIS software and mapping tools.

title: Facilities Database
ufd: This dataset, known as the City Planning Facilities Database (FacDB), compiles information on over 30,000 facilities and program sites across New York City that are owned, operated, funded, or certified by government agencies. It offers a comprehensive view of resources that shape the quality of life in NYC neighborhoods. Key columns include `facname` (facility name), `address`, `city`, `boro` (borough), and `zipcode`, providing location information for each facility. Additionally, the dataset includes geographic coordinates (`latitude`, `longitude`) and identifiers like `bin` and `bbl`.  Researchers, city planners, and the general public can use this dataset to understand the distribution of government resources, identify service gaps, and support community planning initiatives. The inclusion of borough codes and council districts allows for analysis at different administrative levels. This data can be used in conjunction with the interactive web map provided by the Department of City Planning for enhanced filtering and visualization.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The City Planning Facilities Database (FacDB) contains information on over 30,000 facilities and program sites in New York City that are connected to government agencies. It provides details on facility names, addresses, boroughs, zip codes, and geographic coordinates. This dataset is valuable for understanding the distribution of government resources across NYC.

title: 2016-17 - 2020-23 Citywide End-of-Year Attendance and Chronic Absenteeism Data
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive overview of student attendance and chronic absenteeism across New York City's public schools from the 2018-19 to 2022-23 academic years. It includes data for all grades, from Pre-K to 12th grade, and focuses on students in Districts 1-32 and 75 (Special Education). Key columns include 'grade,' 'year,' 'total_days,' 'days_absent,' 'days_present,' 'attendance,' and 'chronically_absent,' allowing users to analyze attendance patterns and identify trends in chronic absenteeism. The 'chronically_absent_1' column represents the percentage of students chronically absent. Researchers, policymakers, and educators can use this data to understand the impact of attendance on student outcomes, evaluate the effectiveness of attendance interventions, and inform strategies to improve student engagement and reduce chronic absenteeism. Note that data from certain student groups (e.g., District 79, charter schools) are excluded, and data suppression may occur to protect student privacy.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains student attendance and chronic absenteeism data for New York City public schools from the 2018-19 to 2022-23 school years. It covers grades Pre-K through 12 in Districts 1-32 and 75 (Special Education). The data includes metrics like total days, days absent, days present, attendance rate, and chronic absenteeism rates, enabling analysis of attendance patterns.

title: 421-a(16) Affordable New York Housing Program Completion Extension - Letters of Intent
ufd: This dataset contains information on buildings seeking tax exemptions under New York State's 421-a Affordable New York Housing Program. It includes data reported by building owners related to construction timelines, the number of dwelling units, and the number of affordable housing units. Key columns include `form_submission_date`, indicating when the form was submitted, `reported_property_addresses` for the building's location, `reported_units` for the total number of units, and `reported_affordale_units` for the number of affordable units. The dataset also provides `reported_commencement_date` and `reported_anticipated` completion dates. Researchers and policy analysts can use this data to track affordable housing development, analyze construction timelines, and assess the impact of the 421-a program. The data spans across different boroughs, specified in the `reported_borough` column, and includes property tax identifiers like `reported_property_tax_block` and `reported_property_tax_lot`.
sfd:

title: DOF: Summary of Neighborhood Sales by Neighborhood Citywide by Borough
ufd: This dataset provides a summary of property sales for one, two, and three-family homes in New York City. Maintained by the Department of Finance (DOF), the data is organized by borough and neighborhood, offering insights into the real estate market at a local level. Key columns include the borough code, neighborhood name, type of home (one, two, or three-family dwelling), and the number of sales recorded. You can also find the lowest, average, median, and highest sale prices for properties in each area. This dataset is valuable for anyone interested in tracking real estate trends, comparing property values across different neighborhoods, or understanding the dynamics of the housing market in New York City. All sales data in this dataset are from 2024.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains 2024 property sales information for one, two, and three-family homes in New York City, as compiled by the Department of Finance (DOF). The data is categorized by borough and neighborhood, providing a localized view of real estate activity. Key metrics include sale counts, and minimum, average, median, and maximum sale prices.

Related Topics:

- New York City

- Two-Family Home: Duplex, two-unit residence

title: Civil Service List (Terminated)
ufd: This dataset contains information about terminated Civil Service Lists in New York City, which are typically valid for four years unless extended. Each row represents a candidate on a list, identified by their `exam_no` and `list_no`, along with their name (`first_name`, `last_name`). The dataset includes the candidate's adjusted final average (`adj_fa`) and the details of the job title they applied for, including the `list_title_code` and `list_title_desc`. Information about the associated agency is provided via `list_agency_code` and `list_agency_desc`. Key dates such as the `established_date`, `anniversary_date`, and `termination_date` are also included. Researchers or job seekers could use this data to analyze trends in civil service hiring, understand the duration of eligibility lists, or investigate the types of positions that are frequently available.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

Each entry represents a candidate's record on a specific list, including their exam details, adjusted final average, and relevant dates like establishment and termination. title: Hyperlocal Temperature Monitoring
ufd: This dataset contains hourly air temperature readings from a sensor located in Brooklyn, specifically in the neighborhood identified by the NTA code BK81. The data was collected in 2018 as part of the Cool Neighborhoods Initiative to monitor street-level temperatures in areas with high heat mortality risk. Each reading includes the air temperature in Fahrenheit, the date, and the hour of the day. The sensor was installed on a street tree. Researchers and urban planners can use this data to analyze temperature variations, understand the impact of urban heat islands, and develop strategies to mitigate heat risks in vulnerable neighborhoods. The dataset provides a localized view of temperature patterns, which can be valuable for hyper-local climate studies and interventions.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides hourly air temperature readings in Fahrenheit, collected from a sensor in the Brooklyn neighborhood (NTA code BK81) in 2018. The data was gathered as part of the Cool Neighborhoods Initiative to monitor street-level temperatures in areas at high risk of heat mortality. It includes the date, hour, and temperature for each reading, offering a localized view of temperature patterns.

Related Topics:

title: DOB License Info
ufd: This dataset contains information on licenses and registrations issued by the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB) for individuals working within the construction trades. It includes details such as the license type (e.g., Welder, Electrical Firm), license number, the name of the license holder, and the current license status (e.g., Expired, Active). The dataset also provides business information, including the business name, address, and contact details, when available. Note that certain license types (Elevator Agency/Inspector, Journeyman, Site Safety, Superintendent of Construction, Welder) are no longer actively updated and contain historical data only. Researchers and analysts can use this data to understand the distribution of different license types, track license status, and potentially identify trends within the construction industry. The dataset could also be used to verify the licensing status of contractors and individuals.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes information on license type, license number, license holder name, and license status. The data also contains business information such as name, address, and contact details where available, though some license types are historical only.

title: DOF Scofftow Case Information
ufd: This dataset contains information on ScoffTow cases, which involve vehicles that have been booted or towed due to unpaid judgment debt. Each row represents a single case, identified by a unique case number. Key details include the vehicle's license plate number, the state of registration, and the type of vehicle. The dataset also tracks the case status (e.g., Redeemed, Executed, Runaway), the judgment amount, and whether the vehicle was towed and/or redeemed. Dates for booting and redemption are provided where applicable. Financial information, such as the total amount owed and collected, is also included. This data can be used to analyze trends in ScoffTow cases, track the resolution of cases, and assess the financial impact of the program.
sfd:

title: Construction-Related Incidents
ufd: This dataset provides details on construction-related incidents reported to the NYC Department of Buildings. Each row represents a specific incident, accident, or notification. Key details include the incident date, type of record (accident, incident, or notification), and a description of what occurred. The dataset also includes location information such as address, street, borough, and zip code, allowing users to analyze incident patterns across different areas of the city. You can use this data to identify common types of construction incidents, assess safety trends over time, or examine the geographic distribution of incidents. Furthermore, the data indicates whether the incident resulted in fatalities or injuries. The accident report ID can be used to uniquely identify each event.
sfd:

title: ACRIS - Document Control Codes
ufd: This dataset provides a mapping of document types and class codes used in the ACRIS (Automated City Register Information System) for real and personal property records. It clarifies the codes found within the larger ACRIS datasets. Key columns include `class_code_description`, which offers a description of the document class (e.g., "Mortgages & Instruments," "Deeds and Other Conveyances"), and `party1_type` and `party2_type`, which specify the roles of the parties involved in the transaction (e.g., "Mortgager/Borrower," "Mortgagee/Lender," "Grantor/Seller," "Grantee/Buyer"). The `record_type` column indicates the type of record, which appears to be consistently "D" for document. While `party3_type` exists, it is sparsely populated. This dataset can be used to understand the meaning of codes in ACRIS records, enabling more effective analysis and interpretation of property transactions within the city. Researchers, legal professionals, and anyone interested in property records can benefit from this reference table.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset maps document types and class codes used in the ACRIS (Automated City Register Information System) for real and personal property records. It provides descriptions for ACRIS codes, clarifying the meaning of `class_code_description`, `party1_type`, and `party2_type`. The dataset serves as a reference table for understanding property transactions within the city.

title: Math Test Results 2013-2023
ufd: This dataset contains math test results for New York State exams from 2013 to 2023. The data is broken down by report category (Citywide or School), geographic division, grade level, and year. You can also filter the results by student category, such as "All Students," "Not SWD" (Students with Disabilities), and "SWD." Key columns include 'number_tested,' which indicates the number of students tested, and 'mean_scale_score,' which represents the average test score. The dataset also provides the number and percentage of students at each performance level (Level 1, Level 2, Level 3, and Level 4). Researchers and educators can use this data to analyze trends in math performance across different grades, geographic areas, and student populations over time. This information can be valuable for evaluating the effectiveness of educational programs and identifying areas where students may need additional support.
sfd:

title: NYCHA Resident Data Book Summary
ufd: This dataset provides a summary of resident demographic data for NYCHA (New York City Housing Authority) public housing developments. It includes information on total families, the number of female and male-headed families, and the total population in each development. Key columns include `program`, indicating the specific housing program (e.g., FEDERAL, FORMER NEW YORK STATE), and `statecity_section8_flag`, which categorizes households by type (e.g., TOTAL HOUSEHOLDS, PUBLIC HOUSING HOUSEHOLDS, SECTION 8). The dataset also contains details on the age demographics of residents, such as the total number of residents 62 years and over, and the number of minors under 18. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze demographic trends in public housing, understand the needs of residents, and inform housing policies and programs. The inclusion of average gross rent and income data allows for analysis of affordability within NYCHA developments. This dataset offers a valuable resource for understanding the composition and characteristics of public housing residents in New York City.
sfd:

title: Emergency Food Supply Gap
ufd: This dataset, titled "Emergency Food Supply Gap," provides insights into food needs across New York City neighborhoods. It focuses on the year 2025 and analyzes data by Neighborhood Tabulation Area (NTA). Key columns include `nta_name` which specifies the neighborhood, `supply_gap_lbs` representing the difference between food need and supply (in pounds), `food_insecure_percentage` indicating the proportion of residents facing food insecurity, and `unemployment_rate`. The `vulnerable_population` column likely represents a composite measure of vulnerability within each neighborhood. A `weighted_score` and `rank` are also provided, potentially indicating the overall severity of the food supply gap in each area. This data could be used by city planners, food banks, and other organizations to identify areas with the greatest need for food assistance and to allocate resources effectively.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The "Emergency Food Supply Gap" dataset details food insecurity and supply gaps across New York City's Neighborhood Tabulation Areas (NTAs) for the year 2025. It quantifies the difference between food need and supply in pounds (`supply_gap_lbs`), alongside metrics like food insecurity percentage, unemployment rate, and a vulnerable population index. The dataset also includes a weighted score and rank to prioritize areas based on the severity of the food supply gap.

title: NYC Ferry Ridership
ufd:
This dataset provides hourly ridership information for NYC Ferries on a specific date, October 31, 2025. It details the number of boardings at various ferry landings, identified by their names, such as "Brooklyn Navy Yard" and "East 34th Street." The data is categorized by route (e.g., "AS", "SV") and direction ("NB" for Northbound, "SB" for Southbound). Each record also specifies the hour of the day and whether it was a weekday.

Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze ferry ridership patterns, understand peak hours at specific stops, and assess the popularity of different routes. This information can be valuable for optimizing ferry schedules, allocating resources, and improving the overall ferry service for New Yorkers. The dataset includes 100 rows of data, focusing solely on weekday ridership.
sfd:

It includes the number of boardings at various ferry landings, categorized by route, direction (Northbound/Southbound), and hour of the day. The data focuses on weekday ridership and provides insights into ferry usage patterns across different routes and locations.

title: Handyman Work Order (HWO) Charges
ufd: This dataset contains information about Handyman Work Orders (HWOs) in New York City, which are issued when property owners fail to address hazardous conditions. These work orders are carried out by agency staff to conduct emergency repairs. Each record includes a unique HWO ID (`hwoid`) and number (`hwonumber`), along with details about the building (`buildingid`), borough (`boro`), house number (`housenumber`), street name (`streetname`), and zip code (`zip`). The dataset also specifies the type of work performed (`worktypegeneral`), the reason for the HWO status (`hwostatusreason`), and the date the HWO was created (`hwocreatedate`). Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze housing maintenance issues, track the types of repairs being conducted, and identify areas with frequent housing violations. The `lifecycle` column indicates whether the building is standing or demolished.
sfd:

Each record provides information on the HWO, building details, location, type of work performed, reason for the HWO, and creation date. The dataset also includes a lifecycle status indicating whether the building is standing or demolished.

title: NYC Historical Vital Records: Index to Digitized Birth Certificates
ufd: This dataset provides an index to digitized historical birth certificates from New York City, spanning the years 1855-1909. It includes records from all five boroughs. The key columns include `first_name` and `last_name` of the individuals, the `county` where the birth was recorded (primarily Kings), and the `year`, `month`, and `day` of the birth. A `soundex` code is also provided, likely for phonetic indexing of names. The `number` column appears to be a record identifier. Researchers, genealogists, or anyone interested in historical records can use this dataset to locate and access digitized birth certificates. The data can be used to study demographic trends, family history, or public health patterns in NYC during this period.
sfd:

It contains key information such as first and last names, birth date (year, month, day), and the county of record. title: Open Market Order (OMO) Charges
ufd: This dataset provides details on Open Market Order (OMO) charges in New York City, which are fees assessed by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) for emergency repairs and other actions taken on properties. It includes information on work orders created through HPD's Emergency Repair Program, Alternative Enforcement Program, and Demolition programs. Key columns include `omoid` and `omonumber` for unique identification, `boro` and `zip` for location, `worktypegeneral` describing the type of work performed (e.g., GC for general construction, ASBEST for asbestos removal), and `omoawardamount` indicating the amount awarded for the work. The `omocreatedate` and `omoawarddate` columns provide timestamps related to the order. Researchers, city planners, and housing advocates can use this data to analyze the types and costs of emergency repairs, identify areas with frequent housing maintenance issues, and assess the financial impact of HPD's intervention on property owners. The data also sheds light on the enforcement of housing maintenance codes across different boroughs.
sfd:

title: NYC Farmers Markets
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive list of farmers markets located across the five boroughs of New York City. It includes key details such as the market name, street address, borough, community district, latitude, and longitude, enabling users to easily locate markets in their vicinity. The dataset also specifies the days and hours of operation, as well as the start and end dates of the market season. Information on whether the market accepts EBT and distributes Health Bucks is included, which is valuable for individuals seeking affordable and healthy food options. Furthermore, the dataset indicates whether each market is open year-round and if they offer cooking demonstrations in collaboration with the NYC Department of Health. This dataset can be used to promote local agriculture, improve access to fresh produce, and support community health initiatives.

title: 2020 Census Blocks
ufd: This dataset contains information about the 2020 Census Blocks for New York City, clipped to the shoreline. It includes census blocks that are partially or totally located on land. Each row represents a census block and includes a unique census block ID (cb2020), the borough code (borocode), and the borough name (boroname). The dataset also provides the 2020 census tract (ct2020) and a combined block and tract code (bctcb2020). Geographic information, such as shape length (shape_leng) and shape area (shape_area), is included, along with a GEOID. This data can be used for urban planning, demographic analysis, and mapping applications, allowing users to analyze population distribution and geographic characteristics at a granular level within New York City.
sfd:

title: Public Recycling Bins
ufd: This dataset provides locations of public recycling bins throughout New York City. It includes information on the Department of Sanitation (DSNY) zone and district where each bin is located, as well as the specific site type (e.g., park, city agency, or sports arena) and location. The dataset also identifies the partner organization responsible for the bins, such as the Hudson River Park Trust or a local Business Improvement District (BID). Crucially, the number of paper recycling bins and mixed glass/metal/plastic (MGP) bins at each location is recorded. This data could be used to analyze the distribution of recycling resources across the city, identify areas with high or low recycling bin density, or assess the involvement of different partner organizations in public recycling efforts. For more information on what materials can be recycled in NYC, refer to the provided link.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details the locations of public recycling bins in New York City, including the number of paper and mixed glass/metal/plastic (MGP) bins at each site. It specifies the Department of Sanitation (DSNY) zone and district, site type (e.g., park, city agency), and the partner organization responsible for the bins. This information can be used to analyze recycling resource distribution and partner involvement in NYC.

**Applications and Use Cases:**

- Track changes in recycling bin availability over time.

title: GreenThumb Garden Info
ufd: This dataset contains information about community gardens supported by GreenThumb in New York City. Each row represents a unique garden and includes details such as its address, borough, and name. The dataset also provides political district information, including assembly, congressional, and council districts. You can find the governing jurisdiction for each garden, such as NYCHA or DOT. The `multipolygon` column contains the garden's geographic coordinates. This data could be used to analyze the distribution of community gardens across different neighborhoods, identify potential areas for new gardens, or understand the relationship between gardens and political districts. The opening hours of the garden are listed in the `openhrsf` column.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details community gardens supported by GreenThumb in New York City. It includes information on each garden's location (address, borough, coordinates), name, and associated political districts (assembly, congressional, council). title: PLUTO Change File
ufd: This dataset tracks changes made to the PLUTO dataset, which combines data from various city agencies to provide comprehensive land use information. Specifically, this dataset focuses on modifications to the 'lotarea' field, detailing the old and new values for each affected property. Each row represents a change to the lot area of a specific property identified by its Building, Block, and Lot number (BBL). The 'old_value' column shows the original lot area, while 'new_value' reflects the updated area. The 'reason' column explains the justification for the change, which in this case is "Zero lot area", and the 'version' column indicates the PLUTO version the change applies to. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to understand how land area calculations are refined and to assess the impact of these changes on property analysis and urban planning initiatives. This dataset provides transparency into the data editing process and ensures data quality within the PLUTO dataset.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset documents modifications to the 'lotarea' field within the PLUTO dataset, a comprehensive land use resource for New York City. It tracks changes made to individual property lot areas, identified by Building, Block, and Lot number (BBL), specifying the original and updated values. The dataset also includes the reason for the change ("Zero lot area") and the PLUTO version associated with the modification.

- PLUTO Dataset: Primary Land Use Tax lot Output, NYC land use data
- BBL: Building Block Lot, property identifier
- Data Modification: Data change, data update, data correction
- Zero Lot Area: Invalid lot size, incorrect area value

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyzing changes in land area calculations over time.
- Identifying properties with corrected lot area data.

- Evaluating the data quality and consistency of the PLUTO dataset.
- Understanding the reasons behind data corrections in city planning databases.

title: New York City Council Discretionary Funding
ufd: This dataset contains information on applications for discretionary funding allocated by the New York City Council for the fiscal year 2009. Each row represents a funding application, identified by a unique `mocs_id`. Key details include the `source` of the funding, the `legal_name_of_organization` applying, and their `ein` (Employer Identification Number). The `amount` column indicates the requested or allocated funding amount, while `agency` specifies the city agency associated with the funding. The `program_name` and `council_member` columns provide further context on the funding's intended purpose and the council member involved. Researchers, city planners, and community organizations can use this data to analyze funding patterns, identify recipients, and understand the allocation of discretionary funds across different programs and agencies in New York City. The dataset also includes location information such as `address`, `city`, `state`, and `postcode` for some organizations.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details applications for New York City Council discretionary funding for the 2009 fiscal year. It includes information on the applying organization, the amount of funding requested or allocated, the relevant city agency, and the council member involved. The data allows for analysis of funding distribution and identification of funding recipients.

title: DSNY Waste Characterization 2023 - Main Sort Results
ufd: This dataset contains the results of the NYC Department of Sanitation's 2023 Waste Characterization Study, which analyzed the composition of waste from various sources like residential households and schools. The data categorizes waste into 96 material categories, providing insights into what New Yorkers throw away. Key columns include `material_group` (e.g., Paper, Plastic, Organics), `material_category` (e.g., Newspaper, #1 PET Bottles), and `dsny_diversion_summary` which indicates how the waste is managed (e.g., Designated Paper, HHW). The dataset also includes percentage breakdowns (`aggregate_percent`, `refuse_percent`, etc.) to show the relative proportions of different materials. Researchers, policymakers, and sustainability advocates can use this data to understand waste patterns, evaluate recycling programs, and develop strategies for waste reduction and diversion. The data is aggregated citywide and presented on an annual basis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The NYC Department of Sanitation's 2023 Waste Characterization Study dataset provides a detailed analysis of the composition of waste generated in New York City. It categorizes waste into 96 material categories, grouped by material type and diversion method. The dataset includes percentage breakdowns to illustrate the proportion of each material in the waste stream, offering insights into waste management practices and potential areas for improvement.

Related Topics:

- Urban Planning
- Public Policy

- Waste Composition: Waste stream analysis, garbage composition, refuse characterization

- Diversion: Recycling, composting, waste reduction
- Aggregate Percent: Total percentage, overall proportion, combined weight
- DSNY: Department of Sanitation New York, NYC Sanitation

Applications and Use Cases:

- Benchmark NYC's waste management performance against other cities.

title: LinkNYC Kiosk Status
ufd: This dataset provides information on the status and location of LinkNYC kiosks throughout New York City. Each row represents a specific kiosk and includes details such as the date the information was generated, a unique site identifier, the current status of the kiosk (e.g., Installed, Live, Repair), and the kiosk type (Link 1.0 or Link 5G). The dataset also provides address information, including city, state, zip code, and borough, as well as latitude and longitude coordinates. Key columns for analysis include 'status', which indicates the operational state of the kiosk, and 'kiosk_type', which specifies the model of the kiosk. Researchers, city planners, and telecommunications companies could use this data to monitor the deployment and maintenance of LinkNYC kiosks, analyze their geographic distribution, and identify areas with potential service issues. The 'community_board' and 'council_district' columns allow for analysis at a neighborhood level.
sfd:

title: Taxi Improvement Fund (TIF) Medallion Payments
ufd: This dataset contains information about monthly payments made from the Taxi Improvement Fund (TIF) to owners of Wheelchair Accessible Vehicles (WAVs). Each row represents a payment record, identified by a unique license number. Key columns include `hackup_payment_amount`, `operational_payment_amount`, and `total_payment_amount`, detailing the breakdown of the payment. The `payment_date` column indicates when the payment was made. The dataset also includes `agent_number`, which may be useful for grouping and analyzing payments by agent. The `last_date_updated` and `last_time_updated` columns indicate when the data was last refreshed. Researchers and analysts can use this data to understand the distribution of TIF payments, track payment trends over time, and analyze the effectiveness of the TIF program.
sfd:

title: Brooklyn Bridge Automated Pedestrian Counts Demonstration Project
ufd: This dataset contains hourly pedestrian counts on the Brooklyn Bridge, specifically on the Manhattan approach. It includes the number of pedestrians heading towards Manhattan and Brooklyn, along with location coordinates. The data also incorporates weather information such as summary, temperature, and precipitation. You can use this dataset to analyze pedestrian traffic patterns on the Brooklyn Bridge, understand the impact of weather conditions on pedestrian flow, or explore trends related to specific events. The 'pedestrians' column provides the total count, while 'towards_manhattan' and 'towards_brooklyn' break down the direction of travel. Additional columns provide geographic region codes and the time the count was recorded.
sfd:

title: Trade Waste Broker Registrants
ufd: This dataset contains information about Trade Waste Broker Registrants authorized by the Business Integrity Commission to broker agreements between businesses and waste removal companies in New York City. Each row represents a registered entity, identified by a unique BIC number and account name, along with their address, city, state, and postcode. Key columns include the effective and expiration dates of their registration, as well as contact information such as phone number and email. The `application_type` column specifies "CL2 - Broker" for all entries, indicating the class of application. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the distribution of waste brokers across different locations, track registration timelines, or understand the network of waste management services in the city. The `created` column indicates when the record was created, while `disposition_date` shows when a record was closed.
sfd:

title: Lead Service Line Location Coordinates
ufd: This dataset provides information on water service lines, specifically focusing on potential lead locations. It includes geographic coordinates (`the_geom`) to pinpoint the service line locations. The `address` column gives the street address of the service line. Key details include the `material` of the service line (indicating whether it's lead or non-lead) and the `record_ty` which specifies the type of inspection or verification performed.  The `city_owned` column indicates if the service line is owned by the city. This data can be used by residents and property owners to understand the composition and status of their water service lines. Environmental agencies and researchers can also use this data for analysis and planning related to water quality and infrastructure.
sfd:

title: Urban Park Ranger Animal Condition Response
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed record of Urban Park Ranger responses to animal-related incidents in New York City parks. It includes information on the date and time of the initial call and the ranger's response, the borough and specific location within the park where the incident occurred, and a description of the animal species involved. Key columns include 'species_description,' detailing the type of animal, 'animal_condition,' indicating the animal's health status, and 'final_ranger_action,' outlining the resolution taken by the ranger. Researchers and park management can use this data to analyze trends in animal encounters, assess the effectiveness of ranger responses, and inform strategies for wildlife management and public safety in NYC parks. The dataset also includes the source of the call ('call_source') and the duration of the ranger's response, offering insights into resource allocation and response efficiency. Information such as the animal's age and species status (native, exotic, etc.) are also recorded.
sfd:

title: NYPD Vehicle Stop Reports
ufd: This dataset contains information on NYPD vehicle stops, collected to provide insights into police-initiated stops, demographics, vehicle details, and resulting actions. Each row represents a single vehicle stop incident. Key columns include the date and time of the stop (`occur_dt`, `occur_tm`), the command code associated with the incident (`cmd_cd`), and various flags indicating whether the vehicle was seized (`veh_seized_flg`), searched (`veh_searched_flg`), or reached a checkpoint (`veh_checkpoint_flg`). The dataset also includes demographic information such as reported age (`rpted_age`), sex (`sex_cd`), and race (`race_desc`) of the individuals involved. Further details cover whether force was used (`force_used_flg`), an arrest was made (`arrest_made_flg`), or a summons was issued (`summon_issued_flg`). Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to analyze trends in vehicle stops, assess the demographics of those stopped, and evaluate the outcomes of these stops. The dataset also includes location data (`latitude`, `longitude`, `x_coord_cd`, `y_coord_cd`), enabling spatial analysis of vehicle stop patterns.
sfd:

It includes flags indicating vehicle searches, seizures, checkpoints, and outcomes such as arrests, summonses, and use of force. The data allows for analysis of police practices, demographic trends in vehicle stops, and spatial patterns of these incidents.

title: Buildings by Borough and Community District
ufd: This dataset provides a count of different types of shelter buildings in New York City, broken down by borough and community district. The data includes the number of adult shelters, family with children (FWC) shelters operating in commercial hotels, and other shelter types. Each row represents a specific borough and community district, with counts for each shelter category. The `report_date` column indicates the date the data was collected. Key columns include `borough` and `community_district` for location, and columns like `adult_shelter`, `fwc_comm_hotel`, and `adult_family_shelter` for shelter counts. This dataset could be used to analyze the distribution of shelter resources across different areas of New York City, identify areas with high or low shelter availability, or track changes in shelter capacity over time. The dataset contains information for two dates, with the majority of records from September 30, 2025.
sfd:

title: Current Reservoir Levels
ufd: This dataset provides daily information on the water levels in New York City's reservoirs. It includes data on reservoir storage, elevation, and water releases for the Ashokan, Schoharie, Rondout, and Neversink reservoirs. Key columns include `neversink_date` for the date of the measurement, `ashokan_east_storage` and `ashokan_west_storage` for the amount of water stored in different sections of the Ashokan reservoir, and `schoharie_elevation` for the water elevation in the Schoharie reservoir. The dataset also tracks water releases from each reservoir, such as `rondout_release`. This information could be used to monitor water supply levels, manage reservoir operations, and understand the impact of releases on downstream water flow. Researchers, water resource managers, and city planners could find this dataset valuable for analyzing and planning for water resources in the region.
sfd:

title: 485-x Affordable Neighborhoods for New Yorkers: Registrations of Prospective Applicants for Tax Benefits
ufd: This dataset contains information on registrations of prospective applicants for 485-x tax benefits in New York City, as mandated by New York State Real Property Tax Law Section 485-x. Each row represents a form submission with details about the applicant's intention to file for tax exemption benefits. Key columns include the date the form was submitted (`form_submission_date`), the address of the property (`reported_property_address`), the borough where the property is located (`reported_property_borough`), and identifiers such as the Building Identification Number (`reported_dob_bin`), property tax block (`reported_property_tax_block`), and tax lot (`reported_property_tax_lot`). The dataset also provides the reported number of total dwelling units (`reported_units`) and restricted units (`reported_restricted_units`), along with the reported commencement (`reported_commencement_date`) and anticipated completion dates (`reported_anticipated`). Researchers, city planners, and housing developers can use this data to analyze trends in affordable housing development, track the progress of projects seeking tax benefits, and assess the geographic distribution of affordable units across the city. The `reported_affordability_option` column indicates the specific affordability option selected by the applicant.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details registrations for 485-x tax benefits in New York City, as required by New York State Real Property Tax Law Section 485-x. It includes information on form submissions from prospective applicants, covering property details, unit counts, and key dates related to development projects. The data allows for analysis of affordable housing trends and project tracking within the city.

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the geographic distribution of affordable housing projects receiving 485-x tax benefits across NYC boroughs.
- Track the progress of development projects seeking 485-x tax exemptions by comparing commencement and anticipated completion dates.
- Identify trends in the number of total and restricted dwelling units being developed under the 485-x program.
- Evaluate the impact of the 485-x tax incentive on affordable housing development in specific neighborhoods.
- Determine the prevalence of different affordability options selected by developers applying for 485-x benefits.

title: NYC Municipal Building Energy Benchmarking Results
ufd: This dataset provides energy benchmarking results for New York City municipal buildings, offering insights into energy consumption and environmental impact. It includes buildings over 10,000 square feet, identified by borough, block, and lot. Key metrics include energy intensity (kBtu/sq. ft.) and total greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions (MTCO2e). The dataset also contains building-specific information such as the responsible agency and building type. While a Portfolio Manager benchmarking rating is included, it is often unavailable. This data can be used to assess the energy efficiency of city-owned buildings, track progress towards sustainability goals, and identify opportunities for energy-saving improvements.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains energy benchmarking results for New York City municipal buildings exceeding 10,000 square feet. It provides detailed information on energy consumption, greenhouse gas emissions, and building characteristics. Key metrics include energy intensity (kBtu/sq. ft.) and total greenhouse gas emissions (MTCO2e), enabling analysis of energy efficiency across city-owned properties.

Related Topics:

  - Environmental Impact
  - Government Data
  - Building Performance

Concepts and Synonyms:

  - Energy Intensity: kBtu/sq. ft., Energy Use Index (EUI)
  - Municipal Buildings: City-owned buildings, Government facilities
  - Portfolio Manager: Energy Star Portfolio Manager, Benchmarking rating
  - Borough, Block, Lot (BBL): Property identification, Geographic location

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Track energy consumption trends in NYC municipal buildings.
  - Identify buildings with high energy intensity for targeted improvements.

title: Industrial & Commercial Abatement Program (ICAP) Businesses that received EO50 certificate of approval from SBS
ufd: This dataset provides a list of businesses participating in New York City's Industrial & Commercial Abatement Program (ICAP) that have received an EO50 certificate of approval from the Department of Small Business Services (SBS), signifying their compliance with equal employment opportunity principles. The data includes the date of the certificate, the contracting company's name, and the address of the work site. Location information is further detailed with borough, state, zip code, latitude, and longitude. You can use this dataset to identify businesses committed to fair hiring practices within the ICAP program. It could also be used to analyze the geographic distribution of these businesses across New York City and surrounding areas. Researchers and policymakers can leverage this information to assess the effectiveness of the EO50 mandate and its impact on promoting equal employment opportunities.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on businesses participating in New York City's Industrial & Commercial Abatement Program (ICAP) that have received an EO50 certificate, indicating compliance with equal employment opportunity principles. The data includes certificate details, company name, work site address, and geographic location (borough, state, zip code, latitude, and longitude). This resource allows for identifying and analyzing businesses committed to fair hiring practices within the ICAP program.

Related Topics:

- Industrial & Commercial Abatement Program (ICAP)
- Business Compliance
- Geographic Data
- Small Business Services (SBS)

- Compliance: Adherence, Conformity, Regulation
