title: DYCD Program Sites
ufd: This dataset provides information on social services programs funded by the NYC Department of Youth and Community Development (DYCD). It details the various service categories offered, the program areas and types they fall under, and the organizations providing these services. Key columns include the `program_area` (e.g., Compass, Discretionary), `program_type` (e.g., COMPASS Elementary, Under Threshold), `service_category` (e.g., Community Services, Educational Services), and the `provider` organization. The dataset also includes location information such as `borough`, `city`, `street_address`, `zipcode`, `latitude`, and `longitude` for program sites.  Researchers, policymakers, and community members can use this data to understand the landscape of DYCD-funded programs, identify service gaps, and locate programs in specific areas. The data spans the years 2017 and 2018. This dataset can be used to analyze the distribution of services across different boroughs and identify which providers offer specific types of programs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on social service programs funded by the NYC Department of Youth and Community Development (DYCD) for the years 2017 and 2018. It includes details on program areas, program types, service categories, and provider organizations. Location information such as borough, city, and address is also provided for program sites.

title: Attendance Results 2013-2019
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at student attendance in a citywide school system from 2013 to 2019. It includes end-of-year attendance rates and chronic absenteeism data, broken down by grade level and demographic categories such as student with disabilities (SWD) status. Key columns include 'year' for the academic year, 'grade' indicating the grade level, 'attendance' representing the overall attendance rate, and 'chronically_absent_1' showing the percentage of students who are chronically absent. The dataset also provides the total number of days, days absent, and days present. Educators, policymakers, and researchers can use this data to analyze attendance trends, identify at-risk student populations, and evaluate the impact of interventions aimed at improving student attendance. The data is reported at the citywide level.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains student attendance information from a citywide school system between 2013 and 2019. It includes yearly attendance rates and chronic absenteeism percentages, categorized by grade level and student demographics like students with disabilities (SWD). title: Temporary Art Program
ufd: This dataset provides information on temporary art installations commissioned by NYC DOT Art in collaboration with community organizations. It includes details on the program initiative, year, title, artist, and partner involved in each project. The dataset also specifies the site location, borough, and site type where the artwork is displayed. Key columns include 'project_type', indicating the art form (e.g., mural, sculpture, projection), and geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) for locating the installations. Researchers, urban planners, and art enthusiasts can use this dataset to analyze trends in public art, identify potential locations for future installations, or explore the work of specific artists and community partners. The 'installation' and 'removal' columns provide date ranges for when the art was on display.
sfd:

It includes information on project specifics such as title, artist, partner organization, location (including borough and coordinates), and installation/removal dates. title: DOB NOW: Safety Boiler
ufd: This dataset contains information on annual compliance filings for both high and low-pressure boilers installed in New York City buildings. It includes details such as the tracking number and boiler ID for each filing, the type of report (initial or subsequent), the boiler's manufacturer, and the pressure type. Inspection dates are recorded, along with an indicator of whether any defects were found during the inspection. The dataset also tracks filing fees and total amounts paid. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze boiler compliance rates, identify common defects, and assess the financial aspects of boiler inspections in NYC.
sfd:

title: Parking Violations Issued - Fiscal Year 2023
ufd: This dataset contains information on parking violations issued in New York City between July 1, 2022, and June 30, 2023, including records from the first month of FY2024. Each row represents a single parking ticket. Key details include the `summons_number` (unique identifier for the ticket), `plate_id` and `registration_state` of the vehicle, the `issue_date` and `violation_time`, and the `violation_code`. The dataset also provides information about the vehicle (`vehicle_body_type`, `vehicle_make`) and the issuing agency.  Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze parking violation patterns, identify areas with high violation rates (using `street_code1`, `street_code2`, `street_code3`), and assess the effectiveness of parking regulations. The data does not reflect the current status of violations (paid, dismissed, etc.).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details parking violations issued in New York City from July 2022 to June 2023, with some data from July 2023. It includes information on each parking ticket, such as the summons number, vehicle details, violation date and time, and violation code. title: DARP-ROTOW Enrollment Status of Active Tow Truck Companies
ufd: This dataset provides information on active tow truck companies licensed by the NYC Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP) and their enrollment status in the Directed Accident Response Program (DARP) and the Rotation Tow Program (ROTOW). It includes details such as the DCA license number, business name, address (building number, street, city, state, and postcode), and unique business ID. Key columns to pay attention to are `darp_enrollment_status` and `rotow_enrollment_status`, which indicate whether a company is authorized to tow vehicles involved in accidents or stolen/abandoned vehicles, respectively. The dataset also includes geographic information like borough and community district. Users can leverage this data to understand which tow truck companies are authorized to perform specific types of tows within New York City. This information can be valuable for city planning, consumer protection, and oversight of the towing industry.
sfd:

This data can be used to identify authorized tow truck operators for specific towing needs within NYC.

title: NYC Cooling Tower Registrations
ufd: This dataset contains information on cooling tower systems registered in New York City, as mandated by Section 17-194.1 of the NYC Administrative Code. The data includes the building identification number (`bin`), the date the cooling tower was registered (`date_registered`), and the address, borough, and zip code of the building where the tower is located. Geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) are also provided, along with the council district and community board. This information can be used to analyze the distribution of cooling towers across the city and identify areas with a high concentration of these systems. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to understand and manage potential health risks associated with cooling towers, such as Legionnaires' disease. The dataset also includes a Building Block Lot (`bbl`) identifier, useful for linking this data to other city datasets related to properties and buildings.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes registration dates, building information (BIN, address, borough, zip code, BBL), and geographic coordinates for each cooling tower location. title: Revenue Budget & Financial Plan -- Exec\Adpt\Prel
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed view of New York City's revenue budget and financial plan. It includes data on adopted and modified budgets, as well as five-year financial plans, broken down by revenue class, category, and source. Key columns include `fiscal_year` for the reporting period, `agency_name` and `agency_number` to identify the responsible city agency, and `revenue_category_name` and `revenue_class_name` to classify the revenue. The `adopted_budget_amount` and `current_modified_budget_amount` columns provide the financial figures for each category. Researchers, city planners, and budget analysts can use this dataset to understand the city's revenue streams, track budget changes over time, and analyze financial planning across different agencies and revenue types. The data is updated three times a year, reflecting the Preliminary, Executive, and Adopted Budget publications.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: Citywide Catch Basins
ufd: This dataset contains information about the locations and attributes of catch basins throughout New York City. Catch basins are part of the city's sewer network, channeling stormwater from streets to wastewater facilities or water bodies. Each catch basin is identified by a unique `unitid` and its location is provided in both latitude/longitude coordinates and as `point_x` and `point_y` values. The `the_geom` column provides a GeoJSON representation of the point location. The dataset also includes several columns representing computed regions, such as `:@computed_region_f5dn_yrer`, `:@computed_region_yeji_bk3q`, `:@computed_region_sbqj_enih`, and `:@computed_region_92fq_4b7q`, which can be used to analyze catch basin distribution across different areas of the city. This data could be used by city planners, environmental researchers, or residents interested in understanding and improving stormwater management in NYC. The dataset can help in optimizing maintenance schedules, identifying areas prone to flooding, or assessing the impact of urbanization on the sewer system.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations and characteristics of catch basins in New York City, which are crucial components of the city's stormwater management system. Each catch basin is uniquely identified and geolocated using latitude/longitude coordinates, `point_x`, `point_y` values, and a GeoJSON geometry (`the_geom`). The dataset also includes computed region identifiers for analyzing catch basin distribution across different areas of NYC.

Related Topics:
- Stormwater Management
- Sewer Systems
- Urban Planning
- Environmental Engineering
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- Infrastructure Management
- Water Resources

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Catch Basin: Storm drain, drain inlet, gully, stormwater inlet
- Stormwater: Runoff, rainwater, surface water
- Sewer Network: Drainage system, wastewater system, collection system
- GeoJSON: Geographic JSON, spatial data format
- Computed Region: Administrative area, statistical area, designated zone

Applications and Use Cases:
- Optimizing catch basin maintenance and inspection schedules.
- Identifying areas with high catch basin density or potential flooding risks.
- Analyzing the spatial distribution of catch basins in relation to land use and population density.
- Assessing the impact of urbanization on stormwater runoff and sewer system capacity.
- Visualizing catch basin locations on a map using GIS software.
- Developing predictive models for catch basin performance and maintenance needs.

title: Community Food Connection (Quarterly Report)
ufd: This dataset provides quarterly reports on community food connections, detailing the number of individuals served by food pantries and the number of meals served by soup kitchens. Both counts include duplicated persons served by CFC-funded programs. Key columns include "facility," indicating whether the data refers to food pantries or soup kitchens, "report_start_date" and "report_end_date," specifying the reporting period, and "number," representing the count of individuals served or meals provided. Researchers, policymakers, and social service organizations can use this data to track trends in food assistance needs, assess the impact of community food programs, and inform resource allocation strategies. The data spans multiple years, allowing for longitudinal analysis of food security within the community. Note that some values in the 'number' column are missing.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains quarterly reports on community food connections, specifically detailing the number of individuals served by food pantries and the number of meals served by soup kitchens. The data includes the facility type (food pantry or soup kitchen), the start and end dates of the reporting period, and the corresponding count of individuals served or meals provided. This information can be used to analyze trends in food assistance and inform resource allocation.

Related Topics:
- Food Security
- Social Services
- Food Assistance Programs
- Community Support
- Poverty
- Hunger Relief

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Food Pantry: Food bank, food distribution center, emergency food provider
- Soup Kitchen: Meal program, community kitchen, feeding program
- Community Food Connections (CFC): Local food initiatives, food access programs
- Individuals Served: Clients, beneficiaries, recipients
- Meals Served: Food provided, meals distributed
- Food Assistance: Food relief, food support

Applications and Use Cases:
- Track trends in food assistance needs over time.
- Assess the impact of community food programs.
- Inform resource allocation strategies for food assistance programs.
- Identify areas with high food insecurity.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of different food assistance models.
- Analyze the relationship between food insecurity and other social determinants of health.

title: NYPD Officer Profile - Title Shield History
ufd: This dataset provides a historical record of NYPD officers' titles and shield numbers. Each row represents a specific title held by an officer, identified by a unique profile ID, along with the date the title became effective. The dataset includes information on various ranks and titles, such as Police Officer, Detective, and Sergeant. Shield numbers are included where applicable. Researchers or data analysts can use this dataset to analyze career progression within the NYPD, track changes in officer titles over time, or study the distribution of different ranks within the department. The `export_date` column indicates when the data was extracted.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains historical information on NYPD officers' titles and shield numbers, offering a longitudinal view of career progression within the department. Each record details a specific title held by an officer, identified by a unique profile ID, and the date the title became effective. The data includes a variety of ranks, such as Police Officer, Detective, and Sergeant, along with associated shield numbers when available.

- Identify trends in promotions and assignments.
- Examine the demographics of different ranks within the NYPD (if demographic data is linked).

title: TLC Driver Exam Testing Center Locations
ufd: This dataset provides a list of locations in New York City where you can take the TLC (Taxi and Limousine Commission) Driver License Exam. The exam is administered by PSI Services, and some locations may be operated by third parties. Each entry includes the name of the testing center (`psi_testing_center`), its full address, and the borough it's located in. You can use the `postcode`, `latitude`, and `longitude` columns to pinpoint the exact location of each testing center. Additional columns like `community_board` and `council_district` provide further geographic context. This information can be valuable for TLC driver applicants looking for convenient testing locations or for researchers studying the distribution of transportation-related services across the city. The dataset is updated as of October 31, 2025, as indicated by the `data_as_of_date` column.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a list of TLC (Taxi and Limousine Commission) Driver License Exam locations in New York City. Each entry includes the testing center name, address, borough, and geographic coordinates. The dataset also provides supplementary geographic information like postcode, community board, and council district, updated as of October 31, 2025.

Related Topics:
- Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC)
- Driver Licensing
- Transportation Services
- New York City
- Geographic Data
- Exam Locations

Concepts and Synonyms:
- TLC Driver License Exam: Taxi Driver Exam, For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) License Exam
- Testing Center: Exam Location, PSI Testing Center, PSI Services
- Geographic Coordinates: Latitude, Longitude, Geolocation
- Borough: NYC Borough, County
- Postcode: Zip Code

Applications and Use Cases:
- Finding the nearest TLC Driver License Exam location.
- Analyzing the distribution of testing centers across different boroughs.
- Mapping exam locations using latitude and longitude.
- Identifying testing centers within a specific community board or council district.
- Planning transportation routes to exam locations.

title: Voter Analysis 2008-2018
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at voter behavior in New York City between 2008 and 2018. It includes demographic information like age and registration year, along with political party affiliation. The dataset also contains geographic information, such as election, assembly, congress, council, and senate districts, as well as borough and community district codes. Researchers can use this data to analyze voter participation trends, understand the relationship between demographics and voting patterns, and examine the impact of geographic location on political preferences. Note that this dataset only includes active voters in 2018, so it cannot be used to calculate overall election turnout. Each row represents an individual voter and their voting history during the specified period. The `random_id` column serves as a unique identifier for each voter.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset offers a granular view of New York City voter demographics and political affiliations from 2008 to 2018. It includes voter attributes like age, registration year, party affiliation, and various geographic district codes. The data allows for analysis of voter behavior trends and the relationship between demographics and voting patterns, focusing on active voters in 2018.

Related Topics:
- Voter behavior
- Political science
- Demographics
- Geographic data analysis
- New York City politics
- Election analysis

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Voter: Elector, constituent
- Demographics: Age, registration year, party affiliation
- Geographic districts: Election district, assembly district, congressional district, council district, senate district, borough, community district
- Political party: Party affiliation, political alignment
- Voter behavior: Voting patterns, voter trends, political preferences

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the correlation between age and political party affiliation in NYC.
- Identify geographic areas with specific voting trends.
- Study the impact of demographic changes on election outcomes.
- Predict voter turnout based on historical data (with the caveat of only including active 2018 voters).
- Develop targeted political campaigns based on voter demographics.

title: LinkNYC Usage Statistics (Historical Data)
ufd: This dataset provides historical usage statistics for LinkNYC kiosks, which are replacing outdated public telephones with free Wi-Fi, calling, and other services. Each row represents a week's worth of data, starting from February 2016. Key columns include `sessions_per_week`, showing the number of Wi-Fi sessions, `bandwidth_utilization_per_week_tb`, indicating data usage, and `average_session_duration`. The dataset also tracks subscriber growth with `new_subscribers_per_week`, `total_subscribers_per_week`, and `cumulative_subscribers_to_date`. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the adoption and usage patterns of LinkNYC, understand bandwidth demands, and assess the program's impact on connectivity within the city. The cumulative columns allow for tracking overall growth and usage trends over time. This information can help optimize resource allocation and inform future deployments of similar public access technologies.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains weekly usage statistics for LinkNYC kiosks, offering free Wi-Fi, calls, and other services. It includes metrics like Wi-Fi sessions, bandwidth utilization, session duration, and subscriber growth from February 2016 onwards. The data allows for analysis of LinkNYC adoption, usage patterns, and impact on city connectivity.

Related Topics:
  - Public Wi-Fi
  - Urban Technology
  - Smart Cities
  - Telecommunications
  - Data Usage Analysis
  - Subscriber Growth
  - City Planning

Concepts and Synonyms:
  - LinkNYC: Public Kiosk, Wi-Fi Hotspot, City Internet Access
  - Sessions: Wi-Fi Connections, User Sessions, Access Events
  - Bandwidth Utilization: Data Usage, Network Traffic, Data Consumption
  - Subscribers: Users, Registered Users, Account Holders
  - Kiosk Usage: Public Terminal Usage, Access Point Activity

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Analyze Wi-Fi usage patterns in different city areas.
  - Track the growth of LinkNYC subscribers over time.
  - Predict future bandwidth demands on the LinkNYC network.
  - Evaluate the impact of LinkNYC on digital inclusion.
  - Optimize the placement of new LinkNYC kiosks.
  - Compare LinkNYC usage to other public Wi-Fi initiatives.
  - Assess the effectiveness of LinkNYC in providing public services.

title: NYC Parks Monuments
ufd: This dataset provides information on monuments maintained by NYC Parks, with records dating back to the 1940s. It includes details such as the name of the monument, its location within a specific borough (Manhattan, Brooklyn, etc.) and park, and a descriptive location. Key columns include 'name' for the monument's name, 'borough' indicating its location, 'parkname' specifying the park, and 'dedicated' showing the year of dedication. The dataset also contains information on whether the monument is extant ('Y' or 'N'), the community board ('commboard') and council district ('council') it falls under. Researchers, historians, and park enthusiasts can use this dataset to explore the distribution of monuments across the city, study their history based on dedication dates, or analyze their locations in relation to community boards and council districts. This information can be valuable for planning park visits, conducting historical research, or understanding the cultural landscape of New York City's parks.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details monuments maintained by NYC Parks, offering records from the 1940s to the present. It includes information on the monument's name, borough, park name, and dedication year. The data also specifies whether the monument is extant and its associated community board and council district.

Related Topics:
- NYC Parks

- Public Art
- Urban Planning

- Monuments: Memorials, Statues, Landmarks, Public Art

- Parkname: Park Name, Park Location
- Dedicated: Year Dedicated, Dedication Date, Established
- Extant: Existing, Present, Standing
- Commboard: Community Board, CB
- Council: Council District, City Council

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the geographic distribution of monuments across NYC boroughs.

- Identify monuments within specific community boards or council districts.
- Plan park visits focusing on historical monuments.
- Conduct research on public art and memorials in New York City.
- Determine the number of extant versus non-extant monuments.

title: DPR_PlayAreas_001
ufd: This dataset provides information about play areas managed by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation (DPR). Each row represents a specific play area, identified by its name (`park_name`), borough (`borough`), and a unique GIS property number (`gispropnum`). The dataset includes the play area's geometry (`the_geom`), represented as a MultiPolygon, along with its calculated area (`shape_area`) and perimeter (`shape_len`). This data could be used to analyze the distribution of play areas across the city, calculate the total area dedicated to play spaces in each borough, or visualize the location and shape of these areas on a map. Researchers, city planners, and community organizations could use this dataset to understand and improve access to recreational facilities for children. The dataset contains 100 rows and 6 columns.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details play areas managed by the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation (DPR). It includes information on the location, geometry, area, and perimeter of each play area, identified by name, borough, and a unique property number. The data can be used to analyze the distribution and characteristics of play areas across New York City.

Related Topics:
- Parks and Recreation
- Urban Planning
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- New York City
- Children's Play Spaces
- Public Amenities

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Play Area: Playground, Recreation Area, Play Space
- Borough: District, County (in the context of NYC)
- Geometry: Shape, Spatial Data, Polygon
- GIS Property Number: Unique Identifier, Property ID
- Shape Area: Area (sq ft), Size
- Shape Length: Perimeter, Boundary Length

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the distribution of play areas across different boroughs.
- Calculate the total area dedicated to play spaces in each borough.
- Visualize the location and shape of play areas on a map.
- Identify areas with limited access to play spaces.
- Support urban planning initiatives related to recreational facilities.
- Assess the impact of play area size and location on community health.

title: DEP Green Infrastructure (Point Layer)
ufd: This dataset provides locations and details of green infrastructure projects in New York City, which help manage stormwater runoff. It includes the location of each project using coordinates in the `the_geom` column, a unique `asset_id`, and a `gi_id` for identification. Key details include the `asset_type` (e.g., Rain Garden, Permeable Pavers), the project's `status` (e.g., Constructed, In Construction), and the `borough` where it's located. The dataset also specifies the type of sewer system the infrastructure interacts with (`sewer_type`) and the related outfall. Researchers, city planners, and environmental organizations can use this data to analyze the distribution of green infrastructure, assess project status, and understand the types of stormwater management strategies being implemented across the city. The `project_na` column provides the name of the specific project, while `dep_contra` and `dep_cont_1` offer contract details.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information about green infrastructure projects in New York City designed to manage stormwater runoff. It includes location data, project status, asset types, and contract details for each project. The data allows users to analyze the distribution, status, and types of green infrastructure across the city.

Related Topics:
- Stormwater Management
- Green Infrastructure
- Urban Planning
- Environmental Science
- New York City
- Water Resources

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Green Infrastructure: GI, Sustainable Drainage Systems (SuDS), Low Impact Development (LID)
- Stormwater Runoff: Urban Runoff, Surface Runoff, Precipitation Runoff
- Asset Type: Rain Garden, Permeable Pavers, Green Roof, Bioswale
- Project Status: Constructed, In Construction, Planned, Design
- Sewer Type: Combined Sewer, Separate Sewer
- Borough: Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the spatial distribution of green infrastructure projects in NYC.
- Assess the current status of green infrastructure projects (e.g., how many are constructed vs. planned).
- Identify areas with specific types of green infrastructure (e.g., areas with a high concentration of rain gardens).
- Evaluate the effectiveness of different green infrastructure types in managing stormwater.
- Support urban planning and environmental management decisions related to stormwater control.
- Track the progress of green infrastructure implementation over time.
- Integrate green infrastructure data with other datasets (e.g., demographics, land use) to understand environmental justice implications.

title: Emergency Department Visits and Admissions for Influenza-like Illness and/or Pneumonia
ufd: This dataset contains information about emergency department visits and hospital admissions related to influenza-like illness (ILI) and/or pneumonia. The data includes the total number of emergency department visits (`total_ed_visits`), the number of visits specifically for ILI or pneumonia (`ili_pne_visits`), and the number of admissions for these conditions (`ili_pne_admissions`). Each record also includes a modified ZIP code tabulation area (`mod_zcta`) to indicate the patient's residence. The `date` column represents the date of the visit or admission, while `extract_date` indicates when the data was extracted. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in respiratory illness, identify geographic areas with high rates of ILI/pneumonia, and inform public health interventions. Researchers and healthcare providers can use this information to understand the burden of respiratory illness on emergency departments and hospitals. The dataset contains 100 rows of data with records dating from 2020 to 2022.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides details on emergency department visits and hospital admissions related to influenza-like illness (ILI) and pneumonia. It includes counts of total ED visits, ILI/pneumonia-specific visits, and ILI/pneumonia-related hospital admissions, along with the patient's residential ZIP code area and relevant dates. The data spans from 2020 to 2022 and can be used to analyze respiratory illness trends and identify high-risk geographic areas.

Related Topics:
- Public Health
- Epidemiology
- Respiratory Illness
- Emergency Medicine
- Hospital Admissions
- Geographic Analysis
- Disease Surveillance

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Influenza-like Illness (ILI): Flu, Respiratory Infection, Viral Illness

- Hospital Admission: Inpatient Care, Hospitalization

- Respiratory Illness: Acute Respiratory Infection (ARI), Lower Respiratory Tract Infection (LRTI), Upper Respiratory Tract Infection (URTI)

Applications and Use Cases:
- Track trends in ILI and pneumonia cases over time.
- Identify geographic hotspots with high rates of respiratory illness.
- Evaluate the impact of public health interventions on respiratory illness.
- Predict future surges in emergency department visits related to ILI and pneumonia.
- Allocate healthcare resources based on the burden of respiratory illness.
- Research the correlation between environmental factors and respiratory illness rates.

title: Street Pavement Rating
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the pavement quality of streets in New York City. It includes street segments on 2nd Avenue in Manhattan, with pavement ratings from ongoing assessments. The `systemrating` column indicates the pavement condition on a scale of 1 to 10, where higher values indicate better conditions. The `inspection` column shows the date when the pavement was last inspected. The `fromstreet` and `tostreetna` columns specify the street segment being rated. The `the_geom` column provides the geographic coordinates of the street segment. This data could be used to analyze pavement conditions across the city, track changes over time, and prioritize maintenance efforts.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset contains pavement quality ratings for street segments in New York City, specifically focusing on 2nd Avenue in Manhattan. It includes pavement condition scores (systemrating), inspection dates, street segment details (fromstreet, tostreetna), and geographic coordinates (the_geom). The data can be used to assess and monitor pavement conditions.

**Related Topics:**
- Pavement Management
- Road Infrastructure
- Urban Planning
- Transportation Engineering
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- City Maintenance

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Pavement Quality: Road surface condition, street surface quality, roadway condition
- System Rating: Pavement score, condition rating, quality index
- Inspection Date: Assessment date, survey date, evaluation date
- Street Segment: Road section, block, street portion
- Geographic Coordinates: Location data, spatial data, GIS data

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Analyzing pavement condition trends over time.
- Identifying areas with poor pavement quality for prioritization of repairs.
- Integrating pavement data with other city datasets for comprehensive urban planning.
- Visualizing pavement conditions on a map using GIS tools.
- Developing predictive models for pavement deterioration.

title: DOHMH Community Mental Health Survey
ufd: This dataset contains results from the 2012 New York City Community Mental Health Survey (CMHS), conducted alongside the Community Health Survey (CHS). It provides insights into the mental health of New Yorkers, offering estimates at the neighborhood, borough, and city levels. The data can be used to inform mental health program decisions and improve understanding of mental health within the city. Key columns include "question," which details the specific mental health topic being surveyed, and "denominator," specifying the population group being analyzed (e.g., all CHS respondents or follow-up respondents with Serious Mental Illness). The "prevalence" column shows the percentage of the population that answered affirmatively to the question.  "lower_95_ci" and "upper_95_ci" provide the lower and upper bounds of the 95% confidence interval for the prevalence estimate. This dataset allows users to explore the prevalence of various mental health conditions and treatment experiences among different population subgroups in New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The 2012 New York City Community Mental Health Survey (CMHS) dataset provides prevalence estimates for various mental health conditions and treatment experiences across different population subgroups in NYC. It includes data collected alongside the Community Health Survey (CHS) and offers insights at the neighborhood, borough, and city levels. Key data points include prevalence rates, confidence intervals, and demographic breakdowns.

Related Topics:
- Mental Health
- Public Health
- Community Health
- Epidemiology
- New York City
- Health Surveys
- Population Health

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Mental Health Survey: CMHS, Community Mental Health Survey, Mental Health Assessment
- Prevalence: Rate, Percentage, Proportion, Occurrence
- Confidence Interval: CI, Lower Bound, Upper Bound, Margin of Error
- Population Subgroups: Demographics, Neighborhoods, Boroughs, Denominator
- Mental Illness: Mental Health Condition, Psychiatric Disorder, Psychological Distress

Applications and Use Cases:
- Informing mental health program development and resource allocation in NYC.
- Identifying areas with high prevalence of specific mental health conditions.
- Comparing mental health outcomes across different demographic groups.
- Tracking changes in mental health prevalence over time (if combined with other survey years).
- Supporting research on the social determinants of mental health.
- Evaluating the effectiveness of mental health interventions.

title: Seating Locations
ufd: This dataset provides locations for seating features, like benches and leaning bars, provided by the DOT in New York City. Each record represents a specific seating location and includes its geographic coordinates, borough, and nearest address. You can use the `borocode` and `boroname` columns to filter seating locations by borough. The dataset also includes political district information, such as congressional (`congdist`), state senate (`stsendist`), and assembly districts (`assemdist`). Installation dates are provided in the `installation_date` column. This data could be used to analyze the distribution of public seating across the city, plan new installations, or assess the accessibility of public spaces. The `on_street`, `from_street`, and `to_street` columns provide address details for each seating location.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains locations of public seating features, such as benches and leaning bars, provided by the NYC DOT. Each entry includes geographic coordinates, borough information, nearest address details, and political district data. Installation dates are also provided, allowing for analysis of seating deployment over time.

title: Housing Database by Community District
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at housing development in New York City Community Districts since 2010. It tracks the net change in housing units, considering new constructions, demolitions, and alterations. The data is aggregated from the NYC Department of City Planning's Housing Database, which sources information from Department of Buildings-approved construction and demolition jobs. Key columns include `commntydst` representing the Community District, and columns like `comp2010`, `comp2011`, etc., which show the number of housing units completed in those respective years. The `the_geom` column contains geographic information, allowing for spatial analysis. This dataset can be used to analyze housing trends, assess the impact of development on different communities, and inform planning decisions related to housing. Researchers, city planners, and developers can leverage this data to understand the dynamics of housing in NYC.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details housing development changes in New York City Community Districts from 2010 onwards. It tracks net housing unit changes, accounting for new construction, demolitions, and alterations, based on NYC Department of Buildings data. The data includes the number of housing units completed per year in each community district, along with geographic information for spatial analysis.

Related Topics:
- Housing Development

- New York City
- Community Districts
- Construction and Demolition
- Spatial Analysis
- Real Estate

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Housing Units: Apartments, Residences, Dwellings

- Demolition: Razing, Tearing Down, Removal
- Alteration: Renovation, Modification, Remodeling
- Completion: Finished, Constructed, Ready for Occupancy

title: Bus Lanes - Local Streets
ufd: This dataset provides information about bus lanes on local streets in New York City. Each record represents a segment of a bus lane, detailing its location, hours of operation, and other characteristics. Key columns include "the_geom" which contains the geographic coordinates of the bus lane segment, "street" indicating the street name, "boro" specifying the borough, and "hours" defining the times when the bus lane is in effect. The "direction" column shows the direction of traffic flow for the bus lane. You can use the "SegmentID" to join this dataset with the LION data for more detailed street information. This dataset can be used to analyze bus lane coverage, identify potential bottlenecks, or plan bus routes. It can also help commuters understand when and where bus lanes are available.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information about bus lanes on local streets in New York City. It includes details such as the location of each bus lane segment, its hours of operation, and the borough it's located in. The dataset can be used to analyze bus lane characteristics and their impact on traffic flow.

title: New York City Truck Routes
ufd: This dataset provides information about the designated truck routes in New York City. It focuses specifically on truck routes within the Bronx. Key columns include 'street', indicating the name of the street, 'routetype' specifying whether the route is local or through, and 'the_geom' which contains the geographic coordinates defining the route's path. The 'nyc_reg' column refers to the specific NYCDOT traffic rule that applies to the truck route. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze the truck route network, understand its spatial distribution, and assess compliance with traffic regulations. This information can be valuable for optimizing traffic flow, improving safety, and managing the impact of commercial vehicles on local communities.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details designated truck routes specifically within the Bronx borough of New York City. It includes information on street names, route types (local or through), geographic coordinates defining the route, and the relevant NYCDOT traffic regulations. The data is useful for analyzing the truck route network and its compliance with city rules.

title: DCWP Charges
ufd: This dataset contains records of charges issued by the NYC Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP) resulting from inspections and investigations. It includes details on the business, the specific violation, and relevant identifiers. Key columns include `business_name`, `business_category` (e.g., "Grocery-Retail", "Tobacco Retail Dealer"), `charge` (the specific violation), and `violation_date`. The `business_unique_id` and `inspection_number` provide unique references for each business and inspection. This data can be used to analyze trends in business violations, identify common issues across different business categories, and assess the effectiveness of DCWP's enforcement efforts. Researchers, policymakers, and business owners can use this information to understand and improve compliance with consumer protection laws. The dataset covers charges filed by both the Enforcement and General Counsel divisions of the DCWP.
sfd:

title: OpenData_ParksProperties
ufd: This dataset provides information about properties under the jurisdiction of NYC Parks. It includes the geographic boundaries of each property, represented in the `the_geom` column as a MultiPolygon. Each property is identified by several ID columns, including `gispropnum` and `omppropid`. The `department` column indicates the relevant Parks department. The `location` column provides a textual description of the property's location, often including street names or nearby landmarks. This dataset could be used to map and analyze the distribution of park properties across the city, identify properties managed by specific departments, or link park locations to other datasets based on location.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details properties managed by NYC Parks, including their geographic boundaries, unique identifiers, and managing department. The geographic boundaries are represented as MultiPolygons in the `the_geom` column. Key identifiers include `gispropnum` and `omppropid`, and location descriptions are provided in the `location` column.

title: In-Service Alarm Box Locations
ufd: This dataset provides locations for in-service alarm boxes throughout New York City. It includes both Emergency Reporting System (ERS) devices and pull-activated Box Alarm Reporting System (BARS) devices. Each record details the location of a specific alarm box, including its street address, borough, zip code, and community district. The dataset also specifies the type of alarm box (ERS or BARS) and the corresponding city council district. Location is further specified with latitude and longitude coordinates. This information could be used by city planners, emergency responders, or researchers to analyze the distribution of alarm boxes and identify areas with high or low coverage. Note that out-of-service BARS devices may be included in this dataset.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains location information for in-service alarm boxes across New York City. It includes both Emergency Reporting System (ERS) and Box Alarm Reporting System (BARS) devices. Each record provides details such as street address, borough, zip code, community district, alarm box type, city council district, latitude, and longitude. Note that out-of-service BARS devices may be included.

title: Centerline
ufd: This dataset represents the road-bed of New York City streets, also known as the NYC Street Centerline (CSCL). It includes key information such as address ranges, traffic directions, and road types for each street segment. The `the_geom` column provides the geographic coordinates defining the street's path. Address ranges are captured using left and right side low and high house numbers (`l_low_hn`, `l_high_hn`, `r_low_hn`, `r_high_hn`), along with corresponding zip codes (`l_zip`, `r_zip`). The `trafdir` column indicates the allowed traffic direction on the street segment. This dataset can be valuable for urban planning, navigation applications, and analyzing street networks. Researchers and city planners can use this data to understand traffic patterns, identify areas with address discrepancies, or improve routing algorithms. The `status` column indicates the state or condition of the street segment.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains the New York City Street Centerline (CSCL), representing the road-bed of NYC streets. title: NYC Community Based Organizations
ufd: This dataset provides information on community-based organizations (CBOs) in New York City. It includes details such as the organization's name, mission statement, volunteer program description, street address, city, state, postcode, and website. The dataset also includes the borough and latitude of the organization. Key columns for understanding an organization's purpose are the "mission" and "volunteer_program_description". Researchers, volunteers, and individuals seeking social services can use this dataset to identify and connect with CBOs that align with their interests or needs. The data can also be used to analyze the distribution and focus areas of CBOs across different boroughs of New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes organizational details like name, address, contact information, mission statements, and descriptions of volunteer programs. title: Prequalified Firms
ufd: This dataset provides a list of firms that are prequalified to perform work for the School Construction Authority. It includes details about the vendors, their trades, and the expiration date of their qualification. Key columns include `prequalified_vendor_name`, which lists the names of the qualified firms, `prequalified_vendor_trade_description`, detailing the type of work the vendor is qualified for (e.g., Temporary Scaffolding and Platforms, Temporary Construction), and `prequalified_vendor_date`, indicating the date until which the vendor is prequalified. Additional information such as vendor address, contact person, and business indicators (minority-owned, women-owned, etc.) are also provided. This dataset could be used to identify qualified vendors for specific construction-related tasks, ensure diversity in vendor selection, or track vendor qualification status. Researchers can use this data to analyze trends in vendor qualifications and demographics within the school construction sector.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: ACRIS - Personal Property Legals
ufd: This dataset contains details on personal property-related legal documents recorded in the Automated City Register Information System (ACRIS). Each row represents a legal record, identified by a unique document ID. Key columns include the borough, block, and lot, which together define a property's location. The dataset also specifies the property type and whether there are easements, partial lots, air rights, or subterranean rights associated with the property. The street number and street name provide address information. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze property ownership, land use, and legal restrictions across different boroughs. The `good_through_date` indicates the validity of the record.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed information on personal property legal documents recorded in the Automated City Register Information System (ACRIS). Each record represents a legal document, uniquely identified by a document ID, and includes property location details such as borough, block, and lot. The dataset also specifies property type and associated rights like easements or air rights, along with address information and record validity.

title: Forestry Inspections
ufd: This dataset contains records of forestry inspections conducted by NYC Parks & Recreation. Inspections are initiated by service requests or internal processes and may lead to work orders. The data includes details about the inspection type (e.g., Level 1, Sidewalk Rating), the condition of the inspected tree point (Good, Fair, Poor), and the structure of the tree point (Full, Shaft). The `treepointdbh` column provides the diameter at breast height of the tree, a key measurement for assessing tree health and size. The `inspectiondate` column indicates when the inspection took place. Researchers and urban planners can use this dataset to analyze tree health trends, evaluate the effectiveness of maintenance programs, and optimize resource allocation for forestry management. The dataset also includes geographic coordinates (`geometry`) for each inspection, allowing for spatial analysis of tree conditions across the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset documents forestry inspections performed by NYC Parks & Recreation. It includes details on inspection types, tree condition and structure, diameter at breast height (DBH), and inspection dates. Geographic coordinates are also provided, enabling spatial analysis of tree health.

title: Free Residential at-the-tap Lead and Copper Data
ufd: This dataset contains results from free residential tap water testing for lead and copper in New York City. The data includes the levels of lead and copper measured in milligrams per liter (mg/L) from samples taken at different times: first draw, after a 1/2-minute flush, and after a 5-minute flush. Each record includes a unique kit ID, the borough and zipcode where the sample was collected, and the dates the sample was collected and received for testing. The borough and zipcode can be used to analyze the spatial distribution of lead and copper levels. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to assess water quality, identify potential contamination hotspots, and evaluate the effectiveness of mitigation strategies. Note that the lead and copper levels after a 5-minute flush are only available for a very small number of samples.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides results from free residential tap water testing for lead and copper in New York City. It includes measurements of lead and copper levels (mg/L) from samples taken at different flush intervals (first draw, 1/2-minute flush, and 5-minute flush). The data also contains location information (borough, zipcode) and sample collection dates, enabling spatial and temporal analysis of water quality.

title: Mayor's Management Report Spending and Budget
ufd: This dataset contains spending and budget information for New York City agencies, as reported in the Mayor's Management Report (MMR) for the fiscal year 2016. It provides a snapshot of how city resources are allocated and spent across various departments. Key columns include `agency_name`, which identifies the specific city agency, `unit_of_appropriation`, detailing the budget line item, `appropriation_type` categorizing the spending (e.g., Personal Services, Other Than Personal Services), `expenditures_previous_fy` showing the prior year's spending, and `modified_budget_current_fy` representing the current fiscal year's budget. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this data to analyze spending patterns, compare budgets across agencies, and track financial performance against established goals. The `agency_code` provides a unique identifier for each agency. Note that the `applicable_mmr_goals` column is empty in this dataset.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details New York City agency spending and budget information for the 2016 fiscal year, as reported in the Mayor's Management Report (MMR). It includes agency-specific data on budget allocations, expenditures, and appropriation types. The data allows for analysis of resource allocation and financial performance across city departments.

title: Street Construction Permits - Fee
ufd: This dataset contains information about fees associated with street construction permits. Each row represents a specific fee charged for a permit. Key columns include the permit number, the type of fee (e.g., administration, inspection), and the amount charged. The dataset also includes the creation and modification timestamps for each fee record. You can use this data to analyze the different types of fees associated with street construction permits, understand the cost distribution, and track changes to fee amounts over time. This information could be valuable for city planners, contractors, and anyone interested in the costs associated with street construction projects. The most common fee type is "ADMINISTRATION FEE". The fee amounts vary, with some permits having costs as high as $13,770.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

Key data points include the permit number, fee type (e.g., administration, inspection), and the fee amount. Timestamps for record creation and modification are also included. title: Inmate Admissions
ufd: This dataset provides information on inmate admissions, including demographic attributes like race and gender, as well as details about their legal status and top charge. Each record includes a unique inmate ID, the date and time of admission, and, if applicable, the date and time of discharge. The `inmate_status_code` column indicates the inmate's current legal status, while `top_charge` specifies the most serious charge against them. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to study trends in incarceration, analyze demographic patterns within the inmate population, and assess the types of charges most frequently associated with admissions. Note that discharge dates and top charges are missing for a significant portion of the inmates in this dataset. The dataset excludes sealed cases, which may cause summaries to differ from other published statistics.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details inmate admissions, providing demographic information (race, gender), legal status, and the top charge associated with each inmate. Each record includes a unique inmate ID, admission date/time, and discharge date/time (if applicable). The data allows for analysis of incarceration trends and demographic patterns within the inmate population, but users should note missing discharge dates and top charges, as well as the exclusion of sealed cases.

title: Current Solicitations
ufd: This dataset provides information on current solicitations from New York City government agencies. It includes details such as the agency name, a description of the type of notice, the category of goods or services being solicited, and a short title for the solicitation. Key columns include `agency_name`, indicating which city agency is issuing the solicitation, `category_description`, specifying the type of goods or services requested (e.g., goods, services, construction), and `selection_method_description`, outlining the process used to select a vendor. The `start_date` and `due_date` columns provide the timeline for the solicitation process. Researchers, businesses, and individuals interested in doing business with New York City can use this dataset to identify relevant opportunities, understand the types of goods and services the city needs, and track the procurement process. The dataset also includes a unique `request_id` for each solicitation and a `pin` for easy reference.
sfd:

title: Annual Examination Schedule of Each Fiscal Year
ufd: This dataset provides an annual list of civil service exams offered by the city government. The exam schedule is typically posted every July and updated monthly, outlining upcoming exams for the fiscal year. Each record includes the `exam_title`, a unique `exam_number`, the `application_period_start` date, the `application_period_end_date`, and the type of exam (`open_competitive_promotion`). Note that civil service exams may only be available for a limited time, and some exams might not be offered every year. You can use this dataset to find information on specific civil service exams, their application periods, and whether they are open to the public or for internal promotions only. This information is valuable for individuals seeking employment with the city government.
sfd:

title: DCLA Programs Funding
ufd: This dataset contains information about cultural development funding provided by the DCLA (presumably the Department of Cultural Affairs). It lists the annual funding amount awarded to various organizations for a specific fiscal year. Each row represents a unique application and the corresponding organization that received funding. Key columns include the "application" identifier, the "organization" that received the award, and the "total_final_award" amount. Researchers, policymakers, or arts organizations can use this dataset to understand funding patterns, identify recipients of cultural grants, and analyze the distribution of resources within the cultural sector. The dataset includes 100 rows of funding allocations. The funding amounts range from $3,000 to $266,250.

title: 2013 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records for yellow taxis in 2013. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including pickup and drop-off dates and times, locations, trip distances, and fares. Key columns include `vendorid` (identifying the Technology Service Provider), `tpep_pickup_datetime` and `tpep_dropoff_datetime` (recording the start and end times of the trip), `passenger_count`, and `trip_distance`. Location data is provided via `pickup_longitude`, `pickup_latitude`, `dropoff_longitude`, and `dropoff_latitude`. The dataset also includes fare information such as `fare_amount`, `tip_amount`, `tolls_amount`, and `total_amount`, along with the `payment_type`. This data could be used to analyze taxi usage patterns, understand travel times and distances, or investigate fare structures. Researchers and urban planners could use this dataset to gain insights into transportation trends and improve city services.
sfd:

title: Licensed Wholesale Cigarette Dealers
ufd: This dataset contains information on licensed wholesale cigarette dealers in New York City. It includes the dealer's name, license number, business address, and location details such as borough, city, state, and zip code. Geographic information like latitude and longitude, along with administrative details like community board and council district, are also provided. This data could be used to analyze the distribution of wholesale cigarette dealers across the city, understand their geographic concentration within different administrative regions, or identify potential areas for regulatory oversight. Researchers or policymakers could use this dataset to study the economic impact of the tobacco industry or to inform public health initiatives related to smoking and tobacco use. The effective date indicates when the data was last updated.

title: NYC Women's Resource Network Database
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of nonprofit organizations and governmental agencies in New York City that focus on women and families. Each entry includes the organization's name, contact information (phone, fax, and URL), and a brief description of their services. The dataset also indicates which boroughs (Brooklyn, Bronx, Manhattan, Queens, and Staten Island) the organization serves. Furthermore, the dataset categorizes organizations by their area of focus, such as aging, arts and culture, children and youth, and disability services. This information can be used to find resources for women and families in specific locations or with particular needs. Researchers can use this data to analyze the landscape of social services available to women and families in NYC.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset catalogs nonprofit organizations and government agencies serving women and families in New York City. It includes organizational contact information, service descriptions, and the boroughs served. Organizations are categorized by their area of focus, such as aging, children and youth, and disability services.

title: SNAP Program Access Index (PAI)
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) Participation Rates, also known as the Program Access Index (PAI), in New York City and the United States. It includes data from 2008 to 2023, showing the percentage of eligible individuals participating in the SNAP program. The key columns are 'year', 'nyc' (SNAP participation rate in New York City), and 'us' (SNAP participation rate in the United States). Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze trends in SNAP participation over time, compare participation rates between NYC and the national average, and assess the effectiveness of outreach and enrollment efforts. The dataset can also be used to identify years with significant changes in participation rates, potentially highlighting the impact of policy changes or economic conditions. Understanding these trends can inform strategies to improve access to food assistance programs and reduce food insecurity.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It provides annual data on the percentage of eligible individuals participating in the SNAP program in both NYC and the US as a whole. This allows for comparative analysis of SNAP participation trends over time.

title: Directory Of Homeless Drop- In Centers
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of homeless drop-in centers in New York City, offering resources like hot meals, showers, and shelter. Each entry includes the center's name, address, and borough, allowing users to easily locate nearby services. The 'comments' field provides information on the center's operating hours, which can be crucial for those seeking immediate assistance. Location data, including latitude and longitude, is available for mapping and navigation purposes. Additionally, community board, council district, and census tract information are included, potentially useful for analyzing service distribution and identifying areas with high needs. Researchers and social workers can use this dataset to understand the landscape of homeless services and improve resource allocation.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a directory of homeless drop-in centers located throughout New York City. It provides key information such as center name, address, borough, operating hours (found in the 'comments' field), and geographic coordinates. The data also includes community board, council district, and census tract information for each center.

title: NYC Wetlands
ufd: This dataset provides information about wetlands in New York City, as mapped and verified by NYC Parks. It includes the class name of the wetland (e.g., Estuarine, Forested, Emergent), the date it was created and last edited, and its verification status, which indicates the level of ground-truthing that has been performed. The `verificationstatusyear` column indicates the year the verification status was assigned. The dataset also contains a `multipolygon` column with coordinate data defining the wetland's location. Researchers and conservationists can use this dataset to understand the distribution and characteristics of wetlands in NYC, track changes over time, and prioritize areas for restoration and conservation efforts. Please note that this dataset is intended to be used alongside other wetland inventories and does not have jurisdictional authority.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the location and characteristics of wetlands in New York City, as mapped and verified by NYC Parks. It includes wetland class, creation and edit dates, verification status, and geographic coordinates. The data allows users to understand wetland distribution, track changes, and inform conservation efforts within NYC.

- Mapping and visualizing wetland locations using GIS software.

title: Community Districts
ufd: This dataset contains geographic boundaries and identifying information for New York City's Community Districts (CDs) and Joint Interest Areas (JIAs). Community Districts are mandated by the city charter to review and monitor quality of life issues for NYC neighborhoods. The dataset includes 71 rows, each representing a unique CD or JIA. Key columns include `boro_cd`, a unique ID for CDs and JIAs, `shape_leng`, representing the length of the district's boundary, and `shape_area`, representing the area of the district. The `the_geom` column contains the geographic data defining the boundaries of each district. This data could be used for mapping applications, spatial analysis, or to understand the geographic distribution of community districts within New York City. Researchers and city planners could use this data to analyze demographic or socioeconomic data in relation to community district boundaries.
sfd:

title: Food Scrap Drop-Off Locations in NYC
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive list of food scrap drop-off locations across New York City, offering a valuable resource for residents looking to compost their food waste. The dataset includes key details such as the borough and neighborhood (ntaname) where each drop-off site is located, the name of the site itself (food_scrap_drop_off_site), and the organization hosting it. You can find information about the operating hours (operation_day_hours) and the months the site is open (open_months) to plan your drop-offs. Additional notes provide details on accepted materials, such as whether meat, bones, or dairy are allowed. The dataset also includes geographic information like latitude and longitude, as well as political divisions like council district and borough code. This information can be used to find the most convenient locations, understand the accessibility of composting programs across different neighborhoods, or analyze the distribution of food scrap drop-off sites throughout the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: NYC Benefits Platform: Benefits and Programs Dataset
ufd: This dataset provides information on benefits, programs, and resources available to NYC residents, covering over 80 health and human services. It includes details such as program names, categories (e.g., cash & expenses, housing, health), and the government agencies responsible for them. The dataset also specifies the populations and age groups served by each program. Key columns include `program_name`, `program_category`, `government_agency`, `population_served`, and `age_group`. Researchers, city planners, and application developers can use this data to understand the landscape of social services in NYC, identify gaps in service delivery, or build tools to help residents discover relevant benefits. The `page_type` column indicates whether an entry is a program, service, benefit, or resource. This dataset is updated regularly to reflect the most current information on eligibility requirements and application processes.
sfd:

title: Public feedback on 311 request/complaint types
ufd: This dataset contains public feedback related to New York City's 311 service request and complaint system, as mandated by Local Law 97 of 2022. It provides valuable insights into how citizens are using the 311 system and what improvements they suggest. Each record includes the date and time the feedback was submitted (`feedback_date_time`), the detailed message from the customer (`customer_message`), the city agency that the feedback pertains to (`agency_name`), and the current status of the feedback (`status`). The `agency_name` column indicates which department is responsible for addressing the feedback, such as the New York City Police Department or the Department of Buildings. The `status` column reveals the current stage of the feedback, such as "In Review" or "Already Exists." Researchers, city planners, and government officials can use this dataset to understand public concerns, identify areas for improvement in city services, and track the progress of addressing citizen feedback related to 311 requests. By analyzing the customer messages, one can identify recurring themes and emerging issues within the city.
sfd:

title: Agency Authorized Parking Permits
ufd: This dataset contains information on agency-authorized on-street parking placards (AAOSP) and citywide agency parking permits (CAPP) issued in NYC. It includes details on permits issued to government employees, teachers, private school facilities, agency heads, elected officials, and the FDNY/DOI for official agency business. Key columns include the agency name (`agencyname`), a description of the agency (`agencydesc`), the parking placard number (`parkingplacardnumber`), and permit dates (`abp_issuedate`, `abp_effectivedate`, `abp_expirationdate`). The dataset also indicates whether a permit is currently active (`activepermit`). This data could be used to analyze parking permit allocation across different city agencies, track permit issuance and expiration, or assess the usage of agency-authorized parking. Note that AAOSP permits no longer allow parking at loading zones below 60th Street in Manhattan, as per Local Law 167 of 2021.

title: NYPD Use of Force Incidents
ufd: This dataset contains information on NYPD's use of force incidents, as recorded in Threat, Resistance, or Injury (TRI) reports. Each row represents a single incident where a member of the service used force. Key details include the `tri_incident_number` for identification, the `forcetype` which is consistently "Physical Force" in this sample, and the `occurrence_date` of the incident. The `incident_pct` indicates the precinct where the incident occurred, while `patrol_borough` specifies the borough. This data can be used to analyze the frequency and location of force incidents within the NYPD. Researchers and the public can use this information to understand patterns and trends in the use of force. The `basisforencounter` column explains the reason for the use of force.

title: Directory Of Homeless Population By Year
ufd: This dataset provides estimates of the homeless population in specific areas from 2009 to 2012. The 'year' column indicates the year of the estimate. The 'area' column specifies the location or category for which the homeless population was estimated, such as "Subways" or "Surface Area - Manhattan." The 'homeless_estimates' column contains the estimated number of homeless individuals for that area and year. This data could be used to analyze trends in homelessness across different areas, compare the prevalence of homelessness in different locations, or evaluate the impact of social programs aimed at reducing homelessness. Researchers, policymakers, and social service providers can use this information to understand and address homelessness in the specified regions.

title: 2016-17 - 2020-21 School End-of-Year Attendance and Chronic Absenteeism Data
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at school attendance and chronic absenteeism in New York City public schools from 2016-17 to 2020-21. It includes data for students in districts 1-32 and 75 (Special Education), excluding those in alternative programs, charter schools, or home schooling. Each row represents attendance information for a specific school, grade level, and student category for a given year. Key columns include 'school_name', 'grade', 'year', 'total_days', 'days_absent', 'days_present', and 'attendance'. The 'chronically_absent' columns indicate the number and percentage of students absent for 10% or more of the school year. This data can be used to analyze attendance trends, identify schools or grade levels with high absenteeism rates, and evaluate the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on student attendance. Note that data from 2019-20 only covers September 2019 through March 13, 2020, due to the shift to remote learning.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It excludes alternative programs, charter schools, and home schooling. The data includes information on total days, days absent, days present, attendance rates, and chronic absenteeism rates, broken down by school, grade, and student category.

title: Real Property Income and Expense Form non-compliance list
ufd: This dataset identifies properties in Manhattan that did not file the required Real Property Income and Expense (RPIE) form in 2017. Each row represents a unique property identified by its borough, block, and lot (BBL). The dataset includes the property's address, zip code, and final actual assessed value for 2018-2019. Additional details include the tax class and building class of the property. Location information is provided through x/y coordinates, latitude, longitude, community district, city council district, census tract, and neighborhood tabulation area (NTA). This data could be used by city government to identify and follow up with non-compliant property owners, analyze patterns of non-compliance, or assess the potential impact of non-filing on city revenue.

title: Donations to Not-for-Profit Organizations Affiliated with Elected Officials
ufd: This dataset contains information on donations made to not-for-profit organizations affiliated with elected officials in New York City. The data includes details about the donation year, the name of the organization receiving the donation, and a unique donation ID. You can also find the donor's name, city and state of residence, the type of donation (money or in-kind), and the donation value. The date of the donation and a description of any in-kind donations are provided as well. This information is reported annually to COIB (Conflicts of Interest Board) pursuant to the Affiliated Not-for-Profits Law. Researchers and the public can use this dataset to understand the flow of donations to organizations connected to elected officials, analyze donation patterns, and assess potential conflicts of interest.

title: Local Law 84 Monthly Data
ufd: This dataset contains monthly energy consumption data for privately owned buildings larger than 25,000 sq ft and city-owned buildings exceeding 10,000 sq ft. The data includes the calendar year and month of consumption, along with the property ID and name, allowing you to track energy usage for specific buildings. You can also identify parent properties using the 'parent_property_id' and 'parent_property_name' columns. The dataset provides details on both natural gas and electricity usage, measured in kBTU. Note that electricity usage data has missing values. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze energy consumption patterns, identify areas for improvement, and track the effectiveness of energy-saving initiatives in buildings.
sfd:

title: NYC EV Fleet Station Network
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive inventory of electric vehicle (EV) charging stations within New York City's fleet network. It includes details on the agency responsible for the station, the station's name, and the type of charger available (Level 2, Level 3 Fast Charger, or EV Solar Arc Charger). Key location information such as street address, city, postcode, borough, latitude, and longitude are provided for each station. The dataset also specifies the number of ports available at each charging station. This information can be used by city vehicle operators to locate and utilize EV charging stations. Additionally, it could be used for urban planning and sustainability initiatives related to electric vehicle infrastructure.

title: Parking Violations Issued - Fiscal Year 2017
ufd: This dataset contains parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2017 (July 1, 2016 to June 30, 2017). Each row represents a single parking ticket. Key details include the `summons_number` (a unique identifier for the ticket), the `plate_id` and `registration_state` of the vehicle, the `issue_date` and `violation_time`, and the `violation_code` describing the infraction. The `issuing_agency` indicates which department issued the ticket. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze parking violation patterns, identify areas with high violation rates, and assess the effectiveness of parking regulations. Note that the dataset only reflects the status of the violation at the time it was issued and may not reflect current status. For current violation status, refer to the Open Parking & Camera Violations dataset.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2017 (July 1, 2016 to June 30, 2017). Each record represents a single parking ticket, including information such as the summons number, vehicle plate ID, issue date, violation time, and violation code. The dataset also identifies the issuing agency responsible for the ticket.

  - Plate ID: License Plate Number, Vehicle Identification

title: Active NYC Health Code Regulated Child Care Programs
ufd: This dataset contains information about active child care programs regulated by the NYC Health Department. It includes details on program names, facility types (GCC or SBCC), and the age range of children served. The dataset also provides the address, borough, and zipcode of each program, allowing users to map and filter programs by location. You can use this data to find child care options in specific areas of New York City or to analyze the distribution of different types of child care facilities. Key columns include 'program_name', 'facility_type', 'age_range', 'borough', and 'zipcode'. Additionally, the dataset indicates whether a program administers medication and its capacity.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides comprehensive information on active child care programs regulated by the NYC Health Department. It details program names, facility types (Group Child Care or School-Based Child Care), age ranges served, addresses, and locations within New York City. title: Big Apple Connect (BAC) Enrollment Statistics
ufd: This dataset provides Big Apple Connect (BAC) enrollment statistics for NYCHA developments in New York City. It includes information on the number of apartments in each development, the total number of Big Apple Connect enrollees, and the percentage of enrollment. The data is broken down by borough, community district, city council district, congressional district, and state senate/assembly district, offering a detailed geographic view of enrollment. The service provider for Big Apple Connect is also listed. This dataset could be used to analyze BAC enrollment rates across different NYCHA developments and geographic areas, identify areas with low enrollment, and inform outreach efforts to increase participation in the program. The reporting date for all entries is November 18, 2025.
sfd:

This dataset contains Big Apple Connect (BAC) enrollment statistics for New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) developments. It provides a geographic breakdown of enrollment, including data by borough, community district, and various legislative districts. Key metrics include the number of apartments, total enrollees, and enrollment percentage, with a reporting date of November 18, 2025.
