- Correlate permit activity with other datasets, such as population density or property values.

title: 2020-2021 SHSAT Admissions Test Offers By Sending School
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the Specialized High Schools Admissions Test (SHSAT) offers for NYC public middle schools during the 2020-2021 school year. It reveals the number of students from each school who participated in the high school admissions process, how many took the SHSAT, and the number who received offers to specialized high schools. Key columns include `feeder_school_dbn` and `feeder_school_name`, identifying the specific middle school. The `count_of_students_in_hs` column shows the total number of students in the high school, while `count_of_testers` indicates how many students took the SHSAT. The `number_of_offers` column shows the number of specialized high school offers received. This data can be used to analyze the success rates of different middle schools in preparing students for the SHSAT, identify schools that may need additional resources, and understand trends in specialized high school admissions. The data includes 100 rows, with the number of offers often represented as a range (e.g., 0-5).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on Specialized High Schools Admissions Test (SHSAT) offers for NYC public middle schools during the 2020-2021 school year. It includes data on the number of students who participated in the high school admissions process, took the SHSAT, and received offers to specialized high schools, broken down by middle school. The dataset allows for analysis of middle school performance in preparing students for specialized high school admissions.

Related Topics:
- High School Admissions
- Standardized Testing
- Education Statistics
- New York City Public Schools
- Middle School Performance
- SHSAT (Specialized High Schools Admissions Test)
- Educational Equity

- Feeder School: Middle School, Sending School
- High School Offers: Admissions Offers, Acceptance Rate

- DBN: District Borough Number, School Identifier

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the success rates of different middle schools in preparing students for the SHSAT.
- Identify schools that may need additional resources to improve student performance on the SHSAT.
- Understand trends in specialized high school admissions in NYC.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of different educational programs in preparing students for specialized high schools.
- Compare SHSAT offer rates across different middle schools.

title: 2017 - 2018 School Locations
ufd: This dataset provides information about school locations for the fiscal year 2018. It includes details such as the location name, address, and type of school (e.g., General Academic, Career Technical). Key columns include `location_name`, `location_type_description`, `location_category_description`, and `grades_text`, which specify the name, type, category, and grades offered at each school location, respectively. The dataset also indicates the agency managing the school (`managed_by_name`), which is consistently "DOE" (Department of Education). Researchers and policymakers can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of different school types, the range of grades offered at various locations, and other characteristics of the educational landscape. The `open_date` column provides insights into the history of each school. This information can be valuable for understanding trends in education and planning for future needs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information about school locations for the fiscal year 2018, including details such as location name, address, and school type. It provides insights into the educational landscape by detailing the types of schools, grades offered, and managing agency. This data is valuable for analyzing school distribution and planning for future educational needs.

title: Office of The Comptroller: NYC Employee Retirement System (NYCERS) Holdings Data
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of the NYC Employee Retirement System (NYCERS) holdings as of June 30, 2022. It includes details on both equity and fixed income investments. Key columns include `security_name` and `security_description`, which identify the specific assets held by NYCERS, as well as financial metrics like `interest_rate`, `shares_par_value`, `base_market_value`, and `base_total_cost`. The data also breaks down unrealized gains/losses and accrued interest for each holding. Researchers and financial analysts can use this dataset to understand the investment portfolio of NYCERS, assess the performance of its holdings, and analyze trends in its investment strategies. The `trade_country_name` and `local_currency_code` columns provide additional context regarding the geographic and currency exposure of the portfolio. This information is valuable for assessing risk and diversification within the retirement system's investments.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on the NYC Employee Retirement System (NYCERS) holdings as of June 30, 2022, detailing both equity and fixed income investments. It includes security names, descriptions, and financial metrics such as interest rates, shares/par value, market value, and total cost. The data also provides insights into unrealized gains/losses, accrued interest, geographic location and currency exposure of the portfolio.

Related Topics:

title: OATH Trials Division Case Status
ufd: This dataset provides detailed information on closed cases adjudicated by the New York City Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings (OATH) Trials Division. It covers a wide array of administrative law matters filed by various city agencies, boards, and commissions. Key details include the filing agency's case ID (`filing_agency_case_id`), a general case number (`case_number`), the case name (`name`), the type and category of the case (e.g., "License", "Taxi & Limousine"), and a more specific subcategory. Dates for when the case was opened (`opened`), closed (`record_closed`), and when the report was issued (`report_issued`) are also included. Researchers, legal professionals, and city oversight bodies can use this data to analyze trends in administrative law, understand the types of cases OATH handles, and assess the timeliness of case resolutions. The `premises` column, though sparsely populated, may provide location information relevant to certain cases.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset contains records of closed cases from the New York City Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings (OATH) Trials Division. It includes information on case identifiers, case types and categories, and key dates related to case processing. The data allows for analysis of administrative law matters handled by OATH across various city agencies.

**Related Topics:**
*   Administrative Law
*   New York City Government
*   Legal Case Data
*   City Agency Adjudication
*   Municipal Courts
*   OATH (Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings)

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
*   OATH Trials Division: Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings, Administrative Tribunal, NYC Adjudication
*   Case: Legal Matter, Proceeding, Adjudication, Claim, Dispute
*   Filing Agency: City Agency, Sponsoring Agency, Initiating Department
*   Case Category: Case Type, Legal Area, Subject Matter
*   Case Resolution: Case Closure, Adjudication Outcome, Disposition

**Applications and Use Cases:**
*   Analyzing trends in administrative law cases handled by OATH.
*   Evaluating the efficiency and timeliness of case resolutions.
*   Identifying patterns in case types filed by different city agencies.
*   Researching specific types of administrative law matters (e.g., license violations, taxi and limousine disputes).
*   Assessing the impact of OATH decisions on city residents and businesses.
*   Using location data (where available) to map case distribution.

title: Special Initiatives Moveouts and Placements
ufd: This dataset provides information on shelter exits and community placements achieved through special initiatives. It focuses on the category "Special Initiatives Shelter Exits & Community Placements," excluding FHEPS A in Community. The data spans multiple fiscal years (FY15-FY20) and details various subsidy programs like DHS LINC, HRA LINC, CFEPS, NYCHA, and SECTION 8. Key columns include the 'year', 'subsidy_program', 'households' moved, and the number of 'individuals' impacted. This dataset can be used to analyze the effectiveness of different subsidy programs in facilitating successful transitions from shelters to community placements. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to understand trends in housing assistance and to evaluate the impact of specific programs on reducing homelessness. The dataset contains 100 rows.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details shelter exits and community placements achieved through special initiatives, excluding FHEPS A in Community. It covers fiscal years FY15-FY20 and includes data on subsidy programs like DHS LINC, HRA LINC, CFEPS, NYCHA, and SECTION 8. Key metrics include the number of households moved and individuals impacted by each program.

Related Topics:

title: Capital Projects Dashboard - Citywide Budget and Schedule
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed overview of New York City's capital infrastructure projects with committed budgets. It includes financial information and project schedules, linked by a unique Financial Management Service (FMS) ID. Key columns include the `managing_agency` responsible for the project, the `fms_project_name`, the `total_budget`, and `spend_to_date`. The `current_phase` column indicates the project's stage, while `borough` and `community_board` specify the project's location. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this dataset to track the progress of capital projects, analyze budget allocations, and understand infrastructure development across different boroughs and communities. The `reporting_period` indicates the month the data was reported. This information can be used to understand the financial status of projects over time.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on New York City's capital infrastructure projects with committed budgets, including financial details and project schedules. It provides details such as the managing agency, project name, total budget, spend to date, project phase, and location (borough and community board). The data is reported monthly, allowing for tracking of project financial status over time.

Related Topics:

title: Pedestrian Ramp Locations
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive inventory of pedestrian ramps throughout New York City, essential for ensuring accessibility for all pedestrians. Each record represents a specific ramp location, identified by a unique `cornerid` and `rampid`. The dataset includes the ramp's location using geographic coordinates in the `the_geom` column, the street it's located on (`ramp_onstr` and `stname1`), and the borough it resides in. The `geocyclora` column indicates the date of the Cyclomedia imagery used for data collection. Key measurements like `curb_reveal` and `ramp_running_slope_total` are included, along with a qualitative assessment of the ramp's condition (`dws_conditions`). This data can be used to analyze the distribution and condition of pedestrian ramps across the city, identify areas where accessibility improvements are needed, and assess compliance with ADA standards (though further review may be required for compliance determinations).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a detailed inventory of pedestrian ramps in New York City. It provides location information, physical characteristics, and condition assessments for each ramp. The data is useful for analyzing accessibility, identifying areas for improvement, and supporting urban planning initiatives.

Related Topics:
- Accessibility
- Urban Planning
- Transportation Infrastructure
- Pedestrian Safety
- ADA Compliance
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Pedestrian Ramp: Curb ramp, sidewalk ramp, accessible ramp
- Accessibility: Universal design, barrier-free access, mobility
- Curb Reveal: Curb height, exposed curb
- Ramp Running Slope: Ramp grade, incline, slope percentage
- DWS Conditions: Deficiencies, condition assessment, ramp quality

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identifying areas with inadequate pedestrian ramp coverage.
- Assessing the condition of existing ramps and prioritizing maintenance.
- Analyzing the distribution of ramps in relation to demographic data.
- Supporting urban planning and infrastructure development projects.
- Evaluating compliance with accessibility standards (requires further review).
- Creating maps and visualizations of pedestrian ramp locations and characteristics.

title: Directory Of Homebase Locations
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of Homebase (Homeless Prevention Network) office locations across New York City. It includes the name of the Homebase office, the address and phone number of the location, and the zip codes served by each office. The dataset also contains geographic information such as borough, latitude, longitude, community board, and council district. This information can be used to identify the Homebase office nearest to a particular location or to understand the geographic distribution of services. Users can leverage this dataset to connect individuals at risk of homelessness with the appropriate resources in their area. The dataset also includes identifiers like census tract, BIN, and BBL for more detailed analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a directory of Homebase office locations in New York City, which are part of the Homeless Prevention Network. It includes details such as office name, address, phone number, and the zip codes they serve. Geographic information like borough, latitude, longitude, community board, and council district are also provided to facilitate location-based analysis.

title: 2022 Green Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records for green taxis in 2022. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including details such as pickup and drop-off times (`lpep_pickup_datetime`, `lpep_dropoff_datetime`), pickup and drop-off locations identified by taxi zones (`pulocationid`, `dolocationid`), and the number of passengers (`passenger_count`). The dataset also provides information on fare amounts (`fare_amount`), tips (`tip_amount`), and total amount paid (`total_amount`).  The `vendorid` column identifies the Technology Service Provider. The `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip record was held in vehicle memory before transmission. This data could be used to analyze taxi ridership patterns, understand fare structures, or investigate the impact of location on trip costs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details individual green taxi trips in 2022, capturing key information about each ride. It includes pickup and drop-off timestamps and locations (using taxi zone IDs), passenger count, and financial details like fare, tip, and total amount. The data also identifies the Technology Service Provider (vendor ID) and whether the trip data was stored before transmission.

Related Topics:
- Taxi trips
- Green taxis
- Transportation network
- Fare analysis
- Ridership patterns
- Location analysis
- New York City (NYC) transportation

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Pickup location: `pulocationid`, origin, start point
- Drop-off location: `dolocationid`, destination, end point
- Trip time: `lpep_pickup_datetime`, `lpep_dropoff_datetime`, duration
- Fare amount: base fare, ride cost
- Tip amount: gratuity
- Total amount: total cost, final price
- Vendor ID: Technology Service Provider, `vendorid`
- Store and forward flag: `store_and_fwd_flag`, data storage indicator

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze spatial distribution of taxi trips.
- Predict taxi demand based on time and location.
- Investigate factors influencing taxi fares.
- Model taxi ridership patterns.
- Identify popular routes and destinations.
- Evaluate the impact of events on taxi usage.
- Compare the performance of different Technology Service Providers.

title: Open Data Coordinators (ODCs)
ufd: This dataset lists the Open Data Coordinators (ODCs) for various New York City government organizations. ODCs are the point people for datasets published by their organization, ensuring data dictionaries and user guides are up-to-date. The dataset includes the first name, last name, and organization name of each coordinator. Researchers, journalists, or anyone interested in understanding the open data landscape in NYC can use this dataset to identify contacts within specific city agencies. This allows for direct communication regarding data availability, quality, and documentation. The dataset contains 92 entries, providing a comprehensive list of ODCs across the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides a directory of Open Data Coordinators (ODCs) within New York City government organizations. It includes contact information (first name, last name) and the affiliated organization for each ODC. This resource is valuable for identifying key contacts within NYC agencies regarding open data initiatives.

- Understanding the organizational structure of open data initiatives within NYC government.
- Facilitating communication and collaboration between researchers, journalists, and city agencies.
- Analyzing the distribution of open data responsibilities across different city departments.

title: Water Consumption And Cost (2013 - May 2025)
ufd: This dataset provides monthly water consumption and cost information for various developments in New York City, spanning from 2013 to May 2025. It includes details such as the development name, borough, and account name, allowing users to analyze water usage patterns across different locations and property types. Key columns include 'tds' and 'edp', which likely represent water consumption metrics, and 'umis_bill_id', a unique identifier for each billing record. The data also specifies the funding source for these developments, which is consistently "FEDERAL" in this sample. Researchers, city planners, and property managers can use this dataset to understand water consumption trends, identify potential areas for conservation, and manage utility costs effectively. The dataset also contains meter information, vendor details (New York City Water Board), and service dates, offering a comprehensive view of water-related data for each development.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains monthly water consumption and cost data for New York City developments from 2013 to May 2025. It includes details on development name, borough, account information, water consumption metrics ('tds', 'edp'), and billing identifiers ('umis_bill_id'). The data allows for analysis of water usage patterns across different locations and property types.

  - Borough: NYC Borough, County (in NYC), Geographic Region
  - Account: Customer Account, Utility Account, Billing Account
  - TDS: Total Dissolved Solids (contextually, likely a water consumption metric)
  - EDP: (Likely a water consumption metric or related code)

title: DCAS Managed Building Energy Usage
ufd: This dataset provides energy usage information for city-managed buildings in New York City. It includes details such as the building's name, address, borough, and zip code, allowing users to pinpoint specific locations. The `fy15_energy_usage_mmbtu_utility_energy_excluding_fuel_oil` column indicates the energy consumption of each building in MMBtu (Million British Thermal Units), excluding fuel oil. Additional geographic information is provided through latitude, longitude, community board, council district, census tract, block, and lot. Researchers, city planners, and energy analysts can use this data to analyze energy consumption patterns across different buildings and boroughs, identify potential areas for energy efficiency improvements, and track the city's progress towards its sustainability goals. The dataset also includes building identification numbers (BIN and BBL) for linking to other city datasets.
sfd:

title: DOHMH Severe Maternal Morbidity
ufd: This dataset provides information on Severe Maternal Morbidity (SMM) in New York City, which refers to life-threatening complications during labor and delivery. The data is aggregated at the population level and includes the number and rate of SMM events. Key columns include 'year', 'race_ethnicity', 'education', 'borough', 'nativity', 'age', and 'insurance', allowing users to analyze SMM trends across different demographic groups and geographic areas. The dataset also includes information on pre-existing conditions like 'diabetes', 'hypertension', and 'heart_disease', as well as factors related to pregnancy and childbirth such as 'trimester', 'miscarriage', and 'parity'. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to identify disparities in maternal health outcomes, assess the impact of various risk factors, and develop targeted interventions to improve maternal health in NYC. The 'smm' and 'smm_rate' columns provide the aggregated number and rate of SMM events, respectively, serving as the primary outcome measures for analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains population-level data on Severe Maternal Morbidity (SMM) in New York City. It includes the number and rate of SMM events, broken down by various demographic and health-related factors. The data allows for analysis of SMM trends and disparities across different groups within NYC.

Related Topics:
- Maternal Health

- Epidemiology
- Women's Health
- Health Disparities
- Obstetrics
- Pregnancy Outcomes

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Severe Maternal Morbidity (SMM): Life-threatening complications during labor and delivery.

- Pregnancy Outcomes: Birth outcomes, maternal health during pregnancy.
- Risk Factors: Conditions or behaviors that increase the likelihood of SMM.
- Demographic Factors: Race/ethnicity, age, education, borough, nativity.
- Pre-existing Conditions: Diabetes, hypertension, heart disease.
- Parity: Number of previous births.

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identify disparities in SMM rates across different demographic groups in NYC.

- Evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at reducing SMM.
- Track trends in SMM rates over time.

title: Street Hail Livery (SHL) Taxi Initial Inspection Schedule
ufd: This dataset provides a schedule of initial inspections for Street Hail Livery (SHL) taxicabs. It includes information on scheduled inspection dates and times, as well as permit and base numbers. The `schedule_date` and `schedule_time` columns indicate when a taxi is scheduled for inspection. The `permit_number` uniquely identifies each taxi permit, while the `base_number` indicates the taxi base the vehicle is associated with. The dataset also tracks when the schedule information was last updated. This data could be used by taxi operators to plan for inspections or by the Taxi and Limousine Commission to monitor inspection schedules and resource allocation. Please note that the schedule is tentative and subject to change, and was last updated on November 20, 2025 at 18:02:05.190.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It provides permit and base numbers for identifying taxis and their associated bases. The data also includes the last updated timestamp for the schedule information.

title: Housing Database by 2024 City Council
ufd: This dataset provides a summary of housing unit changes in New York City Council Districts since 2010. It tracks the net change in housing units resulting from new construction, demolitions, and alterations. The data is aggregated from the NYC Department of City Planning's Housing Database, which is derived from Department of Buildings-approved housing construction and demolition jobs. Key columns include the council district (`councildst`) and the net change in housing units for each year from 2010 to 2017 (`comp2010` to `comp2017`). The `the_geom` column contains the geographic boundaries of each council district. This dataset can be used to analyze housing trends, assess the impact of development on housing stock, and inform planning decisions at the city council district level.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details housing unit changes within New York City Council Districts from 2010 to 2017. It captures the net change in housing units due to new construction, demolitions, and alterations, aggregated from NYC Department of City Planning data. The data includes geographic boundaries of each council district and annual net changes in housing units.

Related Topics:

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Housing Units: Residential units, dwellings, homes
- Council District: Political district, electoral district, ward
- Net Change: Increase/decrease, difference, gain/loss
- New Construction: Building permits, new development, construction projects
- Demolitions: Building removal, teardowns, razing
- Alterations: Renovations, modifications, building changes

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyzing housing trends in NYC Council Districts.
- Assessing the impact of development on housing stock.
- Informing urban planning and policy decisions.
- Visualizing housing changes geographically.
- Comparing housing growth across different council districts.
- Identifying areas with significant housing loss or gain.

title: Enrollment Capacity And Utilization Reports
ufd: This dataset provides enrollment, capacity, and utilization information for educational buildings and the schools within them. It includes details such as building ID (`bldg_id`), building name (`bldg_name`), and the geographic distance (`geo_dist`). Key metrics include building enrollment (`bldg_enroll`), target building capacity (`target_bldg_cap`), and target building utilization (`target_bldg_util`). The dataset also provides information about the organizations within each building, including their ID (`org_id`), name (`organization_name`), and enrollment (`org_enroll`). The `data_as_of` column indicates the date the data was collected. Researchers, policymakers, and educational administrators can use this data to analyze building utilization rates, understand enrollment patterns, and make informed decisions about resource allocation and capacity planning. The dataset contains 100 rows of data, with the data last updated on January 4, 2023.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains enrollment, capacity, and utilization data for educational buildings and the organizations within them. Key fields include building ID, name, enrollment, capacity, utilization, organization ID, and organization name. The data, comprising 100 rows, was last updated on January 4, 2023, and provides a snapshot of building and organizational metrics.

Related Topics:
- School facilities
- Educational administration
- Capacity planning
- Enrollment management
- Resource allocation
- Building utilization
- Geographic data analysis

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Building Enrollment: Student count, number of students enrolled
- Building Capacity: Target capacity, maximum occupancy, building size
- Building Utilization: Capacity utilization rate, occupancy rate, space usage
- Organization Enrollment: Program enrollment, department enrollment, student participation
- Educational Buildings: School buildings, learning facilities, academic institutions

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze building utilization rates to identify underutilized or overcrowded facilities.
- Understand enrollment patterns across different organizations within buildings.
- Inform resource allocation decisions based on capacity and enrollment data.
- Support capacity planning efforts to optimize building usage.
- Conduct geographic analysis to identify areas with high or low building utilization.

title: Congressional Districts
ufd: This dataset contains geographic boundaries and identifiers for US Congressional Districts within New York City. Each row represents a single congressional district. Key columns include `cong_dist`, which provides the district number, and `the_geom`, which contains the spatial geometry defining the district's boundaries. Additionally, `shape_leng` and `shape_area` provide the length of the district's perimeter and the area it covers, respectively. This data could be used for mapping congressional districts, analyzing demographic or socioeconomic data by district, or studying the geographic characteristics of political representation in New York City. The dataset is updated periodically and previous versions are available online.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset delineates the geographic boundaries of US Congressional Districts within New York City. It includes the district number, spatial geometry, perimeter length, and area for each district. This information is valuable for understanding political representation and geographic characteristics within New York City.

**Related Topics:**
- Political Science
- Geography
- New York City
- Government
- Demographics
- Elections
- Spatial Analysis

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Congressional Districts: Electoral districts, legislative districts, constituencies
- Geographic Boundaries: Spatial data, polygons, shapefiles, geometry
- New York City: NYC, The City of New York
- Political Representation: Electoral representation, district mapping
- Shape Area: Area, district size
- Shape Length: Perimeter, district boundary length

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Mapping congressional districts in New York City.
- Analyzing demographic data by congressional district.
- Studying the geographic characteristics of political representation.
- Visualizing election results by district.
- Combining with socioeconomic data to understand district-level trends.

title: NYC Greenhouse Gas Emissions Municipal Inventory
ufd: This dataset provides an inventory of New York City's greenhouse gas emissions, tracking the city's progress in reducing them. It includes data on emissions from various main sectors like electricity, fuel oils, and biodiesel, categorized by source and source category such as buildings, wastewater treatment, and transportation. The dataset provides the amount of energy consumed, total carbon dioxide equivalent (tco2e), and source MMBTU (millions of British thermal units) for each category. These values are recorded for each fiscal year from 2006 to 2017. The units of measurement include liters, kilowatt-hours (kWh), kilograms (kg), metric tons (MT), and gigajoules (GJ). Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze emission trends, identify major sources of greenhouse gases, and evaluate the effectiveness of emission reduction strategies in NYC.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains New York City's greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions inventory from fiscal years 2006 to 2017. It details emissions data across various sectors like electricity, fuel oils, and transportation, broken down by source and source category. The data includes energy consumption, total carbon dioxide equivalent (tco2e), and source MMBTU, allowing for analysis of emission trends and sources.

Related Topics:
- Climate Change
- Environmental Science
- Urban Planning
- Energy Consumption
- Sustainability
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Greenhouse Gas (GHG) Emissions: Carbon footprint, atmospheric pollutants, environmental impact
- Carbon Dioxide Equivalent (tco2e): CO2e, global warming potential (GWP)
- MMBTU (Millions of British Thermal Units): Energy units, heat content, fuel consumption
- Fiscal Year: Financial year, reporting period
- Energy Consumption: Fuel usage, power consumption, energy demand
- Source Category: Emission source, sector, industry

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in NYC's greenhouse gas emissions over time.
- Identify the largest sources of GHG emissions in New York City.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of emission reduction policies and initiatives.
- Compare NYC's emissions performance to other cities or regions.
- Develop predictive models for future GHG emissions based on historical data.
- Support research on the environmental impact of urban activities.
- Inform policy decisions related to climate change mitigation and adaptation.

title: Parks Special Events
ufd: This dataset provides details on special events hosted by NYC Parks, including one-time fitness activities, sports, dances, movies, and concerts. The data includes the unit or organization hosting the event, potential partner organizations, the date and time of the event, and the borough where it took place. You can also find the specific location and type of venue, along with the event name, type, and category. Attendance figures are provided, along with the target audience and a classification of the event. This dataset can be used to analyze the types of events offered in different boroughs, track event attendance, and understand the range of recreational activities provided by NYC Parks.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on special events organized by NYC Parks, encompassing a variety of recreational activities. It details event specifics such as date, time, location (borough and venue type), host organization, and collaborating partners. The dataset also includes event characteristics like name, type, category, target audience, attendance numbers, and event classifications.

Related Topics:
- Parks and Recreation
- New York City
- Event Planning
- Public Events
- Community Activities
- Outdoor Activities

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Special Events: Programs, Activities, Gatherings, Occasions
- NYC Parks: New York City Department of Parks and Recreation, Parks Department
- Recreation: Leisure, Entertainment, Amusement, Fun
- Attendance: Participation, Number of attendees, Headcount
- Borough: District, County (in the context of NYC)
- Venue: Location, Place, Site

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the distribution of event types across different NYC boroughs.
- Track attendance trends for various recreational activities.
- Identify popular event categories and target audiences.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of partnerships between NYC Parks and other organizations.
- Plan and promote future recreational events based on historical data.

title: DSNY Disposal Sites Used by Facilities by Year
ufd: This dataset provides details on the disposal sites used by facilities that handle waste collected by the NYC Department of Sanitation (DSNY). It includes information from 2018 to 2020. Key columns include the facility name, the name and type of disposal site used (e.g., Landfill or Waste-to-Energy), the amount of waste (in tons) disposed of daily, and the distance between the facility and the disposal site. The dataset also specifies the mode of transportation used to carry the waste, whether by truck or rail. A disposal site ID is also provided. This data can be used to analyze waste disposal patterns, transportation logistics, and the environmental impact of waste management in NYC.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on waste disposal sites used by NYC Department of Sanitation (DSNY) facilities from 2018-2020. It details the facility, disposal site name and type, daily waste tonnage, distance between facility and site, and transportation mode (truck or rail). A disposal site ID is also included for tracking purposes.

Related Topics:
  - Waste Management
  - Sanitation Logistics
  - Environmental Impact
  - New York City Government
  - Transportation
  - Data Analysis

Concepts and Synonyms:
  - Waste Disposal: Garbage Disposal, Refuse Disposal, Trash Disposal
  - Disposal Site: Landfill, Waste-to-Energy Facility, Transfer Station
  - DSNY: Department of Sanitation, NYC Sanitation
  - Waste Tonnage: Waste Volume, Amount of Waste, Weight of Waste
  - Transportation Mode: Truck, Rail, Method of Transport
  - Facility: Sanitation Facility, Waste Handling Facility

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Analyze waste disposal patterns across NYC.
  - Optimize waste transportation logistics.
  - Assess the environmental impact of different disposal sites.
  - Track waste tonnage processed at each disposal site.
  - Identify potential inefficiencies in the waste management system.
  - Visualize the relationship between facility location and disposal site distance.

title: 2005 - 2020 Quality Review Ratings
ufd: This dataset contains yearly quality review ratings for schools from 2005 to 2020. It allows users to review historical ratings for schools and compare them across time. The dataset includes information for schools that received a Quality Review during the specified school year, including both current and closed schools. Key columns include 'school_year', indicating the academic year of the review, 'start_date', representing the date the review started, and 'overall_rating', which provides the overall quality rating. Several 'indicator' columns offer more granular insights into specific areas of evaluation. Note that the Quality Review rating scale may vary across different years, so be sure to consult the column information for detailed explanations. This data can be used to understand trends in school performance and identify areas for improvement.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides yearly quality review ratings for schools spanning from 2005 to 2020. It includes overall ratings and indicator scores for schools that underwent a Quality Review, encompassing both active and closed institutions. The data allows for tracking school performance over time and identifying areas of strength and weakness.

Related Topics:
- School performance
- Educational assessment
- School quality
- Academic evaluation
- Education statistics

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Quality Review: School evaluation, performance assessment, academic audit
- Overall Rating: Performance grade, quality score, evaluation outcome
- School Year: Academic year, reporting period, year of review
- Indicator: Metric, measure, evaluation criteria
- School Performance: Academic achievement, educational quality, learning outcomes

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in school quality ratings over time.
- Compare school performance across different years and locations.
- Identify factors that contribute to high or low quality ratings.
- Track the impact of educational interventions on school performance.
- Develop predictive models for school quality based on indicator scores.

title: Deed Restriction Database
ufd: This dataset, titled "Deed Restriction Database," provides a searchable record of real properties with deed restrictions imposed by the Department of Citywide Administrative Services (DCAS) in New York City, pursuant to Local Law 176 of 2016. The data spans from 1966 to the present, including active requests. Key columns include `boro` and `boro_description` which specify the borough, `block` and `lot` which are unique identifiers for properties, and `community_board_district` and `council_district` which indicate the administrative and political districts the property falls within. The `property_disposed_to_entity` column details the entity to which the property was transferred, along with address information broken down into house number, street name, city, state, and zip code. Researchers, real estate professionals, and city planners can use this dataset to understand land use restrictions, track property transfers, and analyze development patterns in Manhattan. The `restriction` column contains the full text of the deed restriction. Please note the disclaimer provided by DCAS regarding the accuracy and use of this data.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The Deed Restriction Database contains records of properties in New York City with deed restrictions imposed by the Department of Citywide Administrative Services (DCAS) under Local Law 176 of 2016. Spanning from 1966 to the present, the dataset includes details on property identifiers (borough, block, lot), administrative districts, and the entity to which the property was transferred. The full text of the deed restriction is also provided.

Related Topics:
- Real Estate
- Land Use Planning
- New York City Government
- Property Records
- Legal Restrictions
- Urban Development

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Deed Restriction: Covenant, encumbrance, limitation, property restriction
- DCAS: Department of Citywide Administrative Services, NYC government agency
- Borough: County, NYC borough (Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island)
- Block and Lot: Property identifier, tax lot, parcel number
- Local Law 176: NYC legislation, city law, LL176
- Property Transfer: Conveyance, sale, disposal, assignment

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyzing land use restrictions and their impact on property development.
- Tracking property transfers and identifying trends in real estate ownership.
- Identifying properties subject to specific deed restrictions based on location or restriction type.
- Researching the history of land use regulations in New York City.
- Supporting urban planning initiatives and policy development.

title: Cool It! NYC 2020 - Drinking Fountains
ufd: This dataset contains information about drinking fountains in New York City, collected as part of the Cool It! NYC initiative to increase cooling features during heat emergencies. Each row represents a specific drinking fountain and includes details about its status (`df_activated`), such as whether it's activated, broken, or under construction. The dataset also specifies the `fountaintype`, indicating the model or style of the fountain, and `fountaincount`, representing the number of fountains at that location. Additional details include whether a filter is installed (`filter_installed`), the fountain's `position` (e.g., "Under Tree, In Playground"), and whether it's located outdoors. Researchers and city planners can use this data to assess the availability and condition of public drinking fountains, identify areas needing improvement, and optimize resource allocation for maintenance and new installations. The `propertyname` and `gispropnum` columns can be used to link the fountains to specific parks and locations within the city's geographic information system.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed information on drinking fountains across New York City, gathered as part of the Cool It! NYC initiative. It includes the status of each fountain (activated, broken, etc.), fountain type, number of fountains at a location, filter installation status, position, and outdoor location. The dataset also provides property names and GIS property numbers for linking to park locations.

Related Topics:
- Public Health
- Urban Planning
- Water Access
- Infrastructure
- New York City
- Heat Mitigation

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Drinking Fountain: Water fountain, bubbler, public water source
- Status: Condition, operational status, df_activated (column name)
- Fountain Type: Model, style, design
- Location: Position, placement, site, gispropnum (column name)
- Filter: Water filter, purification system, filter_installed (column name)

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the distribution and availability of drinking fountains in NYC.
- Identify areas with a high need for additional or improved drinking fountains.
- Assess the maintenance status of existing fountains and prioritize repairs.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of the Cool It! NYC initiative.
- Link drinking fountain locations to demographic data to assess equitable access.
- Integrate with GIS data to visualize fountain locations and related park information.

title: 311 Resolution Satisfaction Survey
ufd: This dataset contains feedback from New York City residents and visitors regarding their satisfaction with how city agencies resolved 311 service requests. Each entry represents a survey response, capturing details about the original service request and the respondent's overall satisfaction. Key columns include `agency` and `agency_name`, indicating the specific city department responsible for addressing the issue, such as the Department of Parks and Recreation (DPR) or the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene (DOHMH). The `complaint_type` and `descriptor` columns provide specifics on the nature of the service request, ranging from "New Tree Request" to "Smoking Violation" or "Food Contains Foreign Object". The `resolution_description` offers insights into how the agency addressed the complaint. Location is captured at the borough level in the `borough` column. Finally, the `overall_satisfaction` column reveals the respondent's level of satisfaction with the resolution. This dataset can be used to analyze public sentiment towards city services, identify areas for improvement in service delivery, and track the effectiveness of different agencies in resolving common issues.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains survey responses from New York City residents and visitors regarding their satisfaction with the resolution of 311 service requests by city agencies. It includes details about the agency involved, the type of complaint, how the complaint was resolved, and the respondent's overall satisfaction level. The data can be used to analyze public sentiment towards city services and identify areas for improvement.

Related Topics:
- City Services
- Public Satisfaction
- 311 Data
- Urban Planning
- Government Performance
- Customer Feedback
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- 311 Service Requests: Citizen requests, non-emergency requests, service inquiries
- Agency: City department, government organization, bureau
- Complaint Type: Issue, problem, service request category
- Overall Satisfaction: Customer satisfaction, feedback score, satisfaction rating
- Resolution Description: Action taken, outcome, how the issue was addressed

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze public satisfaction with different city agencies.
- Identify trends in complaint types and resolution effectiveness.
- Compare satisfaction levels across different boroughs.
- Predict overall satisfaction based on complaint type and agency response.
- Improve the efficiency and effectiveness of city services.
- Track the impact of policy changes on public satisfaction.

title: 2014 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records from yellow taxis in 2014. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including pickup and dropoff times, locations, trip distance, and passenger count. The data also includes fare details such as fare amount, MTA tax, tip amount, and tolls, providing a comprehensive view of the trip cost. Key columns include `pickup_datetime` and `dropoff_datetime` for temporal analysis, `trip_distance` for distance-based calculations, and `passenger_count` to understand ridership. The `vendor_id` indicates the Technology Service Provider. Researchers and analysts can use this dataset to analyze taxi usage patterns, understand fare structures, or build predictive models for trip demand. The `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip record was held in vehicle memory before sending to the vendor.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed trip information for yellow taxis in 2014. It includes pickup and dropoff timestamps, locations, trip distance, passenger count, and fare details. The data offers a comprehensive view of individual taxi trips, enabling analysis of taxi usage patterns and fare structures.

Related Topics:
- Taxi trips
- Transportation
- Fare analysis
- Ridership patterns
- Geographic data
- Time series analysis

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Yellow taxi: Taxi cab, cab, for-hire vehicle
- Trip distance: Travel distance, mileage
- Fare amount: Trip cost, price
- Pickup datetime: Trip start time, origin time
- Dropoff datetime: Trip end time, destination time
- Passenger count: Number of riders, occupancy

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze taxi usage patterns over time.
- Predict taxi demand based on time and location.
- Study the impact of events on taxi ridership.
- Develop fare prediction models.
- Analyze the relationship between trip distance and fare.
- Identify popular pickup and dropoff locations.

title: Street Construction Permits - Stipulations (2020-Present)
ufd: This dataset contains stipulations, or rules, associated with street construction permits issued by DOT in New York City from 2020 to the present. Each row represents a specific stipulation applied to a permit. The key columns include `permitnumber`, which uniquely identifies the permit, `stipulationid`, which is the ID of the stipulation, and `stipulationfulltext`, which provides the complete text of the stipulation. The `createdon` column indicates when the stipulation was created. This dataset can be used to understand the various rules and regulations governing street construction activities, analyze the frequency of specific stipulations, or examine the relationship between permits and their associated requirements. Researchers, city planners, or construction companies could use this data to gain insights into permit compliance and urban development regulations.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the stipulations (rules) attached to street construction permits issued by the NYC DOT from 2020 to the present. Each record represents a specific stipulation linked to a permit, identified by `permitnumber`. Key information includes the `stipulationid`, the full stipulation text (`stipulationfulltext`), and the creation date (`createdon`).

Related Topics:
- Street construction
- NYC Department of Transportation (DOT)
- Permits and regulations
- Urban planning
- Infrastructure management

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Stipulation: Rule, condition, requirement, provision
- Permitnumber: Permit ID, application number
- Stipulationfulltext: Stipulation description, rule text
- Createdon: Date created, issue date
- Street construction: Road work, infrastructure development, excavation

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the frequency and types of stipulations applied to street construction permits.
- Identify common rules and regulations governing street construction in NYC.
- Examine the relationship between specific permits and their associated stipulations.
- Track changes in permit stipulations over time.
- Develop tools for permit compliance and management.

title: Bi-Annual Pedestrian Counts
ufd: This dataset contains bi-annual pedestrian counts collected by the New York City Department of Transportation. It tracks pedestrian volumes at over 100 locations across the city, including retail corridors and bridges, during May and September. The data includes the location of the count (the_geom, borough, street_nam, from_stree, to_street), along with pedestrian counts for morning (am), afternoon (pm), and midday (md) periods. The 'iex' column likely indicates whether a particular location is included in the Pedestrian Volume Index. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze pedestrian traffic patterns, identify areas with high pedestrian volume, and assess the impact of urban development on pedestrian activity. The dataset provides valuable insights into the long-term trends of neighborhood commercial corridors.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides bi-annual pedestrian counts collected by the New York City Department of Transportation (NYCDOT). It includes pedestrian volumes at over 100 locations in NYC, recorded during May and September. The data specifies location details and pedestrian counts for morning, afternoon, and midday periods, enabling analysis of pedestrian traffic patterns.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- Transportation Planning
- Pedestrian Safety
- City Development
- Traffic Analysis
- Commercial Activity
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Pedestrian Count: Foot traffic, pedestrian volume, walker count
- Location: the_geom, borough, street_nam, from_stree, to_street, intersection
- Time of Day: am (morning), pm (afternoon), md (midday)
- NYCDOT: New York City Department of Transportation
- Pedestrian Volume Index: IEX

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze pedestrian traffic patterns in NYC.
- Identify high-volume pedestrian areas.
- Assess the impact of urban development on pedestrian activity.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of pedestrian safety measures.
- Monitor long-term trends in neighborhood commercial corridors.
- Inform transportation planning and infrastructure development.
- Predict pedestrian flow based on location and time of day.

title: 2018 Central Park Squirrel Census - Stories
ufd: This dataset contains stories and observations collected during the 2018 Central Park Squirrel Census. Each row represents a story or note recorded by a "Squirrel Sighter" in a specific hectare of the park, during either the AM or PM shift on a particular date. The core of the dataset is the `note_squirrel_park_stories` column, which provides a textual description of the observations. Accompanying this are several columns indicating the presence of specific themes within each story, such as `story_topic_squirrel` (related to squirrels), `story_topic_park_experience` (general park observations), and `story_topic_other_animals`. Researchers and urban ecologists can use this dataset to analyze squirrel behavior, human-wildlife interactions in urban environments, and overall park ecology. The tagged story themes allow for focused analysis on specific aspects of the observations.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset comprises textual observations and stories gathered during the 2018 Central Park Squirrel Census. Each entry represents a record from a specific park hectare, date, and time (AM/PM shift), including a textual description of observations (`note_squirrel_park_stories`). The dataset also includes thematic tags indicating the presence of topics like squirrels, park experiences, and other animals within each story.

Related Topics:
- Urban Ecology
- Wildlife Observation
- Human-Wildlife Interaction
- Natural Language Processing
- Text Analysis
- Park Management
- Animal Behavior

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Squirrel Census: Squirrel Survey, Rodent Count, Wildlife Inventory
- Park Stories: Field Notes, Observations, Anecdotes, Narratives
- Squirrel Behavior: Animal Actions, Rodent Activity, Squirrel Habits
- Urban Environment: City Park, Metropolitan Habitat, Urban Ecosystem
- Thematic Analysis: Topic Modeling, Content Analysis, Tagging

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze squirrel behavior patterns in an urban environment.
- Study human-wildlife interactions based on park visitor observations.
- Develop natural language processing models to extract insights from textual field notes.
- Identify trends in park usage and visitor experiences.
- Assess the impact of urban environments on wildlife populations.

title: BIC Issued Violations
ufd: This dataset contains information on violations issued by the New York City Business Integrity Commission (BIC) to companies operating in the trade waste industry. The data includes details on both licensed and unlicensed companies. Each record represents a single violation adjudicated by the Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings (OATH). Key columns include the violation number, the name of the company or account, the type of violation (always "OATH" in this dataset), the violation's current disposition (e.g., "Settled," "Default - Granted"), and the account type (e.g., "Unlicensed," "License"). The dataset also provides the address, city, state, and postcode of the violating account, as well as the borough where the violation occurred. Researchers and industry analysts can use this data to understand violation patterns, assess compliance within the trade waste industry, and analyze the outcomes of violation cases. The dataset is updated quarterly.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details violations issued by the NYC Business Integrity Commission (BIC) to companies in the trade waste industry, covering both licensed and unlicensed entities. Each record represents a violation adjudicated by OATH, including details on the company, violation type, disposition, and location. Updated quarterly, this dataset provides insights into compliance and violation patterns within the industry.

Related Topics:
- Business Integrity

- Regulatory Compliance
- New York City Government
- Licensing and Permitting
- Administrative Hearings

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Violation: Infraction, Offense, Transgression

- Trade Waste: Commercial Waste, Refuse, Garbage
- Disposition: Outcome, Resolution, Status
- OATH: Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings
- Unlicensed: Illegal Operation, Non-Compliant

Applications and Use Cases:

- Assess the effectiveness of BIC enforcement actions.
- Identify companies with repeated violations.
- Map the geographic distribution of violations.
- Predict future violations based on historical data.
- Evaluate the impact of licensing on compliance.

title: Designated and Calendared Buildings and Sites
ufd: This dataset contains information about properties in New York City that have been designated as landmarks or are under consideration for designation by the Landmarks Preservation Commission (LPC). Each row represents a specific landmark or a property within a historic district. Key columns include `lm_name` which provides the name of the landmark, `boroughid` indicating the borough in which the landmark is located, and `the_geom` which gives the geographic coordinates of the landmark. The `lp_number` column provides a unique identifier assigned by the LPC. You can use this dataset to explore the distribution of landmarks across the city, identify specific landmarks in a given area, or research the history and designation status of individual properties. It could be used by urban planners, historians, or anyone interested in the preservation of historical sites in New York City. The dataset also includes `public_hea` which represents the dates of public hearings related to the landmark.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details designated landmarks and properties under consideration for landmark status by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission (LPC). It includes information such as landmark name, borough, geographic coordinates, LPC identification number, and public hearing dates. The data allows for analysis of landmark distribution, identification of specific landmarks, and research into their designation status.

Related Topics:
  - Historic Preservation
  - Urban Planning
  - New York City History
  - Architectural History
  - Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Concepts and Synonyms:
  - Landmarks: Historic sites, protected buildings, historical landmarks, heritage sites
  - LPC (Landmarks Preservation Commission): Historic preservation agency, city planning commission
  - Borough: NYC borough (Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island)
  - Designation: Landmark status, protected status, historic designation
  - Historic District: Preservation district, heritage area

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Mapping and visualizing the distribution of landmarks across New York City.
  - Identifying landmarks within a specific borough or neighborhood.
  - Researching the history and designation process of individual landmarks.
  - Analyzing the dates of public hearings related to landmark designation.
  - Integrating landmark data with other datasets, such as property values or demographic information.

title: Multi Agency Response to Community Hotspot (MARCH) Inspections
ufd: This dataset contains information about multi-agency inspections of nightlife establishments in New York City, conducted as part of the Multi Agency Response to Community Hotspot (MARCH) program. The data includes details such as the location ID, zip code, borough, and council district where the establishment is located. Each record also specifies the date and time of the inspection, the duration of the inspection in minutes, and the number of inspectors present from various city agencies, including the NYPD, DEP, DOB, DOHMH and FDNY. Furthermore, the dataset tracks whether the inspection resulted in the closure of the establishment. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze inspection patterns, resource allocation, and the impact of nightlife establishments on public safety across different neighborhoods. The dataset also includes information on specific complaints or conduct observed during the inspections, as well as the number of summonses issued.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details multi-agency inspections of nightlife establishments in New York City conducted under the MARCH program. It includes location information, inspection dates/times, inspection duration, and the number of inspectors from various city agencies (NYPD, DEP, DOB, DOHMH, FDNY). The data also indicates if the inspection led to a closure and records complaints, conduct observed, and summonses issued.

Related Topics:
- Public Safety
- Nightlife Regulation

- Assess the impact of nightlife on neighborhood quality of life.

title: Participatory Budgeting Project Tracker
ufd: This dataset tracks the progress and funding of projects selected through participatory budgeting in a city government. It includes information on projects funded between 2012 and 2014, spanning fiscal years FY13 to FY15. Key details include the district where the project is located, the project description, the ballot price, subproject cost, and total appropriated funds. The data also identifies the implementing agency and whether a non-city entity is involved. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze funding allocations across different districts, assess the types of projects being prioritized, and evaluate the role of different agencies in project implementation. The 'number_of_subprojects' column can be used to understand the scale and complexity of each project.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed information on participatory budgeting projects funded by a city government between 2012 and 2014 (FY13-FY15). It includes project descriptions, locations (district), budget details (ballot price, subproject cost, total appropriated funds), and implementing agencies. The data allows for analysis of funding allocation, project prioritization, and agency involvement in city projects.

Related Topics:
  - Participatory Budgeting
  - Municipal Finance
  - Urban Planning
  - Government Transparency
  - Public Works Projects
  - Community Development

Concepts and Synonyms:
  - Participatory Budgeting: PB, community budgeting, citizen-led budgeting
  - Appropriated Funds: budget allocation, funding, financial resources
  - Implementing Agency: responsible agency, managing department, executing organization
  - District: neighborhood, ward, electoral district
  - Ballot Price: estimated cost, project price, proposed budget

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Analyze funding distribution across different city districts.
  - Evaluate the types of projects prioritized through participatory budgeting.
  - Assess the efficiency of different implementing agencies.
  - Track the progress of individual projects over time.
  - Identify trends in community needs and priorities based on project selection.
  - Compare the actual cost of projects to their initial ballot price.
  - Determine the impact of non-city entities on project implementation.

title: 311 Service Requests for 2009
ufd: This dataset contains 311 service requests from 2009. It provides a historical record of requests made to various New York City agencies. Key columns include `created_date` and `closed_date`, indicating when the request was submitted and resolved, `agency` and `agency_name` specifying the responsible department, `complaint_type` and `descriptor` detailing the issue reported, and `status` reflecting the current state of the request. While location information like `incident_zip` and `city` are available, they have a high percentage of missing values. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze trends in service requests, identify areas with frequent issues, and evaluate the responsiveness of different agencies. The data can also be used to understand the types of problems reported by citizens and improve resource allocation for city services.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains 311 service requests submitted to New York City agencies in 2009. It includes details about the request's creation and resolution dates, the responsible agency, the type of complaint, and its current status. Location information is included, though with a significant amount of missing data.

Related Topics:

- Complaint Type: Issue, problem, service category
- Status: Resolution, current state, open/closed
- Incident Location: Address, zip code, borough

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in service requests over time.
- Identify areas with high volumes of specific complaints.
- Evaluate agency responsiveness and efficiency.
- Improve resource allocation for city services.
- Understand the types of problems reported by citizens.

title: Inmate Incidents - Slashing and Stabbing
ufd: This dataset provides information on violent inmate-on-inmate incidents, specifically slashings and stabbings. Each row represents a single incident. The key columns include `incident_id`, a unique identifier for each incident, `reported_dt`, the date and time the incident was reported, and `incident_type`, which specifies whether the incident was a slashing or stabbing. The `facility` column indicates the location where the incident occurred, though this information is sparsely populated. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in inmate violence, identify high-risk facilities, or develop strategies for preventing future incidents. Note that the dataset contains only 100 rows.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details violent inmate-on-inmate incidents involving slashings and stabbings. Each record represents a single incident, identified by a unique ID and timestamped with the reporting date and time. The data includes the type of incident (slashing or stabbing) and, where available, the facility where it occurred.

title: Property Data (Buildings Information System)
ufd: This dataset contains information about building permits, including permit numbers, application details, permit types and subtypes, status descriptions, and relevant dates. Key columns include `permit_bin`, `permit_application_job_number`, `permit_type`, `permit_status_description`, `permit_issuance_date`, and `permit_experation_date`. The dataset provides a historical record of issued permits and their expiration dates. Although the description indicates that the dataset does not accurately reflect its title and original intent, and that improvements are in progress, it could potentially be used to analyze trends in permit issuance, track permit status, or examine the distribution of different permit types. Please note the warning in the dataset description before using this data.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details building permits, encompassing permit numbers, application specifics, permit types, status updates, and critical dates like issuance and expiration. It offers a historical view of issued permits and their lifecycles. Despite acknowledged data quality issues and deviations from its intended purpose, the dataset holds potential for analyzing permit trends and tracking permit status.

Related Topics:

- Issuance Date: Permit Start Date, Approval Date

Applications and Use Cases:

title: 2014 - 2015 DOE High School Directory
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of New York City high schools for the 2014-2015 school year. It includes information such as the school name, borough, building code, contact phone and fax numbers, and the minimum and maximum grade levels served. The dataset also contains information about transportation options, including bus and subway lines that serve the school. Key columns include 'school_name', 'boro' (borough), 'grade_span_min', and 'grade_span_max'. Researchers, parents, and students can use this dataset to find high schools in specific boroughs, identify schools that serve particular grade levels, and determine transportation options to and from the schools. The 'building_code' can be used to uniquely identify the school building, while address information allows for mapping and spatial analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a directory of New York City high schools for the 2014-2015 school year. It provides key information about each school, including its name, borough, grade levels served, contact information, and transportation options. This data can be used to analyze school locations, accessibility, and grade level offerings within the NYC public school system.

- Researching school characteristics and demographics.

title: Associated Address by Borough and Community District
ufd: This dataset provides a breakdown of social service cases and the number of individuals involved, categorized by borough and community district within New York City. The data includes the `report_date`, `borough` (e.g., Manhattan, Brooklyn), `community_district` (a numerical identifier), `case_type` (currently only "All Case Types"), the number of `cases`, and the number of `individuals` associated with those cases. The dataset allows users to explore the distribution of social service needs across different geographic areas of NYC. It can be used to identify areas with high demand for services, track changes in case numbers over time (though only two months are present), and potentially inform resource allocation decisions. Note that some community district values are missing. This dataset contains information from August and September 2025.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details social service cases and the individuals they impact within New York City, broken down by borough and community district. It includes the number of cases and individuals for "All Case Types" for August and September 2025. The data allows for analysis of social service distribution across NYC's geographic areas.

title: DOF Condominium Comparable Rental Income in NYC
ufd: This dataset contains information on condominium comparable rental income in NYC, as assessed by the Department of Finance (DOF) from 2012 to 2018. The DOF uses this data to value condominiums and cooperatives as if they were rental apartment buildings, based on similar properties in terms of physical features and location. Key columns include `boro_block_lot` and `address` to identify specific properties, `neighborhood` for location context, and `building_classification` to categorize building types. Financial details such as `estimated_gross_income`, `estimated_expense`, and `net_operating_income` are provided, along with property characteristics like `total_units`, `year_built`, and `gross_sqft`. Researchers, real estate professionals, and city planners can use this dataset to analyze property values, rental income trends, and financial performance of condominiums across different neighborhoods in New York City. The data can also be used to understand the DOF's valuation methods and compare them against market values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides comparable rental income data for condominiums in New York City, collected by the Department of Finance (DOF) from 2012 to 2018. It includes financial details, property characteristics, and location information for individual condominium properties. The data is used by the DOF to assess property values based on rental income potential.

Related Topics:

title: Wi-Fi in Public Space (Open Space)
ufd: This dataset provides information on Wi-Fi access points in public open spaces across New York City. It includes details such as the name of the open space (e.g., "Crotona Park," "Abe Stark Skating Rink"), the borough and neighborhood where it's located, and the Wi-Fi provider (e.g., ALTICEUSA, SPECTRUM). The dataset also specifies the number of access points available at each location, along with the SSID (network name) for connecting. Location is further specified with latitude and longitude coordinates. This data could be used to analyze Wi-Fi availability in different neighborhoods, identify areas with limited access, or compare services offered by different providers. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this information to understand and improve public Wi-Fi infrastructure.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations of public Wi-Fi access points in open spaces throughout New York City. It includes information on the open space name, borough, neighborhood, Wi-Fi provider, number of access points, SSID, and geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude). The data allows for analysis of Wi-Fi availability across different areas of the city.

Applications and Use Cases:

title: Children's Play Areas (CPAs)
ufd: This dataset provides information on Children's Play Areas (CPAs) managed by NYC Parks. Each record represents a specific play area, identified by its `gispropnum` and `omppropid`. The `name` and `propname` columns offer the common name of the play area and the park it resides in, respectively. Location is specified using a `point` column, containing coordinates. Additional columns such as `@computed_region_efsh_h5xi`, `@computed_region_f5dn_yrer`, `@computed_region_yeji_bk3q`, `@computed_region_92fq_4b7q`, and `@computed_region_sbqj_enih` provide computed region identifiers for spatial analysis. This dataset can be used to locate playgrounds, analyze their distribution across different regions of New York City, or integrate with other datasets for a comprehensive view of recreational resources. The `system` column may be useful for internal park system tracking. Note that the dataset was updated in 2024 with a new schema and methodology.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset catalogs Children's Play Areas (CPAs) managed by NYC Parks, providing location and identification details for each play area. Key information includes the play area's name, the park it's located in, and geographic coordinates. The dataset also includes computed region identifiers for spatial analysis and integration with other datasets.

title: Individual Landmark and Historic District Building Database
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive inventory of buildings and structures located within designated historic districts and individual landmark sites. It includes spatial information (`the_geom`) representing the building's location, along with identifiers like Building Identification Number (`bin`) and Borough-Block-Lot (`bbl`). The dataset also specifies the borough, block, and lot for each building. Key attributes include the building's address (`des_addres`) and the approximate construction date (`circa`, `date_low`, `date_high`). Researchers, urban planners, and historians can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of historic buildings, study architectural trends over time, or assess the impact of historic district designations on property values. The data can also be used to create interactive maps and visualizations of historic landmarks.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset inventories buildings and structures within historic districts and landmark sites, providing spatial locations and key identifiers. title: MUSEUM
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of museums located throughout New York City. Each row represents a unique museum and includes its name, address (address1, address2, city, zip), phone number (tel), and website URL. The geographic location of each museum is stored in the `the_geom` column. This dataset could be used to find museums in a specific area of New York City, plan a museum tour, or gather contact information for research or outreach purposes. Researchers could use this data to analyze the distribution of cultural institutions across the city. The dataset contains 100 rows and covers museums in all five boroughs.
sfd:

title: Business Improvement District (BID) Trends Report (FY24)
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive overview of Business Improvement Districts (BIDs) in New York City, offering insights into their operations and impact. Each row represents a specific BID, identified by its name and borough. Key columns include `service_area_linear_feet`, indicating the size of the area the BID covers, and staffing information such as `full_time_staff`, `sanitation_workers_employed`, and `public_safety_officers`. The dataset also tracks the number of `individual_businesses`, `occupied_storefronts`, and `vacant_storefronts` within each BID, providing a snapshot of the local business environment. Additional details cover whether the BID provides supplemental services and the type of sanitation services offered. Researchers, policymakers, and business owners can use this data to analyze the effectiveness of BIDs, understand the economic conditions of different neighborhoods, and inform decisions related to urban development and resource allocation. The data allows for comparisons between BIDs and can help identify trends in business activity and public services across the city.
sfd:

title: Moving Violation B Summons (Historic)
ufd: This dataset contains information on moving violation summonses issued by the NYPD in New York City. Each record represents a single summons and includes details such as the violation date and time, the law code violated (e.g., VTL for Vehicle and Traffic Law, or NYCTRR), and the specific violation code. The dataset also specifies the vehicle category involved (e.g., CAR/SUV, MCL for motorcycle), the city where the violation occurred, and the NYPD command responsible for the report. Location data is provided through x and y coordinates, latitude, longitude, and a combined location point. Researchers and analysts can use this dataset to study traffic enforcement patterns across the city, identify areas with high violation rates, and analyze the types of violations that are most common. The `rpt_owning_cmd` column identifies the command that owns a report.
sfd:

title: Digital Tax Map: Condominium Units
ufd: This dataset contains information about condominium units in New York City, extracted from the Department of Finance's Digital Tax Map collection. It provides details on individual condo units, their location, and identifiers. Key columns include `condo_base_bbl` (Borough, Block, and Lot number for the base condominium), `condo_number` (the specific condo unit number), and `unit_bbl` (Borough, Block, and Lot number for the unit). The dataset also includes `unit_designation`, which describes the unit's use (e.g., residential, commercial). Researchers, real estate professionals, and city planners can use this data to analyze condo development, assess property values, and understand land use patterns. The data is updated monthly, reflecting the most recent changes in the Digital Tax Map. Note that this dataset reflects formal applications submitted to DOF but may not reflect the latest changes in other City systems.
sfd:
