title: Parking Violations Issued - Fiscal Year 2018
ufd: This dataset contains information on parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2018 (July 1, 2017 to June 30, 2018). Each row represents a single parking ticket. Key details include the `summons_number` (a unique identifier for the ticket), the `plate_id` and `registration_state` of the vehicle, the `issue_date` of the ticket, and the `violation_code` indicating the reason for the violation. The `vehicle_body_type` and `vehicle_make` provide information about the vehicle that received the ticket. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze parking violation patterns, identify areas with high violation rates, and understand the types of vehicles most frequently ticketed. Please note that this dataset only reflects the status of violations at the time of issuance and does not include updates on payments or dismissals.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2018 (July 1, 2017 to June 30, 2018). Each record represents a parking ticket, including information such as the summons number, vehicle plate ID, issue date, and violation code. The data also includes vehicle details like body type and make.

title: HISTORICAL Sidewalk Café Licenses and Applications
ufd: This dataset provides a historical record of sidewalk café licenses and applications in New York City. Although the program is no longer active, the data offers insights into the operation and regulation of outdoor dining spaces. Key columns include `lic_status` indicating the license status (Active or Inactive), `business_name` and `business_name2` specifying the name of the business, and location details such as `building`, `street`, `city`, `state`, and `zip`. The dataset also contains information on the type of sidewalk café (`swc_type`) and its size (`swc_sq_ft`), along with the number of tables (`swc_tables`) and chairs (`swc_chairs`). Researchers and urban planners can use this data to analyze the distribution of sidewalk cafes, understand the characteristics of businesses that obtained licenses, and inform future policies related to outdoor dining and public space. The `community_district` and `city_council_district` columns allow for analysis at a neighborhood level.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes details on license status, business names, location information, café type, size, and the number of tables and chairs. Although the sidewalk café program is no longer active, the data provides valuable insights into outdoor dining regulations and business characteristics.

title: 2013 - 2014 DOE High School Performance-Directory
ufd: This dataset contains performance data for New York City high schools. It includes information on quality reviews, student progress, student performance, and the school environment for the years 2010-2011 and 2011-2012. Key columns include `dbn` (a unique identifier for each school), `quality_review_year` and `quality_review_score`, which provide insights into the school's overall quality. The dataset also contains letter grades (`A`, `B`, `C`, etc.) for progress reports, student progress, student performance, and the school environment. Graduation and college enrollment rates are provided as percentages. This data could be used to analyze school performance trends, identify factors that contribute to student success, or compare the performance of different schools. Note that the `college_ready_10_11` column contains no data.
sfd:

This dataset provides performance metrics for New York City high schools during the 2010-2011 and 2011-2012 academic years. It includes data from quality reviews, progress reports, and student outcomes. Key indicators include quality review scores, letter grades for various performance areas, graduation rates, and college enrollment rates.

title: 2020-2021 Annual Report on Special Education
ufd: This dataset presents the 2020-2021 Annual Report on Special Education, as mandated by Local Law 27 of 2015. It offers insights into special education services across different districts, tracking key metrics related to Individualized Education Program (IEP) meetings and student eligibility. The dataset includes the total number of students in each district (`sy2020_2021_total_students`), the number of IEP meetings held (`total_iep_meetings_held`), and counts of students determined ineligible or classified with IEPs. Columns like `closed_without_iep_meeting` provide information on cases closed without a meeting. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze trends in special education, assess the effectiveness of IEP processes, and identify areas for improvement in supporting students with special needs. The data also includes information on parental consent status, such as `open_and_awaiting_parental` and `open_and_parental_consent`.
sfd:

It includes metrics on IEP meetings, student eligibility for special education, and parental consent status. The data can be used to analyze trends in special education and assess the effectiveness of IEP processes.

title: Full-Time And Full-Time Equivalent Staffing Levels
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at the staffing levels within New York City government agencies. It includes estimated fiscal year-end headcount information for both full-time and full-time equivalent (FTE) employees. The data is broken down by agency, personnel type (Civilian), and funding source, offering a comprehensive view of the city's workforce. Key columns include `agency_name`, `fiscal_year`, `full_time_full_time_equivalents_ft_fte_positions` (detailing the type of employment), and various headcount columns (`city_funded_headcount`, `ifa_funded_headcount`, etc.) that specify the number of positions funded by different sources. Researchers, city planners, and the public can use this dataset to analyze staffing trends, understand the distribution of personnel across different agencies, and assess the impact of funding on staffing levels. The dataset is updated quarterly.
sfd:

title: Parking Violations Issued - Fiscal Year 2020
ufd: This dataset contains information on parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2020 (July 1, 2019 - June 30, 2020). Each row represents a single parking ticket. Key details include the `summons_number` (unique identifier for the ticket), `plate_id` and `registration_state` of the vehicle, the `issue_date` and `violation_time`, and the `violation_code` explaining the reason for the ticket. The `vehicle_body_type` and `vehicle_make` provide information about the vehicle involved. Researchers and city planners could use this data to analyze parking violation patterns, identify areas with high violation rates based on `street_code1`, `street_code2`, and `street_code3`, and assess the effectiveness of parking regulations. Keep in mind that this dataset reflects the status of violations at the time of issuance and may not reflect current status.

title: SNAP Center Wait Time
ufd: This dataset provides monthly snapshots of client wait times at various SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) centers. It includes the name of the SNAP center (nca_snap_center_name) and a corresponding center number for identification. The report_date column indicates the month for which the wait times are reported. The key metric is snap_center_wait_time, showing the average wait time experienced by clients at each center during the reporting period. This data can be used to monitor and compare wait times across different SNAP centers, identify centers with consistently long wait times, and assess the impact of interventions aimed at reducing wait times. Analyzing this data can help improve the efficiency and accessibility of SNAP services for the community. The dataset contains approximately 100 rows of data, covering several months and a selection of SNAP centers.
sfd:

title: Storefront Registration Statistics for Designated Class One
ufd: This dataset provides aggregate statistics on registered storefronts in Designated Class One properties, offering insights into the commercial landscape of the city. The data is broken down by geographic boundaries, including citywide, borough, and council district levels, allowing for granular analysis. Key columns include `reporting_year`, `aggregate_level_citywide` (specifying the geographic aggregation level), `total_storefronts`, `median_square_feet`, and various storefront status indicators like `storefront_leased_to_tenants`, `storefront_reported_occupied`, `storefront_reported_not_leased`, and `storefront_under_construction`. You can use this dataset to track storefront occupancy rates, understand the distribution of storefront sizes, and identify areas with high vacancy or construction activity. The dataset also includes information on the median and average years for construction, which could be useful for understanding development timelines. Note that some columns contain placeholder values, indicated by asterisks (*), which represent missing or suppressed data. This dataset is valuable for city planners, real estate developers, and researchers interested in understanding and analyzing commercial property trends.
sfd:

This dataset contains aggregate statistics on registered storefronts in Designated Class One properties, providing a detailed view of the city's commercial landscape. Data is aggregated at citywide, borough, and council district levels, offering granular insights into storefront occupancy, size, and construction activity. Key metrics include total storefronts, median square footage, and various storefront status indicators.

title: 2050s Sea Level Rise Projections
ufd: This dataset contains sea level rise projections for New York City in the 2050s, based on data from the New York City Panel on Climate Change (2019). Each row represents a specific geographic area and its projected sea level rise. The `the_geom` column provides the geometry of the area as a MultiPolygon, defining its spatial boundaries. The `id` column serves as a unique identifier for each area. While the dataset includes a column named `orig_fid`, its purpose is not explicitly defined. Researchers and policymakers can use this dataset to assess the potential impact of sea level rise on different parts of New York City and develop adaptation strategies. The geographic data allows for spatial analysis and visualization of the projected changes.
sfd:

title: Internet Master Plan: Adoption and Infrastructure Data by Neighborhood
ufd: This dataset provides key indicators of broadband adoption, service, and infrastructure across New York City neighborhoods. It includes data on home and mobile broadband adoption rates, broken down by connection level (High, Medium, Low). You can explore the relationship between internet connectivity and demographics by examining columns like `total_population`, `population_density_per_sq`, and `total_number_of_households`. The dataset also provides insights into broadband choices, commercial fiber availability, and the number of internet service providers (ISPs) available in each area. Columns like `area_sq_mi` and `street_mileage` offer a geographical context for understanding infrastructure. This data can be used to analyze digital equity, identify areas with limited internet access, and inform policies aimed at improving broadband infrastructure and adoption in NYC. The data is organized by neighborhood tabulation area, allowing for granular analysis and targeted interventions. Note that data accuracy is limited as of the date of publication and by the methodology and accuracy of the original sources.
sfd:

title: ACRIS - UCC Collateral Codes
ufd: This dataset provides a mapping of ACRIS (Automated City Register Information System) collateral types for codes used in the ACRIS Personal Property Master Dataset. It includes a `record_type` column, which appears to always be "U" in this dataset. The `ucc_collateral_code` column contains the specific code, and the `description` column offers a textual explanation of what the code represents. For example, code "D" corresponds to "TRANSMITTING UTILITIES DBTR," while "F" indicates "FIXTURE FILING." This dataset can be used to decode and understand the collateral types associated with personal property records in ACRIS. Researchers, data analysts, and city planners can leverage this information to gain insights into the types of collateral used in various transactions and filings within the city. The dataset is relatively small, containing only 8 rows, but it provides a valuable reference for interpreting ACRIS data.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset maps ACRIS (Automated City Register Information System) collateral types to their corresponding codes used in the ACRIS Personal Property Master Dataset. It provides a lookup table for understanding the meaning of `ucc_collateral_code` values found in other ACRIS datasets. The dataset includes the code, a textual description, and a `record_type` field (always "U").

title: Vehicles
ufd: This dataset provides an inventory of vehicles used by contracted bus vendors for the Department of Education. It details the active vehicle inventory for each vendor, including school buses, ambulances, and coach buses. Each record includes the school year, the name of the vendor, a description of the vehicle type, and the number of active vehicles of that type. Key columns include `vendor_name`, specifying the transportation company, `vehicle_typedescription`, which indicates the type of vehicle (e.g., Mini-Wagon, Standard Bus), and `active_vehicles`, representing the count of vehicles of that type. The dataset can be used to understand the types and quantities of vehicles used by different vendors, track changes in vehicle inventory over time (school year), and analyze the distribution of different vehicle types. Researchers and policymakers can leverage this data to optimize transportation resources and ensure adequate service for students with diverse needs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains an inventory of vehicles used by contracted bus vendors for the Department of Education. It includes details on active vehicle inventory for each vendor, broken down by school year, vendor name, vehicle type, and the number of active vehicles of that type. title: Sea Level Rise Maps (2080s 100-year Floodplain)
ufd: This dataset shows the 100-year floodplain in the 2080s, based on FEMA's Preliminary Work Map data and sea-level rise projections. It uses the New York Panel on Climate Change's 90th Percentile projections, which estimate a 58-inch rise in sea level. The dataset was created by the Mayor's Office of Long-Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) on behalf of the CUNY Institute for Sustainable Cities (CISC) and the New York Panel on Climate Change (NPCC). The key column, "the_geom", contains the geographic boundaries of the floodplain areas. This data can be used to understand the potential impact of sea-level rise on coastal communities. It can also inform urban planning, infrastructure development, and risk management strategies. Researchers, policymakers, and community members can use this dataset to assess vulnerability and develop adaptation plans.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset delineates the projected 100-year floodplain in the 2080s, incorporating sea-level rise estimates based on the New York Panel on Climate Change's (NPCC) 90th percentile projections (58-inch rise). Derived from FEMA's Preliminary Work Map data, it provides geographic boundaries of floodplain areas (the_geom). This data is crucial for understanding the future impacts of sea-level rise on coastal regions.

**Related Topics:**
- Climate Change

- Coastal Management

- Disaster Preparedness
- FEMA Flood Maps

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- 100-year Floodplain: Area with a 1% annual chance of flooding, Special Flood Hazard Area (SFHA)
- Sea-Level Rise (SLR): Rising sea levels, coastal inundation
- Climate Change Projections: Future climate scenarios, climate models
- FEMA Preliminary Work Map: Initial flood hazard maps, flood risk assessment
- the_geom: Geographic boundaries, spatial data, polygon data
- Vulnerability Assessment: Risk evaluation, impact analysis

**Applications and Use Cases:**

title: NYC Taxi Zones
ufd: This dataset provides geographic information about New York City taxi zones, which are based on Neighborhood Tabulation Areas (NTAs). Each taxi zone is represented by a polygon geometry in the `the_geom` column, along with attributes like `shape_leng` and `shape_area` indicating the zone's size and shape. The `zone` and `borough` columns provide the name and borough of the taxi zone, while `locationid` offers a unique identifier. This dataset can be used to visualize taxi trip data by geographic area, analyze taxi ridership patterns, or study the relationship between taxi activity and neighborhood characteristics. Researchers, urban planners, and data enthusiasts can leverage this dataset to gain insights into transportation patterns and urban dynamics within New York City. The dataset contains 100 rows and 6 columns.
sfd:

title: Campaign Contributions
ufd: This dataset contains information about campaign contributions to candidates, committees, and other recipients. The data focuses on the 2001 election year. Key columns include `election` indicating the election year, `recipid` which is a unique identifier for the recipient, `recipname` which is the name of the recipient, and `amnt` which represents the contribution amount. The dataset also includes information about the candidate, such as their first name (`candfirst`) and middle initial (`candmi`).  Additional details include the office code (`officecd`), filing number, and contribution schedule. Researchers and analysts can use this dataset to study campaign finance trends, identify top recipients of contributions, and analyze the distribution of funds across different candidates and committees. The data also allows for examining contribution patterns based on location through the `city` and `zip` columns.
sfd:

title: DHS Daily Report (Historical)
ufd: This dataset provides a historical record of the daily census of individuals and families residing in New York City's Department of Homeless Services (DHS) shelter system. Each row represents a daily snapshot, capturing the total number of adults and children in shelters. Key columns include `date_of_census`, `total_adults_in_shelter`, `total_children_in_shelter`, and `total_individuals_in_shelter`. The dataset also breaks down the population by single adult men, single adult women, and families with children. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze trends in shelter usage, understand the demographics of the homeless population, and inform resource allocation strategies. The data spans a period for which only 100 days are represented. Please note that this dataset does not include records after March 1, 2021; refer to the linked dataset for more recent information.
sfd:

title: Department of Youth and Community Development (DYCD) Contracts
ufd:
This dataset contains information about contracts managed by the Department of Youth and Community Development (DYCD). It includes details on the funding, registration, and status of these contracts. Each row represents a contract's information for a specific fiscal year, with the total amount funded across all years also provided.

Key columns include `solicitation_name` and `solicitation_detail`, which describe the type of program or service being solicited. The `major_program` column indicates the DYCD business unit overseeing the contract, while `provider` identifies the organization providing the services. Contract start and end dates are specified in the `term_start_date` and `term_end_date` columns.

Researchers, city planners, and community organizations can use this data to understand the scope and distribution of DYCD funding. It allows users to track funding allocations, identify key service providers, and analyze contract durations. The dataset can also be used to assess the reach and impact of various youth and community development programs across the city.
sfd:

title: Parking Violations Issued - Fiscal Year 2021
ufd: This dataset contains information on parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2021 (July 1, 2020 to June 30, 2021). Each row represents a single parking ticket. Key details include the `summons_number` (unique identifier for the ticket), `plate_id` and `registration_state` of the vehicle, the `issue_date` and `violation_time`, and the `violation_code` explaining the reason for the ticket. The dataset also provides information about the vehicle, such as `vehicle_body_type` and `vehicle_make`, as well as location information via `street_code1`, `street_code2`, and `street_code3`. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze parking violation patterns, identify areas with high violation rates, and understand the types of vehicles receiving the most tickets. This dataset reflects the status of violations at the time of issuance and is not updated to reflect subsequent changes like payments or dismissals.
sfd:

title: Historical Medallion  Vehicles - Authorized
ufd: This dataset provides historical information on medallion vehicles authorized to operate in New York City. It includes details such as the license number, the name of the vehicle owner or company, the type of authorization (e.g., medallion), and the current status. Key columns include the DMV license plate number, the vehicle identification number (VIN), the vehicle type (e.g., HYB for hybrid), and the model year. The dataset also specifies the medallion type, indicating whether the owner must drive or if a named driver is permitted. Additional information includes the agent number, name, telephone number, and address associated with the vehicle. This data could be used to analyze trends in vehicle types, track changes in medallion ownership, or investigate the distribution of authorized vehicles across different agents. The dataset is accurate up to the last updated date and time provided.
sfd:

title: Hurricane Evacuation Zones
ufd: This dataset contains information about New York City's hurricane evacuation zones, which indicate varying levels of flood risk from storm surges. The data includes a zone identifier (`hurricane_`), the length (`shape_leng`) and area (`shape_area`) of the zone's shape, and the zone's geometry (`the_geom`). These zones are used in the city's hurricane contingency plans.  It is important to note that these evacuation zones differ from FEMA flood insurance risk zones.  This dataset can be used by city planners, emergency management personnel, and residents to understand and prepare for potential hurricane-related flooding. By visualizing the geometry data, users can map and analyze the spatial extent of each evacuation zone. The area and length attributes can be used to compare the sizes of different zones.
sfd:

It provides spatial information about each zone, including its geometry, area, and length. These zones are used in the city's hurricane contingency plans to guide evacuations based on flood risk from storm surges.

title: Steam Consumption And Cost (2010 – May 2025)
ufd: This dataset provides monthly steam consumption and cost information for properties in Manhattan, spanning from 2010 to May 2025. It includes details such as the development name, account name, and specific building location. Key columns include `revenue_month` indicating the month of the data, `tds` and `edp` representing some kind of numeric values related to steam consumption and cost, and `funding_source` specifying the origin of funds for the development. The data also identifies the utility vendor (`vendor_name`) and provides meter information like `meter_number`. Researchers, city planners, or property managers can use this dataset to analyze steam consumption patterns, track costs, and understand funding sources related to housing developments in Manhattan. The `umis_bill_id` column can be used to track specific bills within the UMIS system.

title: DSNY Commercial Waste Zones
ufd: This dataset provides information about the 20 commercial waste zones established by the NYC Department of Sanitation (DSNY) across the five boroughs. Each row represents a specific zone, identified by its `zone` code and `zone_name`. The `cd` column lists the community districts included within each waste zone, along with any joint interest areas like parks or airports. The dataset also includes the `shape_area` and `shape_length` of each zone, offering insights into their geographical size and perimeter. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the spatial distribution of waste zones, understand their composition in terms of community districts, and potentially optimize waste management strategies. The `multipolygon` column contains the geographic coordinates defining the boundaries of each zone.

title: Holiday Construction Embargo- Intersection
ufd: This dataset identifies street intersections in New York City that are subject to construction embargoes during the holiday season (November to January). Each entry represents an intersection, with its location specified by coordinates in the `the_geom` column. The `boroughcod` column indicates the borough in which the intersection is located, while `primarynam` and `primaryn_1` provide the names of the intersecting streets. Additional columns such as `@computed_region_efsh_h5xi`, `@computed_region_f5dn_yrer`, `@computed_region_yeji_bk3q`, `@computed_region_92fq_4b7q`, and `@computed_region_sbqj_enih` offer further geographic categorization using computed regions. This data can be valuable for construction companies, transportation planners, and city residents who want to understand where construction restrictions are in place during the holidays. By using this dataset, one can avoid planning construction work in restricted areas or anticipate potential traffic disruptions.
sfd:

Each entry includes the intersection's coordinates (`the_geom`), borough code (`boroughcod`), and names of intersecting streets (`primarynam`, `primaryn_1`). Computed region columns provide additional geographic categorization. This data is useful for planning and avoiding construction in restricted areas during the holidays.

Applications and Use Cases:
- Planning construction projects to avoid embargoed areas.
- Analyzing traffic patterns and potential disruptions due to construction restrictions.
- Visualizing construction embargo zones on a map.
- Informing residents and visitors about construction-free routes during the holidays.
- Integrating construction embargo data with navigation apps.

title: 2019-2020 SHSAT Admissions Test Offers By Sending School
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the Specialized High Schools Admissions Test (SHSAT) offers for NYC public middle schools during the 2019-2020 school year. It allows you to see how many students from each school participated in the admissions process, how many took the SHSAT, and how many received offers to specialized high schools. Key columns include `feeder_school_dbn` and `feeder_school_name`, which identify the middle school. The `count_of_students_in_hs` column shows the total number of students in the high school, while `count_of_testers` indicates how many students took the SHSAT. Finally, `number_of_offers` reveals the number of students who received offers. This data can be used to analyze the success rates of different middle schools in preparing students for specialized high schools, identify disparities in access to these schools, and inform strategies to improve outcomes for all students. Researchers, educators, and policymakers can use this information to understand trends in specialized high school admissions.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on Specialized High Schools Admissions Test (SHSAT) offers for NYC public middle schools during the 2019-2020 school year. It includes data on the number of students who took the SHSAT and the number of offers received, broken down by middle school. The dataset allows for analysis of middle school performance in preparing students for specialized high schools.

title: 2019 School Food Report LL215
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at school food programs in Manhattan (borough "M") across districts 1 and 2. It includes information on meal participation, specifically focusing on breakfast, lunch, snacks and supper programs. Key columns include `school_name`, `borough`, `district`, and various columns detailing average daily participation (ADP) in different meal programs for fiscal years 2018 and 2019 (e.g., `lunches_adp_fy18`, `snacks_adp_fy19`). The dataset also indicates whether schools offer salad bars (`salad_bar_y_salad_bar_offered`) and breakfast in the classroom (`breakfast_in_classroom_offered`). Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze student meal participation rates, identify trends in food program utilization, and assess the availability of different food service options in Manhattan schools. The data could also be used to evaluate the impact of specific programs like "breakfast before the bell" on student attendance and academic performance. Note that many columns related to program offerings have a high fraction of missing values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on school food programs in Manhattan districts 1 and 2, focusing on meal participation rates. It includes average daily participation (ADP) data for breakfast, lunch, snacks, and supper programs for fiscal years 2018 and 2019. - Identify schools with low meal participation rates for targeted interventions.

title: Directory of NYCHA Community Facilities
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of community facilities located on NYCHA (New York City Housing Authority) properties in the Bronx. It includes details on programs sponsored by NYCHA or other entities, all open to the public. Key information includes the funding agency, program type (e.g., Senior Center, Child Care), the facility's status (Occupied, Vacant), and the development name and address. The dataset also provides geographic information such as postcode, community board, council district, and census tract. Researchers and community organizers can use this data to identify available resources, assess community needs, and understand the distribution of social services within NYCHA properties in the Bronx. The data can also be used for spatial analysis and resource allocation planning.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It details publicly accessible programs, including funding sources, program types (e.g., Senior Centers, Child Care), and facility status. title: Department for the Aging (NYC Aging) - All Contracted Providers
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive listing of contracted social service providers funded by the NYC Department for the Aging (NYC Aging). It includes a variety of services for older adults across New York City's five boroughs, such as home-delivered meals, case management, caregiver support, and elder abuse prevention. Key columns include `providertype` which specifies the type of service offered, `programname` and `sponsorname` which detail the program and sponsoring organization, and `programaddress`, `programcity`, `programstate`, `programzipcode`, and `borough` which provide location information. The `programphone` column offers contact information for each provider. This dataset can be used to identify aging services available in specific locations, understand the range of services offered by different providers, and connect older adults with the resources they need. Researchers can also use this data to analyze the distribution of social services across the city and assess the impact of NYC Aging's programs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes information on various services for older adults in New York City, such as home-delivered meals, case management, and caregiver support. The dataset provides details on provider type, program name, location, and contact information, enabling users to identify and connect with relevant aging services.

title: 2018-2019 School Demographic Snapshot
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of school demographics and enrollment trends in New York City public schools from 2014-15 through 2018-19. Each row represents a specific school and year, identified by a unique school ID (`dbn`) and school name. Key columns include `total_enrollment`, which indicates the total number of students enrolled, and enrollment counts for each grade level (e.g., `grade_k`, `grade_1`, etc.). The dataset also breaks down enrollment by gender (`male`, `female`) and race/ethnicity (`asian`, `black`, `hispanic`, `white`). Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze enrollment patterns, demographic shifts, and resource allocation across different schools and over time. Educators and parents can also use this information to understand the composition of student populations in their communities. The dataset includes 39 columns and 100 rows.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains enrollment and demographic information for New York City public schools from the 2014-15 to 2018-19 school years. It provides a school-by-school breakdown of total enrollment, enrollment by grade level, gender, and race/ethnicity. The data can be used to analyze enrollment trends and demographic shifts in NYC public schools.

title: ACRIS - Country Codes
ufd: This dataset provides a mapping between country codes and their corresponding descriptions, primarily for use with the ACRIS Real and Personal Parties Property Datasets. It contains 100 rows, each representing a unique country. The key columns include `country_code`, which holds the standard country abbreviation, and `description`, which provides the full country name. The `record_type` column simply indicates the type of record, which is consistently "T" in this dataset. This dataset can be used to standardize country references within property records or to enhance reporting by providing full country names alongside abbreviated codes. Researchers and data analysts working with property data can leverage this dataset to ensure consistent and accurate country identification. The data covers a wide range of countries, making it a valuable resource for international property analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset maps country codes to their full country names, containing 100 unique countries. It's designed for use with property datasets like ACRIS, providing a standardized reference for country identification. Key columns include `country_code` (country abbreviation) and `description` (full country name).

title: 2020 Community District Tabulation Areas (CDTAs)
ufd: This dataset contains information about the 2020 Community District Tabulation Areas (CDTAs) in New York City. CDTAs are created by the Department of City Planning to approximate the 59 Community Districts for reporting American Community Survey (ACS) data, using aggregations of whole 2020 census tracts. Each row represents a CDTA, identified by a unique code (`cdta2020`) and name (`cdtaname`). The dataset includes the borough code (`borocode`), borough name (`boroname`), and county FIPS code (`countyfips`) for each CDTA, providing geographic context.  The `cdtatype` column indicates the type of CDTA. Additionally, the dataset provides the length (`shape_leng`) and area (`shape_area`) of each CDTA's shape, along with the geographic coordinates in the `the_geom` column. This dataset can be used to analyze data at the community district level, create maps, or perform spatial analysis.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset provides geographic and descriptive information for the 2020 Community District Tabulation Areas (CDTAs) in New York City. CDTAs are aggregations of 2020 census tracts used to approximate Community Districts for reporting American Community Survey (ACS) data. The dataset includes unique identifiers, borough information, geographic coordinates, and shape measurements for each CDTA.

**Related Topics:**

- Comparing geographic characteristics (area, shape) across different CDTAs.

title: Synthetic Turf Fields
ufd: This dataset provides information on synthetic turf fields located on New York City Parks properties. Each row represents a specific synthetic turf system, identified by a unique system ID. Key details include the location of the field (`synturf_location`), a description of the recreational area (`description`), and the type of system (e.g., `Field Group`, `Play Area`) under `system_type`. The dataset also specifies the `turf_type` (Infill, Non-Infill, or Unknown) and the `infill_material` used. Additional columns detail the department responsible (`department`), maintenance information (`maint_by`), and the date the field was commissioned (`commission_date`). Researchers, urban planners, and parks enthusiasts can use this data to analyze the distribution of synthetic turf fields, understand the types of materials used, and track maintenance responsibilities across different parks in NYC. The data dictionary provides additional context for each field.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details synthetic turf fields located within New York City Parks properties. It includes information on field location, system type, turf type (Infill, Non-Infill, or Unknown), infill material, and maintenance responsibilities. The data can be used to analyze the distribution, materials, and maintenance of synthetic turf fields across NYC parks.

Related Topics:

- Maintenance: Upkeep, repair, servicing

Applications and Use Cases:

- Track maintenance responsibilities and identify potential areas for improvement.

title: Energy Usage From DOE Buildings
ufd: This dataset contains energy usage information from a selection of City-owned buildings, as reported by the Department of Energy. The data includes the building address and borough, allowing for location-based analysis of energy consumption. Key measurements include electricity demand and usage, gas consumption, and total energy usage in mmBTUs. The dataset provides monthly energy consumption data, starting from July 2008. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze energy consumption patterns in different buildings, identify potential areas for energy efficiency improvements, and track the impact of sustainability initiatives. The data spans multiple years, enabling longitudinal studies of energy usage trends.
sfd:

title: Work Order Management Module
ufd: This dataset contains information about work orders associated with customer service request (CSR) complaints related to environmental issues. Each row represents a specific work order, identified by a unique work order number and service request number. Key details include the `workorder_activity_code` and `workorder_activity_description`, which specify the type of work performed, such as repairing connections or replacing manhole castings. The dataset also tracks timestamps for when the work order was added (`workorder_added`), and potentially when it was started (`workorder_started`), and completed (`workorder_completed`). The `time_stamp` column records when the data was recorded. Researchers or city planners could use this data to analyze the types and frequency of environmental maintenance activities, track work order completion times, and potentially identify areas where infrastructure improvements are needed. Analyzing trends in work order activity could help optimize resource allocation and improve response times to environmental concerns.
sfd:

Each entry represents a specific work order, identified by unique work order and service request numbers, and describes the type of environmental maintenance activity performed. - Evaluate the effectiveness of environmental maintenance programs.

title: Business Improvement Districts
ufd: This dataset provides information about Business Improvement Districts (BIDs). BIDs are public-private partnerships in which property and business owners in a defined area elect to make a collective contribution to maintain and improve their district. The dataset includes geographic information about the BIDs, represented in the `the_geom` column, which contains MultiPolygon coordinates defining the district boundaries. Other key columns include `f_all_bids`, `f_all_bi_1` (likely the borough), `f_all_bi_2` (BID name), and `f_all_bi_3` (potentially budget or revenue). The `f_all_bi_4` column provides a URL for each BID. This dataset could be used to analyze the distribution of BIDs across different boroughs, assess their financial resources, or map their locations for urban planning and economic development purposes. Researchers, city planners, and business owners can leverage this data to understand the landscape of BIDs and their potential impact on local economies.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information about Business Improvement Districts (BIDs), including their geographic locations and key attributes. Each BID is represented by a MultiPolygon geometry in the `the_geom` column, defining its boundaries. The dataset also includes details such as borough, BID name, URL, and potentially financial information.

title: NYC Parks Active and Passive Recreation
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed inventory of public open spaces in New York City, including parks, playgrounds, and other recreational areas managed by NYC Parks and partner organizations. It offers insights into the allocation of space for active (sports, exercise) and passive (relaxation, picnicking) recreation within each location. Key columns include `public_open_space_name` to identify the specific location, `recreation_category` to classify the space as Active, Passive, or Mixed, and `acres` to quantify the total area. The dataset also breaks down the area into `active_acres` and `passive_acres`, along with corresponding percentages. Researchers and urban planners can use this data to analyze the distribution of recreational resources across the city, assess the balance between active and passive spaces, and inform decisions about future park development and resource allocation. The `location` column provides address details, while `type_category` classifies the space (e.g., Neighborhood Park, Nature Area).
sfd:

It classifies spaces by recreation category (Active, Passive, Mixed) and quantifies total area in acres, including breakdowns for active and passive uses. The data enables analysis of recreational resource distribution and informs park development decisions.

title: School Discharge Reporting (Local Law 42)
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of high school student discharges and transfers within New York City during the 2010-2011 school year. It breaks down the reasons students left or moved schools, categorized by "discharge_category" and described in detail by "discharge_description," such as graduation, dropout, or transfer to another school. The data is further segmented by "student_category," including all students and specific cohorts. The "count_of_students" column indicates the number of students for each discharge type, while "total_enrolled_students" provides context on the overall student population. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze student attrition rates, identify trends in discharge types, and evaluate the effectiveness of interventions aimed at improving student retention. The dataset focuses on citywide data, with a single "year," "report_category," and "school_level."
sfd:

It categorizes the reasons for student departures, such as graduation, dropout, or school transfers, and provides counts of students within each category. title: Landmarks Complaints
ufd: This dataset contains information on landmark violation complaints received by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission (LPC). Each row represents a complaint, identified by a unique complaint number, and includes the date the complaint was filed. Key details include the address and street name of the property, along with its borough, block, lot, and postcode. The dataset also specifies the historic district or landmark name associated with the complaint. Furthermore, you can find a description of the reported work that led to the complaint, the action taken by the LPC (e.g., warning letter issued), and the current status of the complaint. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze trends in landmark violations, identify areas with frequent complaints, and assess the effectiveness of LPC enforcement actions.
sfd:

title: Schoolyard to Playgrounds
ufd: This dataset provides information on participating Department of Education (DOE) Schoolyards in the Schoolyards to Playgrounds program. The program aims to expand public access to open spaces during non-school hours by improving schoolyards with play equipment, sports surfaces, trees, and benches. Each record represents a DOE Schoolyard and includes its address, borough, and location. Key columns include 'acres' representing the size of the schoolyard, 'borough' indicating the borough in New York City, and 'communityboard' and 'councildistrict' providing administrative districts. The dataset also includes political identifiers such as 'nys_assembly', 'nys_senate', and 'us_congress'. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of open spaces in the city, assess the impact of the program, and identify areas where additional improvements are needed. The 'multipolygon' column contains the geospatial data defining the schoolyard boundaries.

title: TLC Driver Education 24 Hour Course Providers
ufd: This dataset lists authorized providers of the TLC Driver Education 24-hour course and exam, a requirement for all TLC Driver License applicants. Each row represents a different education provider, identified by their `schoolname`. The dataset includes contact information such as `telephone`, `email`, and `web` address, as well as the name of a `contact` person. Geographical information is provided, including `city`, `state`, and `zipcode`, which can be used to locate providers in specific areas. The `languagesoffered` column indicates the languages in which the course is available. This dataset can be used by individuals seeking to obtain a TLC Driver License to find a suitable education provider, or by researchers interested in the distribution and characteristics of TLC driver education programs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on authorized providers of the TLC Driver Education 24-hour course and exam, a mandatory requirement for TLC Driver License applicants. Each record details a specific education provider, including their contact details, geographical location, and languages offered for the course. The data can be used to locate and compare different TLC driver education providers.

title: OER Cleanup Sites
ufd: This dataset provides information on properties in New York City that have been remediated under the oversight of the Office of Environmental Remediation (OER). It includes both properties in the E-Designation program and the NYC Voluntary Cleanup Program, with details on sites that are completed or in progress. Key columns include project numbers, project names, street addresses, borough, and BBL (Borough, Block, and Lot number). The dataset also specifies the OER program under which the remediation occurred, the current class (status) of the project (e.g., Active or Completed), and the phase of the project (e.g., Construction, Closure, or Site Management). Each project is linked to a project-specific document repository. Location data, including latitude, longitude, zip code and community district, are also provided. Researchers, city planners, and environmental advocates can use this dataset to understand the distribution and progress of environmental remediation efforts across the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on environmental remediation projects in New York City overseen by the Office of Environmental Remediation (OER). It includes details on properties in the E-Designation and NYC Voluntary Cleanup Programs, specifying project status, phase, and location. The dataset provides a comprehensive view of remediation efforts, including project numbers, addresses, program types, and links to project documents.

Related Topics:

  - Brownfields
  - Urban Planning
  - New York City
  - Environmental Health
  - Land Use
  - Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

  - E-Designation Program: Environmental Designation, Restrictive Declaration
  - NYC Voluntary Cleanup Program: VCP, Voluntary Remediation

  - OER: Office of Environmental Remediation

  - Evaluating the effectiveness of different remediation programs.

title: Street Construction Inspections and Corrective Action Requests
ufd: This dataset contains information about street construction inspections and corrective action requests in New York City. It is maintained by the DOT's Highway Inspection & Quality Assurance (HIQA) division, which enforces laws and rules related to work performed on sidewalks, roadways, and highways. Each row represents an inspection, identified by a unique `inspectionid`, and includes details such as the `permitnumber`, `permitteename` (the organization or individual responsible for the work), and `permittype` (e.g., repair gas, sidewalk occupancy). The dataset also specifies the location of the work with `onstreetname`, `fromstreetname`, and `tostreetname`. Key information includes the `inspectiontype`, `inspectiondate`, and `inspectionresulttype`, along with any `inspectionremarks`. This data could be used to analyze trends in street construction, identify common violations, or assess the performance of different contractors. Researchers and city planners could use this dataset to improve street construction practices and ensure compliance with regulations.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details street construction inspections and corrective action requests in New York City, managed by the DOT's HIQA division. Each record represents a unique inspection, identified by `inspectionid`, and includes permit details, location information, inspection type, date, result, and any associated remarks. The data provides insights into street construction activities, compliance, and potential violations.

Related Topics:

- Highway Maintenance
- Infrastructure Management
- Regulatory Compliance
- Urban Planning
- Transportation Permits

- HIQA: Highway Inspection & Quality Assurance

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in street construction activities and identify recurring issues.
- Evaluate the performance of different contractors and their compliance with regulations.
- Identify areas with frequent construction violations and target enforcement efforts.
- Improve street construction practices and ensure public safety.
- Optimize permit processes and reduce delays.
- Support urban planning and infrastructure development initiatives.

title: 2018-2019 Daily Attendance
ufd: This dataset provides daily attendance information for a specific school (identified by the school_dbn "01M015") during the 2018-2019 school year. Each row represents a single day and includes the date, the number of students enrolled, the number of students absent, and the number of students present. The 'released' column indicates the number of students released from the school on a given day. Researchers and educators can use this data to analyze attendance patterns, identify trends in absenteeism, and understand daily student flow within the school. The dataset could be used to explore the relationship between attendance and other factors, or to evaluate the impact of interventions aimed at improving attendance rates. Note that this sample only contains data for one school, so school-level comparisons are not possible with this subset.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains daily attendance records for school "01M015" during the 2018-2019 school year. It includes the date, total enrollment, number of absent students, number of present students, and the number of students released. This data can be used to analyze attendance patterns and student flow within a single school.

Related Topics:

- School DBN: school identification number, school ID

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze daily attendance trends for a specific school.
- Identify patterns of absenteeism throughout the school year.
- Calculate daily attendance rates.
- Model the relationship between student releases and attendance.
- Develop predictive models for student attendance.

title: Queens Library Branches
ufd: This dataset provides information on the locations and operating hours of Queens Library branches. Each row represents a specific branch, including its name, address, city, and postcode. You can find the phone number for each location, as well as the opening hours for each day of the week (Monday through Sunday). The dataset also includes geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) for each branch. This information could be used to find the nearest library, check opening times, or perform spatial analysis of library locations within Queens. The dataset contains 68 rows and 27 columns.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations and operating hours of all Queens Library branches. It includes information such as branch name, address, phone number, and daily opening hours (Monday-Sunday). Geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) are also provided for each of the 68 library branches.

title: Uptown Bicycle Counts
ufd: This dataset provides a record of bicycle traffic in upper Manhattan, specifically along 86th Street, various avenues, within Central Park, and on the greenways. Each row represents a year from 2007 to 2024, with columns detailing the number of cyclists observed at different locations. Key columns include 'year' and the counts for specific locations like 'hudson_river_greenway_b', 'riverside_drive_a', and avenues such as 'broadway_a' and '_5th_ave'. The 'total' column provides the aggregate count of cyclists across all locations for that year. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze trends in bicycle usage, evaluate the impact of infrastructure changes, and make informed decisions about transportation planning and resource allocation. The dataset offers insights into the popularity of different cycling routes and the overall growth of cycling as a mode of transportation in Manhattan. Note that data was not collected in all years.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains annual bicycle traffic counts in upper Manhattan from 2007 to 2024. It includes counts from various locations, such as the Hudson River Greenway, Riverside Drive, Broadway, 5th Avenue, Central Park, and other greenways. The data allows for analysis of cycling trends and route popularity over time.

Related Topics:

- Bicycle traffic: Bike counts, cyclist volume, bicycle ridership

Applications and Use Cases:

- Evaluate the impact of infrastructure changes on cycling traffic.
- Identify popular cycling routes.
- Inform transportation planning and resource allocation decisions.
- Compare cycling traffic across different locations in Manhattan.

- Assess the growth of cycling as a mode of transportation.

title: Enforcement Fines
ufd: This dataset contains information on enforcement actions taken by the NYC Conflicts of Interest Board (COIB) against public servants who violated the City's conflicts of interest law. Each row represents a specific case, identified by a unique case number and the name of the individual involved. The data includes the date of the action, the agency the public servant worked for, and details of the penalties imposed. Penalties can include fines paid to the COIB, suspensions, and other disciplinary actions. The dataset also notes if a 3-way settlement occurred. Researchers and the public can use this data to understand how the COIB enforces ethics regulations, the types of violations that occur, and the range of penalties applied. The dataset provides insight into the City's efforts to ensure integrity and accountability in public service.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details enforcement actions by the NYC Conflicts of Interest Board (COIB) regarding violations of the city's conflict of interest laws. It includes information on individual cases, such as the date of the action, the involved agency, and penalties imposed. The data offers insights into the COIB's enforcement practices and the types of ethical violations that occur within New York City government.

Related Topics:
- Ethics in government
- Public servant accountability
- Municipal law enforcement
- Conflict of interest regulations
- New York City government

- Conflicts of Interest Board (COIB)
- Enforcement actions: disciplinary actions, penalties, sanctions
- Public servants: city employees, government officials
- Violations: ethical breaches, misconduct, infractions
- Penalties: fines, suspensions, disciplinary measures
- 3-way settlement: agreement between COIB, public servant, and agency

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyzing trends in ethical violations within NYC government agencies.
- Evaluating the effectiveness of COIB enforcement actions.
- Identifying agencies with higher rates of conflict of interest violations.
- Researching the types and severity of penalties imposed for different violations.
- Comparing enforcement patterns across different time periods.

title: Parking Violations Issued - Fiscal Year 2016
ufd: This dataset contains information on parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2016 (July 1, 2015 to June 30, 2016). Each row represents a single parking ticket. Key details include the summons number, plate ID and registration state of the vehicle, the date the ticket was issued, and the violation code. The dataset also specifies the vehicle's body type and make, the issuing agency, and street codes indicating the location of the violation. Researchers and city planners could use this data to analyze parking violation patterns, identify areas with high violation rates, and understand the types of vehicles most frequently ticketed. Please note that the status of violations (paid, dismissed, etc.) is not reflected in this dataset; it only represents the violation at the time of issuance.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details parking violations issued in New York City during fiscal year 2016 (July 1, 2015 to June 30, 2016). Each record represents a single parking ticket, including information on the vehicle, violation details, and location. It offers a snapshot of parking violations at the time of issuance, without reflecting subsequent status changes.

**Related Topics:**

- Law Enforcement
- Municipal Government
- Public Safety
- Traffic Management

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Parking Violation: Parking Ticket, Summons, Citation, Notice of Violation
- Fiscal Year 2016: FY2016, July 1 2015 - June 30 2016
- Vehicle Information: Plate ID, Registration State, Make, Body Type
- Violation Details: Violation Code, Issue Date, Street Code, Issuing Agency

**Applications and Use Cases:**

- Understand the types of vehicles most frequently receiving parking tickets.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of existing parking regulations.
- Support urban planning initiatives related to parking and traffic flow.
- Predict future parking violation hotspots based on historical trends.

title: BUILDING_HISTORIC
ufd: This dataset provides a historical view of building footprints in New York City, offering insights into the city's evolving urban landscape. Each row represents a building footprint with its corresponding geographic location (`the_geom`), represented as a MultiPolygon. Key attributes include the Building Identification Number (`bin`), a unique identifier, and the Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications ID (`doitt_id`). The dataset also contains the area of the building footprint (`shape_area`), the base Building Block Lot (`base_bbl`), the years of construction and demolition (`construction_year`, `demolition_year`), the source of the geographic data (`geom_source`), and the date the record was last updated (`last_edited_date`). Researchers, urban planners, and developers can use this dataset to analyze historical building patterns, track urban development, and assess changes in the city's built environment over time. The dataset can be linked with other datasets using the `bin` or `doitt_id` to provide a more comprehensive understanding of buildings in New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains historical building footprints in New York City, providing a view of the city's urban development. Each record represents a building footprint with its geographic location, unique identifiers, and construction/demolition years. It allows users to analyze building patterns, track urban development, and assess changes in the city's built environment.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- Historical Data
- New York City
- Building Permits
- Real Estate
- Demographics

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Building Footprint: Building outline, building polygon, structure boundary
- Building Identification Number (BIN): BIN number, unique building ID
- Department of Information Technology and Telecommunications ID (DOITT_ID): DOITT ID, building identifier
- Shape Area: Building area, footprint size
- Base Building Block Lot (Base_BBL): BBL, lot number
- Construction Year: Year built, year of construction
- Demolition Year: Year demolished, year of demolition
- Geom Source: Geometry source, data source
- Last Edited Date: Update date, modification date

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze historical building patterns and urban sprawl in NYC.
- Track urban development and redevelopment projects over time.
- Assess changes in the city's built environment due to factors like zoning regulations or economic shifts.
- Link building footprints with other datasets (e.g., property records, census data) to gain a more comprehensive understanding of buildings and their surrounding areas.
- Identify areas with high rates of construction or demolition.
- Visualize building age and distribution across the city.
- Support urban planning initiatives and infrastructure development.

title: 2020-2021 Local Law 231 Training Data
ufd: This dataset contains information on LGBTQ+ training and resources in New York City schools during the 2020-2021 school year. It indicates whether a school has a Gender Sexuality Alliance (GSA) and the number of staff members who received LGBTQ+ training, broken down by teachers, administrators, and other staff. Each row represents a specific school, identified by its location code and name. The location category description specifies the school type (e.g., K-8, High school). Researchers and educators can use this data to understand the availability of LGBTQ+ support and training in different schools, identify areas where resources may be lacking, and assess the implementation of the Dignity for All Students Act. The dataset includes 100 rows, each representing a unique school.
sfd:

It includes information on Gender Sexuality Alliances (GSAs) and the number of staff members trained in LGBTQ+ issues, categorized by role (teachers, administrators, other staff). Each record represents a specific school, identified by location code and name, along with its school type.

title: NYC.gov Web Analytics
ufd: This dataset provides web traffic statistics for the top 2000 most visited pages on NYC.gov. It includes data from July 2015, offering a snapshot of online engagement with city services and information. Key columns include `page_views`, representing the number of times a page was viewed, `avg_view_time_sec`, indicating the average time spent on a page in seconds, and `visits`, which counts the number of distinct sessions during which a page was viewed. The `page` column contains the URL, and the `title` column provides the title of the webpage. Researchers and city planners could use this dataset to understand user interests, optimize website content, and improve the accessibility of online services. Analyzing page views and average view times can reveal which services are most popular and which may need improvement to better serve the public.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains web traffic statistics for the top 2000 most visited pages on NYC.gov during July 2015. It includes metrics such as page views, average view time, and visits for each page. The data offers insights into user engagement with city services and information available online.

Related Topics:

- Government websites
- User behavior

- Online engagement
- Website optimization

- Page views: website hits, impressions, page requests
- Visits: sessions, unique visitors

- Web traffic: website activity, online usage

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identify popular city services based on page views.

- Optimize website content based on average view time.

title: Sea Level Rise Maps (2100 100-year Floodplain)
ufd: This dataset depicts the 100-year floodplain for the year 2100, taking into account potential sea-level rise. It utilizes data from FEMA's Preliminary Work Maps and incorporates sea-level rise projections from the New York Panel on Climate Change. The dataset focuses on the impact of a 100-year flood event, considering a 75-inch sea-level rise. The key column, "the_geom," contains geospatial data representing the boundaries of the 100-year floodplain. This dataset can be used to visualize and analyze areas at high risk of flooding due to climate change. It is valuable for urban planning, risk assessment, and developing strategies to mitigate the effects of sea-level rise. The data was provided by the Mayor's Office of Long-Term Planning and Sustainability (OLTPS) on behalf of CUNY Institute for Sustainable Cities (CISC) and the New York Panel on Climate Change (NPCC).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset delineates the projected 100-year floodplain for the year 2100, incorporating sea-level rise estimates. It combines FEMA's Preliminary Work Maps with sea-level rise projections from the New York Panel on Climate Change, specifically modeling a 75-inch rise scenario. The primary feature is the geospatial data ("the_geom" column) representing the boundaries of the future floodplain.

Related Topics:
- Climate Change
- Sea-Level Rise
- Flood Risk
- Urban Planning
- Environmental Science
- Coastal Management
- Geospatial Analysis

Concepts and Synonyms:
- 100-year floodplain: 1% annual chance flood, base flood
- Sea-level rise: SLR, climate change impacts, coastal inundation
- Geospatial data: GIS data, spatial data, shapefiles, "the_geom"
- Flood risk assessment: vulnerability assessment, hazard mapping
- Climate change adaptation: resilience planning, mitigation strategies

Applications and Use Cases:
- Visualize areas at high risk of future flooding.
- Assess the impact of sea-level rise on coastal communities.
- Inform urban planning and infrastructure development decisions.
- Develop strategies to mitigate flood risk and enhance resilience.
- Support research on climate change impacts and adaptation measures.
- Identify vulnerable populations and prioritize resources.

title: NYC Bridge Strike Data
ufd: This dataset contains information about bridge strikes on New York City roadways with low clearances. Each record represents a single strike incident, including the date, borough, and the direction of travel on the main street where the incident occurred. The main street and cross street columns provide specific location details. Key details captured include whether the incident involved a truck route and if the overpass was struck. Researchers and city planners can use this data to identify high-risk areas for bridge strikes, analyze contributing factors, and implement preventative measures. The dataset also includes the state of the operator's license and latitude/longitude coordinates for precise incident mapping. The 'bin' column provides a unique identifier for each incident.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details bridge strike incidents on New York City roadways with low vertical clearances. Each entry represents a single incident, noting the date, borough, location (main and cross streets), and direction of travel. The data includes information on truck route involvement, overpass strikes, operator license state, and geographic coordinates.

Applications and Use Cases:

- Develop preventative measures to reduce bridge strike incidents.

- Inform urban planning and infrastructure improvements.
- Analyze trends in bridge strike incidents over time.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of existing bridge protection measures.

title: LinkNYC New Site Permit Applications
ufd: This dataset contains information on proposed locations for LinkNYC kiosks in New York City, including the newer Link5G models. Each row represents a specific site and its permit application status. Key details include the `site_id`, `planned_kiosk_type` (Link5G_Ad, Link5G_NonAd, or Link1.0), `installation_status_` (e.g., Planning, PreCx, Installed), and the `borough` and `council_district` where the kiosk is planned. Several date fields track the submission and comment periods related to the permit application process. The dataset also includes street addresses and cross streets to pinpoint the proposed kiosk location. Researchers and city planners can use this data to track the progress of LinkNYC deployments, analyze the distribution of kiosks across boroughs and council districts, and understand the timelines associated with the permitting process. The data could also be used by the public to identify proposed kiosk locations in their neighborhood and participate in the public comment process.

title: City Council Legislation: Bills and Local Laws
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive look into the legislative activities of the New York City Council from 1998 through 2024. It includes information on all introduced bills, regardless of whether they were ultimately enacted. Key details include the `matter_id` for each bill, its current `status` (e.g., Committee, Enacted), the assigned `file_num`, and the `primary_sponsor` (the Council Member who introduced the bill). The dataset also specifies the `committee` to which the bill was assigned, a brief `name` describing the bill's purpose, and important dates like the `intro_date` and `agenda_date`. Researchers, policy analysts, and engaged citizens can use this dataset to track the progress of legislation, understand the priorities of different Council Members and committees, and analyze trends in city governance. The `law_number` column indicates the official number assigned to enacted bills. By exploring this data, users can gain valuable insights into the legislative process and the issues shaping New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains detailed legislative information for the New York City Council from 1998 to 2024. It includes data on all introduced bills, their status, sponsors, committee assignments, and key dates. The data allows users to track legislation, analyze trends in city governance, and understand the priorities of council members.
