title: Parking Permit for People with Disabilities (PPPD) - State
ufd: This dataset contains information about Parking Permits for People with Disabilities (PPPD) in New York State. These permits are issued to individuals certified by a physician as having a disability that severely affects their ability to walk long distances. Each record includes a unique `permit_tag`, the `effective_date` and `expiration_date` of the permit, and application and permit statuses. The `appl_date` indicates when the permit application was submitted. The `status` and `status_1` columns provide information on the permit's current state, with all permits in this sample having a status of "A" and "C" respectively. This dataset could be used to analyze the issuance and management of disability parking permits, though the limited variability in some columns in this sample may restrict certain analyses. Researchers or policymakers could use this data to understand trends in permit applications and renewals.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details Parking Permits for People with Disabilities (PPPD) issued in New York State. Each record includes a unique permit identifier (`permit_tag`), the effective and expiration dates of the permit, the application date, and permit statuses. The data provides a snapshot of permit issuance and management, although some status fields exhibit limited variability in this sample.

Related Topics:
- Disability Rights
- Accessibility
- Urban Planning
- Transportation Policy
- Government Services

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Parking Permit for People with Disabilities (PPPD): Disabled Parking Permit, Handicap Parking Permit, Accessibility Parking Placard
- Effective Date: Start Date, Issue Date
- Expiration Date: End Date, Renewal Date
- Application Date: Appl_date, Submission Date
- Permit Status: Status, Permit Condition, Active/Inactive

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in disability parking permit applications and renewals over time.
- Investigate the duration of permit validity.
- Identify potential areas for improvement in the permit application process.
- Examine the geographic distribution of permit holders (requires additional location data not present in this sample).

title: Agency Spending by Budget Function
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look into the planned spending of city agencies, focusing on how funds are allocated across different budget functions. Updated three times a year, it offers insights into the financial planning of agencies like the Police Department and the Department of Youth & Community Development. Key columns include `agency_name`, specifying the agency, `budget_function`, detailing the area of spending (e.g., Patrol Borough Brooklyn South), and `plan_amount_year_1` and `plan_amount_year_2`, showing the planned spending for the next two fiscal years. The `spending_type_description` column further breaks down the type of expenditure, such as "UNIFORM" or "ADDITIONAL GROSS PAY". Users can analyze this data to understand city budget allocations, track spending trends within specific agencies or budget functions, and compare planned spending across different years. This information can be valuable for city planners, budget analysts, and residents interested in government spending transparency. The data includes both spending and headcount information.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains planned spending information for city agencies, broken down by budget function and spending type. It includes planned spending amounts for the next two fiscal years, along with agency names and headcount data. The data is updated three times a year, providing a current view of city budget allocations.

Related Topics:
- City Budget
- Government Spending
- Municipal Finance
- Public Sector Economics
- Agency Performance
- Headcount
- Budget Planning

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Agency Name: Department, Bureau, Division
- Budget Function: Spending Category, Program Area, Expenditure Type
- Plan Amount: Budgeted Amount, Projected Spending, Estimated Cost
- Spending Type Description: Expenditure Detail, Cost Category, Item Description
- Headcount: Number of Employees, Staffing Levels, Personnel Count
- Fiscal Year: Budget Year, Financial Year

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze budget allocations across different city agencies.
- Track spending trends within specific budget functions over time.
- Compare planned spending amounts between different fiscal years.
- Identify areas where spending is increasing or decreasing.
- Evaluate the financial planning of specific city agencies.
- Assess the impact of budget decisions on agency staffing levels.
- Predict future spending based on historical trends.
- Compare planned spending to actual spending (if actual spending data is available elsewhere).

title: Sidewalk Management Database - Inspection
ufd: This dataset contains information about sidewalk inspections conducted by the New York City Department of Transportation (DOT). It tracks inspections, violations, and the status of sidewalks in NYC. Key columns include `inspectionid`, a unique identifier for each inspection, `inspectiondate`, the date the inspection was performed, and boolean-like columns indicating whether a violation was found (`noviolationfound`), whether the city will address the issue (`citydoit`), or if the owner will be responsible (`ownerwilldoit`). The dataset also indicates if the inspection was initiated through a 311 service request (`is_311_inspection`). Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze sidewalk conditions across the city, identify areas with frequent violations, and track the resolution of sidewalk defects. The `damageid` and `damagetypecode` columns provide insights into the types of damage observed during inspections.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details sidewalk inspections performed by the NYC DOT, encompassing inspection dates, violation statuses, and responsibility assignments for repairs (city or owner). It includes information on damage types and whether inspections originated from 311 service requests. This data enables analysis of sidewalk conditions, violation patterns, and repair progress across New York City.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- Public Works
- Infrastructure Management
- City Services
- 311 Service Requests
- Transportation Safety
- Pavement Management

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Sidewalk Inspection: Pavement assessment, walkway survey, pedestrian path examination
- Violation: Defect, infraction, non-compliance
- 311 Inspection: Citizen request, service request inspection, complaint-driven inspection
- Damage Type: Defect category, pavement condition, sidewalk issue
- City Responsibility: DOT repair, municipal maintenance, city-funded fix
- Owner Responsibility: Private repair, property owner maintenance, homeowner fix

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identify areas with high rates of sidewalk violations.
- Analyze the correlation between 311 requests and sidewalk inspection outcomes.
- Track the time it takes to resolve sidewalk defects, comparing city vs. owner repairs.
- Predict future sidewalk maintenance needs based on damage types and inspection history.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of sidewalk maintenance programs.
- Visualize sidewalk conditions across different neighborhoods in NYC.

title: Beach Water Samples
ufd: This dataset contains information about beach water quality in New York City, collected as part of the DOHMH's Beach Surveillance and Monitoring Program. It includes enterococci measurements from water samples taken at various beaches between April and September. Key columns include the `sample_date`, `beach_name`, `sample_location` (e.g., left, center, right), and `enterococci_results`, which measures the level of enterococci bacteria in MPN/100 ml. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to monitor beach water quality, identify potential health risks, and assess the effectiveness of environmental management practices. The data spans 100 rows and includes 35 unique beach names. The enterococci results range from 9.9 to 171.0 MPN/100 ml.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset provides beach water quality data collected in New York City as part of the DOHMH's monitoring program. It contains enterococci measurements from water samples taken at various beaches between April and September. The data includes the date, beach name, sample location, and enterococci results (MPN/100 ml).

**Related Topics:**
*   Water Quality
*   Environmental Health
*   Public Health
*   Beaches
*   Microbiology
*   New York City

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
*   Enterococci: fecal indicator bacteria, intestinal bacteria
*   MPN/100 ml: Most Probable Number per 100 milliliters, measurement unit
*   Beach Water Quality: recreational water quality, coastal water quality
*   DOHMH: Department of Health and Mental Hygiene
*   Beach Surveillance and Monitoring Program: water sampling program

**Applications and Use Cases:**
*   Monitoring beach water quality trends over time.
*   Identifying beaches with consistently high enterococci levels.
*   Assessing the impact of rainfall or other environmental factors on water quality.
*   Developing predictive models for enterococci levels.
*   Evaluating the effectiveness of beach management practices.
*   Informing public health advisories and beach closures.

title: Inmate Assault on Staff
ufd: This dataset contains information about inmate assaults on staff, specifically incidents resulting in the use of force. Each row represents a single incident, with a unique `incident_id` and the `reported_dt` indicating when the incident was reported. The dataset specifies that the `incident_type` is "Use of Force" and the `reason` is "Assault on Staff" for all entries. This data could be used to analyze the frequency and patterns of assaults on staff within a correctional facility. Researchers or public safety officials might use this information to develop strategies for improving staff safety and reducing the number of incidents. The dataset includes 100 records.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details 100 instances of inmate assaults on staff within a correctional facility, all classified as "Use of Force" incidents. Each record includes a unique incident ID and the date the incident was reported. The dataset focuses specifically on incidents where the reason for the use of force was an assault on staff.

**Related Topics:**
- Correctional Facilities
- Inmate Behavior
- Staff Safety
- Use of Force
- Incident Reporting
- Public Safety
- Law Enforcement
- Prison Violence

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Inmate Assault: Prisoner attack, offender aggression, detainee violence
- Use of Force: Physical intervention, restraint, control techniques
- Staff: Correctional officer, employee, personnel
- Incident: Event, occurrence, episode
- Reported Date: Date of record, filing date, notification date
- Correctional Facility: Prison, jail, penitentiary, detention center

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Analyze trends in inmate assaults on staff over time.
- Identify potential risk factors associated with these incidents.
- Develop and evaluate strategies to improve staff safety in correctional facilities.
- Inform training programs for correctional officers on de-escalation and self-defense techniques.
- Track the frequency of use of force incidents related to staff assaults.
- Compare incident rates across different correctional facilities (if combined with other datasets).

title: 2020-2021 Student Discipline Annual Report - All
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at student discipline in temporary housing for the 2020-2021 school year. It includes information on removals, suspensions, and expulsions, as well as interventions by principals and superintendents. Each row represents a specific school, identified by its system code and location name, along with its location category (e.g., Elementary, High School). The dataset also includes the administrative district code for each school. Key columns for analysis include 'total_removals_suspensions' and 'expulsions', which quantify disciplinary actions. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to understand disciplinary trends, identify potential disparities, and evaluate the effectiveness of different intervention strategies in schools. The 'principal' and 'superintendent' columns indicate whether these roles were involved in disciplinary actions.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details student discipline incidents within temporary housing during the 2020-2021 school year. It covers removals, suspensions, and expulsions, along with principal and superintendent interventions. Data is organized by school, identified by system code and location name, allowing for analysis of disciplinary trends and intervention effectiveness.

Related Topics:

- Student suspensions

- Educational policy
- Student demographics

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Removals: Exclusion, time-out, disciplinary removal
- Suspensions: Out-of-school suspension (OSS), in-school suspension (ISS)
- Expulsions: Permanent removal, dismissal
- Temporary Housing: Homelessness, unstable housing, transitional living
- Interventions: Support services, disciplinary actions, remediation
- System Code: School ID, district code
- Location Name: School name, institution name

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze disciplinary disparities among students in temporary housing.
- Evaluate the impact of principal and superintendent involvement on disciplinary outcomes.
- Identify schools with high rates of removals, suspensions, and expulsions.
- Develop and assess the effectiveness of targeted interventions for students in temporary housing.
- Inform educational policy related to student discipline and support services.
- Compare disciplinary trends across different school districts.

title: NYC Veteran Owned Businesses
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of Veteran Owned Businesses operating in New York City. It includes valuable contact information such as business name, address, phone number, and the services they offer, ranging from construction to photography. The dataset also specifies the borough, city, state, and zip code for each business, enabling location-based analysis and targeted outreach. Furthermore, it lists any certifications the business holds, such as NYS SDVOB or NYC MBE. This information can be used to identify and support veteran-owned businesses in specific sectors or locations within NYC. Researchers, city planners, and consumers can leverage this dataset to understand the landscape of veteran-owned businesses and promote economic opportunities within this community. The dataset contains 100 rows and 27 columns.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a directory of Veteran Owned Businesses in New York City, providing key contact information and business details. It includes location data (borough, city, state, zip code) and certification information (e.g., NYS SDVOB, NYC MBE). The data allows for analysis of the veteran-owned business landscape in NYC and targeted support initiatives.

Related Topics:

title: NYCDEP Recreation Area Maps
ufd: This dataset provides information on recreation areas managed by the NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP). Each row represents a specific recreation unit, identified by its name and acreage. Key details include the county and town where the unit is located, as well as the Wildlife Management Unit (WMU) it falls within. The dataset also indicates whether a permit is required for access and provides a URL to a map of the area. Users can leverage this data to find recreation areas based on location, size, or permit requirements. Hunters can use the WMU information to verify hunting regulations. The `lastmodifi` column indicates when the data was last updated.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details recreation areas managed by the NYC Department of Environmental Protection (DEP), offering information on location, size, and permit requirements. Each entry represents a specific recreation unit, including its name, acreage, county, town, and Wildlife Management Unit (WMU). The dataset also provides permit information and a URL to a map of the area.

**Related Topics:**
- Recreation
- Environmental Management
- Wildlife Management
- Land Use
- New York City
- Department of Environmental Protection (DEP)
- Hunting Regulations
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Recreation Area: park, preserve, open space, recreational unit
- Wildlife Management Unit (WMU): hunting zone, game management area, wildlife area
- Acreage: size, area, land area
- Permit: license, authorization, access pass
- Location: county, town, geographic location
- DEP: Department of Environmental Protection, NYCDEP

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Identify recreation areas near a specific town or county.
- Determine if a permit is required for access to a particular recreation area.
- Find recreation areas within a specific Wildlife Management Unit (WMU) for hunting purposes.
- Analyze the distribution of recreation areas across different counties.
- Calculate the total acreage of recreation areas managed by the NYC DEP.
- Develop a map or application showing the locations and details of these recreation areas.
- Track changes in recreation area data over time using the `lastmodifi` column.

title: Location of Disposal Facilities and Sites Used for DSNY-Managed Waste
ufd: This dataset provides locations of disposal facilities and sites used for waste managed by the New York City Department of Sanitation (DSNY). It includes the name, address, and geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) of each facility. Key columns include "name" for the facility name, "type" indicating the type of facility (e.g., Landfill (LF), Transfer Station (TS), Waste-to-Energy (WTE), Marine Transfer Station (MTS)), "borough_city" for the city where the facility is located, and "state" and "zipcode" for location information. The dataset also contains computed region identifiers. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this data to understand waste management infrastructure, analyze facility distribution, and assess environmental impact. The location data can be used for mapping and spatial analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations of waste disposal facilities managed by the New York City Department of Sanitation (DSNY). It includes facility names, addresses, geographic coordinates, and types (e.g., Landfill, Transfer Station). The data allows users to understand the distribution of waste management infrastructure across New York City.

Related Topics:

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Disposal Facilities: Waste disposal sites, recycling centers, landfills, transfer stations

- Waste Management Infrastructure: Sanitation facilities, waste processing locations
- Geographic Coordinates: Latitude, longitude, spatial data
- Borough: City, region, district

Applications and Use Cases:
- Mapping and spatial analysis of waste disposal facilities.
- Analyzing the distribution of different types of waste management facilities across NYC.
- Assessing the environmental impact of waste disposal sites.
- Planning for future waste management infrastructure needs.
- Identifying areas with limited access to waste disposal services.

title: Lottery Applications for Tobacco Retail Dealer (TRD) and Electronic Cigarette Dealer Licenses (ECD)
ufd: This dataset contains information about lottery applications for Tobacco Retail Dealer licenses in New York City. It includes details on the application process, such as the application submission date, lottery application order, and lottery priority number. Key columns include the applicant name, record type, lottery selection date, and an indicator of whether the applicant was selected from the lottery. The dataset also provides location information like city, zip code, borough, and community district. Researchers and business analysts can use this data to understand the distribution of tobacco retail dealer licenses across different communities, analyze the lottery selection process, and identify trends in application submissions. The Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP) uses this data to manage and regulate tobacco retail dealer licenses within the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details lottery applications for Tobacco Retail Dealer licenses in New York City. It includes application submission dates, lottery order, priority numbers, and applicant details. The data also contains location information such as city, zip code, borough, and community district.

  - Lottery Application: License Application, Permit Application
  - Lottery Selection: License Award, Permit Approval
  - DCWP: Department of Consumer and Worker Protection
  - Borough: County, District
  - Community District: Neighborhood, Local Area

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Analyze the geographic distribution of tobacco retail licenses in NYC.
  - Evaluate the fairness and efficiency of the lottery selection process.
  - Identify trends in tobacco retail license applications over time.
  - Understand the demographics of tobacco retail license applicants.
  - Support regulatory oversight and compliance efforts by the DCWP.
  - Predict future demand for tobacco retail licenses.

title: 2020-21 Guidance Counselor/Social Worker Data - Demographic, Post Secondary
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at guidance counselor and social worker resources within New York City Department of Education schools for the 2020-2021 school year. It includes information on the number of guidance counselors and social workers in each school, broken down by full-time, part-time, and bilingual roles. The dataset also specifies the type of school (e.g., elementary, high school) using the 'location_type' column. Key columns include 'total_guidance_counselors', 'total_gc' (likely representing total guidance counselor count), and 'total_sw' (total social worker count). Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze the distribution of student support staff across different school types and identify potential resource gaps. The dataset also contains information on specific program designations and additional support services offered at each school. This allows for a comprehensive understanding of the support systems available to students in NYC public schools.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the distribution of guidance counselors and social workers in New York City Department of Education schools during the 2020-2021 school year. It provides counts of full-time, part-time, and bilingual staff, along with school type ('location_type'). The data allows for analysis of student support resource allocation across different school settings.

Related Topics:
- School Resources
- Student Support Services
- Education Policy
- New York City Education
- School Staffing
- Mental Health in Schools

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Guidance Counselors: School Counselors, College Counselors, GC
- Social Workers: School Social Workers, SW
- Location Type: School Type, Elementary School, High School, K-8 School
- Bilingual: Multilingual, Language Support
- Full-time: FTE (Full-Time Equivalent)
- Part-time: PTE (Part-Time Equivalent)

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the ratio of guidance counselors and social workers to students in different school types.
- Identify schools with potential shortages of student support staff.
- Evaluate the distribution of bilingual counselors and social workers across schools with diverse student populations.
- Inform policy decisions related to resource allocation for student support services.
- Research the impact of guidance counselor and social worker availability on student outcomes.

title: Electric Vehicle (EV) Charging Data- Municipal Lots and Garages
ufd: This dataset contains information about electric vehicle (EV) charging sessions at New York City municipal lots and garages. Each row represents a single charging session, including the date, station name, and location of the charging point. Key columns include `charge_box_id` which identifies the specific charging box used, `driver_id` which identifies the driver using the charging station, and `connected_time` and `disconnected_time` which indicate the start and end times of the charging session. The dataset also provides information on the duration of the charge (`charge_duration_min`) and the amount of energy provided (`energy_provided_kwh`). This data could be used to analyze EV charging patterns, optimize the placement of charging stations, and understand the energy consumption of electric vehicles in New York City. The `session_status` column indicates whether the session was paid or through roaming.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details electric vehicle (EV) charging sessions at New York City municipal lots and garages. Each entry represents a single charging event, recording details such as the charging station ID, driver ID, connection and disconnection times, charge duration, and energy provided. The data also includes information on the session status, indicating whether the session was paid or through roaming.

Related Topics:
- Electric Vehicles (EVs)
- Charging Infrastructure
- Energy Consumption
- Transportation Planning
- Urban Mobility
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Charging Session: EV charging event, charging transaction
- Charge Box ID: Charging station identifier, EVSE ID
- Driver ID: User ID, EV driver identifier
- Connected Time: Start time, charging start
- Disconnected Time: End time, charging end
- Charge Duration: Session length, charging time
- Energy Provided: Kilowatt-hours (kWh), electricity delivered
- Session Status: Payment type, roaming status

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze EV charging behavior and patterns in NYC.
- Optimize the location and deployment of EV charging stations.
- Understand energy consumption patterns of EVs.
- Evaluate the utilization of existing charging infrastructure.
- Develop predictive models for charging demand.
- Study the impact of EV adoption on the energy grid.

title: Historic Land Use Data
ufd: This dataset provides a historical view of land use on specific lots in New York City that were vacant, privately owned, and zoned for manufacturing as of 2009. It compiles information gathered from historical Sanborn maps, spanning over 100 years, to identify industrial uses and potential environmental contamination. The key columns include 'bbl' and '_2021_bbl', both representing the building identification number for a tax lot, 'facility_type' indicating the type of facility present, 'environmental_concern' noting any potential environmental issues, and 'map_year' specifying the year of the map from which the data was extracted. Researchers and urban planners can use this dataset to analyze historical land use patterns, assess potential environmental risks associated with past industrial activities, and inform current land management and development strategies. The 'comments_string' column provides additional context and details about the land use observed on the maps. This dataset offers a valuable resource for understanding the environmental history of specific locations within New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset documents the historical land use of vacant, privately owned, manufacturing-zoned lots in New York City, as of 2009. It leverages historical Sanborn maps to identify industrial activities and potential environmental concerns over a century. Key data points include building identification numbers (BBLs), facility types, environmental concerns, and the year of the source map.

Related Topics:
- Environmental History
- Urban Planning
- Land Use
- Industrial Sites
- Environmental Contamination
- New York City
- Sanborn Maps

Concepts and Synonyms:
- BBL: Building Identification Number, Tax Lot Number
- Facility Type: Industrial Use, Land Use Category, Business Type
- Environmental Concern: Potential Contamination, Pollution Risk, Hazard
- Map Year: Sanborn Map Date, Historical Record Year
- Vacant Land: Undeveloped Property, Empty Lot
- Sanborn Maps: Historical Fire Insurance Maps, Land Use Records

Applications and Use Cases:
- Assessing potential environmental risks associated with historical industrial land use.
- Analyzing changes in land use patterns over time in specific areas of New York City.
- Informing urban planning and land management decisions.
- Identifying sites for environmental remediation or further investigation.
- Researching the environmental history of specific locations.
- Supporting brownfield redevelopment initiatives.

title: 2020-2021 Co-Location Report
ufd: This dataset provides insights into co-located schools in New York City for the 2020-2021 school year. It includes information on school demographics, enrollment, and academic performance. Key columns include `school_name`, `district`, `total_enrollment`, and enrollment figures for different grade levels (`grades_3k_5_enrollment`, `grades_6_8_enrollment`, `grades_9_12_enrollment`). Demographic data, such as the percentage of students identifying as Asian, Black, Hispanic, Multiracial, Native American, and White, is also included. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze the composition and performance of co-located schools, identify trends, and inform decisions related to resource allocation and educational equity. The `building_id_s` column identifies the building the school is located in, and the `transfer_school` column indicates whether the school is a transfer school. Data on students with disabilities (`swd`), English language learners (`ell`), and poverty levels are also available.
sfd:

title: Headcount Actuals By Funding Source
ufd: This dataset provides headcount actuals by funding source for New York City government agencies. It includes the publication date (`pub_dt`), fiscal year (`fisc_yr`), agency code (`agy_cd`), agency name (`agy_nm`), funding source (`fnding`), and headcount (`hc`). The funding source indicates whether the funding is from the city or a non-city source. The headcount represents the actual full-time and full-time equivalent headcount. This dataset can be used to analyze staffing levels across different city agencies and funding sources. Researchers and city planners can use this data to understand how city resources are allocated and to track changes in agency staffing over time.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains headcount information for New York City government agencies, broken down by funding source (city vs. non-city). It includes data on agency code, agency name, fiscal year, publication date, funding source, and the actual headcount. This data allows for analysis of staffing levels and resource allocation across different city agencies.

title: EquityNYC Data (Previously Social Indicator Report Data)
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the economic, social, and health landscape of New York City. It includes data on various social indicators, such as ActionNYC service recipients, ACS family service recipients, and applications for DHE and SCHE benefits. The data is organized by domain (e.g., Economic Security and Mobility, Housing), and agency (e.g., Department of Finance, Department of Homeless Services). Key dimensions like income, gender, race/ethnicity, and age are used to categorize the data. The `value` column represents the measured quantity for each indicator, with units specified as either individuals or families. Researchers and policymakers can use this dataset to analyze trends, identify disparities, and evaluate the impact of social programs across different segments of the population in NYC. The data spans from 2019 to 2021 and is presented as either calendar year totals or point-in-time measurements.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains social indicators for New York City, covering economic, social, and health aspects. It includes data on service recipients and benefit applications, categorized by domain, agency, and demographic dimensions like income, gender, and race/ethnicity. The data spans from 2019 to 2021 and provides insights into social program impact and disparities across NYC.

- Demographic Dimensions: Population characteristics, socioeconomic factors, group attributes

- Housing: Affordable housing, homelessness, housing assistance
- ActionNYC: Immigration legal services, immigrant support, NYC immigration
- ACS Family Services: Child welfare, family support, child protective services
- DHE/SCHE: Department of Health and Environmental Control, Senior Citizen Home Exemption, NYC tax exemptions

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in social service utilization across different demographic groups in NYC.
- Identify disparities in access to social programs based on income, gender, or race/ethnicity.
- Evaluate the impact of specific social programs on economic security, housing stability, or health outcomes.
- Track changes in social indicators over time (2019-2021) to assess the effects of policy changes or external events.
- Compare social service needs and outcomes across different neighborhoods or boroughs in NYC.

title: Agency Voter Registration Activity
ufd: This dataset provides insights into voter registration efforts by New York City agencies. It tracks the number of voter registration applications distributed by each agency, as well as the number of applications sent to the Board of Elections by agency staff. You can also see how many staff members each agency trained to distribute voter registration applications. The dataset indicates whether each agency includes a link to voting.nyc on its website and, if so, the number of clicks that link received during the reporting period. Key columns include "agency," the name of the city agency; "applications_distributed," the number of applications given out; and "web_clicks," measuring traffic to the voting.nyc website from the agency's page. This data could be used to assess agency participation in voter registration drives, identify agencies that could benefit from additional resources, and measure the effectiveness of online voter registration promotion. The reporting periods are typically six months long.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details voter registration activities undertaken by New York City agencies. It includes metrics on voter registration applications distributed, applications submitted to the Board of Elections, and staff training for voter registration. The data also captures website link inclusion and click-through rates to voting.nyc, providing a comprehensive view of agency-level voter outreach efforts.

Related Topics:
- Voter Registration
- Civic Engagement
- Government Transparency
- New York City
- Elections
- Public Administration

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Voter Registration Applications: Voter forms, registration documents
- Agency: Department, Bureau, City Office
- Applications Distributed: Forms given out, outreach materials
- Web Clicks: Link clicks, website traffic, referral traffic
- Board of Elections: BOE, Election Authority
- Reporting Period: Timeframe, duration, cycle

Applications and Use Cases:
- Evaluate the effectiveness of different city agencies in voter registration.
- Identify agencies with low application distribution or web click rates for targeted support.
- Analyze trends in voter registration across different reporting periods.
- Compare the impact of staff training on application distribution.
- Assess the reach of the voting.nyc website through agency referrals.

title: 2010 Census Tract to Neighborhood Tabulation Area Equivalency table
ufd: This dataset provides a mapping between 2010 Census Tracts and Neighborhood Tabulation Areas (NTAs) in New York City. It was created to project populations at the NTA level for PlaNYC, New York City's long-term sustainability plan. The dataset includes the borough, FIPS county code, NYC borough code, 2010 Census Tract, PUMA (Public Use Microdata Area), NTA code, and NTA name. Key columns include `neighborhood_tabulation_area_nta_code` and `neighborhood_tabulation_area_nta_name`, which identify specific neighborhoods within the city. The `_2010_census_tract` column provides the corresponding census tract. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze population data at a neighborhood level, understand the relationship between census tracts and NTAs, or perform spatial analysis. The data is limited to the Bronx in this sample, but the full dataset covers all of New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset maps 2010 Census Tracts to Neighborhood Tabulation Areas (NTAs) in New York City. It facilitates population projection at the NTA level, originally for PlaNYC. The dataset includes geographic identifiers like borough, census tract, PUMA, NTA code, and NTA name, enabling analysis at the neighborhood level.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- Demographics
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- New York City
- Census Data
- Population Analysis

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Neighborhood Tabulation Area (NTA)
- Census Tract
- PUMA (Public Use Microdata Area)
- FIPS Code
- Borough
- Geographic Boundaries
- Population Projection
- Spatial Analysis

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyzing population distribution within NYC neighborhoods.
- Converting data between census tracts and NTAs.
- Performing spatial analysis using neighborhood-level data.
- Supporting urban planning initiatives and research.
- Understanding the relationship between census tracts and neighborhood boundaries.

title: Parks Trails
ufd:
This dataset provides information about trails in designated Forever Wild areas of NYC Parks. It includes details on 100 trails, such as the park they are located in, their width, and surface type (e.g., dirt, gravel, paved). The dataset also classifies trails based on their development level (Class II to Class V) and general topography (level, wavy, or sloped).

Key columns include `park_name`, `width_ft`, `class`, `surface`, `gen_topog`, and `difficulty`, offering a comprehensive overview of each trail's characteristics. The `trailmarkersinstalled` column indicates whether trail markers are present. This dataset could be used by park visitors to plan their routes based on difficulty, surface type, or desired park.  Researchers could also use this data to analyze trail characteristics across different parks.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the characteristics of 100 trails within Forever Wild areas of NYC Parks. It includes information on trail location (park name), physical attributes like width and surface type, and classifications based on development level and topography. Key features include trail difficulty and the presence of trail markers, providing a comprehensive overview for park users and researchers.

Related Topics:
- Hiking Trails
- Urban Parks
- Environmental Conservation
- Recreation
- New York City
- Park Management

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Trail: Path, Route, Track, Way
- Park: Green space, Recreation area, Preserve
- Surface Type: Trail material, Ground cover (e.g., dirt, gravel, paved)
- Topography: Terrain, Landscape, Elevation (e.g., level, wavy, sloped)
- Difficulty: Trail rating, Challenge level, Ease of use
- Trail Markers: Signage, Wayfinding, Trail blazes

Applications and Use Cases:
- Planning hiking routes based on difficulty, surface, and park location.
- Analyzing trail characteristics across different NYC parks.
- Assessing the accessibility and suitability of trails for different user groups.
- Mapping and visualizing trail networks within Forever Wild areas.
- Informing park management and maintenance decisions.

title: DEP Green Infrastructure (Medians)
ufd: This dataset provides detailed information on green infrastructure practices implemented within medians across New York City. Managed by the NYC Department of Environmental Protection and updated monthly, it pinpoints the locations of these green spaces, which are designed to capture stormwater runoff from streets and sidewalks, reducing sewer system overflows and local flooding. Key details include the location (the_geom), project name (project_na), asset type (asset_type), and current status of each green infrastructure project. Researchers, urban planners, and environmental advocates can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of green infrastructure, assess its impact on stormwater management, and inform future greening initiatives. The dataset also includes identifiers for each asset (asset_id, gi_id) and information on the responsible department or contractor (dep_contra, dep_cont_1).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset catalogs green infrastructure projects located in medians throughout New York City. It details the location, type, status, and responsible parties for each project, which are designed to manage stormwater runoff. Updated monthly by the NYC Department of Environmental Protection, the data supports analysis of green infrastructure distribution and impact on stormwater management.

Related Topics:
- Green Infrastructure
- Stormwater Management
- Urban Planning
- Environmental Protection
- New York City
- Public Works

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Green Infrastructure: GI, Sustainable Urban Drainage Systems (SUDS), Low Impact Development (LID)
- Stormwater Runoff: Surface runoff, rainwater runoff, urban runoff
- Medians: Traffic islands, center dividers, road islands
- Asset Type: Project type, infrastructure category, green space designation
- Project Status: Implementation phase, operational status, maintenance status

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the spatial distribution of green infrastructure in NYC medians.
- Assess the effectiveness of green infrastructure in reducing stormwater runoff and sewer overflows.
- Identify areas with high potential for new green infrastructure projects.
- Track the maintenance and performance of existing green infrastructure assets.
- Support urban planning and environmental advocacy efforts related to green spaces.

title: Ready NY Events
ufd: This dataset contains information about Ready NY events, which aim to increase emergency preparedness awareness across New York City's five boroughs. Each row represents a specific event, detailing the date, start and end times, event type (e.g., RNY General Presentation, RNY for Kids, RNY Fair), and the specific event topic, such as "Winter Storm Prep" or "Youth Preparedness". The dataset also includes the borough where the event took place, the event location and address, and the number of actual participants. Location information is further specified with postcode, latitude, and longitude. Researchers and public safety officials can use this data to analyze the reach and impact of Ready NY events, identify areas with high or low participation, and optimize future event planning and resource allocation. By examining event types and topics, one can understand community interests and tailor preparedness programs accordingly.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details Ready NY events held across New York City, focusing on emergency preparedness. It includes information on event dates, times, types, topics, location details (borough, address, postcode, latitude, longitude), and participant counts. The data allows for analysis of event effectiveness and community engagement in emergency preparedness initiatives.

Related Topics:
- Emergency Preparedness
- Public Health
- Disaster Response
- Community Outreach
- New York City
- Public Events

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Ready NY: Emergency preparedness program, NYC preparedness initiative
- Event Type: Presentation, Fair, Workshop, Training
- Event Topic: Winter Storm Prep, Hurricane Preparedness, Fire Safety, Youth Preparedness
- Borough: Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island
- Participant Count: Attendance, Number of attendees, Event participation

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the geographic distribution of Ready NY events and identify underserved areas.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of different event types and topics in attracting participants.
- Track trends in community interest in specific emergency preparedness topics.
- Optimize resource allocation for future Ready NY events based on past performance.
- Develop targeted preparedness campaigns based on borough-specific needs and interests.
- Assess the impact of Ready NY events on community resilience and preparedness levels.

title: Suitability of City-Owned and Leased Property for Urban Agriculture (LL 48 of 2011)
ufd: This dataset contains information about city-owned and leased properties in New York City, fulfilling the requirements of Local Law 48 of 2011. It includes details such as the borough, block, and lot number (BBL) to uniquely identify each property, along with its address and parcel name. The dataset also specifies the agency responsible for the property and its current uses. Key metrics include the total area of the parcel and the total gross area of structures on the property. Furthermore, the dataset provides insights into the suitability of these parcels for urban agriculture, as assessed by the Department of Parks and Recreation. Researchers, urban planners, and community organizations can use this data to identify potential sites for urban agriculture, analyze land use patterns, and understand the distribution of city-owned properties. The presence of open petroleum spills or government clean-up programs is also noted, which could be relevant for environmental assessments and remediation efforts.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides a comprehensive inventory of city-owned and leased properties in New York City, as mandated by Local Law 48 of 2011. It includes detailed information on property identification (BBL, address), responsible agency, current uses, and size metrics (parcel area, gross area). The dataset also features assessments of urban agriculture suitability and environmental considerations like petroleum spills.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- Real Estate
- Government Assets
- Environmental Assessment
- Urban Agriculture
- Land Use
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Borough, Block, Lot (BBL): Property identifier, land parcel code
- Parcel: Property, land area, tract
- Gross Area: Building size, total floor space
- Urban Agriculture: Community gardens, urban farming, local food production
- Petroleum Spill: Oil leak, environmental contamination, pollution
- Government Clean-up Programs: Remediation efforts, environmental restoration, hazard mitigation

Applications and Use Cases:

- Assessing environmental risks associated with city-owned land.
- Supporting urban planning and development projects.
- Evaluating the efficiency of government asset management.
- Mapping and visualizing city-owned properties.

title: Citywide Mobility Survey - October 2020
ufd: This dataset comes from the Citywide Mobility Survey conducted by the NYC DOT in October 2020. It explores how residents traveled and used public spaces during the pandemic. The data includes detailed information on individual travel behavior, focusing on modes of transportation and trip purposes. Key columns include `person_id` and `hh_id` for identifying individuals and households, `bike_num_days` indicating the number of days a person used a bike, and several `bike_purpose_*` columns specifying the purpose of bike trips, such as recreation, grocery shopping, or commuting to work. The dataset also contains information about shopping habits, including food purchases and delivery services. Researchers and urban planners can use this dataset to analyze mobility patterns, understand the impact of the pandemic on transportation choices, and inform policies related to cycling infrastructure and public space usage. The values of 995 in many of the bike purpose columns likely represent a "no" or "not applicable" response.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The NYC DOT Citywide Mobility Survey from October 2020 provides insights into travel behavior and public space usage during the COVID-19 pandemic. The dataset details individual transportation choices, focusing on modes like biking and trip purposes. It includes information on demographics, travel habits, and shopping behaviors, offering a comprehensive view of mobility patterns in New York City.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- Transportation
- Public Health
- Demographics
- Survey Data
- COVID-19 Impact
- Cycling Infrastructure
- Public Space Usage

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Mobility Survey: Travel survey, transportation study, movement patterns
- Bike Purpose: Cycling reason, trip motivation, biking activity
- Person ID: Individual identifier, respondent ID, unique person code
- Household ID: HH ID, family identifier, dwelling unit code
- Transportation Modes: Travel methods, commuting options, transit types

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the impact of the pandemic on cycling habits in NYC.
- Identify key factors influencing transportation choices during the pandemic.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of cycling infrastructure and public space design.
- Inform urban planning policies related to sustainable transportation.
- Model and predict future transportation demand based on pandemic-era trends.

title: 2019 - 2020 School Year Local Law 226 Report for the Demographics of School Staff - Ethnicity
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed report on the demographics of school staff in New York City public schools for the 2019-2020 school year, as mandated by Local Law 226. It breaks down staff demographics by ethnicity within three categories: teaching staff, leadership, and other professional and paraprofessional staff. Key columns include 'school' which identifies the school, 'leadership', 'teachers', and 'other_staff' which provide counts for each staff category. Several columns capture the ethnic breakdown of staff, such as 'asian_count', 'black_african_american_count', 'hispanic_count', and 'white_count'. The dataset also includes information on staff experience, such as 'white_average_years_in_title' and 'white_average_years_at_school'. This data can be used to analyze diversity and representation within NYC public schools, track demographic trends, and inform policies aimed at promoting equity in staffing. Researchers, policymakers, and education advocates can leverage this information to gain insights into the composition of school staff across the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains demographic information for staff in New York City public schools during the 2019-2020 school year, as required by Local Law 226. It provides a breakdown of staff ethnicity across different categories: teaching staff, leadership, and other professional/paraprofessional staff. The data includes counts of staff by ethnicity, average years of experience, and school identifiers.

Related Topics:

- Other staff: paraprofessionals, support staff, non-teaching staff

- Compare staff demographics across different schools or districts within NYC.
- Evaluate the impact of Local Law 226 on staff diversity.

title: NYPD Neighborhood Coordination Officer (NCO) Directory
ufd: This dataset provides contact information for NYPD Neighborhood Coordination Officers (NCOs), who act as liaisons and problem-solvers between the police and the community. It includes details for 100 officers. Key columns include `pct` (Precinct), `sector` (the specific area or unit the officer is responsible for), `rank` (officer's rank, e.g., PO, SGT, DET), `first_name`, `last_name`, and `email_address`. The dataset allows users to easily find and contact the NCO responsible for a specific neighborhood or sector. You can use this data to connect with the appropriate officer for community concerns, crime prevention initiatives, or to build relationships with local law enforcement. The dataset covers 12 different precincts and 8 sectors. Note that a small fraction of records have missing first name, last name, and email address.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains contact information for NYPD Neighborhood Coordination Officers (NCOs), including their precinct, sector, rank, name, and email address. NCOs serve as liaisons between the police and the community, addressing local concerns and fostering relationships. The dataset covers 100 officers across 12 precincts and 8 sectors, enabling users to easily identify and contact the appropriate officer for their neighborhood.

title: NYC Independent Budget Office (IBO) Tax Revenue FY 1980 - FY 2020
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive overview of New York City's tax revenue streams from fiscal year 1980 to 2020. It includes annual figures for major tax sources, offering insights into the city's financial health and economic trends over time. Key columns include "year," indicating the fiscal year, and various tax categories such as "property," "personal_income_total," "general_sales," and "general_corporation," each representing the total revenue collected from that source. The "total_taxes" column provides the overall tax revenue for each year. Users can analyze this data to understand the historical performance of different tax revenue sources, identify patterns and trends in the city's economy, and assess the impact of economic policies on tax collection. This information is valuable for budget planning, economic forecasting, and policy analysis related to New York City's finances. The dataset is published by the NYC Independent Budget Office (IBO).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains annual tax revenue data for New York City from fiscal years 1980 to 2020. It details revenue collected from various tax sources, including property, personal income, sales, and corporation taxes. The data provides insights into NYC's financial history and economic trends.

Related Topics:

Applications and Use Cases:

- Assess the impact of economic policies on tax collection.
- Support budget planning and financial decision-making for NYC.
- Identify periods of economic growth and recession in NYC based on tax revenue data.

title: NYC Climate Budgeting Report: Climate Alignment Assessment and Capital Climate Investments
ufd: This dataset provides insights into New York City's climate budgeting process, assessing the climate alignment of capital projects exceeding $50,000. Updated annually during the Executive Budget, it categorizes investments related to climate change. Key columns include `project_id` and `project_description`, detailing specific projects, and `asset_category`, which classifies the type of asset involved (e.g., Buildings & Facilities, IT & Technology). The dataset also assesses environmental impacts through columns like `ghg_mitigation`, `flood_resiliency`, and `heat_resiliency`. Financial aspects are captured by `first_fiscal_year` and `fiscal_year_amount`, indicating the project's timeframe and budget allocation. Users can analyze this data to understand the city's commitment to climate action, track investments in climate-related projects, and evaluate the environmental impact of various initiatives. The `budget_line` column provides a financial code for each project, while `budget_line_title` offers a description of the budget line item.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details New York City's climate-related capital project investments, focusing on projects exceeding $50,000. It provides information on project descriptions, asset categories, environmental impacts (GHG mitigation, flood and heat resiliency), and financial aspects like budget allocation and project timelines. The data allows for analysis of the city's climate action commitment and the environmental impact of its initiatives.

Related Topics:
- Climate Change

- Government Spending
- Environmental Policy
- Infrastructure
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Climate Budgeting: Green budgeting, environmental budgeting, sustainable finance
- Capital Projects: Infrastructure projects, public works, construction projects
- GHG Mitigation: Greenhouse gas reduction, carbon emissions reduction, decarbonization
- Flood Resiliency: Flood protection, flood preparedness, coastal resilience
- Heat Resiliency: Heat wave preparedness, urban heat island mitigation, cooling strategies
- Asset Category: Infrastructure type, project classification, sector

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze NYC's investment in climate-related projects over time.
- Evaluate the environmental impact of different asset categories.
- Track budget allocations for specific climate initiatives.
- Identify projects contributing to GHG mitigation, flood resiliency, and heat resiliency.
- Compare climate budgeting across different city agencies.

title: Watershed Water Quality - Wastewater
ufd: This dataset contains water quality monitoring results from various wastewater treatment plants, collected from 1987 to present. It includes key information such as the sample ID, the site where the sample was taken, and the date and time of the sample. The dataset also specifies the analyte being measured (e.g., Coliform, BOD, Solids), the status of the analysis, the final result, and the units of measurement.  Information about the water treatment plant, its group (e.g., City Owned - Effluent), and the SPDES number (environmental permit) are also included.  Researchers and environmental professionals can use this data to analyze trends in water quality, assess the performance of wastewater treatment plants, and ensure compliance with environmental regulations. The `sample_start_date` and `start_time` columns provide additional temporal context for the samples.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides water quality monitoring results from wastewater treatment plants, spanning from 1987 to the present. It includes sample details like ID, site, date, time, analyte, analysis status, result, and units. The data also contains information about the treatment plant, its group, and the SPDES permit number, enabling analysis of water quality trends and treatment plant performance.

Related Topics:

- Environmental Regulations
- Pollution Control
- Water Resources Management

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Analyte: Parameter, Substance, Constituent
- Wastewater Treatment Plant: Sewage Treatment Plant, Water Resource Recovery Facility
- SPDES Number: State Pollutant Discharge Elimination System Permit, Environmental Permit
- Water Quality Monitoring: Water Quality Assessment, Water Sampling
- Coliform: Fecal Coliform, E. coli
- BOD: Biochemical Oxygen Demand
- Solids: Total Suspended Solids (TSS), Total Dissolved Solids (TDS)

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze long-term trends in water quality parameters.
- Assess the performance and efficiency of different wastewater treatment plants.
- Evaluate the impact of environmental regulations on water quality.

title: ACS Community Partners
ufd:
This dataset, titled "ACS Community Partners," provides a comprehensive list of preventive service providers in New York City. It includes key details such as program names, agency affiliations, service descriptions (e.g., General Preventive, Family Treatment), and the boroughs they serve. The dataset also offers valuable contact information, including contact names, phone numbers, and email addresses (where available), enabling direct communication with the programs.

Researchers, social workers, and community members can use this dataset to identify and connect with local social service programs. The "active_flag" column indicates whether a program is currently active. The program address and borough information allows users to locate services within specific geographic areas. This information can be used to create a directory of services, analyze service distribution across the city, or facilitate referrals for individuals and families in need.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: Other Tobacco Products License
ufd: This dataset contains information about businesses holding Other Tobacco Products (OTP) licenses in New York City. It includes details such as the business name, license number, business address, city, state, and zip code. The dataset also provides geographic information, including borough, latitude, longitude, community board, and council district. Key columns for identifying businesses are the 'name' and 'license' columns, while location information is captured in columns like 'business_address', 'city_or_town', 'state', and 'zip_code'. Researchers and city planners could use this dataset to analyze the distribution of tobacco product wholesalers across the city, understand the geographic concentration of these businesses, or examine the relationship between OTP licenses and other socioeconomic factors. The data could also be used to ensure compliance with regulations and to inform public health initiatives related to tobacco use.
sfd:

title: 2010 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records from yellow taxis in 2010. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including pickup and drop-off times, locations, trip distance, and fare information. Key columns include `vendorid` (identifying the Technology Service Provider), `tpep_pickup_datetime` and `dropoff_datetime` (recording the trip's start and end), `passenger_count`, and `trip_distance`. The dataset also provides a breakdown of costs, such as `fare_amount`, `tip_amount`, and `tolls_amount`, which sum up to the `total_amount`. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi usage patterns, analyze fare structures, or build predictive models for trip demand. The `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip record was held in vehicle memory before transmission. Location data is provided in longitude and latitude coordinates for both pickup and drop-off.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed records of individual taxi trips from yellow taxis in 2010. It includes information on trip timing, locations, distances, passenger counts, and fare breakdowns. The data allows for analysis of taxi usage patterns and fare structures.

title: School Zones 2024-2025 (High School)
ufd: This dataset contains zoning information for high schools in New York City for the 2024-2025 school year. It includes details such as school names (`sch_name`), catchment areas, borough codes (`boro`), and school district numbers (`schooldist`). The dataset also provides geographic coordinates (`the_geom`) defining the school zones. Key columns like `dbn` and `label` offer unique identifiers for each school. This data can be used to identify the high school options available to students based on their residential zone, analyze school zone boundaries, or study the geographic distribution of schools within the city. Researchers, parents, and city planners can leverage this information for educational planning and resource allocation.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the zoning information for New York City high schools for the 2024-2025 academic year. It includes school names, borough codes, school district numbers, and geographic coordinates defining school zones. The data allows for identifying school options based on residential zones and analyzing school zone boundaries.

Related Topics:
- Education
- School Districts
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- New York City
- Zoning
- Demographics

Concepts and Synonyms:
- School Zones: Attendance areas, catchment areas, school boundaries
- School District Number: District code, administrative district
- Borough Code: Boro, county code
- Geographic Coordinates: the_geom, latitude/longitude, spatial data
- DBN: District Borough Number, school ID

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identifying high school options based on residential address.
- Analyzing the geographic distribution of schools within NYC.
- Studying the relationship between school zones and demographic data.
- Planning for school resource allocation and capacity.
- Visualizing school zones on a map using geographic coordinates.

title: Citywide Mobility Survey - Trip 2022
ufd: This dataset contains trip-level data collected as part of the Citywide Mobility Survey in 2022. Each row represents a single trip leg taken by a survey participant, identified by a household ID (`hh_id`) and person ID (`person_id`). Key columns include `travel_date`, `travel_dow` (day of the week), `mode_type_nyc` (mode of transportation), and origin/destination information such as `o_county` and `d_county`. The `linked_trip_id` and `linked_leg_num` columns can be used to reconstruct complete trips from individual legs. Researchers and transportation planners can use this data to analyze travel patterns, understand mode choices, and evaluate the impact of transportation policies. The `trip_num` column provides a unique identifier for each trip taken by a participant. The dataset also includes information on whether a travel day was considered complete (`is_complete` and `day_is_complete`).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed information on individual trip legs from the 2022 Citywide Mobility Survey. It includes trip characteristics such as travel date, mode of transportation, origin and destination locations, and identifiers for linking trip legs together. Researchers can use this data to analyze travel behavior and patterns within the city.

Related Topics:
- Transportation Planning
- Urban Mobility
- Travel Surveys
- Mode Choice
- Origin-Destination Analysis

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Trip Leg: Segment of a journey, travel segment
- Mode of Transportation: Travel method, transport type, transit mode
- Origin-Destination: Start and end point, trip endpoints, OD
- Travel Patterns: Commuting behavior, movement trends, mobility patterns
- Citywide Mobility Survey: Transportation survey, urban travel study

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze mode share for different demographics and geographic areas.
- Evaluate the impact of new transportation infrastructure on travel patterns.
- Model travel demand and predict future transportation needs.
- Understand the relationship between land use and transportation choices.
- Identify areas with limited transportation access.

title: GreenThumb Site Visits
ufd: This dataset contains information collected during NYC Parks GreenThumb staff visits to community gardens in New York City. GreenThumb provides support to over 550 community gardens, and staff conduct site visits to observe and record information about the gardens' physical status, operation, maintenance, and programming. Each row represents a single site visit, identified by a unique `parksid` and `inspectionid`. Key details captured include the `totalfencelength`, `totalsidewalkarea`, and `totalsidewalklength`, as well as indicators for features like `rainharvesting`, `solarpanels`, and `compostsystem`. Researchers and urban planners can use this data to analyze the characteristics of community gardens, assess their environmental sustainability practices, and understand the resources and infrastructure present in these spaces. The data also includes boolean flags indicating the presence of hydrants and on-site services.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details site visits to community gardens in New York City conducted by NYC Parks GreenThumb staff. It includes observations on garden infrastructure, environmental features, and services available at each site. The data covers over 550 gardens and provides insights into their physical characteristics, maintenance, and sustainability practices.

Related Topics:
- Urban Gardening

- Environmental Sustainability

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Community Garden: Urban garden, allotment garden, shared garden space
- GreenThumb: NYC Parks GreenThumb, community garden support program
- Site Visit: Inspection, assessment, evaluation
- Environmental Sustainability: Eco-friendly practices, green initiatives, sustainable development
- Infrastructure: Fencing, sidewalks, water access, utilities
- Rain Harvesting: Water collection, rainwater harvesting system
- Compost System: Composting, organic waste management

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the prevalence of sustainable practices in community gardens.
- Assess the infrastructure needs and resource allocation for community gardens.
- Identify correlations between garden characteristics and community engagement.
- Evaluate the impact of GreenThumb support on garden development.
- Map the distribution of community gardens and their environmental features across NYC.

title: 2020-21 SMH Service Coverage
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of mental health service coverage in New York City Department of Education (DOE) schools for the 2020-2021 school year. Each record represents a school covered by a mental health program. The dataset includes the geographical district code, building code, school name (location_name), primary address, city, and zip code for each school. The 'service' column specifies the type of mental health service provided, such as "School-based Health Center w/ Mental Health" or "School Mental Health Specialist Program." Researchers and policymakers can use this data to identify schools with mental health coverage and analyze the distribution of different service types across districts. Keep in mind that this data does not represent all mental health programs offered at a school. The data includes 100 rows, focusing on schools within a few geographical districts.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details mental health service coverage within New York City Department of Education (DOE) schools for the 2020-2021 academic year. It includes information on the location of schools offering specific mental health services, such as school-based health centers and mental health specialist programs. The data provides geographic details like district code, address, and zip code for each school.

- School Mental Health Specialist Program: SMHSP, mental health professional, school counselor, social worker
- NYC Department of Education: NYCDOE, DOE, NYC Schools
- Geographical District: School district, district code, region

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the distribution of mental health services across different school districts in NYC.
- Identify schools that lack mental health service coverage.
- Evaluate the types of mental health services offered in different schools.
- Support resource allocation decisions for mental health programs in schools.
- Research the relationship between mental health service availability and student outcomes.

title: 2021 Public Data File - Parent
ufd: This dataset contains results from the 2021 NYC School Survey, focusing on parent responses. It provides insights into parents' perceptions of their children's schools. Each row represents a specific school, identified by its DBN and school name. Key columns include the total parent response rate and a series of questions (q1-q30) gauging parent opinions on various aspects of the school environment. These questions cover topics such as staff effectiveness, teacher collaboration, communication, respect, and overall school quality. Researchers, policymakers, and school administrators can use this data to understand parental satisfaction, identify areas for improvement in schools, and track changes in parent perceptions over time. The percentages provided reflect the proportion of parents who agree with the survey statements.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset presents parent responses from the 2021 NYC School Survey. It offers a school-level view of parental opinions on various aspects of the school environment, including staff, teachers, communication, and overall quality. The data includes the total parent response rate and responses to 30 questions reflecting parental agreement with specific statements.

Related Topics:
- School Surveys
- Parent Involvement
- Education Quality
- School Performance
- NYC Public Schools
- Educational Assessment
- Student Outcomes

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Parent Perceptions: Parent opinions, Parent views, Parent attitudes
- School Environment: School climate, School culture, Learning environment
- Response Rate: Participation rate, Survey completion rate
- School Quality: Educational effectiveness, Academic standards, School performance
- NYC School Survey: NYC DOE Survey, Department of Education Survey

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identify schools with high or low parental satisfaction.
- Analyze the relationship between parent perceptions and school performance metrics.
- Track changes in parent opinions over time to assess the impact of school initiatives.
- Compare parent perceptions across different schools or districts.
- Inform school improvement plans and resource allocation decisions.
- Investigate factors influencing parent involvement in schools.

title: Citywide Marketing Directory
ufd: This dataset is a directory of approved ethnic and community media outlets that qualify for city agencies to meet the Local Law 83 of 2021 goal of spending at least 50% of their advertising budgets with ECM outlets. It includes information on the media outlet's name, the type of media they produce (e.g., print, digital, TV), the languages they serve, and their geographic focus within New York City. The dataset also specifies the communities the outlet serves, such as Latino, South Asian, or hyper-local communities. Each entry provides the outlet's website, though email and phone contact information are consistently marked as "TBD." This directory can be used by city agencies to identify and connect with relevant media outlets for advertising opportunities, ensuring that they are meeting the requirements of Local Law 83. Researchers and community organizations could also use this data to understand the landscape of ethnic and community media in NYC. The data was last updated on April 1, 2025.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides a directory of approved ethnic and community media (ECM) outlets in New York City, as mandated by Local Law 83 of 2021. It includes details on media type, languages served, geographic focus, and communities reached by each outlet. The data is intended to help city agencies meet advertising budget requirements and understand the ECM landscape.

- Local Law 83: NYC Advertising Law, ECM Spending Mandate
- Geographic Focus: Coverage Area, Service Area, Target Region
- Community Served: Target Audience, Demographic Group, Cultural Group

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identifying ECM outlets for city advertising campaigns.
- Analyzing the reach and scope of ethnic media in NYC.
- Supporting research on media diversity and representation.
- Facilitating communication between city agencies and diverse communities.
- Tracking compliance with Local Law 83.

title: Participatory Budgeting Survey Data
ufd: This dataset contains results from optional, anonymous surveys of participants in the city's participatory budgeting process. The surveys help the City Council understand community preferences and improve outreach efforts. Each row represents an individual survey response, with columns indicating the survey year, the district the participant belongs to, and the language the survey was administered in. Key demographic information captured includes gender, ethnicity, education level, income, and age. The dataset also tracks how participants learned about the budgeting process ("information" column) and their preferred language. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze demographic trends in participatory budgeting, assess the effectiveness of outreach strategies, and identify areas for improvement in engaging diverse communities.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains anonymous survey responses from participants in the city's participatory budgeting process. The surveys capture demographic information such as gender, ethnicity, education, income, and age, along with details on how participants learned about the process and their preferred language. The data is organized by survey year and district, providing insights into community preferences and outreach effectiveness.

  - Demographic Information: demographics, population characteristics, socio-economic data
  - Outreach: engagement, communication, public awareness
  - District: neighborhood, ward, electoral district

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Analyze demographic trends in participatory budgeting participation.
  - Evaluate the effectiveness of different outreach strategies.
  - Identify areas for improvement in engaging diverse communities.
  - Understand community preferences for budgeting priorities.
  - Track changes in participation and preferences over time.
  - Inform city planning and resource allocation decisions.

title: DSNY Garages
ufd: This dataset contains information about the locations of Department of Sanitation (DSNY) garages across New York City. Each row represents a single garage and includes its address, borough, city, and zip code. The dataset also provides a district code and a unique name for each garage. Location is further specified using a `point` column with coordinate data. Key columns for identifying the location of each garage include `address`, `city`, `boro` (borough code), and `zip`. This data could be used to analyze the distribution of DSNY garages across the city, optimize resource allocation, or plan emergency response strategies.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details the locations of Department of Sanitation (DSNY) garages throughout New York City. Each entry represents a single garage and includes its address, borough, city, zip code, district code, and a unique name. Location is further specified using a `point` column with coordinate data.

- Determine service areas for each garage based on proximity.

title: 2019 - 2020 School Year Local Law 226 Report for the Demographics of School Staff - Gender
ufd: This dataset contains demographic information on school staff in New York City public schools for the 2019-2020 school year, as mandated by Local Law 226. It includes details about the gender distribution of staff across different categories: leadership, teachers, and other staff. For each school (identified by a unique school ID), the dataset provides the number of male and female staff members. Additionally, the dataset includes information on the average years of experience for male and female staff in their current title and at the school. A potential use case would be to analyze gender representation across different staff categories within the NYC public school system. This data could be used to identify potential disparities and inform policies aimed at promoting diversity and equity in schools. Note that some columns contain a high percentage of missing values, represented by asterisks (*).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides demographic information on New York City public school staff for the 2019-2020 school year, focusing on gender distribution across leadership, teachers, and other staff roles. It includes the number of male and female staff members per school, identified by a unique school ID. The dataset also contains average years of experience for male and female staff in their current title and at the school.
