- Track changes in staff demographics over time (if data from other years is available).
- Compare staff demographics across different schools or districts within NYC.

title: SAT (College Board) 2010 School Level Results
ufd: This dataset contains school-level SAT scores for New York City graduating seniors of 2010. It includes the school's DBN (district borough number), school name, and the number of test takers. For each school, the dataset provides the mean scores for critical reading, mathematics, and writing sections of the SAT. Researchers and educators can use this data to analyze SAT performance across different schools in NYC. This allows for comparisons of academic performance and identification of schools that may benefit from additional resources or support. Keep in mind that records with 5 or fewer students are suppressed. The data was collected and processed by the College Board.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides school-level SAT scores for New York City's 2010 graduating seniors. It includes school identifiers (DBN, name) and the number of test takers per school. The data also contains the mean SAT scores for critical reading, mathematics, and writing sections, offering insights into academic performance across different schools.

Related Topics:

title: 2021 -2022 Guidance Counselor
ufd: This dataset provides information on guidance counselors and social workers in schools for the 2021-2022 school year. It includes details such as the school's DBN (district, borough, number), school name, and location type (e.g., elementary, high school). Key columns detail the total number of guidance counselors (`total_gc`) and social workers (`total_sw`), as well as the breakdown between full-time and part-time staff. Additional columns indicate the number of bilingual counselors and social workers. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze the distribution of student support staff across different school types. This information can be valuable for understanding resource allocation and identifying potential disparities in access to mental health and guidance services within the education system.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on guidance counselors and social workers in schools for the 2021-2022 school year. It includes school identifiers (DBN, name) and location type, along with counts of total, full-time, part-time, and bilingual guidance counselors and social workers. This data can be used to analyze the distribution of student support staff across schools.

title: Heating Gas Consumption And Cost (2010 -  May 2025)
ufd: This dataset contains monthly heating gas consumption and cost information for housing developments across New York City. The data spans from 2010 to May 2025, offering a longitudinal view of energy usage. Key columns include `development_name` and `borough`, which identify the location, along with `tds` and `edp`, likely representing consumption metrics. The `vendor_name` column specifies the utility provider, while `umis_bill_id` serves as a unique identifier for each bill. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze energy consumption patterns in public housing, track costs, and evaluate the impact of energy-saving initiatives. The `funding_source` column indicates the origin of financial support for these developments. This information can be valuable for budgeting, resource allocation, and policy decisions related to housing and energy efficiency.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides monthly heating gas consumption and cost details for New York City housing developments from 2010 to May 2025. It includes information on energy usage (`tds`, `edp`), location (`development_name`, `borough`), utility provider (`vendor_name`), and funding source. The data enables analysis of energy consumption patterns, cost tracking, and evaluation of energy-saving initiatives in public housing.

title: 2018 - 2020 CLASS and ECERS-R Data
ufd: This dataset contains information about schools, including their location (address, zip code, district, and borough) and assessment data from 2018 to 2020. The dataset includes CLASS (Classroom Assessment Scoring System) and ECERS-R (Early Childhood Environment Rating Scale-Revised) data. CLASS data includes scores for emotional support, classroom organization, and instructional support. ECERS-R data provides ratings for various aspects of the early childhood environment, such as space and furnishings, personal care routines, language reasoning, activities, interactions, and program structure. Researchers and educators can use this data to analyze school environments, identify areas for improvement, and track changes in assessment scores over time. The `site_id` and `site_name` columns uniquely identify each school.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides comprehensive information on school characteristics and assessment scores from 2018 to 2020. It includes location details like address, zip code, district, and borough, alongside CLASS and ECERS-R assessment data. The data allows for analysis of school environments and tracking of assessment score changes over time.

Related Topics:

- School environment

- Child development

Concepts and Synonyms:
- CLASS (Classroom Assessment Scoring System): classroom observation tool, teaching quality assessment
- ECERS-R (Early Childhood Environment Rating Scale-Revised): early learning environment rating, quality of care assessment
- Site ID: school identifier, unique school code
- Site Name: school name, institution name
- Emotional Support: teacher sensitivity, positive climate
- Classroom Organization: behavior management, productivity
- Instructional Support: concept development, quality of feedback

Applications and Use Cases:

- Identifying schools with high or low assessment scores for targeted interventions.
- Tracking changes in assessment scores over time to evaluate the effectiveness of educational programs.
- Comparing school environments across different districts or boroughs.
- Researching the impact of specific environmental factors on child development.

title: CityStore - The Official Store of the City of New York
ufd: This dataset provides information on products sold at the CityStore, the official store of the City of New York. It includes details such as the product name, a unique item number, whether the product is exclusive to CityStore, and its unit price. You can also find the category and a detailed description of each product. While size and color information are available for some items, they are not consistently populated across the dataset. This data could be used to analyze product sales, understand pricing strategies, or identify popular items. Additionally, it can be helpful for inventory management or for creating marketing campaigns focused on specific product categories or exclusive items.
sfd:

This dataset details products sold at the CityStore, New York City's official store. It includes product names, unique item numbers, exclusivity status, unit prices, categories, and descriptions. title: NYC Rezoning Tracker
ufd: This dataset tracks the progress of capital and programmatic commitments made by New York City in conjunction with neighborhood rezonings. It includes commitments from areas like East New York, Far Rockaway, and Jerome Avenue. Each row represents a specific commitment, with details on the responsible lead agency, the relevant policy domain (e.g., Housing, Open Space), and the current stage of completion. The `commitment_title` column provides a brief description of the initiative, while `statement_from_source_document_poa` offers a more detailed explanation from the original planning documents. The `year` column indicates the year the commitment was made. Researchers, community members, and city planners can use this dataset to monitor the implementation of rezoning plans, assess the allocation of resources, and evaluate the effectiveness of different policy interventions across New York City neighborhoods. The data spans multiple years, allowing for longitudinal analysis of project timelines and outcomes.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details New York City's capital and programmatic commitments tied to neighborhood rezonings in areas like East New York and Far Rockaway. It tracks the progress of each commitment, including the lead agency, policy domain, and completion stage. The data spans multiple years, enabling analysis of project timelines and outcomes.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- Rezoning
- Municipal Finance
- Community Development
- Public Policy
- New York City Government
- Infrastructure Projects

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Capital Commitments: Infrastructure investments, financial pledges, funding allocations
- Programmatic Commitments: Policy initiatives, service delivery programs, community programs
- Rezoning: Land use changes, zoning regulations, urban redevelopment
- Lead Agency: Responsible department, managing organization, implementing entity
- Policy Domain: Sector, area of focus, thematic category (e.g., Housing, Open Space)
- Completion Stage: Project status, progress level, implementation phase

Applications and Use Cases:
- Monitor the progress of rezoning-related commitments across NYC neighborhoods.
- Analyze the allocation of resources to different policy domains and communities.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of various policy interventions implemented through rezoning plans.
- Track project timelines and identify potential delays in commitment fulfillment.
- Assess the accountability of lead agencies in delivering promised improvements.
- Inform community advocacy efforts by providing data on the status of local projects.
- Conduct research on the impact of rezoning on housing, open space, and other community assets.

title: CEQR Projects
ufd: This dataset provides information on projects undergoing or completed through the City Environmental Quality Review (CEQR) process in New York City. Each row represents a specific project, identified by a unique CEQR number and project name. The dataset includes a detailed project description, outlining the purpose and scope of the project. Key columns include the borough where the project is located and the lead agency responsible for overseeing the project. A URL is provided for each project, linking to additional documentation in the CEQR Access Database. Researchers, city planners, and community members can use this dataset to understand the types of projects being reviewed, their potential environmental impacts, and the agencies involved. This information can be used for urban planning, environmental monitoring, and civic engagement. The dataset contains 100 rows of project information.
sfd:

The dataset also provides a URL linking to the CEQR Access Database for further project documentation.

title: Medicaid Offices
ufd: This dataset provides information on Medicaid offices in New York City, including their names, addresses, and phone numbers. It is useful for individuals seeking to apply for, recertify, or inquire about Medicaid benefits. Key columns include `name_of_medicaid_office`, `office_address`, `phone_number`, and `name_of_borough`. The `comments` column provides additional information such as operating hours and temporary closures. Location information is further specified by `city`, `postcode`, `latitude`, and `longitude`. This dataset could be used to create a directory of Medicaid offices, map their locations, or analyze their distribution across different boroughs. Additional geographic information is provided via `community_board`, `community_council`, `BIN`, `BBL`, `census_tract`, and `NTA` columns.
sfd:

title: EZ Pass Readers July 2024- current
ufd: This dataset contains traffic speed data collected from E-ZPass readers installed on local streets in Manhattan, New York City. The data includes measurements like `median_speed_fps` (median speed in feet per second) and `median_tt_sec` (median travel time in seconds) for specific street segments identified by `link_name` and represented geometrically by `polyline`. Each record also includes the `link_length_ft`, the `aggregation_period_sec` over which the data was collected, and the number of samples `n_samples` used to calculate the median values. The `median_calculation_timestamp` indicates when the median values were calculated. This information can be used to analyze traffic patterns, identify areas of congestion, and evaluate the impact of traffic calming initiatives. The data covers the period from July 2024 to the present, with a potential gap in data availability between May 17th, 2025 and June 30th, 2025 due to system issues.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides traffic speed data from Manhattan, NYC, collected via E-ZPass readers on local streets. It includes metrics like median speed, travel time, and link length for specific street segments, along with timestamps and sample counts. The data spans from July 2024 to the present, with a potential gap in mid-2025, and can be used for traffic analysis and congestion identification.

Related Topics:
- Traffic Management
- Urban Planning
- Transportation Engineering
- Smart Cities
- Congestion Analysis
- E-ZPass Data
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Traffic Speed: Velocity, rate of travel, flow
- Travel Time: Trip duration, commute time, time to traverse
- Link Name: Street segment ID, road section identifier
- Polyline: Geographic representation, street geometry, road shape
- Congestion: Traffic jam, bottleneck, slowdown
- E-ZPass: Electronic toll collection, RFID transponder

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze traffic patterns and identify areas of congestion in Manhattan.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of traffic calming initiatives.
- Develop real-time traffic monitoring systems.
- Predict travel times for specific routes.
- Optimize traffic signal timing.
- Support urban planning and infrastructure development decisions.

title: 2017 For Hire Vehicle Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains records of For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) trips, including those from traditional livery, luxury, and black car services. Each row represents a single trip. Key columns include `dispatching_base_num`, which identifies the dispatching base for the trip, and `pickup_datetime` and `dropoff_datetime`, indicating when the trip started and ended. The `pulocationid` and `dolocationid` columns provide location information using taxi zone IDs. This data could be used to analyze FHV trip patterns, understand transportation demand in different zones, or evaluate the performance of various dispatching bases. Note that location IDs and the service request flag (`sr_flag`) may have missing values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details individual For-Hire Vehicle (FHV) trips, encompassing livery, luxury, and black car services. Each record represents a single trip with information on dispatching base, pickup and dropoff times, and location IDs. The data allows for analysis of FHV trip characteristics, transportation demand, and dispatching base performance.

Related Topics:
- Taxi trips
- For-Hire Vehicles (FHV)
- Transportation network
- Dispatch services
- Location analysis
- Urban mobility

Concepts and Synonyms:
- For-Hire Vehicle (FHV): Livery, Black Car, Luxury Car, Ride-hailing
- Dispatching Base: Dispatcher, FHV company, Base number
- Pickup/Dropoff Location: Origin/Destination, Start/End point, Taxi Zone ID, `pulocationid`, `dolocationid`
- Trip characteristics: Trip duration, Ride details

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze FHV trip patterns and trends.
- Understand transportation demand in specific geographic zones.
- Evaluate the performance of different dispatching bases.
- Predict future FHV demand.
- Optimize dispatching strategies.
- Identify areas with limited transportation access.

title: NYC Independent Budget Office (IBO) Revenue And Spending Summary FY 1980 - FY 2020
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed summary of New York City's revenue and expenditures from fiscal year 1980 through 2020. It breaks down the city's finances into major categories, offering insights into how the city generates revenue and allocates its resources. Key columns include "revenue_and_expenditure_summary_in_millions," which specifies the revenue or expenditure type, and columns labeled "fy_2020" through "fy_1980," which represent the financial values in millions for each fiscal year. Users can analyze trends in revenue sources like property taxes and personal income taxes, as well as track changes in spending across different areas of the city budget. This data can be used to understand the city's financial health, identify areas of growth or decline, and inform policy decisions related to budgeting and resource allocation. The dataset allows for year-over-year comparisons and long-term trend analysis of NYC's financial performance.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains New York City's revenue and expenditure data from fiscal years 1980 to 2020. It provides a breakdown of the city's finances by major categories, showing revenue sources and expenditure allocations. The data allows for analysis of financial trends and informs decisions related to budgeting and resource management.

Related Topics:
- Municipal Finance
- Government Budgeting
- Urban Economics
- Public Policy
- New York City

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Revenue: Income, receipts, funds, tax revenue, fees
- Expenditure: Spending, expenses, outlays, disbursements, allocations
- Fiscal Year (FY): Budget year, financial year
- Budget: Financial plan, appropriations, resource allocation
- NYC: New York City, City of New York

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in NYC revenue and expenditure over time.
- Compare spending across different city departments or categories.
- Identify the major sources of revenue for New York City.
- Evaluate the impact of economic events on the city's finances.
- Inform policy decisions related to budgeting and resource allocation.

title: Worker Coops
ufd: This dataset provides a list of Worker Cooperatives assisted by the Worker Cooperative Business Development Initiative (WCBDI). It includes key information about each business, such as its name (`business_name_dba`), address (`address1`, `city`, `state`, `zip`), and borough. The dataset also provides details on the type of services offered by each cooperative, indicated by the `naics_code` and `subtype` columns, which describe the industry and specific business functions, respectively. Location data, including latitude and longitude, is available for geographic analysis. Additionally, the dataset contains political information such as the city council district. Researchers, policymakers, and individuals interested in supporting worker cooperatives can use this data to identify and analyze these businesses, understand their distribution across different boroughs, and explore the types of services they provide. This information can be valuable for economic development initiatives, community planning, and understanding the cooperative business landscape.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on Worker Cooperatives assisted by the Worker Cooperative Business Development Initiative (WCBDI). It includes details such as business name, address, location coordinates (latitude/longitude), industry codes (NAICS), service subtypes, and political districts. This data can be used to analyze the distribution, types of services, and political context of worker cooperatives.

- Economic Development
- Community Planning

Concepts and Synonyms:

- NAICS Code: North American Industry Classification System, industry code

- Location Data: Latitude, longitude, geographic coordinates
- Political District: City Council District, electoral district
- WCBDI: Worker Cooperative Business Development Initiative

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identifying worker cooperatives in specific geographic areas.
- Analyzing the types of services offered by worker cooperatives.
- Mapping the distribution of worker cooperatives across different boroughs.
- Understanding the relationship between worker cooperatives and political districts.
- Supporting economic development initiatives focused on worker cooperatives.
- Researching the cooperative business landscape.
- Community planning and resource allocation.

title: NYC Agencies and Governance Organizations
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive list of New York City agencies, offices, and governance organizations. It includes various types of entities, such as mayoral agencies, advisory councils, non-profit organizations, and elected offices. Key information in the dataset includes the organization's name, acronym, operational status, and type. You can also find contact information like website URLs and the names and titles of principal officers. Researchers, journalists, and city residents can use this dataset to understand the structure of NYC government, identify relevant agencies for specific issues, and find contact information for key personnel. The dataset also tracks alternate or former names for some organizations, offering historical context.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset catalogs New York City's governmental structure, encompassing agencies, offices, and related organizations. It details key attributes like organization name, operational status, type, and contact information. The dataset also includes historical names for some organizations, providing valuable context for understanding the evolution of NYC government.

title: City Bench Locations (Historical)
ufd: This dataset contains information about the locations of City Benches in New York City. The CityBench initiative aims to increase public seating, particularly near bus stops, retail areas, and senior citizen areas. Each record includes the bench's geographic coordinates (`the_geom`), borough (`boroname`, `borocode`), and identifiers for various political districts (`borocd`, `coundist`, `assemdist`, `stsendist`, `congdist`). The dataset also provides a unique `siteid` and `benchid` for each bench, along with its `category` (e.g., Bus Route, Senior Center, General) and `benchtype` (e.g., backed, backless). Installation dates (`installati`) and addresses are also included. This data could be used to analyze the distribution of public seating across the city, identify areas with limited seating, or plan new bench installations. Researchers, urban planners, and community organizations could use this dataset to improve public spaces and accessibility for residents and visitors.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations and characteristics of City Benches in New York City. It includes geographic coordinates, borough information, political district identifiers, and unique IDs for each bench. The dataset also specifies the bench category, type, installation date, and address, offering a comprehensive view of public seating infrastructure.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- Public Infrastructure
- Transportation
- Accessibility
- New York City
- Public Seating
- Geographic Data

Concepts and Synonyms:
- City Bench: Public seating, street furniture, park bench
- Geographic Coordinates: Latitude, longitude, `the_geom`
- Borough: `boroname`, `borocode`, NYC borough (e.g., Manhattan, Brooklyn)
- Political Districts: `borocd`, `coundist`, `assemdist`, `stsendist`, `congdist`
- Bench Type: Backed, backless, seating style
- Installation Date: `installati`, placement date

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the spatial distribution of public seating across NYC.
- Identify areas with insufficient public seating, particularly near bus stops or senior centers.
- Plan new bench installations based on population density and accessibility needs.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of the CityBench initiative.
- Map and visualize public seating locations for residents and visitors.
- Study the relationship between public seating and urban demographics.

title: 2021 DOE High School Directory
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of high schools within New York City's Department of Education for the year 2021, specifically focusing on schools located in Manhattan. It includes key information such as the school's name, a unique identifier (DBN), and a borough code. The dataset also offers a detailed overview paragraph describing each school's mission, programs, and special features. Furthermore, it highlights academic opportunities available to students, including advanced placement courses, college partnerships, and specialized electives. Researchers, parents, and students can use this dataset to explore the landscape of high school options in Manhattan, compare schools based on their offerings, and identify schools that align with their academic interests and goals. The URL column provides a direct link to each school's website for more in-depth information.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset catalogs high schools in Manhattan, New York City, under the Department of Education for 2021. It provides essential details like school name, DBN, borough code, and a descriptive overview. The dataset also highlights academic opportunities such as AP courses and college partnerships, along with a URL for each school's website.

title: ACRIS - Personal Property Remarks
ufd: This dataset contains remarks related to personal property documents recorded in the Automated City Register Information System (ACRIS). Each row represents a remark associated with a specific document, identified by a unique `document_id`. The `remark_text` column provides details about corrections or modifications made to the document, such as name or block corrections. The `sequence_number` indicates the order of the remark within the document's record. The `good_through_date` specifies the date until which the information in the record is valid. This dataset could be used to track changes to property records, identify common correction types, or analyze the validity period of specific document details. Researchers or city planners might find this information valuable for understanding property record management and ensuring data accuracy.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset contains remarks associated with personal property documents recorded in the Automated City Register Information System (ACRIS). Each remark provides details about corrections, modifications, or other important information related to a specific document. The data includes the remark text, sequence number, and a "good through" date, indicating the validity period of the information.

**Related Topics:**
- City Government
- Property Records
- Real Estate
- Data Correction
- Document Management
- Public Records
- Urban Planning

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- ACRIS: Automated City Register Information System
- Remark: Note, comment, annotation, correction, modification
- Document ID: Record identifier, unique document number
- Sequence Number: Order, position, index
- Good Through Date: Expiration date, validity date, effective date
- Personal Property: Chattel, movable property, belongings

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Track changes and corrections to property records over time.
- Identify common types of errors or modifications in property documents.
- Analyze the validity period of specific information within property records.
- Improve data quality and accuracy in the ACRIS system.
- Support research on property record management and urban planning.
- Develop tools for automated document review and validation.

title: General Obligation Debt Service by Fiscal Year
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at New York City's General Obligation bond debt service by fiscal year. It includes information on the outstanding principal and interest amounts for these bonds. Each row represents a specific fiscal year, with columns detailing the 'fiscal_year', 'principal' amount, 'total_interest' paid, and the 'total_debt_service' for that year. The dataset spans 36 fiscal years, offering a comprehensive view of debt obligations. Users can analyze trends in debt service, understand the balance between principal and interest payments, and forecast future financial obligations. This data is valuable for financial analysts, city planners, and anyone interested in understanding the financial health and debt management strategies of New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on New York City's General Obligation bond debt service for 36 fiscal years. It details the outstanding principal, total interest paid, and total debt service for each fiscal year. This data allows for analysis of debt trends and financial obligations.

title: Topographical Bureau Maps - Final Sections
ufd: This dataset contains information about final section maps from the Topographical Bureau, detailing legal street information for the Borough of Brooklyn. Each row represents a specific section map and its boundaries. Key columns include `final_section_fs`, a unique identifier for each map section, and `left_side`, `top`, `right_side`, and `bottom`, which describe the boundaries of the map section, often referencing street names, waterways, or borough boundaries. Researchers, urban planners, or anyone interested in the historical layout and legal definitions of streets in Brooklyn can use this dataset. It can be used to understand the evolution of street layouts, identify historical boundary definitions, or cross-reference with other geographical datasets. The data provides a snapshot of the legal street landscape as defined in these final section maps. The location information is primarily focused on street-level detail.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed information on final section maps from the Topographical Bureau, specifically focusing on legal street information for Brooklyn. Each record represents a unique map section, identified by `final_section_fs`, and its geographical boundaries defined by `left_side`, `top`, `right_side`, and `bottom` attributes. These boundaries often reference street names, waterways, or borough limits, offering a snapshot of the legal street landscape.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning
- Topography
- Brooklyn History
- Street Mapping
- Legal Boundaries
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Final Section Map: Topographical map, legal map, street map section
- Boundary: Limit, border, edge, demarcation
- Legal Street: Officially recognized street, gazetted street
- Topographical Bureau: Surveying department, mapping agency
- `final_section_fs`: Map ID, section identifier, unique section code
- `left_side`, `top`, `right_side`, `bottom`: Map coordinates, boundary descriptions, location references

Applications and Use Cases:
- Historical street layout analysis and evolution tracking.
- Identification of historical boundary definitions and changes over time.
- Cross-referencing with other geographical datasets for spatial analysis.
- Urban planning and development research related to street networks.
- Reconstructing historical maps and understanding legal street definitions.
- Visualizing the spatial arrangement of Brooklyn's streets based on historical records.

title: Lost Property Contact Information
ufd: This dataset provides contact information for bases affiliated with TLC Street Hail Livery (SHL), Boro taxis, and Yellow Medallion Taxicabs. It includes details such as the license number, name, and type of vehicle (Medallion or Street Hail Livery). Key columns include `base_name`, `base_license_number`, `base_phone_number`, and `base_address`, which offer contact information for the taxi or livery base. The `dmv_plate_number` uniquely identifies each vehicle. The dataset also contains `last_updated_date` and `last_updated_time` to indicate when the information was last modified. This information could be useful for individuals trying to locate lost property in taxis or for researchers studying the taxi and livery industry in New York City. Please note that the dataset contains a large number of null values in the `base_website` column.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains contact information for taxi and livery bases in New York City, including Street Hail Livery (SHL), Boro taxis, and Yellow Medallion Taxicabs. It provides details such as base name, license number, phone number, and address, along with vehicle identification via DMV plate number. The dataset also includes timestamps indicating the last update of the information.

Related Topics:
- Taxi and Livery Services
- Transportation Networks
- Vehicle Licensing and Regulation
- New York City Transportation
- Contact Information Databases

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Taxi Base: Dispatch center, Livery base, Taxi garage
- Street Hail Livery (SHL): Green taxi, Boro taxi
- Yellow Medallion Taxicab: NYC taxi, Medallion taxi
- Base License Number: TLC license number, Permit number
- DMV Plate Number: Vehicle registration number, License plate

Applications and Use Cases:
- Locating lost property in taxis by contacting the associated base.
- Researching the structure and organization of the taxi and livery industry in NYC.
- Analyzing the distribution and density of taxi and livery bases across the city.
- Verifying the legitimacy of taxi and livery services.
- Building a directory of taxi and livery bases for public use.

title: Department for the Aging (NYC Aging) - Social Adult Day Care Services
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive listing of registered agencies in New York City that offer Social Adult Day Care Services. It includes key details such as the program name, sponsoring organization, address, city, state, and zip code, allowing users to easily locate services in their area. The dataset also specifies the borough where the program is located and provides a phone number for direct contact. A notable feature is the "dfta_funded" column, indicating whether the program receives funding from the Department for the Aging. Additionally, geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) are included for many programs, enabling mapping and spatial analysis. Researchers, city planners, and individuals seeking adult day care services can use this dataset to identify and assess available resources across the city. The inclusion of community board and council district information allows for analysis at a neighborhood level.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: 2020 - 2021 LL Settlement Data
ufd: This dataset contains information on settlement agreements completed on or before October 22, 2021, that resulted from Ten-Day notices or Due Process Complaints filed during the 2020-2021 school year. Each row represents a unique case, identified by `caseid`. The dataset includes the student's community school district and the student's representative, which is consistently an attorney in this dataset. Key dates are provided, detailing the timeline of the settlement process, including when the Department of Education (DOE) received the initial notice, when the DOE referred the case, and when the parent filed. Further dates track when the DOE received documentation, approved the written agreement, and issued the first payment. Researchers and education advocates can use this data to analyze the timeline of settlement agreements, identify trends in different school districts, and understand the payment process.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details settlement agreements finalized by October 22, 2021, stemming from Ten-Day Notices or Due Process Complaints filed during the 2020-2021 school year. It includes information on the student's school district, representative (always an attorney), and key dates related to the settlement process, such as notice receipt, referral, and payment issuance. The data allows for analysis of settlement timelines and trends within the Department of Education.

**Related Topics:**
- Special Education
- Due Process
- Legal Settlements
- School Districts
- Education Law
- Student Rights
- Dispute Resolution

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Settlement Agreement: Resolution agreement, legal settlement, case resolution
- Due Process Complaint: Special education complaint, legal action, formal grievance
- Ten-Day Notice: Notice of intent to sue, pre-litigation notice, legal notification
- Community School District: School district, local education agency (LEA), district
- Department of Education (DOE): Education authority, school system, education agency
- Case ID: Unique identifier, record number, case number

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Analyze the time elapsed between initial notice and final settlement payment.
- Identify school districts with a high volume of settlement agreements.
- Investigate the types of claims leading to settlement agreements.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of the settlement process.
- Compare settlement outcomes across different student demographics.
- Track trends in settlement amounts and payment schedules.

title: Inmate Incidents - Inmate Fights
ufd: This dataset contains information about inmate fights, specifically violent incidents between inmates. Each record represents a single incident. The dataset includes a unique `incident_id` for each fight, allowing for easy tracking and reference. The `incident_dt` column provides the date and time the incident occurred. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in inmate violence, identify peak times for incidents, or evaluate the effectiveness of intervention strategies. Researchers, prison administrators, and public safety analysts could use this data to gain insights into the dynamics of inmate behavior and improve safety within correctional facilities. The dataset contains 100 rows of data.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: M/WBE Upcoming Procurements
ufd: This dataset provides a list of upcoming contract opportunities for Minority and Women-Owned Business Enterprises (M/WBEs) within New York City government. It focuses on opportunities categorized under DCAS (Department of Citywide Administrative Services) MWBE Non-Competitive Small Purchases, DCAS Specific Procurements, and upcoming citywide goods and services. Key columns include `fiscal_year`, indicating the relevant fiscal year for the procurement; `procurement_type`, specifying the type of procurement process; `procurement_name`, detailing the specific goods or services being procured; `procurement_industry`, classifying the industry to which the procurement belongs; and `procurement_method`, outlining the method used for procurement. Users can leverage this dataset to identify potential contract opportunities, understand the types of procurements available to M/WBEs, and gain insights into the city's procurement processes. The data can be used to track trends in procurement, analyze the distribution of contracts across different industries, and identify areas where M/WBE participation can be increased. This information is valuable for M/WBEs seeking to do business with the city, as well as for government agencies aiming to promote equity in procurement.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It focuses on procurements managed by the Department of Citywide Administrative Services (DCAS) and citywide goods and services. Key information includes fiscal year, procurement type, name, industry, and method.

- Evaluate the effectiveness of M/WBE programs.

title: Self Hauler Registrants
ufd: This dataset contains information on companies registered as Class 1 self-haulers by the New York City Business Integrity Commission. These companies are authorized to remove, collect, or dispose of trade waste generated by their own businesses. Each record includes the company's name, address, and contact information, as well as their Business Integrity Commission (BIC) number. Key columns include `account_name` for the company name, `address` for their business address, `city`, `state`, and `postcode` for location information, and `bic_number` as a unique identifier. The dataset also provides the `effective_date` and `expiration_date` of their registration, along with the `application_type`, which is 'CL1' for Class 1 Self Hauler Registration. This data could be used to verify the registration status of self-hauling companies, analyze the distribution of these companies across different areas of New York City, or contact them.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details companies registered as Class 1 self-haulers by the New York City Business Integrity Commission (BIC). It includes information on businesses authorized to handle their own trade waste. Key details provided are company name, address, BIC number, registration dates, and application type.

- Registration: Official authorization to operate.

Applications and Use Cases:
- Verify the registration status of Class 1 self-hauling companies in NYC.
- Analyze the geographic distribution of self-haulers across different boroughs.
- Contact registered self-haulers for surveys or compliance checks.
- Track registration effective and expiration dates for regulatory oversight.
- Identify trends in self-hauling registration applications.

title: DOF: Refund List - Real Property Tax
ufd: This dataset provides details on property tax refund checks issued by the city government. Each row represents a specific refund, identified by a unique case number and refund number. Key information includes the issue date of the refund check, the check number itself (or "ACH" for electronic transfers), and the Building, Block, and Lot number (BBL) associated with the property. The effective date indicates when the overpayment occurred, and the refund year specifies the tax year for which the refund was issued. The amount column shows the monetary value of the refund. This data could be used to analyze trends in property tax refunds, identify properties that frequently receive refunds, or investigate the efficiency of the refund process.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on property tax refund checks issued by the city government. Each record details a specific refund, including the issue date, check or ACH number, property's BBL (Building, Block, Lot), effective date of overpayment, refund year, and the refund amount. This data allows for analysis of property tax refund patterns and identification of properties frequently receiving refunds.

Related Topics:
- Property Tax
- City Finance
- Government Spending
- Real Estate
- Tax Assessment
- Public Records

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Property Tax Refund: Tax Overpayment Return, Tax Rebate, Refund Check
- BBL: Building Block Lot, Property Identification Number, Parcel Number
- Issue Date: Refund Date, Check Date, Payment Date
- Refund Year: Tax Year, Year of Overpayment, Year Refund Applies To
- Amount: Refund Value, Monetary Value, Payment Amount

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in property tax refunds over time.
- Identify properties that frequently receive refunds and investigate potential causes.
- Evaluate the efficiency of the property tax refund process.
- Track government spending on property tax refunds.
- Cross-reference with property assessment data to identify potential discrepancies.

title: 2010 - 2011 School Attendance and Enrollment Statistics by District
ufd: This dataset contains school attendance and enrollment statistics for the 2010-2011 school year, broken down by district. It includes 35 rows of data, with each row representing a different school district. Key columns include the district identifier, year-to-date average attendance (ytd_attendance_avg_), and year-to-date average enrollment (ytd_enrollment_avg_). The average attendance is represented as a percentage, while enrollment is a raw number of students. The dataset could be used to compare attendance and enrollment rates across different districts. Researchers and policymakers could use this data to identify districts with low attendance or high enrollment and investigate the underlying causes. The dataset provides a snapshot of school performance metrics for the specified time period.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides school attendance and enrollment statistics for the 2010-2011 school year, organized by school district. It includes year-to-date average attendance (as a percentage) and year-to-date average enrollment numbers for 35 districts. This data allows for comparisons of attendance and enrollment across different districts.

Related Topics:
- School Performance
- Educational Statistics
- District Demographics

Applications and Use Cases:

- Analyze the relationship between enrollment and attendance.
- Identify districts with low attendance or high enrollment for further investigation.
- Benchmark school district performance against state averages.
- Inform policy decisions related to school funding and resource allocation.

title: 2017 – 2018 Anticipated Bilingual Education Programs
ufd: This dataset contains information about anticipated bilingual education programs in schools, focusing on Dual Language and Transitional Bilingual Education programs. It includes details for 100 rows of schools. Key columns include the school's unique identifier (`dbn`), the `school_name`, the `school_type` (e.g., Elementary, K-8, High school), the specific `program` offered (Dual Language or Transitional Bilingual Education), and the `language` of instruction for the program (e.g., Spanish, Chinese, French). Researchers and educators can use this data to understand the distribution of bilingual programs across different school types and languages. It can also be used to identify schools offering specific language programs or to analyze the prevalence of different bilingual education models. The data appears to be from the 2017-2018 academic year.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides information on anticipated bilingual education programs in schools, specifically Dual Language and Transitional Bilingual Education programs. It encompasses 100 schools and includes details such as school identifiers, school names, school types, program types, and the language of instruction. The data offers a snapshot of bilingual education offerings, likely from the 2017-2018 academic year.

Related Topics:

- Transitional Bilingual Education
- School Programs

Applications and Use Cases:

- Inform education policy and resource allocation related to bilingual education.

title: DOB Cellular Antenna Filings
ufd: This dataset contains information on applications filed with the Department of Buildings (DOB) for work on cellular antennas in New York City. Each row represents a single filing and includes details such as the job number, borough, house number, street name, block, and lot. The dataset also provides information on the job type and status, as well as the latest action date. Key columns for identifying the location of the antenna work include 'borough', 'house__', 'street_name', 'block', and 'lot'. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze trends in cellular antenna development, understand the geographic distribution of antenna work, and track the progress of antenna-related projects. The 'applicant_s_first_name' and 'applicant_s_last_name' columns could be used to identify frequent applicants.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details cellular antenna work applications filed with the NYC Department of Buildings (DOB). Each record represents a single filing and includes location information (borough, house number, street, block, lot), job details (type, status), and applicant information. The data can be used to analyze trends and geographic distribution of cellular antenna development in New York City.

Related Topics:

title: Real-World Fuel Efficiency
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at the real-world fuel efficiency of city vehicles compared to EPA estimates. It includes information on vehicle characteristics such as year, make, model, hybrid status, and standard type (e.g., sedan, SUV, van). Key columns include `epa_rating_city` (EPA's city MPG rating), `total_actual_miles`, `total_actual_fuel` consumed, and `actual_fuel_economy_geotab`. The dataset also calculates the `percent_difference_actual` between expected and actual fuel economy, offering insights into how real-world performance deviates from EPA estimates. Additionally, estimated fuel costs are provided. This data could be used to analyze the fuel efficiency of different vehicle types, identify discrepancies between EPA ratings and actual performance, and estimate the real-world fuel costs associated with city vehicles.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains real-world fuel efficiency data for city vehicles, comparing actual fuel consumption to EPA estimates. It includes vehicle characteristics like year, make, model, and type, alongside EPA city MPG ratings and actual fuel consumption metrics. The dataset calculates the percentage difference between expected and actual fuel economy, providing insights into the accuracy of EPA ratings in real-world conditions.

Related Topics:
- Fuel Efficiency
- Vehicle Performance
- EPA Ratings
- Environmental Impact
- Transportation
- Urban Planning
- Cost Analysis

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Fuel Economy: MPG, Miles Per Gallon, Fuel Consumption
- EPA Rating: Estimated MPG, Official Fuel Economy, Government Rating
- Actual Fuel Economy: Real-world MPG, Observed Fuel Consumption, Geotab Fuel Economy
- Vehicle Type: Car Class, Body Style, Standard Type (Sedan, SUV, Van)
- Percent Difference: MPG Deviation, Accuracy of EPA Rating, Variance in Fuel Economy
- Fuel Cost: Operating Cost, Expense, Expenditure

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the fuel efficiency of different vehicle types in urban environments.
- Identify discrepancies between EPA fuel economy ratings and real-world performance.
- Estimate the actual fuel costs associated with operating city vehicles.
- Evaluate the impact of vehicle characteristics (e.g., hybrid status) on fuel efficiency.
- Develop models to predict real-world fuel economy based on vehicle and usage data.
- Compare the fuel efficiency of different vehicle makes and models.
- Assess the environmental impact of city vehicle fleets.

title: NYPD Use of Force: Subjects
ufd: This dataset contains information on non-NYPD subjects involved in use of force incidents, as recorded in Threat, Resistance, or Injury (TRI) reports. Each row represents a single subject involved in such an incident. Key details include the `tri_incident_number` to identify the specific event, the `subject_injury_level` and `subject_injured` flags indicating whether the subject sustained injuries. The dataset also provides demographic information about the subject, such as `subject_race` and `subject_gender`. Furthermore, it details the type of force used against the subject (`force_against_mos`) and whether the subject themselves used force (`subject_used_force`). This data could be used to analyze patterns in use of force incidents, understand the demographics of individuals involved, and assess the types of force most frequently employed. Note that in this sample of 100 rows, all subjects are male, Black, uninjured, subjected to physical force, and used force themselves.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details non-NYPD subjects involved in use of force incidents, as documented in Threat, Resistance, or Injury (TRI) reports. Each record represents an individual subject and includes details on the incident, subject demographics, injuries sustained, and the types of force used. It also indicates whether the subject used force themselves.

Related Topics:

Applications and Use Cases:

title: Forestry Planting Spaces
ufd: This dataset contains information about forestry planting spaces managed by NYC Parks & Recreation. It includes the location of these spaces, identified by building number, street name, and cross streets. Each planting space is associated with a community board and sanitation zone. The dataset also provides political district information such as zipcode, city council, state senate, state assembly, and congressional districts. You can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of planting spaces across different neighborhoods and political districts in New York City. The 'psstatus' column indicates whether a planting space is populated, empty, or retired. The 'geometry' column provides the geographic coordinates for each planting space, enabling spatial analysis and mapping.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations and attributes of forestry planting spaces managed by NYC Parks & Recreation. It includes geographic location data, political district information, and status indicators for each planting space. This allows for analysis of planting space distribution and characteristics across New York City.

Related Topics:
- Urban Forestry

- New York City
- Parks and Recreation
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Planting Space: Tree bed, tree pit, planting area
- Political Districts: City Council District, State Senate District, Congressional District
- Status: Condition, 'psstatus' (populated, empty, retired)
- Geographic Coordinates: Latitude, Longitude, 'geometry'

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the spatial distribution of planting spaces across different community boards.
- Identify areas with a high concentration of empty or retired planting spaces for potential revitalization projects.
- Map planting spaces to understand their proximity to other environmental features or infrastructure.
- Evaluate the relationship between planting space distribution and political district boundaries.
- Support urban forestry planning and resource allocation decisions.

title: Exclusive Pedestrian Signal (Barnes Dance) Locations
ufd: This dataset contains information about the locations of Exclusive Pedestrian Signals, also known as Barnes Dance signals, in New York City. These signals temporarily halt all traffic to allow pedestrians to cross intersections in any direction. The dataset includes the geographic coordinates (`the_geom`) of each signal, along with its location described by borough (`boroname`), borough code (`borocode`), and neighborhood (`ntaname`). You can also find the intersecting streets (`main_stree` and `cross_stre`). The dataset also contains information about political districts such as congressional district (`congdist`). Additionally, the dataset includes information about flood zones (`femafldz`) and hurricane evacuation zones (`hrcevac`). This data could be used by city planners to analyze pedestrian safety, by researchers to study traffic patterns, or by residents to find the nearest Barnes Dance intersection.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details the locations and attributes of Exclusive Pedestrian Signals (Barnes Dance signals) throughout New York City. It provides geographic coordinates and location details such as borough, neighborhood, and intersecting streets for each signal. The dataset also includes information on political districts, flood zones, and hurricane evacuation zones associated with each location.

**Related Topics:**
- Pedestrian Safety
- Traffic Management
- Urban Planning
- New York City Infrastructure
- Emergency Preparedness
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Exclusive Pedestrian Signal: Barnes Dance, Pedestrian Scramble, All-Way Walk
- Intersection: Junction, Crossing
- Borough: NYC Borough (Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx, Staten Island)
- Geographic Coordinates: Latitude, Longitude, the_geom
- Flood Zone: FEMA Flood Zone, femafldz
- Hurricane Evacuation Zone: hrcevac

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Analyze the distribution of pedestrian signals across different neighborhoods.
- Identify areas with high pedestrian traffic and potential safety concerns.
- Evaluate the impact of Barnes Dance signals on traffic flow and pedestrian safety.
- Integrate the data with other datasets to assess flood risk and evacuation planning.
- Develop a mobile app to help pedestrians locate the nearest Barnes Dance intersection.

title: 2021 City Council February Attendance
ufd: This dataset provides insights into student attendance rates for the City of New York during February 2021. It focuses on students whose learning preference is remote, blended, or missing, and who have attended school in person at least once since February 1, 2021. The data is broken down by geographic unit (Citywide), and further categorized by student groups such as "STH Not in Shelters," "Female," "Male," and grade levels. Key metrics include the overall attendance rate, the percentage of remote students online, and attendance rates for blended students, both overall and specifically in-person or online. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze attendance patterns across different student categories and learning modalities. This information can help in understanding the impact of remote and blended learning on attendance and identifying potential disparities among student groups. The dataset includes attendance data only for students for whom attendance data is reported.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains student attendance rates for New York City in February 2021, focusing on remote, blended, and students with missing learning preference data who have attended in-person at least once since February 1, 2021. The data is aggregated citywide and segmented by student groups (e.g., gender, grade level, students not in shelters). Key metrics include overall attendance rate, percentage of remote students online, and blended student attendance rates (overall, in-person, and online).

title: Citywide HRA- Administered Medicaid Enrollees
ufd: This dataset provides a monthly count of individuals enrolled in Medicaid, administered by the HRA (Human Resources Administration). It breaks down enrollment by different categories of assistance, including those receiving cash assistance, supplemental security income, and nursing home care, as well as those receiving medical assistance only. The "month" column indicates the date for which the enrollment numbers are reported. The "total_hra_enrolled_medical_assistance_individuals" column represents the overall number of people enrolled in HRA-administered Medicaid. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to track trends in Medicaid enrollment, understand the distribution of enrollees across different assistance categories, and assess the impact of policy changes on access to healthcare. The data spans 100 months. Each category of assistance has its own column showing the number of enrollees.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains monthly counts of individuals enrolled in Medicaid through the NYC Human Resources Administration (HRA). It details enrollment numbers across various assistance categories, including cash assistance, SSI, nursing home care, and medical assistance only. The data allows for tracking trends in Medicaid enrollment and understanding the distribution of enrollees.

title: Debt Burden
ufd: This dataset, titled "Debt Burden," provides insights into New York City's financial obligations. It presents various calculations of the city's debt burden as percentages, offering a comprehensive view of its financial health. Key columns include `dbt_bdn_typ`, which specifies the type of debt burden calculation (e.g., "Total Debt Service as % of Total Revenues"), and `fy1_yr`, representing the fiscal year for which the data is reported. The dataset also includes percentage values (`fy1_pct` through `fy5_pct`) projecting the debt burden for the current and subsequent four fiscal years. The `ft_nt` column provides important footnotes and clarifications regarding the types of debt included in the calculations. This dataset is updated twice a year with preliminary and executive budget data. Users can leverage this information to analyze trends in NYC's debt, assess the city's financial stability, and make informed decisions related to municipal finance.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The "Debt Burden" dataset offers a detailed look at New York City's debt obligations. It presents calculations of the city's debt burden as percentages across multiple fiscal years. Key data points include the type of debt burden calculation, fiscal year, projected debt burden percentages, and explanatory footnotes.

Related Topics:
- Municipal Finance
- City Budgeting
- Government Debt
- New York City Finances
- Fiscal Policy

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Debt Burden: Financial obligations, debt service, debt ratio
- Fiscal Year (FY): Budget year, reporting period
- Debt Service: Principal and interest payments
- Total Revenues: City income, tax revenue, funds received
- Financial Stability: Economic health, solvency, creditworthiness

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in NYC's debt burden over time.
- Assess the city's financial stability and credit risk.
- Compare NYC's debt burden to that of other major cities.
- Inform investment decisions related to NYC municipal bonds.
- Evaluate the impact of fiscal policies on the city's debt.
- Forecast future debt burden based on historical trends.

title: 2022 Fall Diversity in Admissions Outcomes - MS
ufd: This dataset contains information on diversity in middle school admissions outcomes for Fall 2022. It focuses on the offers made to prioritized groups, such as students eligible for Free or Reduced Lunch (FRL), students with temporary housing (STH), and English Language Learners (ELL). Key columns include `school_name`, `prioritized_group`, `diversitytarget` (the target percentage for diversity), `total_offers_to_school`, `offers_to_prioritized_group`, and `diversity_percentage_from` (the actual diversity percentage achieved). The dataset also indicates whether the school met its diversity goal (`met_diversity_goal`) and whether the data is district-wide (`district_wide`). This data could be used to analyze the effectiveness of diversity initiatives in middle school admissions, identify schools that are successfully reaching prioritized groups, and understand the distribution of offers across different student populations. Researchers, policymakers, and school administrators can use this information to inform strategies for promoting equitable access to education.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides insights into diversity in middle school admissions outcomes for Fall 2022, specifically focusing on offers made to prioritized student groups like FRL, STH, and ELL students. It includes data on diversity targets, total offers, offers to prioritized groups, and achieved diversity percentages for each school. The dataset also indicates whether schools met their diversity goals and if the data represents district-wide figures.

title: 2014 Green Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records from green taxis in New York City during 2014. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including pickup and dropoff times, locations, trip distance, and fare details. Key columns include `lpep_pickup_datetime` and `lpep_dropoff_datetime` for timestamps, `pickup_longitude`, `pickup_latitude`, `dropoff_longitude`, and `dropoff_latitude` for locations, and `trip_distance` for the length of the trip. The dataset also provides information on payment types (`payment_type`), fare amount (`fare_amount`), and passenger count (`passenger_count`). Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi ridership patterns, analyze fare structures, and understand the spatial distribution of taxi trips in the city. The `vendorid` column identifies the Technology Service Provider, while the `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip record was temporarily stored in the vehicle before being sent.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains detailed trip information for green taxis operating in New York City during 2014. It includes pickup and dropoff timestamps and geographic coordinates, along with trip distance, fare amounts, and payment details for each ride. The data allows for analysis of taxi ridership patterns, spatial distribution of trips, and fare structures.

title: DSNY Waste Characterization - Comparative Results
ufd: This dataset contains the results of waste characterization studies conducted by the NYC Department of Sanitation (DSNY) in 2005, 2013, 2017, and 2023. It provides a comparative analysis of the composition of the city's waste streams over time. Key columns include `year` representing the year of the study, `material_group` categorizing the type of waste material (e.g., Paper, Plastic, Metal), `comparative_category` providing a more granular classification of the waste, and `dsny_diversion_summary` indicating how the waste is managed (e.g., recycling, composting). The percentage columns (`aggregate_percent`, `refuse_percent`, `mgp_percent`, `paper_percent`, and `organics_percent`) show the proportion of each material type in the waste stream.  The `generator_residential_schools` column specifies the source of the waste. This dataset can be used to analyze trends in waste composition, evaluate the effectiveness of waste diversion programs, and inform future waste management strategies.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset presents waste characterization study results from the NYC Department of Sanitation (DSNY) for the years 2005, 2013, 2017, and 2023. It details the composition of New York City's waste streams, categorizing waste by material group, comparative category, and DSNY diversion method. Percentage breakdowns are provided for various material types, offering insights into waste management trends and the effectiveness of diversion programs.

title: NYPD Officer Profile - Members of Service
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of active uniformed members of service (UMOS) in the NYPD. Each row represents an individual officer, identified by a unique profile ID and name. Key details include the officer's rank (e.g., Police Officer, Sergeant), their command or precinct assignment, and their shield number. The dataset also tracks the officer's appointment date, total number of arrests, and department recognitions received. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study officer demographics, deployment patterns across different commands, and the relationship between officer experience and performance metrics like arrests and recognitions. Note that officers who retire, resign, or are terminated are not included in this dataset.
sfd:

This dataset contains information on active uniformed members of service (UMOS) in the NYPD. It includes details such as rank, command assignment, shield number, appointment date, total arrests, and department recognitions for each officer. The data can be used to analyze officer demographics, deployment strategies, and performance metrics.

title: Civilian Complaint Review Board: Penalties
ufd: This dataset contains information on penalties for NYPD officers with substantiated complaints of misconduct. It includes details on the Civilian Complaint Review Board (CCRB) substantiated officer disposition and the board's discipline recommendation. Key columns include `complaint_id`, a unique identifier for each complaint, `ccrb_substantiated_officer_disposition`, describing the CCRB's finding, and `nypd_officer_penalty`, detailing the final penalty issued by the NYPD Commissioner. The `officer_is_apu` column indicates whether the case was handled by the Administrative Prosecution Unit (APU). This dataset can be used to analyze trends in police misconduct penalties, compare CCRB recommendations with final NYPD penalties, and assess the impact of APU involvement on case outcomes. Note that most of the columns related to penalties have a high null fraction, meaning that information is not available for all rows. The data is current as of `2025-11-19`.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details penalties issued to NYPD officers following substantiated misconduct complaints. It includes information on Civilian Complaint Review Board (CCRB) findings, discipline recommendations, and the final penalties determined by the NYPD Commissioner. The dataset also indicates whether the Administrative Prosecution Unit (APU) was involved in the case.

Related Topics:
- Police misconduct
- Civilian oversight
- Law enforcement accountability
- NYPD
- CCRB
- Disciplinary actions

Concepts and Synonyms:
- CCRB: Civilian Complaint Review Board, civilian oversight agency
- NYPD Officer Penalty: Discipline, punishment, sanction
- Substantiated Complaint: Founded complaint, proven misconduct
- Officer Disposition: Finding, determination, outcome
- APU: Administrative Prosecution Unit
- Misconduct: Wrongdoing, violation, infraction

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in police misconduct penalties over time.
- Compare CCRB recommendations with final NYPD penalties to identify discrepancies.
- Assess the impact of APU involvement on case outcomes and penalty severity.
- Investigate the relationship between different types of misconduct and the resulting penalties.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of different disciplinary measures in deterring future misconduct.

title: Historical Driver Application Status
ufd: This dataset contains historical status information for driver applications. Each row represents a single application, identified by a unique application number (`app_no`). Key details include the type of application (`type`), the date it was submitted (`app_date`), and its current status (`status`), which can be either "Denied" or "Approved - License Issued". The dataset also tracks the completion status of various requirements, such as drug tests, WAV courses, defensive driving courses, driver exams, and medical clearance forms.  Additionally, the `other_requirements` column provides details on any outstanding items needed for the application. This data could be used to analyze application approval rates, identify common bottlenecks in the licensing process, or understand the time it takes to complete different requirements. The `last_updated` column indicates when the application record was last modified.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides a historical record of driver application statuses, encompassing details like application type, submission date, and current status (Approved or Denied). It tracks the completion of essential requirements such as drug tests, WAV courses, and medical clearances. The data can be used to analyze application approval processes and identify potential areas for improvement.

Related Topics:
- Driver Licensing
- Transportation Regulation
- Application Processing
- Compliance
- Government Services

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Driver Application: License application, permit application, driving permit
- Application Status: Approval status, application outcome, application result
- Requirements: Prerequisites, qualifications, conditions
- WAV Course: Wheelchair Accessible Vehicle training, accessibility course
- Drug Test: Substance screening, toxicology report
- Defensive Driving Course: Safe driving course, driver safety education
- Driver Exam: Driving test, road test, skills assessment
- Medical Clearance: Medical certificate, health assessment, doctor's approval

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze application approval rates and identify factors influencing approval.
- Identify bottlenecks in the licensing process and optimize workflow.
- Track the time taken to complete different requirements and estimate processing times.
- Predict application outcomes based on applicant characteristics and requirement completion.
- Monitor compliance with licensing regulations and identify potential violations.

title: Denied TW and Wholesale Market Companies
ufd: This dataset contains information about Trade Waste and Wholesale Market companies that have been denied a license or registration by the New York City Business Integrity Commission. Each record represents a company and includes details such as the BIC number (a unique identifier), account name, trade name, and the type and industry of the application. The application status is consistently "Denied," with the date of the denial also provided. Location information, including street address, city, state, and postcode, is available for each company. Researchers and analysts can use this data to understand the characteristics of businesses that are denied licenses, identify trends in specific industries or locations, and potentially inform policy decisions related to business regulation and compliance. The dataset also indicates whether the application was a renewal.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details companies involved in Trade Waste and Wholesale Markets that were denied a license or registration by the New York City Business Integrity Commission (BIC). It includes company-specific information such as BIC number, account name, trade name, application type and industry, denial date, and location details. All applications in the dataset have a status of "Denied."

Related Topics:
- Business Integrity

- Waste Management Industry
- Wholesale Market Industry
- New York City Business
- Regulatory Compliance
- Business Denials

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Business Integrity Commission (BIC)
- License Denial
- Registration Rejection
- Trade Waste Management
- Wholesale Market Operations
- Application Status: Denied
- BIC Number (Unique Identifier)

Applications and Use Cases:

- Identify trends in license denials across specific industries.
- Investigate geographic patterns of denied applications in New York City.
- Inform policy decisions related to business regulation and compliance in the Trade Waste and Wholesale Market sectors.
- Research the impact of license denials on business operations.
- Develop predictive models to identify businesses at high risk of license denial.

title: Universal Solicitation for Broadband Asset Dataset
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive inventory of city-owned and city partner assets, focusing on those relevant to broadband infrastructure. It includes key details such as the name and location (latitude, longitude, street address, city, postcode, and borough) of each asset. The dataset also specifies the asset's domain (e.g., LIBRARIES), its neighborhood tabulation area (nta_code), the responsible agency, the operator, and the owner. Primarily focused on public libraries, the data reveals which entities manage and own these assets. Users can leverage this dataset to understand the distribution of city assets, identify potential locations for broadband expansion, or analyze the roles of different agencies in managing public resources. The dataset contains 100 rows and 28 columns.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset inventories city-owned and partner assets, particularly those relevant to broadband infrastructure planning. It details asset locations (latitude, longitude, address) and administrative information like responsible agency, operator, and owner. The data focuses on public libraries and their management structure, providing a view of city resource distribution.

Related Topics:
- Broadband Infrastructure
- City Assets
- Public Libraries
- Municipal Government
- Resource Management
- Geographic Data

Concepts and Synonyms:
- City Assets: Municipal properties, public resources, government holdings
- Broadband Infrastructure: Internet access, telecommunications network, connectivity infrastructure
- Responsible Agency: Managing department, overseeing organization, administrative body
- Operator: Manager, service provider, operating entity
- Location: Latitude, longitude, address, geographic coordinates

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identify optimal locations for broadband expansion.
- Analyze the distribution of city-owned assets.
- Understand the roles of different agencies in managing public resources.
- Map the ownership and management structure of public libraries.
- Support city planning and resource allocation decisions.

title: DOB Sign Application Filings
ufd: This dataset contains information on sign applications filed with the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB). It includes details such as the borough, house number, street name, block, lot, and BIN (Building Identification Number) associated with each application. The dataset also provides the job type, job status, a description of the job status, and the latest action date. Key columns for understanding the status of an application include `job_status` and `job_status_descrp`. Researchers, city planners, and advertising companies can use this dataset to analyze trends in sign applications, understand compliance with regulations, and identify areas with high sign activity. The data can also be used to assess the efficiency of the application process and identify potential areas for improvement.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides comprehensive information on sign applications submitted to the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB). It includes details about the location of the sign, such as borough, house number, street name, block, and lot, as well as the status of the application, including job type, job status, and latest action date. This data can be used to analyze trends in sign applications and understand compliance with regulations.

Related Topics:
- Building Permits
- Urban Planning
- Real Estate Development
- Advertising Regulations
- NYC Department of Buildings (DOB)
- Construction

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Sign Application: Sign Permit, Sign Installation Request
- Job Status: Application Status, Permit Status, Project Status
- Job Status Description: Status Details, Application Description, Permit Description
- BIN (Building Identification Number): Building ID, Property ID
- DOB: Department of Buildings, NYC Buildings Department

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in sign applications across different boroughs of NYC.
- Identify areas with high sign activity for targeted advertising campaigns.
- Assess the efficiency of the sign application process by analyzing job status and timelines.
- Understand compliance with sign regulations by examining application details and job status.
- Identify potential areas for improvement in the sign application process.
- Track the progress of individual sign applications.

title: 2019-2020 PSAL Report - (December 2020)
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed breakdown of student demographics within the NYC Department of Education's Public Schools Athletic League (PSAL) for the 2019-2020 school year. It includes information on the total number of students, as well as the number and percentage of students belonging to different racial and ethnic groups (Black, Hispanic, Asian, and White). The dataset also breaks down student populations by gender, students with disabilities, and English language learners. Key columns include `category_type` (Citywide, Borough, or District), `total_number_of_students`, and the various columns detailing the number and percentage of students within each demographic category. This data can be used to analyze student demographics across different categories, identify trends in student populations, and inform decisions related to resource allocation and program development within the PSAL. Researchers and policymakers can use this information to understand equity and access within the athletic league.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains student demographic information for the NYC Department of Education's Public Schools Athletic League (PSAL) during the 2019-2020 school year. It provides a breakdown of student populations by race/ethnicity, gender, students with disabilities, and English language learners. The data is categorized by Citywide, Borough, and District levels, offering a granular view of student demographics within the PSAL.
