- Students with Disabilities: Special education students, students with IEPs, SWD
- English Language Learners: ELL, Limited English Proficiency (LEP), Multilingual Learners

Applications and Use Cases:

- Inform resource allocation and program development to promote equity.
- Evaluate the representation of different student groups in athletic programs.

- Compare student demographics across different boroughs and districts.

title: Students Receiving Recommended Special Education Programs by Program Type
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the special education services received by students, broken down by school and primary program type. It details the number of students fully receiving, partially receiving, or not receiving services, along with the corresponding percentages. Key columns include `school_dbn`, a unique identifier for each school, and `primary_program_type`, which specifies the type of educational program, such as Integrated Co-Teaching Services or Special Class. The columns `fully_receiving`, `partially_receiving`, and `not_receiving` show the counts of students in each category, while the percentage columns provide a relative measure. Note that some values are suppressed (represented by '*' or '<=5') to protect student privacy. This data can be used to analyze the distribution of special education services across different schools and program types, identify potential disparities, and inform resource allocation decisions. Researchers and educators can use this dataset to understand the landscape of special education service delivery.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the provision of special education services to students, categorized by school and primary program type. It includes counts and percentages of students fully, partially, or not receiving services. Data is suppressed in some instances to protect student privacy.

Related Topics:
- Special Education
- Education Services
- School Performance
- Student Support
- Resource Allocation
- Educational Programs

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Special Education Services: SPED, IEP (Individualized Education Program), Special Needs Education
- Primary Program Type: Educational Program, Program Model, Service Delivery Model
- School DBN: School Identifier, School Code, School ID
- Fully Receiving: Complete Services, Full Support
- Partially Receiving: Some Services, Partial Support
- Not Receiving: No Services, Without Support

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the distribution of special education services across schools.
- Identify disparities in service provision based on program type.
- Inform resource allocation decisions for special education programs.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of different special education program models.
- Research trends in special education service delivery.

title: Digital Tax Map: Condominiums
ufd: This dataset contains information about condominiums in New York City, extracted from the Department of Finance's Digital Tax Map collection. Each row represents a condominium and includes its borough, block, and lot (BBL) information, as well as a unique condominium key and number. The `condo_base_boro` column indicates the borough in which the condominium is located, while `condo_base_lot` provides the base lot number. The dataset also includes the condominium's billing BBL and, when available, the condominium's name. This data can be used to analyze condominium distribution across the city, link condominium data with other datasets using the BBL, or identify specific condominiums for property research. Keep in mind that the `condo_name` field is sparsely populated. The data is updated monthly from the DOF's internal system.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides details on condominiums in New York City, sourced from the Department of Finance's Digital Tax Map. It includes key identifiers like borough, block, and lot (BBL) information, along with a unique condominium key and name (when available). Updated monthly, this data allows for analysis of condominium distribution and property research.

Related Topics:

- Tax Data

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Condominium: Condo, Apartment, Co-op
- Borough, Block, Lot (BBL): Property Identifier, Tax Lot, Parcel Number
- Department of Finance (DOF): NYC DOF, Tax Authority
- Condo Key: Unique Identifier, Property ID
- Condo Name: Building Name, Development Name

Applications and Use Cases:

- Link condominium data with other datasets using BBL identifiers.
- Identify specific condominiums for property research and valuation.
- Track changes in condominium ownership and development over time.
- Map condominium locations and density.

title: DSNY Salt Usage
ufd: This dataset contains information on the amount of salt used by the New York City Department of Sanitation (DSNY) during snowstorms. The data tracks salt usage in tons for each borough (Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens, and Staten Island) after individual storms. Each row represents the salt usage reported on a specific date for a particular storm event. The `dsny_storm` column identifies the storm, and the `date_of_report` column indicates when the salt usage was recorded. The `total_tons` column provides the overall salt usage across all boroughs for that storm and date. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze salt usage patterns across different boroughs during snow events. This information can help optimize resource allocation and improve snow removal strategies, contributing to safer roadways during winter weather. The dataset covers 100 storms.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details salt usage by the New York City Department of Sanitation (DSNY) during 100 snowstorms. It includes the date of report, the specific storm event, and the total tons of salt used across all five boroughs (Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens, and Staten Island). This data can be used to analyze salt distribution and consumption patterns during winter weather events in NYC.

Related Topics:
- Snow removal
- Winter weather management
- City resource allocation
- Department of Sanitation (DSNY)
- Borough-level data
- Salt usage
- Storm events

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Salt: Sodium chloride, de-icing agent, road salt
- DSNY Storm: Snowstorm event, winter storm, blizzard
- Total Tons: Salt quantity, salt amount, salt volume, salt weight
- Borough: Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island, NYC districts
- Date of Report: Reporting date, recording date, observation date

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze salt usage trends across different boroughs during snowstorms.
- Optimize salt distribution strategies based on historical usage patterns.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of snow removal operations.
- Predict future salt needs based on weather forecasts and historical data.
- Compare salt usage across different storm intensities.
- Develop more efficient and environmentally friendly de-icing methods.

title: 2018-2021 Daily Attendance by School
ufd: This dataset provides daily attendance information for schools, including the number of students enrolled, present, absent, and released. Each record represents a specific school (identified by its `school_dbn`) on a particular date. The `schoolyear` column indicates the academic year the data pertains to. Researchers and educators can use this data to analyze attendance patterns, identify schools with high absence rates, and understand the factors that contribute to student absenteeism. The dataset could also be used to evaluate the impact of attendance on student performance and to develop interventions to improve attendance rates. Note that the current dataset only contains data from the 2018-2019 school year and the 'released' column contains only 0 values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains daily school attendance records, detailing the number of students enrolled, present, absent, and released for each school on a given date. The data is organized by school (identified by `school_dbn`) and date, with the `schoolyear` column specifying the academic year. Currently, the dataset includes data only from the 2018-2019 school year.

Related Topics:
- School attendance
- Student absenteeism
- Education statistics
- School performance
- Enrollment data
- Academic year data

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Attendance: Presence, being present, attending school
- Absenteeism: Absence, truancy, non-attendance
- Enrollment: Number of students registered, student body size
- School DBN: School district borough number, school identifier
- Released: Dismissed, discharged (in this dataset, always 0)

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze attendance patterns across schools.
- Identify schools with high rates of absenteeism.
- Investigate the relationship between attendance and student outcomes.
- Develop and evaluate interventions to improve attendance.
- Track attendance trends over time (if more years were available).

title: SY2021 Local Law 60 Annual Report
ufd: This dataset provides a summary of room types and their utilization in Brooklyn schools for the 2020-2021 school year, as part of the Local Law 60 Annual Report. Each row represents a specific room category within a school building, identified by its building ID (`bldg_id`) and name (`bldg_name`). The dataset includes information on the borough (`boro`), community school district (`csd`), and city council district where the school is located. Key columns include `room_category`, which specifies the type of room (e.g., Auditorium, Library), and `of_rooms`, indicating the number of rooms of that type. The `shared` column indicates whether the room is shared among multiple schools. This data can be used to analyze school capacity, room allocation, and resource sharing within the Brooklyn school system. Researchers, policymakers, and school administrators can use this information to understand space utilization patterns and make informed decisions about resource allocation and facility management.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details room types and their utilization in Brooklyn schools during the 2020-2021 school year, as reported under Local Law 60. It provides information on the number of rooms per category (e.g., Auditorium, Library) within each school building, identified by building ID and name. The data also includes location details like borough, community school district, and city council district, along with an indicator of whether the room is shared.

Related Topics:

- Space utilization

- Local Law 60
- Brooklyn schools

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Room Category: Room type, space designation
- Building ID: bldg_id, school identifier
- Number of Rooms: of_rooms, room count, quantity of rooms
- Shared Room: Shared space, jointly used room, common area
- Community School District: CSD, school district
- Borough: boro, NYC borough

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze room allocation and utilization patterns in Brooklyn schools.
- Identify schools with specific room type shortages or surpluses.
- Assess the prevalence of shared rooms and their impact on school resources.
- Support resource allocation and facility management decisions.
- Inform policy related to school space and resource optimization.
- Compare room utilization across different community school districts.

title: Capital Project Detail Data - Milestones
ufd: This dataset provides details on capital projects managed by New York City agencies. It includes information on project milestones, schedules, and managing agencies. Key columns include `managing_agcy`, which identifies the agency responsible for the project, `project_id`, a unique identifier for each project, and `project_descr`, which offers a brief description of the project's purpose, such as ADA compliance or infrastructure upgrades. The dataset also tracks the progress of each project through `task_description` and associated start and end dates (`orig_start_date`, `orig_end_date`, `task_start_date`, `task_end_date`). While the dataset was updated regularly until January 2024, it is now superseded by the Capital Projects Dashboard. However, this data can still be valuable for historical analysis of project timelines and agency performance. Researchers and city planners could use this information to understand past project management practices and identify trends in capital project execution.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details capital projects managed by New York City agencies, including project milestones, schedules, and responsible agencies. It contains information on project identifiers, descriptions, task details, and associated start and end dates. While superseded by the Capital Projects Dashboard as of January 2024, this dataset remains valuable for historical analysis of project timelines and agency performance.

Related Topics:

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Capital Projects: Infrastructure projects, public works, construction projects
- Managing Agency: Responsible agency, lead agency, project sponsor
- Project ID: Project identifier, unique project number
- Project Description: Project purpose, scope of work, project overview
- Task Description: Milestone description, activity description, work package
- Project Timeline: Project schedule, project duration, start and end dates

Applications and Use Cases:
- Historical analysis of NYC capital project timelines.
- Evaluating agency performance in managing capital projects.
- Identifying trends in capital project execution.
- Comparing planned vs. actual project timelines.
- Researching the impact of specific agencies on project outcomes.
- Understanding past project management practices in NYC.

title: School Bus Report October_2021_21-993
ufd: This dataset provides a monthly snapshot of student transportation, specifically focusing on school bus usage. It details the number of students routed on buses by various bus companies from January to June 2021. Key columns include the month of the report, the name of the bus company, and two columns representing counts of students traveling. The dataset likely captures planned routes, not necessarily actual ridership. Researchers and education officials can use this data to analyze transportation patterns, compare bus company utilization, and potentially identify trends in student ridership over time. This information can inform decisions related to resource allocation, route optimization, and transportation planning for students.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains monthly data on student bus transportation from January to June 2021. It details the number of students routed on school buses by different bus companies. The data includes the month, bus company name, and counts of students routed.

title: SCOUT CORE
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the condition and customer service at New York City's walk-in service centers through the Customers Observing and Reporting Experience (CORE) program. It includes facility-specific information such as the agency responsible, the facility's name and address, and the borough in which it's located. Key columns include `facility_cleaning_maintenance` and `facility_operations_score`, which contribute to the `facility_overall_score`, reflecting the facility's rating. The data can be used to identify high-performing and underperforming facilities, track improvements over time, and inform decisions related to resource allocation and service delivery. Users can analyze the data to understand the factors that contribute to positive customer experiences and identify areas for improvement across different agencies and boroughs. The dataset covers the year 2023. It includes location information such as address and zip code, as well as community board and council district.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information about the condition and customer service performance of New York City's walk-in service centers, collected through the CORE program. It includes facility details like agency, name, address, borough, and scores related to cleaning, maintenance, operations, and overall performance. The data allows for analysis of facility performance, identification of areas for improvement, and tracking of changes over time.

title: 2019 For Hire Vehicles Trip Data
ufd:
This dataset contains trip records from For-Hire Vehicles (FHV) in New York City, specifically from January 2019. It includes information about trips made by traditional livery, luxury, and black car services. Each row in the dataset represents a single FHV trip.

Key columns include `dispatching_base_num`, which identifies the base that dispatched the vehicle, `pickup_datetime` and `dropoff_datetime`, indicating when the trip started and ended, and `dolocationid`, representing the drop-off location's taxi zone ID. The dataset could be used to analyze FHV trip patterns, understand demand in different taxi zones, or examine the activity of specific dispatching bases. Researchers and transportation planners could use this data to gain insights into FHV usage and its impact on the city's transportation network. Note that some `dolocationid` values are missing.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed trip records for For-Hire Vehicles (FHV) operating in New York City during January 2019. It focuses on trips made by livery, luxury, and black car services. The data includes timestamps for pickup and drop-off, as well as location identifiers and dispatching base information.

Related Topics:
- Transportation
- New York City
- For-Hire Vehicles (FHV)
- Taxi Data

Concepts and Synonyms:
- For-Hire Vehicle (FHV): Livery car, Black car, Luxury car, Private transportation
- Dispatching Base Number: Base ID, Dispatcher identifier, Company code
- Pickup/Dropoff Datetime: Trip start time, Trip end time, Timestamp
- DolocationID: Drop-off location ID, Destination zone, Taxi zone ID
- Trip Record: Ride data, Journey information, Transportation event

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze FHV trip patterns and demand across different NYC taxi zones.
- Investigate the operational characteristics of specific FHV dispatching bases.
- Model and predict FHV demand based on time of day and location.
- Evaluate the impact of FHV services on the overall transportation network.
- Develop visualizations to represent FHV trip density and flow.

title: Revenue Budget & Financial Plan--Qtr1
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at the revenue budget and financial plans of city government agencies. It includes adopted and modified revenue amounts, broken down by revenue class, category, and source. Key columns include `fiscal_year` for the relevant financial period, `agency_name` to identify the responsible agency, and `revenue_category_name` to classify the type of revenue. The `adopted_amt` and `curr_mod_amt` columns represent the original and currently modified revenue amounts, respectively. Researchers, city planners, and financial analysts can use this dataset to understand the city's revenue streams, track financial performance, and analyze budget allocations across different agencies and revenue categories. The data spans multiple years, allowing for trend analysis and forecasting. Furthermore, the inclusion of revenue source details enables a granular understanding of where the city's funds originate.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains detailed revenue budget information for city government agencies, including adopted and modified revenue amounts. Data is categorized by revenue class, category, and source, and spans multiple fiscal years. Key fields include agency name, revenue category, and corresponding revenue amounts, enabling analysis of city revenue streams and budget allocations.

Related Topics:

- Fiscal Year: Financial Year, Budget Year
- Agency Name: Department, Bureau, Office
- Revenue Category Name: Revenue Type, Income Category, Funding Source

- Identify key revenue sources for the city.
- Evaluate the impact of budget modifications on agency finances.

ufd: This dataset contains information related to investigations and reporting from the New York City Office of Pupil Transportation. Researchers or analysts interested in the oversight and accountability mechanisms within the NYC Office of Pupil Transportation could use this data. It may also be valuable for understanding how customer support interactions are categorized and managed. The data covers at least the period of September 1 - December 31, 2020.

title: 2013 - 2014 School Locations
ufd: This dataset provides information about school locations, including their names, addresses, and the grades they serve. It includes details such as the school's location code, the grades offered (both as a text string with special education noted and a final, cleaned text string), the type and category of the location (e.g., General Academic Elementary), and who manages the school. The dataset also contains the opening date of the school and its current status. Key columns for analysis include `location_name`, `location_type_description`, `location_category_description`, and `grades_final_text`. Researchers and education professionals can use this data to analyze the distribution of different school types, understand the grade levels served by schools in specific locations, or track changes in school characteristics over time. The `managed_by_name` column indicates that all schools in this dataset are managed by the DOE (Department of Education).

title: Watershed Water Quality Data
ufd: This dataset contains water quality data collected at the DEL18DT site, focusing on turbidity and fecal coliform levels. Turbidity, measured in Nephelometric Turbidity Units (NTU), is recorded every four hours (12am, 4am, 8am, 12pm, 4pm, and 8pm), along with a 24-hour average. The dataset also includes daily fecal coliform counts per 100ml. These measurements are used to monitor compliance with the Surface Water Treatment Rule (SWTR) and Filtration Avoidance Determination (FAD). Researchers and water quality professionals can use this data to analyze trends in water quality, assess the effectiveness of water treatment processes, and ensure regulatory compliance. Each record represents a specific date and provides a snapshot of the water quality at that time. The data spans 100 days.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides water quality measurements from the DEL18DT site, including turbidity (NTU) readings taken every four hours and daily fecal coliform counts. The data spans 100 days and includes 24-hour average turbidity. It's used for monitoring compliance with water quality regulations like the Surface Water Treatment Rule (SWTR) and Filtration Avoidance Determination (FAD).

Related Topics:
- Water Quality
- Environmental Monitoring
- Public Health
- Regulatory Compliance
- Water Treatment
- Surface Water
- Pollution

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Turbidity: Cloudiness, haziness, water clarity
- Fecal Coliform: Bacteria, E. coli, microbial contamination
- NTU: Nephelometric Turbidity Units, measurement of turbidity
- SWTR: Surface Water Treatment Rule, water treatment regulation
- FAD: Filtration Avoidance Determination, filtration exemption
- DEL18DT: Water sampling location, site identifier

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in turbidity and fecal coliform levels over time.

- Develop predictive models for water quality parameters.

- Compare water quality data across different time periods.

title: AddressPoint
ufd: This dataset provides precise geographic locations, or address points, for addresses in New York City. It includes the coordinates of each address point, represented by latitude and longitude, along with its corresponding Building Identification Number (BIN) and ZIP code. The dataset also contains information about the street type (e.g., ST, AVE, PL) and various computed regions for geographic aggregation and analysis. Researchers, city planners, and emergency responders can use this data to improve location-based services, analyze spatial patterns of addresses, and enhance the accuracy of computer-aided dispatch systems. The `addresspointid` serves as a unique identifier for each address point, while `house_number` and `post_type` provide address details. Maintained by the city, this dataset is a valuable resource for understanding and working with NYC addresses.
sfd:

It includes latitude, longitude, Building Identification Number (BIN), ZIP code, street type, and computed regions for each address. title: Expense Financial Plan - Exec
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed view of New York City's expense financial plan, offering insights into how various city agencies allocate their resources. It includes agency-level summary data for Personal Services (PS), Other Than Personal Services (OTPS), and total expenses, broken down by funding type. Key columns include `agency_name`, `line_number_description` which specifies the type of expense, and financial data for the prior year actuals, current fiscal year executive budget (`year_1_executive_bud`), actuals, forecasts, and estimates for the following four years. All dollar amounts are rounded to the nearest thousand. Users can analyze trends in agency spending, compare budgeted versus actual expenses, and forecast future financial needs based on the provided estimates. The `publication_date` indicates when the data was released, and the `fiscal_year_1` column specifies the fiscal year the data pertains to. This dataset is valuable for anyone interested in understanding the financial operations of New York City government.

title: Intimate Partner Violence Related Snapshots: New York City Community Board Districts
ufd: This dataset provides insights into intimate partner violence in New York City, broken down by community district. It includes annual counts of domestic incident reports, felony assaults, and rapes, distinguishing between family-related and general domestic violence incidents. Key columns include `report_year`, `comm_dist_boro` (borough), `comm_district`, and counts for different types of incidents like `fam_fel_assault`, `dv_fel_assault`, `fam_rape`, and `dv_rape`. Researchers, policymakers, and community organizations can use this data to analyze trends in intimate partner violence, identify areas with higher rates of incidents, and inform the development and implementation of targeted prevention and support programs. The data spans the years 2018 and 2019. The Mayor's Office to Combat Domestic Violence collects this data from the NYPD to produce an annual report.

title: Holiday Construction Embargo- Block
ufd: This dataset identifies street blocks in Staten Island with active construction embargoes during the holiday season (November and December). Each record represents a street segment defined by its geometry (`the_geom`), on-street name (`onstreetna`), and the intersecting streets (`fromstreet`, `tostreetna`). The `oftcode` provides a unique identifier for each segment. This data can be used to understand where construction is restricted during the holidays, potentially aiding in traffic management, route planning, and minimizing disruptions. The dataset includes the borough code (`boroughcod`), which is consistently "S" for Staten Island. Researchers and city planners can leverage this information to analyze the impact of construction embargoes on traffic flow and pedestrian movement during the holiday period.

title: Pupil Transportation Report April2020_21_995 - July 1, - December 31, 2019
ufd: This dataset contains investigation reports from the Office of Pupil Transportation, covering the period from July 1, 2019, to December 31, 2019. Finally, `case_count` provides a count of cases for each combination of factors. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in reported incidents, identify areas needing improved supervision, or evaluate the effectiveness of investigative processes.

Key columns include 'overall_attendance_rate', 'remote_students_online', 'blended_students_overall', 'blended_students_in_person', and 'blended_students_online', offering a comprehensive view of student engagement during this period. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze the impact of different learning modalities on attendance and identify schools that may need additional support to improve student engagement. The data was reported by schools in STARS Attendance Tracker or ATS as of June 15, 2021, covering attendance from May 3 through May 28, 2021.

title: Bicycle Parking
ufd: This dataset contains information about bicycle parking locations throughout the five boroughs of New York City. It includes the location of bike racks and corrals, identified by geographic coordinates in the `the_geom` column. Key columns include `borocode` and `boroname`, which specify the borough code and name, respectively, where the bicycle parking is located. The `program` column indicates whether the parking is a "Bike Rack" or "Bike Corral." Additional columns such as `coundist`, `assemdist`, `stsendist`, and `congdist` provide further location details based on council, assembly, state senate, and congressional districts. This dataset could be used by urban planners, transportation officials, or cyclists to identify and map bicycle parking availability, analyze parking distribution across different areas, or plan new bicycle infrastructure. The `ifoaddress`, `onstreet`, `fromstreet`, and `tostreet` columns offer address-based location information, though some values may be missing.

title: Inspections of Municipal Solid Waste Disposal Locations (No Longer Maintained)
ufd: This dataset contains information about inspections of permitted, privately operated, municipal solid waste disposal locations in New York City. While the dataset is based on a legacy system and is no longer actively maintained, it provides a historical record of inspections. Each row represents a single inspection, identified by a unique `inspection_no` and the `inspection_date`. The dataset also includes the number of `violations` and `warnings` issued during each inspection. Although the data is outdated, it could be used for historical analysis of inspection trends or to understand past compliance levels at solid waste disposal locations. For current information, consider exploring the 311 Service Requests dataset, filtering for "Transfer Station Complaint". Note that all inspections in this dataset had zero violations and zero warnings.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset provides a historical record of inspections conducted at permitted, privately operated, municipal solid waste disposal locations in New York City. Each entry represents a single inspection, detailing the inspection date and a unique inspection number. The dataset also includes the number of violations and warnings issued during each inspection, though all records indicate zero violations and warnings. This data is from a legacy system and is no longer actively maintained.

**Related Topics:**

- Inspections and Regulations
- Waste Disposal

- Violations: Infractions, non-compliance, offenses
- Warnings: Notices, alerts, cautions
- Permitted Locations: Licensed facilities, authorized sites
- Legacy System: Outdated system, historical data

- Research on the effectiveness of past inspection practices.

- Training data for data science or data analysis courses using real-world government data.

title: NYC Pool Inspections
ufd: This dataset contains information about pool inspections conducted in New York City. It includes details on both indoor and outdoor pools, as well as related facilities like saunas and steam rooms. Each row represents a single inspection and provides the facility name, address, and zip code. The dataset also specifies the inspection date and type, such as routine or complaint-based inspections. A key feature is the count of different violation types, including public health hazards, critical violations, and general violations. Users can analyze this data to understand compliance levels across different facilities, identify trends in violations, and assess the effectiveness of inspection programs. The 'permit_type' column indicates whether the inspection was for an indoor or outdoor facility.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details pool inspections conducted in New York City, encompassing both indoor and outdoor pools, as well as related facilities like saunas and steam rooms. Each record represents a single inspection, including facility details, inspection specifics (date, type), and counts of various violation types. The data allows for analysis of compliance, violation trends, and inspection program effectiveness.

title: 2020 Fall Admission LL1486
ufd: This dataset contains information on school applications and offers of admission for the Fall of 2020. It focuses on schools participating in centralized admissions processes, reporting data for pre-K, Kindergarten, Middle School (Grade 6), and High School (Grade 9). The data includes the number of applicants and offers made for each grade level within a single school district. Key columns include `school_district`, which identifies the district, and columns like `pre_k_applicants`, `kindergarten_applicants`, `grade_6_applicants`, and `grade_9_applicants` representing the number of applications received. Similarly, `pre_k_offers`, `kindergarten_offers`, `grade_6_offers`, and `grade_9_offers` indicate the number of offers made. This dataset could be used to analyze admission trends, identify areas with high demand, or evaluate the effectiveness of the centralized admissions process. Note that a large number of values are represented by "s", which may indicate suppressed data.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides a detailed look at school applications and admissions offers for the Fall 2020 term. It focuses on schools within a single district using a centralized admissions process. The data includes applicant and offer counts for Pre-K, Kindergarten, Grade 6, and Grade 9, allowing for analysis of admission trends across different grade levels.

title: 2019-20 Students In Temporary Housing
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the housing situations of students in New York City schools during the 2019-2020 academic year. It includes information on the number of students in temporary housing, broken down by those residing in shelters (DHS and non-DHS) and those who are "doubled up" (living with other families). The dataset also contains the total number of students enrolled at each school, identified by a unique DBN code and school name. Key columns include `total_students`, `students_in_temporary_housing`, `students_residing_in_shelter`, `residing_in_dhs_shelter`, `residing_in_non_dhs_shelter`, and `doubled_up`. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to understand the prevalence of student homelessness and housing instability, allocate resources to support affected students, and evaluate the impact of housing programs on educational outcomes. Note that some values are represented as "s" which likely indicates suppressed data for privacy reasons. The column `students_in_temporary_housing_1` provides the percentage of students in temporary housing.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the housing status of students in New York City public schools during the 2019-2020 school year. It focuses on students experiencing temporary housing situations, including those in shelters (DHS and non-DHS) and those "doubled up" with other families. The data also includes total student enrollment per school, allowing for analysis of housing instability prevalence.

Related Topics:

title: DOE Building Space Usage
ufd: This dataset provides details on room usage within Department of Education (DOE) buildings. It includes information on the building ID, organization code, and room number for each space. Key features of the dataset are the room's dimensions (length, width, and calculated area) along with its designated function, such as "AUDITORIUM", "STORAGE ROOM", or "FOURTH GRADE". The data is current as of April 17, 2025. Researchers and administrators can use this data to analyze space allocation, understand how different rooms are utilized, and optimize building layouts for educational purposes. The dataset could also be used for space planning and resource allocation within the DOE.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset contains information about room usage in Department of Education (DOE) buildings. It includes details such as building ID, organization code, room number, dimensions (length, width, area), and the designated function of each room. The data is current as of April 17, 2025, and provides insights into space allocation and utilization within DOE facilities.

title: Pupil Transportation Count of Employees Bus Company - July 1, - December 31, 2021
ufd: This dataset provides a count of employees working for school bus companies between July 1st and December 31st, 2021. The data includes the name of the school bus company, the type of employee (Driver, Attendant, or both), the month the count was recorded, and the total employee count. While the dataset contains 100 rows, the school bus company name and employee type columns have a high percentage of missing values. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze staffing levels in pupil transportation services. This information could be valuable for understanding workforce trends within school bus companies and potentially identifying areas where staffing shortages may exist. The employee count column offers insights into the size of the workforce at each company, while the month column allows for tracking changes in staffing levels over time. Keep in mind that the data is subject to data entry errors by the school bus companies.
sfd:

This dataset contains monthly employee counts for school bus companies from July to December 2021. It includes the company name, employee type (Driver, Attendant, or both), the month of the count, and the total number of employees. title: New York City Fleet Daily Service Report
ufd: This dataset, titled "New York City Fleet Daily Service Report," provides a snapshot of vehicle availability across various New York City agencies. The data tracks the daily in-service status of vehicles, comparing target numbers with actual counts. Key columns include "date," indicating the date of the report; "agency," specifying the responsible city agency; "fleet_name," detailing the type of fleet (e.g., "All vehicles," "Buses"); "fleet_roster," representing the total number of vehicles in the fleet; and "actual_count_in_service," showing the number of vehicles actually in service. Additional columns provide target in-service percentages and flags for seasonal or agency-wide totals. Users can analyze this data to understand fleet utilization rates, identify potential shortfalls in vehicle availability, and track trends in fleet service across different agencies and vehicle types. The "average_over_fy_18_to_date" column allows for comparison against historical data.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The New York City Fleet Daily Service Report dataset details the daily in-service status of vehicles across various NYC agencies. It tracks the number of vehicles in service compared to target numbers, providing insights into fleet utilization. Key data points include the date, agency, fleet name, fleet roster size, and the actual number of vehicles in service.

title: Student COVID Vaccinations (04/16 - 05/03/2022
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of student COVID vaccinations in New York City schools (Districts 1-32 and 75) between April 16th and May 3rd, 2022. It includes enrollment data and vaccination-related information for students in grades 1-12. Key columns include `schooldbn` (school identifier), `total_consented_students`, and counts for various racial/ethnic groups (`asian_or_pacific_islander`, `hispanic_of_any_race`, `black_or_african_american`, etc.). The dataset also contains information on students with IEPs (`iep`) and those with limited English proficiency (`lep`). Note that some values are suppressed with "S" or "T" to protect student privacy, as explained in the dataset description. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze vaccination rates across different student subgroups and identify potential disparities. This information can inform public health strategies and resource allocation to promote equitable access to vaccinations.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on COVID-19 vaccination rates among students in New York City public schools (Districts 1-32 and 75) during a specific period in April-May 2022. It includes enrollment numbers, counts of consented students, and demographic breakdowns by race/ethnicity, IEP status, and LEP status. Data is suppressed in some instances to protect student privacy.

title: Mapped In NY Companies
ufd: This dataset contains information about companies in New York City, extracted to power the Mapped In NY website. Each row represents a unique company, identified by its name and providing address details, including street address, city, and postcode. The dataset also includes geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude) and administrative information such as borough, community board, and council district. Additional columns like census tract, BIN (Building Identification Number), and BBL (Borough, Block, and Lot) offer further location-specific details. This data could be used for geographic analysis of businesses, urban planning, or creating targeted marketing campaigns. Note that a large fraction of the entries lack complete address information beyond the company name.
sfd:

title: Projected Public School Ratio
ufd: This dataset provides projected public school ratios, estimating the number of students expected from future housing growth in New York City. It breaks down the projected student contribution by borough and community school district. Key columns include the borough (e.g., Brooklyn, Queens), the community school district number, and the estimated number of children per housing unit within specific age ranges (4-10, 11-13, and 14-17). The dataset also includes a "data\_as\_of" column, indicating the date the projections were made. Researchers and city planners can use this data to forecast school enrollment, allocate resources, and plan for future educational needs based on anticipated housing development. The data spans multiple dates, allowing for trend analysis over time. With 100 rows, the dataset offers a detailed snapshot of projected student populations across different areas of New York City.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains projected public school student ratios for New York City, estimating the impact of future housing growth on school enrollment. The data is broken down by borough and community school district, providing projected student contributions per housing unit for different age groups. title: School Bus Route Reporting April2020_21_996 - July 1, - December 31, 2019
ufd: This dataset contains information about school bus ride times for different school districts over a few months. Each row represents a school district and includes the average ride time in minutes for July, August, and September. The `school_district` column identifies the specific district, while the `average_ride_time_minutes` columns show the average duration of student rides. The dataset appears to track ride times to assess the service provided to students, focusing on individual student ride times rather than full route durations. Researchers or school administrators could use this data to analyze trends in ride times across districts and months, identify potential areas for improvement in bus route efficiency, or compare ride times between different school districts. The dataset includes similar columns for August and September (named with "_1" and "_2" suffixes respectively), allowing for a comparison of ride times across these months.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides average school bus ride times in minutes for various school districts across July, August, and September. Each record represents a school district and its corresponding average ride times for each of the three months. The data allows for comparison of ride times across different districts and months, potentially highlighting areas for improvement in transportation efficiency.

title: Local Law 44 - Unit Income Rent
ufd: This dataset contains information on unit income and rent for housing development projects, as reported under Local Law 44. It includes details on bedroom size, maximum allowable household income (limited to 0%-30% in this dataset), and the total number of units. Key columns include `projectid` and `buildingid` to identify specific projects and buildings. The dataset also provides initial legal and actual rent amounts (median, high, and low) for these units. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze rent affordability and housing availability within Local Law 44 projects. Note that rent data is not available for all units, as indicated by the missing values in the rent columns.
sfd:

title: PreK Riders by Transportation Site
ufd: This dataset provides a summary of Pre-K student ridership by transportation site, offering insights into student transportation patterns. It includes the school year, a unique OPT code for each site, the name of the site, the associated school name, and the number of riders. Key columns include 'school_year', indicating the academic year the data pertains to, 'site_name' and 'school_name' which identify the transportation location and educational institution, respectively, and 'number_of_riders', representing the total count of students using transportation services at that site. Researchers and transportation planners can use this data to analyze ridership trends over time, identify high-demand areas, and optimize transportation routes and resource allocation. The dataset contains 100 rows of data spanning multiple school years, with the majority of records from 2017-2018 and 2024-2025. The number of riders ranges from 1 to 237 students per site.

title: Mayor's Management Report Agency Resources
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of New York City agency resources as reported in the Mayor's Management Report (MMR) for the fiscal year 2015. It offers insights into agency expenditures, personnel, revenues, and overtime paid. Key columns include `agency` and `agency_name`, which identify the specific city agency, and `resource_indicators`, which detail the type of resource being tracked, such as expenditures or personnel. The dataset also includes `current_fy_projected_actual`, `current_fy_authorized_budget`, and `next_fy_authorized_budget`, providing a view of current and future financial planning. The `_5yr_trend` column indicates the trend of the resource indicator over a five-year period. This data can be used to analyze resource allocation across different city agencies, track financial trends, and understand the city's budgetary planning. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this information to gain a better understanding of how city resources are managed.

title: IBO Federal Stimulus Budget and Spending Tracker (ARPA and CRRSAA)
ufd: This dataset tracks the budget and spending of New York City initiatives funded by the American Rescue Plan Act (ARPA) and the Coronavirus Response and Relief Supplemental Appropriations Act (CRRSAA). Each row represents a specific initiative, detailing its purpose and funding allocation. Key columns include 'agency', indicating the responsible city department; 'initiative_category', providing a broad categorization of the initiative (e.g., Covid Response, Direct Human Services); and 'initiative_detailed', offering a more granular description of the project. The dataset also contains budget and spending figures for the years 2021-2024, allowing users to analyze financial trends and track the utilization of federal stimulus funds. Researchers, policymakers, and city residents can use this data to understand how stimulus funds are being allocated and spent across different city agencies and initiatives, assess the impact of these investments, and promote government transparency. The 'budget' columns represent the planned allocation for each year, while the 'spent' columns reflect the actual expenditure.

title: Citywide Mobility Survey - Person 2022
ufd: This dataset comes from the Citywide Mobility Survey and focuses on individual members within participating households. It includes demographic information such as age and race, as well as transportation-related details. Key columns include `num_trips`, representing the number of trips taken, and `num_days_complete`, indicating the number of days the survey was completed. The dataset also contains identifiers for households (`hh_id`) and individuals (`person_id`). Researchers and urban planners could use this data to analyze travel patterns, understand demographic influences on mobility, and inform transportation policy decisions. The `phone_type` column may provide insights into communication methods used by participants. Analyzing the relationships between demographic factors and travel behavior can help tailor transportation solutions to specific community needs.

title: Office of The Comptroller: Police Retirement System Holdings Data
ufd: This dataset contains information about the Police Retirement System's holdings as of June 30, 2017. It includes details on both equity and fixed income investments. Key columns include the `local_currency_code`, the `trade_country_name` where the security is traded, the `security_name`, and a `security_description`. Financial details such as `interest_rate`, `original_face`, `shares_par_value`, `base_market_value`, and `base_total_cost` are also provided.  The dataset also tracks unrealized gains/losses and accrued interest. Users can analyze the portfolio composition, assess investment performance, and understand the financial risks and returns associated with the Police Retirement System's holdings. This data could be used by financial analysts, government oversight bodies, or members of the police retirement system to understand how funds are invested.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the Police Retirement System's investment portfolio as of June 30, 2017, encompassing both equity and fixed income holdings. It provides comprehensive information on individual securities, including their names, descriptions, and trading locations. Key financial metrics such as market value, total cost, interest rates, and unrealized gains/losses are also included, enabling in-depth portfolio analysis.

Related Topics:

title: 2017 DOE High School Directory
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of Department of Education schools in New York City for 2017. It includes information on 100 different schools, such as their name, the borough they are located in, and an overview paragraph describing the school's mission and programs. Key columns include "school_name," which lists the name of each school, "boro," indicating the borough, and "overview_paragraph," which provides a brief description of the school. The dataset also contains information on academic opportunities available at each school and the ELL programs they offer. Researchers, parents, or students can use this dataset to explore and compare different school options, understand the educational landscape in NYC, and identify schools that align with specific academic interests or needs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a directory of New York City Department of Education schools for the year 2017. It includes key information such as school name, borough, and a descriptive overview paragraph for 100 schools. The dataset also provides details on academic opportunities and ELL programs offered at each school.

title: Future Floodplain 2050s
ufd: This dataset, titled "Future Floodplain 2050s," provides insights into potential flood risks in the future, specifically the 2050s. It is based on FEMA's Preliminary Work Map data and incorporates sea-level rise projections from the New York Panel on Climate Change. The dataset focuses on the 100-year floodplain, indicating areas with a 1% annual chance of flooding. A key column, "the_geom," contains the geospatial information defining the boundaries of these flood-prone areas as MultiPolygons. Other columns include "gridcode," "join_count," "fld_zone," "static_bfe," and "abfe_0_2pc," though their specific meanings are not detailed here. This dataset could be valuable for urban planning, risk assessment, and infrastructure development, helping stakeholders prepare for and mitigate the impacts of future flooding.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The "Future Floodplain 2050s" dataset projects flood risk areas for the 2050s, utilizing FEMA's Preliminary Work Map data and sea-level rise projections. It identifies 100-year floodplain zones, representing areas with a 1% annual chance of flooding. The dataset's geospatial information, stored in the "the_geom" column as MultiPolygons, defines the boundaries of these flood-prone areas.

Related Topics:
- Flood Risk Assessment
- Climate Change Adaptation
- Sea Level Rise
- Urban Planning
- Disaster Management
- Coastal Resilience

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Floodplain: Area subject to flooding, flood zone, inundation zone
- 100-year Floodplain: 1% annual chance flood, base flood, regulatory floodplain
- Sea Level Rise: SLR, coastal inundation, rising sea levels
- FEMA: Federal Emergency Management Agency
- Geospatial Data: Spatial data, geographic information, "the_geom"
- MultiPolygon: Geometry type, polygon feature, spatial boundary

Applications and Use Cases:
- Urban planning and zoning regulations to restrict development in high-risk areas.
- Infrastructure planning and design to ensure resilience to future flooding.
- Risk assessment and insurance pricing for properties within the floodplain.
- Emergency preparedness and response planning for flood events.
- Climate change adaptation strategies and mitigation efforts.
- Public awareness campaigns to educate communities about flood risks.

title: 2019-2020 Local Law 102 Physical Education Report -Final
ufd: This dataset contains information on physical education in New York City schools for the 2019-2020 school year, as reported through the STARS database. It includes details about the provision of physical education instruction, such as average class size, frequency, and duration. The data is broken down by school district and student category (e.g., all students, kindergarten, 1st grade). Key columns include the district, category of students, average number of days per week of PE, average minutes per week of PE, total students, and the proportion of students who received PE. Note that due to the shift to remote learning in March 2020, the data reflects mid-year reporting. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in physical education across different districts and grade levels, or to identify disparities in access to physical education.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides insights into physical education (PE) in New York City schools during the 2019-2020 academic year. The data, sourced from the STARS database, details the frequency, duration, and class sizes of PE instruction. Information is categorized by school district and student grade level, offering a view of PE provision before the shift to remote learning in March 2020.

Related Topics:

- Compare PE provision for different student grade levels.
- Evaluate the impact of school district policies on PE instruction.

- Track changes in PE provision over time (requires historical data).

title: SNAP and Cash Assistance for NYCHA Residents - Local Law 163
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the usage of social services, specifically SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) and Cash Assistance, among NYCHA (New York City Housing Authority) residents. It presents the number of residents in each borough who received benefits under these programs. The dataset spans from 2017 to 2024, offering a longitudinal view of service utilization. Key columns include "year" for the year of data collection, "borough" indicating the New York City borough, "received_benefits_under_snap" showing the number of residents receiving SNAP benefits, and "received_benefits_under_cash" representing the number receiving Cash Assistance. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to understand the reach of these programs within NYCHA communities and identify trends in service needs across different boroughs. The dataset can also help in resource allocation and program evaluation to ensure effective support for public housing residents. Note that several columns related to application submissions and income eligibility contain only missing data.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the utilization of SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) and Cash Assistance by NYCHA (New York City Housing Authority) residents across New York City boroughs from 2017 to 2024. It provides counts of residents receiving benefits under each program, broken down by year and borough. This longitudinal data allows for analysis of trends in social service usage within NYCHA communities.

title: Financial Plan Headcount Baseline & Initiatives By Funding
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of headcount information related to financial initiatives within New York City government. Updated quarterly, it reflects changes after the release of financial plans. Key columns include `agency_name`, indicating the specific city agency involved (e.g., Police Department, Fire Department), `init_type` which categorizes the type of initiative, and `fy1_hc` through `fy5_hc`, representing headcount figures for the initiative over five fiscal years. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze staffing trends across different agencies and track the impact of financial initiatives on city government employment. The dataset also includes `init_grp`, which groups initiatives by type, such as expenditure increases or baseline plans. This allows for comparative analysis of different funding strategies and their effects on headcount.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains quarterly headcount data for financial initiatives within New York City government agencies. It provides a breakdown of staffing levels across various agencies and initiative types over a five-year period. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze staffing trends and the impact of financial initiatives on city government employment.

Related Topics:

- Headcount Analysis

- Agency Name: City Department, Government Organization

- Headcount (HC): Staffing Levels, Number of Employees, Workforce Size
- Fiscal Year (FY): Budget Year, Financial Period
- Initiative Group: Program Group, Project Category

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze staffing trends across different NYC agencies over time.
- Track the impact of specific financial initiatives on headcount.

- Predict future staffing needs based on historical trends.

title: Learning Preference City Remote Learning - as of Jan 4, 2021
ufd: This dataset provides insights into student learning preferences in New York City, specifically focusing on remote and blended learning models as of January 4, 2021. It includes total enrollment counts for students who have attended school in person at least once since September 16, 2020, and whose learning preference is remote, blended, or missing. The data is broken down by district, disaggregation category (e.g., grade level, race/ethnicity, gender, English Language Learner status), and specific category within each disaggregation (e.g., specific grade, ethnicity, male/female, ELL/non-ELL). Key columns include `total_enrollment`, `blended` (number of students in blended learning), `blended_1` (percentage in blended learning), `remote` (number of students in remote learning), and `remote_1` (percentage in remote learning). Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze trends in learning preferences across different student groups and districts, understand the prevalence of remote and blended learning, and inform decisions related to resource allocation and educational strategies. Note that certain student groups are excluded (e.g., charter schools, home/hospital instruction), and data for small groups may be suppressed to protect privacy. The `district` column allows for geographical analysis of learning preferences.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details student learning preferences (remote, blended) in New York City public schools as of January 4, 2021. It provides enrollment counts and percentages for remote and blended learning models, broken down by district and various student demographics. The data includes information on total enrollment, blended learning participation, and remote learning participation, allowing for analysis of learning trends across different student groups.

title: Parking Permit for People with Disabilities (PPPD) - City
ufd: This dataset contains information about Parking Permits for People with Disabilities (PPPD) in a city. Each row represents a single permit, identified by a unique permit number. Key details include the effective and expiration dates of the permit, as well as the date it was issued. The permit status indicates whether the permit is currently active, expired, or revoked. The application date reflects when the permit was initially requested. While the dataset includes a column indicating if the vehicle was stolen, this column contains no data. This dataset could be used to analyze permit durations, track permit status over time, or understand the distribution of disability parking permits within the city.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset provides details on Parking Permits for People with Disabilities (PPPD) within a city. Each record represents a unique permit, including its effective, expiration, and issuance dates. The dataset also tracks the permit's status (active, expired, revoked) and the initial application date.

title: 2009 Yellow Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records from yellow taxis in 2009. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including pickup and dropoff times, locations, trip distance, and fare information. Key columns include `vendorid` (identifying the Technology Service Provider), `tpep_pickup_datetime` and `tpep_dropoff_datetime` (recording the trip's start and end), `passenger_count`, and `trip_distance`. Location data is provided via `pickup_longitude`, `pickup_latitude`, `dropoff_longitude`, and `dropoff_latitude`. Fare details are broken down into `fare_amount`, `extra`, `tip_amount`, `tolls_amount`, and `total_amount`, with the `payment_type` indicating the method of payment. Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi usage patterns, analyze fare structures, or build predictive models for trip demand. The `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip record was stored in the vehicle before being sent to the vendor.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed trip information for yellow taxis in 2009. It includes pickup and dropoff timestamps, geographic coordinates, passenger count, trip distance, and comprehensive fare breakdowns. The data allows for analysis of taxi usage patterns and fare structures.

Related Topics:
- Taxi trips
- Transportation data

- Fare analysis

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Taxi trip: ride, cab ride, taxi cab
- Fare amount: trip cost, price, charge
- Pickup location: origin, starting point
- Dropoff location: destination, end point
- Trip distance: mileage, travel length
- Payment type: method of payment, payment option

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze taxi trip demand based on time of day and location.
- Predict taxi fares based on distance, time, and other factors.
- Identify popular taxi routes and destinations.
- Study the impact of events on taxi usage patterns.
- Develop models for optimizing taxi dispatch and routing.

title: April_2021_21-993 New York City Transportation Reporting
ufd: This dataset, titled "April_2021_21-993 New York City Transportation Reporting," contains information related to student transportation in New York City. It appears to focus on the period between September 1, 2020, and December 31, 2020. The dataset includes notes about transportation policies during the 2020-2021 school year, specifically regarding students enrolled in blended learning programs and their bus routes. It also clarifies that the data reflects planned and routed students, not necessarily actual ridership. The single column contains textual information about various aspects of the transportation system, such as student stop assignments, vehicle identification, and MetroCard assignments. Users can analyze this data to understand the logistics and policies surrounding student transportation in NYC during the specified period. This dataset could be useful for researchers, policymakers, or anyone interested in the operational details of the NYC school transportation system.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The "April_2021_21-993 New York City Transportation Reporting" dataset details student transportation logistics in NYC between September and December 2020. It focuses on planned bus routes and transportation policies for students in blended learning programs during the 2020-2021 school year. The data includes information on student stop assignments, vehicle identification, and MetroCard assignments.

title: 2021 Fall Admission LL1486
ufd: This dataset provides information on student admissions for the 2021 fall semester. It focuses on schools participating in centralized admissions processes, detailing the number of applicants and offers made for pre-kindergarten, kindergarten, 6th grade, and 9th grade. The data includes only main round admissions. Key columns include `school_district`, `category` (representing student groups), and the applicant/offer counts for each grade level (`pre_k_applicants`, `pre_k_offers`, etc.). Note that many columns contain "s" values, which likely represent suppressed data. This dataset could be used to analyze admission trends, identify areas of high demand, or evaluate the effectiveness of outreach programs. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to understand school capacity and student access across different grade levels.

title: NYC Open Data Plan: FOIL Datasets
ufd: This dataset provides insights into datasets identified through Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) requests within New York City government. It details the agency responsible for the data, the name and description of the dataset, and the number of FOIL requests received for it. A key field indicates whether the dataset is currently available on the NYC Open Data portal or is scheduled for future publication. The dataset also includes a public statement from the agency regarding data availability, often explaining why a dataset is not public, such as containing personally identifiable information (PII). Finally, when applicable, a URL is provided to the dataset on the NYC Open Data portal. Users can leverage this dataset to understand the types of data held by city agencies, the demand for specific datasets via FOIL requests, and the city's progress in making data publicly accessible. Researchers, journalists, and transparency advocates can use this information to identify potential datasets of interest and track the city's open data initiatives.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset catalogs datasets held by New York City government agencies, identified through Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) requests. It includes details on the responsible agency, dataset name and description, FOIL request count, and availability status on the NYC Open Data portal. The dataset also provides agency statements regarding data availability, including reasons for non-publication, and links to datasets on the NYC Open Data portal when available.

**Related Topics:**

- Agency: Government department, city agency, bureau
- Dataset Availability: Data accessibility, publication status, public access
- PII: Personally Identifiable Information, confidential data, sensitive information

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Track the types of data held by NYC government agencies.

- Identify potential datasets of interest for research or analysis.

title: Election Districts
ufd: This dataset contains the New York City Board of Elections election district boundaries, clipped to the shoreline. Each row represents a single election district within New York City. The key columns include `elect_dist`, which is a unique identifier for each election district, and `the_geom`, which provides the geographic boundaries of the district in a MultiPolygon format. The `shape_leng` and `shape_area` columns specify the length and area of the district's shape. This data can be used for spatial analysis, redistricting planning, voter analysis, and visualization of election districts. Researchers, urban planners, and political analysts can leverage this dataset to understand the spatial distribution of voters and election patterns in New York City. All previously released versions of this data are available on the DCP Website: BYTES of the BIG APPLE.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides the geographic boundaries of election districts in New York City, as defined by the New York City Board of Elections. Each record represents a single election district, identified by a unique `elect_dist` code. The dataset includes the district's geometry (`the_geom`), shape length (`shape_leng`), and shape area (`shape_area`).

- Integrating election district boundaries with other datasets, such as census data.

title: School Bus Routing Report October_2021_89C_21-996
ufd: This dataset, titled "School Bus Routing Report," provides insights into student ride times on school buses. It contains 18 rows of data, covering several months. The key columns include "month," indicating the month the data pertains to, "ride_time_hours," which categorizes ride times into ranges like less than 1 hour, 1-2 hours, and greater than 2 hours, and "student_count," representing the number of students within each ride time category for a given month. Researchers and school administrators could use this data to analyze trends in student commute times, identify potential areas for route optimization, and assess the impact of transportation on student well-being. The original report details that ride times are calculated as the difference between scheduled stop time and school session time at the individual student level. Note that curb-to-school routing systems do not capture scheduled pick up times.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The School Bus Routing Report dataset contains information on student ride times on school buses, aggregated by month and ride time categories. It includes the month, ride time ranges (in hours), and the number of students within each range. This data can be used to analyze trends in student commute times and identify areas for route optimization.

title: Workforce1 Recruitment Events
ufd: This dataset provides a schedule of recruitment events offered by Workforce1 Centers in New York City. It includes information on the location of the event, the date and time for check-in, and the title of the event, which often specifies the type of screening being conducted (e.g., Retail Screening, Food Service Screening). The dataset also details the job family associated with the event, such as Food Service and Accommodations or Protective Service, along with the names of the companies participating. A key column is "qualifications," which outlines the specific requirements and skills needed for the available positions. You can use this dataset to find recruitment events relevant to your job search, identify companies that are hiring, and understand the qualifications needed for various job roles within specific industries. The data covers events in locations like the Bronx, Brooklyn, and Coney Island.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a schedule of recruitment events hosted by Workforce1 Centers across New York City. It includes details such as event location, check-in time, event title (often specifying screening type), associated job family, participating companies, and required qualifications. This data can be used to identify relevant job recruitment opportunities and understand employer needs.

Related Topics:
- Job Fairs
- Recruitment Events
- Workforce Development
- Employment Opportunities
- New York City Jobs
- Career Services

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Recruitment Event: Job fair, hiring event, career day, open house
- Job Family: Industry sector, occupation category, career field
- Qualifications: Requirements, skills, experience, prerequisites
- Workforce1 Center: Career center, employment agency, job center
- Screening: Interview, assessment, evaluation

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identify upcoming recruitment events in specific locations or industries.
- Determine the qualifications needed for various job roles.
- Find companies that are actively hiring in New York City.
- Analyze trends in employer demand across different job families.
- Develop targeted job search strategies based on employer requirements.

title: DOHMH School Cafeteria Inspections (2020-Present)
ufd: This dataset contains inspection information for cafeterias in public, private, and parochial schools across New York City. Annual inspections ensure these cafeterias comply with NYS and NYC Food Safety Regulations. Key details include the school's name (`schoolname`), address (number, street, city, zipcode, borough), and the dates of the last inspection (`lastinspection`) and the actual inspection (`inspectiondate`). The dataset also identifies the permitting organization (`permittee`) and the type of cafeteria (`site_type`). Researchers and the public can use this data to understand the landscape of school cafeteria inspections, identify trends in compliance, or locate inspection records for specific schools. The `entityid` column provides a unique identifier for each cafeteria. The `ptet` column and `level` column may provide additional details about the type or grade level of the school.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides inspection details for school cafeterias in New York City, covering public, private, and parochial schools. It includes information on inspection dates, school details (name, address, borough), and permitting organizations. The data allows for analysis of food safety compliance and tracking of inspection records across different schools.

Related Topics:
- School Health
- Food Safety
- New York City
- Public Health
- Inspections
- Education
- Cafeterias

Concepts and Synonyms:
- School Cafeteria Inspections: Food safety audits, school kitchen evaluations, cafeteria compliance checks
- School Details: School name, school address, school location, school identifier
- Inspection Date: Date of inspection, inspection timeline, inspection period
- Compliance: Food safety regulations, health code adherence, violation records
- Permitting Organization: Permittee, licensing agency, regulatory body

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in school cafeteria inspection results across NYC.
- Identify schools with consistently high or low compliance rates.
- Track the frequency of inspections for specific schools or boroughs.
- Locate inspection records for a particular school cafeteria.
- Investigate the relationship between school type (public, private, parochial) and inspection outcomes.

title: 2018 Pre-K School Directory
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of Pre-K for All programs in New York City for 2018. It includes information on approximately 100 schools, with details like school name (`locationname`), address (`final_address`), and contact information. The dataset also specifies the borough and district each school is located in, as well as the type of pre-K program offered (`prek_type`). Additional details include information on meals provided (`meals`), play spaces (`play`), and whether uniforms are required (`uniforms`). This data is useful for families looking to apply to Pre-K programs, and for researchers interested in the distribution and characteristics of early childhood education in NYC. Note that the data reflects programs available in 2018 and may not be current.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on Pre-K for All programs in New York City during 2018. It includes details on approximately 100 schools, such as location name, address, borough, district, and contact information. The dataset also specifies the type of pre-K program, meals provided, play spaces, and uniform requirements.

Related Topics:
- Early Childhood Education

- School Directory

- Pre-K for All: Universal Pre-Kindergarten, UPK, Early Childhood Education
