title: Weights, Measures, and Other Tests
ufd: This dataset provides details on inspections conducted by the Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP) for various devices related to weights and measures in New York City. The data includes information on devices like gasoline pumps, fuel oil meters, and scales, ensuring businesses comply with New York State Department of Agriculture laws. Each record represents a specific inspection, identified by an inspection number and certificate of inspection. Key columns include the date of the inspection, the business's name and unique ID, the category of the business (e.g., Grocery-Retail, Gas Station), and the type of inspection performed (e.g., Scale, WAM - Petroleum). The dataset also details the category and class of device inspected, such as "Scale Inspection" or "Gas Pumps," and the number of devices inspected, approved, and condemned. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze compliance trends, identify areas needing increased oversight, and assess the effectiveness of DCWP's inspection programs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

The inspections cover devices such as scales, gas pumps, and fuel oil meters, ensuring compliance with state regulations. Each record details the inspection date, business information, device type, and the outcome of the inspection, including the number of devices inspected, approved, and condemned.

title: DOHMH COVID-19 Antibody-by-Modified ZIP Code Tabulation Area
ufd: This dataset provides information on COVID-19 antibody testing in New York City, broken down by modified ZIP Code Tabulation Area (MODZCTA). It includes the number of people tested (`num_peop_test`), the number of positive results (`num_peop_pos`), the percentage of positive tests (`percent_positive`), and the testing rate per 100,000 people (`test_rate`). Each record also contains the MODZCTA (`modzcta_first`), neighborhood name (`neighborhood_name`), latitude (`lat`), and longitude (`lon`) for spatial analysis. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to understand antibody prevalence across different NYC neighborhoods. Keep in mind that the data reflects those tested and may not represent the antibody prevalence of all New Yorkers. The dataset is updated daily, preserving historical records, so it's important to use the latest extract date for current analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains daily information on COVID-19 antibody testing in New York City, organized by modified ZIP Code Tabulation Area (MODZCTA). It includes key metrics such as the number of people tested, positive test results, percentage positive, and testing rate per 100,000 residents. The data also provides geographic information (MODZCTA, neighborhood name, latitude, longitude) for spatial analysis.

title: Trust Fund Invasions
ufd: This dataset contains information on trust fund invasions related to home improvement businesses and tow truck companies. It tracks instances where funds are withdrawn to cover unpaid consumer restitution awards or fines. Key columns include the business name, the industry they operate in, the date the case was opened and completed, and the amount withdrawn from the trust fund. The dataset also specifies the reason for the withdrawal, such as covering fines from the Department of Consumer Affairs (DCA) or providing restitution to consumers. Researchers and analysts can use this data to understand trends in trust fund invasions, identify businesses with frequent violations, and assess the financial impact on consumers. This information can be valuable for regulatory agencies, consumer advocacy groups, and businesses in the home improvement and towing industries. Please note that the dataset reflects data as of July 21, 2023, and an updated version is expected.
sfd:

title: Certified Asbestos Investigators
ufd: This dataset provides a list of Certified Asbestos Investigators (CAI), offering valuable information for those seeking qualified professionals in asbestos management. Each entry includes the investigator's first and last name, along with their unique certification number. A key piece of information is the expiration date of the certification, allowing users to verify the current validity of an investigator's credentials. The dataset also contains telephone contact information, though some entries may be missing this data. Researchers, building owners, or anyone needing asbestos-related services can use this dataset to find and verify certified investigators in their area. Please note that 22% of the telephone entries are missing.
sfd:

title: NYC Parks Pools
ufd: This dataset provides information on indoor and outdoor pools managed by NYC Parks. It includes details such as the pool's name, location (indoor or outdoor), and identifiers like `gispropnum` and `omppropid`. Location information is further specified by borough, community board, and council district. The dataset also contains geographic coordinates in the `polygon` column, enabling mapping and spatial analysis. Researchers and city planners could use this dataset to analyze the distribution of pools across different boroughs and community districts. Swimmers can use this dataset to locate pools near them.

- Spatial Analysis: Geographic analysis, mapping, location intelligence

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the distribution of pools across different boroughs and community districts.
- Locate pools near a specific location.
- Map the locations of all NYC Parks pools.
- Study the relationship between pool availability and population density.
- Plan new pool construction or renovations.

title: Fair Fares Enrollees
ufd: This dataset provides monthly statistics on enrollment in the Fair Fares program, managed by the Department of Social Services Office of Performance Management & Data Analytics. It includes data from January 2019 to May 2024. Each row represents a specific month and the corresponding total number of Fair Fares enrollees. The key columns are "month," indicating the date of the observation, and "total_fair_fares_enrollees," representing the total number of individuals enrolled in the program for that month. Researchers, policymakers, and social service providers can use this data to analyze trends in Fair Fares enrollment over time, assess the program's reach, and inform decisions related to resource allocation and program improvement. The dataset contains 81 rows, each with unique month and enrollment values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains monthly enrollment statistics for the Fair Fares program, spanning from January 2019 to May 2024. It tracks the total number of individuals enrolled in the program each month. The data can be used to analyze enrollment trends and program reach over time.

Related Topics:
- Social Services
- Public Transportation
- Low-Income Assistance Programs
- Government Programs
- Urban Planning
- Demographics

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Fair Fares: Reduced fare program, subsidized transit, affordable transportation
- Enrollment: Participation, registration, membership, program uptake
- Total Fair Fares Enrollees: Number of participants, program beneficiaries, total recipients
- Monthly Statistics: Time series data, monthly data, periodic reporting

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in Fair Fares enrollment over time.
- Assess the program's reach and impact on low-income individuals.
- Inform decisions related to resource allocation and program improvement.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of outreach efforts to increase enrollment.
- Compare Fair Fares enrollment with other social service program participation.
- Predict future enrollment based on historical trends.

title: 2013 Green Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip records for green taxis in 2013. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including details such as pickup and dropoff dates/times (`lpep_pickup_datetime`, `lpep_dropoff_datetime`), pickup and dropoff locations (`pickup_longitude`, `pickup_latitude`, `dropoff_longitude`, `dropoff_latitude`), trip distance (`trip_distance`), and fare information (`fare_amount`, `tip_amount`, `total_amount`). The dataset also includes the `vendorid`, a rate code ID (`ratecodeid`), passenger count (`passenger_count`), and a flag indicating if the trip record was stored in the vehicle before transmission (`store_and_fwd_flag`). Researchers and analysts can use this data to study taxi usage patterns, analyze fare structures, and understand the spatial distribution of taxi trips. The data could also be used to build predictive models for taxi demand or fare estimation. Note that the `trip_type` column has a high null fraction.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed trip records for green taxis operating in 2013. It includes information on pickup and dropoff locations and times, trip distances, fare details, and passenger counts for each trip. The data allows for analysis of taxi usage patterns and fare structures.

Related Topics:
- Taxi trips
- Green taxis
- Transportation data
- New York City
- Fare analysis
- Spatial analysis
- Time series analysis

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Trip record: ride data, journey log
- Pickup/Dropoff: origin/destination, start/end
- Fare amount: trip cost, price
- Vendor ID: taxi company identifier
- Rate code ID: fare type, rate category

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze taxi ridership patterns and trends.
- Predict taxi demand based on time and location.
- Study the impact of pricing on taxi usage.
- Visualize taxi trip density and popular routes.
- Develop fare estimation models.

title: DOB Disciplinary Actions
ufd: This dataset contains records of disciplinary actions taken by the New York City Department of Buildings (DOB) against construction professionals. It includes information on the year and date of the action, the type and number of the professional's license, and the name of both the individual and their company. The most important column is "disposition," which describes the specific disciplinary action taken, such as fines, probation, or surrender of license, and the basis for the action. Researchers and the public can use this dataset to understand the types of violations that lead to disciplinary actions in the construction industry. Analyzing the data can reveal trends in violations, identify repeat offenders, and assess the effectiveness of DOB's enforcement efforts. The data spans from 2023 to 2025 and includes various license types, with Professional Engineers and Registered Architects being the most frequently represented.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details disciplinary actions enforced by the NYC Department of Buildings (DOB) against construction professionals from 2023-2025. It includes details on the professional's license, company, and the specific disciplinary action taken (disposition), such as fines or license suspension. The data allows for analysis of violation trends and DOB enforcement effectiveness.

Related Topics:
- Construction Industry Regulation
- NYC Building Codes
- Professional Licensing
- Regulatory Compliance
- Urban Development
- Government Oversight

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Disciplinary Actions: Enforcement actions, penalties, sanctions, violations
- NYC Department of Buildings (DOB): Building Department, DOB violations, NYC construction regulation
- Construction Professionals: Architects, Engineers, Contractors, Licensees
- Disposition: Outcome, resolution, penalty, sanction, fine, probation, license suspension
- Violations: Infractions, offenses, non-compliance, code violations

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in construction violations in NYC.
- Identify repeat offenders in the construction industry.
- Assess the effectiveness of DOB's disciplinary actions.
- Research the types of violations that lead to specific penalties.
- Investigate the prevalence of violations among different license types (e.g., engineers vs. architects).
- Develop predictive models for identifying high-risk construction professionals.

title: Buildings Selected for the Underlying Conditions Program
ufd: This dataset contains information on buildings in New York City that have been selected for the Underlying Conditions Program by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD). The program focuses on buildings with a high number of class "B" and "C" violations related to mold or water leaks. Each row represents a building and includes its `building_id`, `borough`, street address (`phn` and `street_name`), and the number of `total_units`. Key details include the `order_issue_date` when the building was designated for the program and its `current_status` (e.g., Active or Discharged). The dataset also provides location information via `postcode`, `latitude`, and `longitude`, as well as administrative details like `community_board` and `council_district`. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze the prevalence of housing issues across different areas of the city, track the progress of buildings in the program, and potentially identify areas that require more focused intervention.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details buildings in New York City participating in the HPD's Underlying Conditions Program, which targets properties with significant mold and water leak violations. Each record represents a building and includes its location, program status, and administrative details. The data allows for analysis of housing conditions and program effectiveness across different NYC neighborhoods.

Related Topics:
- Housing Quality
- Building Violations
- Urban Planning
- New York City
- Public Health
- Property Management
- Code Enforcement

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Underlying Conditions Program (UCP)
- Housing Preservation and Development (HPD)
- Building Violations (Class B violations, Class C violations, Mold, Water Leaks)
- Property Address (Street Address, Building ID, Borough, Postcode)
- Program Status (Active, Discharged)
- Location Data (Latitude, Longitude)
- Residential Units (Total Units)

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the geographic distribution of buildings with underlying conditions.
- Track the progress of buildings through the Underlying Conditions Program.
- Identify areas in NYC with a high concentration of housing quality issues.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of the Underlying Conditions Program.
- Inform urban planning and resource allocation decisions related to housing.
- Predict which buildings are most likely to require intervention.
- Research the correlation between housing conditions and public health outcomes.

title: Low Income Housing Tax Credits Awarded by HPD: Project-Level (4% Awards)
ufd: This dataset provides project-level information on Low Income Housing Tax Credits awarded by the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) for projects receiving tax-exempt bonds. Each row represents a specific allocation to a low-income housing development, targeting households at or below 60% of the Area Median Income. Key details include the applicant's contact information (house number, street name, city, state, and postcode), project name and borough, and whether the project involves new construction or rehabilitation. The dataset also contains financial information, such as the DOCE (Date of Credit Execution) amount and the credit year. Researchers, urban planners, and developers can use this data to analyze trends in affordable housing development, assess the geographic distribution of tax credits, and identify potential investment opportunities. The number of total and tax credit units, along with building identification numbers, offer further insights into project scale and scope.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details Low Income Housing Tax Credit allocations awarded by the NYC HPD for projects receiving tax-exempt bonds. It provides project-level information, including applicant details, project specifics (name, borough, new construction/rehabilitation), and financial data like DOCE amount and credit year. The data allows for analysis of affordable housing trends and investment opportunities.

Related Topics:

- Identify potential investment opportunities in affordable housing development.

title: 2018-2019 Bullying Harassment Discrimination Bi- Annual Report
ufd: This dataset contains information on bullying, harassment, and discrimination incidents reported by New York City high schools during the period of July to December 2018. Each row represents a specific high school, identified by its DBN and school name. The dataset includes counts of complaints, material incidents, and incidents related to disability, ethnicity, gender identity, race, and religion. The counts are provided for the July-December 2018 period. Note that most of the incident counts are masked with asterisks. This data could be used to identify schools with higher rates of reported incidents, although the masking limits detailed analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details reported bullying, harassment, and discrimination incidents in New York City high schools from July to December 2018. It provides aggregated counts of various incident types, categorized by factors like disability, ethnicity, gender identity, race, and religion, for each school. Incident counts are largely masked.

Related Topics:
- School safety
- Bullying prevention
- Discrimination in education
- NYC public schools

- Incident: Complaint, report, occurrence

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identifying schools with potentially higher rates of reported incidents (despite masking).
- Comparing overall incident reporting across different schools.
- Investigating trends in specific categories of incidents (e.g., race-related incidents).
- Supporting research on school climate and safety initiatives.

title: NYC Honorary Street Names Map (Street Line)
ufd: This dataset provides information about honorary street names in New York City. It includes details on the City Council Introduction Number, enactment date and number, and the category of the street name change. The data also specifies the borough, the new honorary name, the existing street name, and the limits of the honorary designation. Location is provided via coordinate geometries. Researchers, city planners, and the general public can use this dataset to explore the history and locations of honorary street names throughout the city. This information can be valuable for understanding community recognition efforts and the cultural landscape of New York City.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details honorary street names in New York City, offering insights into community recognition and cultural landmarks. It includes information such as the City Council Introduction Number, enactment details, borough, new honorary name, existing street name, and location coordinates. The data allows users to explore the history and locations of honorary street names across the city.

title: HIV/AIDS Diagnoses by Neighborhood, Age Group, and Race/Ethnicity
ufd: This dataset provides insights into HIV and AIDS diagnoses in New York City, specifically focusing on the Bronx borough. It presents the number of new HIV and AIDS diagnoses, along with rates per 100,000 population, for the year 2021. The data is broken down by neighborhood, race/ethnicity, and age group, allowing for detailed comparisons across these demographics. Key columns include `hiv_diagnoses_num`, `aids_diagnoses_num`, and their respective rates per 100k, offering a view of disease prevalence. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to identify at-risk populations, track trends in HIV/AIDS diagnoses, and inform targeted interventions. The `concurrent_hiv_aids_among_all` column provides additional context on the overlap between HIV and AIDS diagnoses.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details HIV and AIDS diagnoses in the Bronx, New York City for 2021. It includes the number of new diagnoses and rates per 100,000 people, categorized by neighborhood, race/ethnicity, and age group. The data allows for analysis of disease prevalence across different demographic segments.

Related Topics:

title: OneNYC 2050 (Historical)
ufd: This dataset provides a historical record of New York City's progress towards the goals outlined in the OneNYC 2050 Strategic Plan. It includes key performance indicators (KPIs) across eight overarching goals, such as "Healthy Lives," "Inclusive Economy," and "Livable Climate." Each record details the agency responsible, the specific initiative, the reporting year, the indicator being measured (e.g., "Adult New Yorkers who exercised in the past 30 days"), the indicator's value, the type of measurement (e.g., percentage, number), the data period, and the target set for that indicator. Researchers, policymakers, and city residents can use this dataset to track the city's performance over time, assess the effectiveness of various initiatives, and identify areas where further action is needed to achieve the OneNYC 2050 goals. The data spans from 2019 to 2022 and offers insights into various aspects of city government and its efforts to improve the lives of New Yorkers. The dataset allows users to understand the city's strategic priorities and how different agencies contribute to achieving them.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains key performance indicators (KPIs) related to New York City's OneNYC 2050 Strategic Plan goals from 2019-2022. It tracks progress across eight goals like "Healthy Lives" and "Livable Climate," detailing agency initiatives, indicator values, and targets. This allows for monitoring city performance and assessing initiative effectiveness.

Related Topics:

title: Sandy Inundation Zone
ufd: This dataset details the areas of New York City that experienced flooding as a result of Hurricane Sandy. It includes geographic information defining the inundation zones, represented by the `the_geom` column which contains MultiPolygon coordinates. Key attributes include the `state` where the inundation occurred, the `demsource` indicating the source of the data, and the `status` describing the verification level of the data. The `sourcedata` column provides information on the origin of the data, while the `verified` column confirms whether the data has been verified. Researchers, urban planners, and emergency responders can use this dataset to analyze the impact of Hurricane Sandy, improve flood risk assessments, and develop better mitigation strategies for future events. The data can also be used for visualization and mapping to communicate flood risks to the public.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains geographic information about the areas in New York City that were flooded during Hurricane Sandy. It includes inundation zones defined by MultiPolygon coordinates, along with attributes like data source, verification status, and state. This data is valuable for understanding the impact of the hurricane and improving flood risk management.

Related Topics:
- Hurricane Sandy
- Flood Risk Assessment
- Coastal Inundation
- Emergency Response
- Urban Planning
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- Disaster Management

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Inundation Zone: Flood Zone, Flooded Area, Submerged Area
- MultiPolygon: Geographic Coordinates, Spatial Data, Geometry
- Data Source: Source Data, Origin, Provenance
- Verification Status: Verified, Validation, Accuracy
- Flood Risk: Hazard Assessment, Vulnerability, Exposure

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the spatial extent and impact of Hurricane Sandy flooding.
- Develop flood risk maps and improve flood risk assessments.
- Support emergency response planning and resource allocation.
- Inform urban planning and infrastructure development decisions.
- Visualize flood risks and communicate them to the public.
- Research the effectiveness of flood mitigation strategies.

title: Low Income Housing Tax Credits Awarded by HPD: Project-Level (9% Awards)
ufd: This dataset contains information on low-income housing projects in New York City that have been awarded 9% Low Income Housing Tax Credits by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD). Each row represents a specific project and includes details about the applicant organization, such as their name, address, and contact phone number. The dataset also provides the project's name, the borough where it's located, and whether it involves new construction or rehabilitation. Key columns include `cra_amount`, representing the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA) amount awarded, and `total_units`, indicating the number of housing units in the project. Researchers, urban planners, and housing advocates can use this dataset to analyze trends in affordable housing development, track the allocation of tax credits, and assess the impact of these projects on different communities within New York City. The `credit_year` and `cra_date` columns allow for time-based analysis of project funding.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details low-income housing projects in New York City funded through 9% Low Income Housing Tax Credits awarded by the Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD). It includes information on applicant organizations, project details like location and type (new construction or rehabilitation), and financial data such as the Community Reinvestment Act (CRA) amount. The data allows for analysis of affordable housing development trends and the impact of tax credit allocation.

title: Water and Sewer Permits (Historic)
ufd: This dataset contains historical information on water and sewer permits issued in New York City. Each row represents a permit, including its borough, block, lot, and zip code. The `serv_order_type` and `permit_description` columns provide details on the type of service and permit issued, such as sewer installation or tapping permits. The `permit_no` is a unique identifier for each permit, and `dateissued` indicates when the permit was issued. This dataset could be used to analyze trends in water and sewer permits over time, identify areas with high permit activity, or understand the distribution of different types of permits across the city. Note that this is a historical dataset; for the latest information, refer to the Water and Sewer Permits dataset.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides historical records of water and sewer permits issued in New York City. Each entry details a specific permit, including its location (borough, block, lot, zip code), permit type, and issuance date. Key information includes the service order type, permit description, and a unique permit number.

Related Topics:

title: Neighborhood Development Areas
ufd: This dataset contains the boundaries of Neighborhood Development Areas (NDAs) in New York City, along with the borough each NDA is located in. NDAs are low-income communities targeted by the Department of Youth and Community Development (DYCD) for Community Services Block Grant (CSBG) funding. The dataset includes a column with the geometry of each NDA, represented as a MultiPolygon, and a column indicating the borough the NDA is in. This data can be used to understand the geographic distribution of NDAs across the city. It can also be used to analyze the characteristics of these communities and to plan and evaluate programs and services targeted to low-income residents. Researchers, policymakers, and community organizations can use this dataset to identify areas with high needs and to advocate for resources to address poverty and promote community development.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes geographic boundaries as MultiPolygons and the borough each NDA is located within. This data facilitates understanding the spatial distribution of NDAs and supports analysis of community characteristics.

title: Capital Projects Dashboard - Citywide Budget and Spend by Fiscal Year
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at New York City's capital projects, outlining the budget and spending for major infrastructure initiatives by fiscal year. Each record is uniquely identified by a Financial Management Service (FMS) ID, which allows for joining with other datasets from the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). Key columns include the managing agency responsible for the project, the fiscal year the budget applies to, the total budget allocated, and the amount spent. The dataset differentiates between city and non-city budget allocations. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this data to track financial progress on capital projects, understand how city funds are allocated, and assess the financial performance of different managing agencies. Note that spend data is sparsely populated in this dataset. The reporting period indicates the month the data was reported.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains financial information on New York City's capital projects, including budget allocations and spending. Each project is identified by a unique FMS ID. The data includes the managing agency, fiscal year, total budget, amount spent (though sparsely populated), and breakdowns of city vs. non-city funding.

Related Topics:

- Government Budgets
- Urban Planning
- New York City
- Capital Projects

- Managing Agency (Responsible Agency, Department)
- Fiscal Year (Budget Year, Financial Year)

- Amount Spent (Expenditure, Actual Spending)
- City Budget (NYC Budget, Local Funding)
- Non-City Budget (Federal Funding, State Funding, External Funding)
- Capital Projects (Infrastructure Projects, Public Works)

- Track financial progress of NYC capital projects.
- Analyze budget allocation trends across different city agencies.
- Compare city vs. non-city funding sources for infrastructure.
- Identify potential cost overruns or underexpenditures.
- Assess the financial performance of managing agencies.
- Combine with other OMB datasets using the FMS ID for more comprehensive analysis.

title: DOF: Cooperative Comparable Rental Income (Citywide)
ufd: This dataset contains information on cooperative and condominium properties in New York City, used by the Department of Finance to assess property values. The data includes details such as the address, neighborhood, building classification (e.g., elevator or walk-up), total number of units, and year built. Financial information is also provided, including estimated gross income, expenses, and market value, both in total and per square foot. Key columns for analysis include 'neighborhood' for spatial analysis, 'year_built' for understanding the age of the properties, and 'total_units' to gauge the size of the building. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze property values, rental income, and expenses across different neighborhoods, assess the impact of building age and type on market value, and gain insights into the city's housing market. The 'boro_block_lot' and 'address' columns can be used to uniquely identify properties.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

It includes property characteristics such as address, neighborhood, building type, unit count, and construction year. Financial details like estimated gross income, expenses, and market value (total and per square foot) are also included, enabling comprehensive property analysis.

title: Firefighter Probationary School Results Admissions and Graduation Statistics
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the Firefighter career path, tracking applicants from initial application through probationary school graduation. It includes cumulative counts of applicants from both open-competitive (Exam 7001) and promotional (Exam 7501) firefighter exam listings. Key columns include `date`, `report_type` (Exam Results, PFS_Candidates), `metric` (detailing specific stages like exam scores and graduation outcomes), `demographic_type` (Ethnicity, Gender), `demographic_subtype` (e.g., Asian, Black, Male, Female), and `number_of_applicants`.  The data allows users to analyze applicant progress at different stages, identify potential bottlenecks, and assess demographic representation throughout the firefighter recruitment and training pipeline. This information can be used to inform recruitment strategies, improve training programs, and promote diversity within the fire department. Note that some values in `number_of_applicants` are represented as "**", indicating potentially missing or suppressed data. The dataset covers data up to December 31, 2024.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset tracks firefighter applicants from application to probationary school graduation, providing cumulative counts for open-competitive (Exam 7001) and promotional (Exam 7501) exams. It includes metrics on exam results, candidate progress, and demographic breakdowns (Ethnicity, Gender) of applicants at each stage. The data spans up to December 31, 2024, and can be used to analyze recruitment pipelines and demographic representation.

**Related Topics:**
- Fire Department Recruitment
- Public Safety Workforce
- Diversity and Inclusion
- Applicant Tracking
- Training Program Evaluation
- Government Employment
- Emergency Services

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Firefighter Applicant Pipeline: Recruitment process, candidate journey, hiring funnel
- Exam 7001: Open-Competitive Exam, Entry-Level Firefighter Exam
- Exam 7501: Promotional Exam, Firefighter Advancement Exam
- Demographic Data: Ethnicity, Gender, Race, Sex
- Probationary School: Fire Academy, Training Program, Recruit School
- Number of Applicants: Candidate Count, Application Volume, Headcount
- PFS_Candidates: Physical Fitness Screening Candidates, Physical Ability Test

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Analyze demographic representation at each stage of the firefighter recruitment process.
- Identify bottlenecks in the application and training pipeline.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of recruitment strategies.
- Inform diversity and inclusion initiatives within the fire department.
- Track applicant progress from initial application to graduation.
- Compare outcomes for open-competitive and promotional exam candidates.
- Monitor the impact of training program changes on graduation rates.

title: 2020-2021 Demographic Snapshot Citywide
ufd:
This dataset provides a citywide snapshot of student enrollment and demographic information across multiple years. It includes the total enrollment for each year, as well as enrollment counts for specific grades, from pre-kindergarten through 12th grade. The dataset also breaks down enrollment by gender (female and male) and race/ethnicity (Asian, Black, Hispanic, and White).

Key columns include "year" representing the school year, "total_enrollment" indicating the total number of students enrolled, and columns like "grade_k," "grade_1," etc., showing enrollment in each grade level. Columns such as "female," "male," "asian," "black," "hispanic," and "white" provide the number of students in each demographic category. The corresponding columns with "_1" appended to the name represent the fraction of students in each demographic category.

Researchers, policymakers, and education advocates can use this data to analyze trends in student enrollment, understand demographic shifts within the student population, and assess the representation of different groups across grade levels. This information can be valuable for resource allocation, program development, and addressing disparities in educational outcomes. The data is collected using multiple data sources, including DOE's Audited Register, biographic data from Automate The Schools (ATS) system and the Location Code Generation and Management System (LCGMS).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains citywide student enrollment and demographic information spanning multiple years. It includes total enrollment, grade-level enrollment (pre-K to 12th), and breakdowns by gender and race/ethnicity. The data is sourced from DOE's Audited Register, Automate The Schools (ATS) system, and the Location Code Generation and Management System (LCGMS).

Related Topics:
- Education Statistics
- Student Demographics
- School Enrollment
- Educational Equity
- Demographic Trends
- Public School Data

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Enrollment Data: Student counts, registration numbers, attendance records
- Student Demographics: Gender, race, ethnicity, demographic groups
- Grade Levels: Kindergarten, elementary school, middle school, high school
- School Year: Academic year, reporting period
- Total Enrollment: Overall student population, aggregate enrollment
- Demographic Representation: Diversity in schools, proportional representation

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in student enrollment over time.
- Identify demographic shifts within the student population.
- Assess the representation of different groups across grade levels.
- Inform resource allocation and program development in education.
- Investigate disparities in educational outcomes based on demographics.
- Support research on educational equity and access.
- Evaluate the impact of policies on student enrollment patterns.

title: E-Designations
ufd: This dataset provides information on E-Designations in New York City, which are environmental requirements related to potential hazardous materials, noise levels, or air emissions on specific tax lots. It includes the E-Designation number (`enumber`), the effective date of the designation, and location information via borough code (`borocode`), tax block (`taxblock`), and tax lot (`taxlot`). The dataset also contains codes indicating the presence of hazardous materials (`hazmat_code`), air emission concerns (`air_code`), and noise issues (`noise_code`). Furthermore, it includes related identifiers such as the CEQR number (`ceqr_num`) and ULURP number (`ulurp_num`). You can use this data to identify properties with environmental concerns, understand the types of environmental requirements in place, and link these designations to specific locations and projects. The `description` column provides a brief explanation of the environmental requirement.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on E-Designations in New York City, which are environmental requirements placed on specific tax lots due to potential hazardous materials, noise levels, or air emissions. The data includes the E-Designation number, effective date, location details (borough, block, lot), and codes indicating the type of environmental concern. It also provides related identifiers like CEQR and ULURP numbers, along with a description of the environmental requirement.

- Assessing the potential environmental impact of new construction or renovation projects.

title: Financial Empowerment Centers
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive list of Financial Empowerment Centers in New York City, offering valuable information for individuals seeking financial assistance and resources. The data includes details such as the provider of the services, the host organization, and the full site location address, along with the days and hours of operation. Key columns like "provider" indicate the organization offering the financial services, while "city" and "borough" specify the location of the center. The "days_open" and "hours" columns are crucial for planning visits, and "language_s" indicates the languages spoken at each location. Additionally, the dataset includes contact information via the "telephone" column. This dataset can be used to find nearby financial empowerment centers, determine their hours and services, and identify locations that offer assistance in specific languages.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a listing of Financial Empowerment Centers located throughout New York City. It provides details on the center's provider, location address, days and hours of operation, and languages spoken. The data is useful for individuals seeking financial assistance and resources in NYC.

Related Topics:
- Financial Literacy

- New York City Resources
- Social Services

- Financial Empowerment Center: FEC, Financial Opportunity Center, Financial Counseling Center

- Identify locations that offer assistance in specific languages.

title: Hurricane Inundation by Evacuation Zone
ufd: This dataset contains information about hurricane inundation areas in New York City, based on the National Hurricane Center’s 2020 SLOSH model. The inundation areas are post-processed to a 10-meter resolution, assuming storm surges occur at high tide. This data is used to develop New York City’s Hurricane Evacuation Zones. Key columns include `borocode` representing the borough code, `evac_zone` indicating the evacuation zone, `shape_leng` for the length of the shape, `shape_area` for the area of the shape, and `the_geom` which provides the geometry of the inundation area as a MultiPolygon. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to understand potential flood risks during hurricanes and to refine evacuation strategies. The data can also be used to inform infrastructure planning and development in vulnerable areas.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details hurricane inundation areas in New York City, derived from the National Hurricane Center’s 2020 SLOSH model and refined to a 10-meter resolution. It represents potential storm surge flooding at high tide and is used to define NYC's Hurricane Evacuation Zones. The data includes borough codes, evacuation zones, shape measurements, and geometry of inundation areas.

Related Topics:
  - Hurricane Modeling
  - Coastal Flooding
  - Emergency Management
  - Urban Planning
  - Climate Change
  - Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Concepts and Synonyms:
  - Hurricane Inundation: Storm surge flooding, coastal inundation, flood zone mapping
  - SLOSH Model: Sea, Lake, and Overland Surges from Hurricanes model, storm surge prediction model
  - Evacuation Zone: Evacuation area, flood risk zone, emergency response area
  - Borocode: Borough code, NYC borough identifier
  - Shape_Area/Shape_Leng: Polygon area, polygon length, geometric measurements
  - The_Geom: Geometry, spatial data, MultiPolygon, GIS data

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Hurricane evacuation planning and zone refinement.
  - Infrastructure vulnerability assessment in coastal areas.
  - Flood risk mapping and mitigation strategies.
  - Urban planning and development regulations in flood-prone zones.
  - Climate change impact analysis on coastal communities.
  - Emergency response resource allocation and preparedness.

title: Bus Stop Shelter
ufd: This dataset provides the locations of bus stop shelters in New York City. Each record includes the shelter's geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude), the streets it's located on ('on_street' and 'cross_stre'), and the corner of the intersection where it stands. The dataset also contains administrative information, such as the borough, community district, assembly district, state senate district, and congressional district. You can use this data to analyze the distribution of bus shelters across the city, identify areas with limited shelter coverage, or plan infrastructure improvements. The 'boro_name' column indicates the borough (e.g., Brooklyn, Queens), while 'shelter_id' provides a unique identifier for each shelter. Information about flood zones is also included.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains geographic and administrative information about bus stop shelters in New York City. It includes location details like latitude, longitude, street names, and corner location, along with administrative districts (borough, community district, etc.). The data can be used to analyze shelter distribution, identify coverage gaps, and inform infrastructure planning.

Related Topics:
- Public Transportation
- Urban Planning
- Infrastructure
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

- Accessibility

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Bus Stop Shelter: Bus Shelter, Transit Shelter, Bus Stop Canopy
- Geographic Coordinates: Latitude, Longitude, Geolocation
- Administrative Districts: Borough, Community District, Assembly District, State Senate District, Congressional District
- Location: Street Address, Intersection, Corner
- Flood Zone: Floodplain, FEMA Flood Map

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the spatial distribution of bus shelters across NYC boroughs.
- Identify areas with inadequate bus shelter coverage.
- Plan new bus shelter installations based on population density and ridership.
- Integrate shelter locations with bus route data for improved transit planning.
- Assess the vulnerability of bus shelters to flooding.
- Visualize bus shelter locations on a map.
- Determine the political representation (districts) associated with each shelter.

title: NYCDCP_Manhattan_Bike_Counts
ufd: This dataset contains information on bike count locations in Manhattan, collected by the New York City Department of City Planning. The data identifies both on-street and off-street locations. Key columns include `name`, which provides the street address of the bike count location, and `the_geom`, `latitude`, and `longitude`, which provide the geographic coordinates. The `type` column specifies whether the location is on-street or off-street. Researchers and urban planners can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of bike count locations across Manhattan. This information can be used to understand cyclist traffic patterns and inform decisions related to bicycle infrastructure planning.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the locations of bike count points in Manhattan, as recorded by the New York City Department of City Planning. It includes both on-street and off-street locations, identified by street address and geographic coordinates. The dataset is useful for analyzing the spatial distribution of bike count locations and understanding cyclist traffic patterns.

Related Topics:

- Urban planning

- Geographic data
- New York City
- Cyclist traffic patterns

Concepts and Synonyms:

- On-street: Street-level, roadway
- Off-street: Path, trail, greenway
- Geographic coordinates: Latitude, longitude, the_geom
- Manhattan: New York County, NYC borough

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyzing the density of bike count locations in different areas of Manhattan.
- Identifying areas with a high concentration of bike traffic.
- Informing the placement of new bicycle infrastructure.
- Comparing on-street and off-street bike count location distributions.
- Integrating with other transportation datasets to understand multimodal traffic patterns.

title: Inmate Deaths
ufd: This dataset contains information about non-natural inmate deaths in custody. Each row represents a single incident, identified by a unique `incident_id`. The `reported_dt` column indicates the date and time the incident was reported. All incidents in this dataset are classified as `Suicide`. The `facility` column specifies the correctional facility where the incident occurred; note that some values are missing. Researchers and public safety analysts can use this data to understand the frequency and location of inmate suicides. This dataset could be used to identify facilities with higher rates of such incidents and inform preventative measures. Keep in mind that this dataset contains a limited number of records.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details non-natural inmate deaths classified as suicides within correctional facilities. Each record represents a single incident, identified by a unique ID and the date/time it was reported. The data includes the facility where the incident occurred, though some facility information is missing. This dataset provides insights into the frequency and location of inmate suicides in custody.

Related Topics:
- Inmate Mortality
- Correctional Facilities
- Suicide Prevention
- Public Safety
- Prison Reform

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Inmate Death: Prisoner Death, Custodial Death, Death in Custody
- Suicide: Self-inflicted Death, Self-Harm Fatality
- Correctional Facility: Prison, Jail, Detention Center
- Incident: Occurrence, Event, Case

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze suicide rates across different correctional facilities.
- Identify facilities with potentially higher risk of inmate suicide.
- Inform suicide prevention strategies and resource allocation within correctional systems.
- Investigate potential contributing factors to inmate suicide.

title: E-Designations
ufd: This dataset provides information on E-Designations in New York City, which are environmental requirements for specific tax lots related to potential hazards like contamination, noise, or air emissions. Each record represents a specific E-Designation and includes identifiers like the E-number, borough code, tax block, and tax lot. The dataset also contains CEQR and ULURP numbers, which are project and land use permit identifiers, respectively. A key field is the "descriptio" column, which describes the specific environmental requirements or restrictions for the designated location. The "the_geom" column provides the geographic coordinates for each location. Researchers, city planners, and developers can use this data to understand environmental regulations affecting properties, assess potential environmental risks, and ensure compliance with zoning requirements. The data is primarily focused on Manhattan (borough code 1).
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details E-Designations in New York City, outlining environmental requirements imposed on specific tax lots due to potential hazards. Each record includes identifiers like E-number, borough code, tax block, tax lot, CEQR and ULURP numbers, a description of the environmental requirements, and geographic coordinates. The data is primarily focused on Manhattan and is useful for understanding environmental regulations affecting properties.

**Related Topics:**
- Environmental Regulations
- Urban Planning
- Land Use
- Zoning
- New York City Government
- Property Development
- Environmental Impact Assessment

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- E-Designation: Environmental Designation, Environmental Restriction, Environmental Requirement
- Tax Lot: Property Parcel, Land Parcel
- CEQR: City Environmental Quality Review
- ULURP: Uniform Land Use Review Procedure
- Borough Code: NYC Borough, Manhattan (Borough Code 1), Brooklyn (Borough Code 3), Queens (Borough Code 4), Bronx (Borough Code 2), Staten Island (Borough Code 5)
- the_geom: Geographic Coordinates, Location Data, Spatial Data

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Assessing environmental risks associated with specific properties in NYC.
- Ensuring compliance with environmental regulations during property development.
- Identifying areas with specific environmental restrictions for urban planning purposes.
- Analyzing the spatial distribution of E-Designations across different boroughs.
- Integrating E-Designation data with other datasets related to property and land use.

title: 2019-2020 Arts Report
ufd: This dataset, titled "2019-2020 Arts Report," provides school-level data related to high school graduates, 8th grade students, and grades 1-6. It includes information on the number of graduates and 8th-grade students in each community school district, along with metrics on those who met certain criteria. The dataset also details the number of full-time and part-time teachers. Key columns include "community_school_district," "of_graduates," "of_8th_grade_students," and various columns quantifying the number of schools serving different grade levels. Researchers and educators can use this data to analyze student performance, staffing levels, and school resources across different community school districts. The data could be used to identify trends, assess the impact of arts programs, or inform resource allocation decisions.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The "2019-2020 Arts Report" dataset contains school-level information for high school graduates, 8th-grade students, and grades 1-6 across community school districts. It includes counts of graduates and 8th graders, along with data on students meeting specific criteria. The dataset also provides information on the number of full-time and part-time teachers in each district.

title: Elected Official Agency Engagement Form
ufd: This dataset contains information on requests made by elected officials to engage with various New York City agencies. It includes the date and time of the request, contact information for both the elected official and the requestor, and the specific city agencies involved. Key columns include `submission_time`, `elected_offical_s_office` (the elected official's name and office), `elected_officials_office` (the elected official's office address), `e_mail_address_of_requestor`, and `name_of_the_city_agency_you` (the city agency the requestor is affiliated with). Researchers and city planners could use this data to analyze communication patterns between elected officials and city agencies. The dataset could also be used to identify which agencies are most frequently contacted and the types of requests being made. This information can help improve inter-agency coordination and resource allocation within the city government. The `position_title_of_requestor` column provides insight into who within the elected official's office is making the engagement request.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details requests submitted by elected officials to New York City agencies. It includes submission timestamps, contact information for both the elected official and the requestor, and the specific city agencies involved in each request. The data allows for analysis of communication patterns and engagement between elected officials and city agencies.

Related Topics:

- Identify the city agencies most frequently contacted by elected officials.

- Improve inter-agency coordination and resource allocation.
- Track engagement requests from specific elected officials' offices.
- Identify trends in requests over time.

title: Cash Assistance and SNAP Cases Rejections
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the reasons why applications for Cash Assistance and SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) benefits are rejected in New York State. It includes the count of rejected cases, categorized by the specific NYS Welfare Management System (WMS) rejection code, type of government assistance (Cash Assistance or SNAP), calendar year, and quarter (date). The 'nys_wms_rejection_code' column details the specific reason for rejection, while the 'type_of_government_assistance' column indicates whether the rejection was for Cash Assistance or SNAP. The dataset also breaks down the rejections by age group ('_18_24', '_25_44', '_45_64', '_65') and by a series of columns named 'cd_01' through 'cd_62'.  Researchers and policymakers can use this data to identify common reasons for rejection, understand trends over time, and potentially improve the application process to reduce unnecessary denials. Please note that values represented by asterisks (*) indicate counts between 1 and 10.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on rejected applications for Cash Assistance and SNAP benefits in New York State. It details the number of rejected cases, categorized by NYS Welfare Management System (WMS) rejection code, type of assistance (Cash Assistance or SNAP), year, and quarter. The data also includes breakdowns by age group and a series of columns 'cd_01' through 'cd_62'.

Related Topics:
- Public Assistance
- Social Welfare Programs
- Government Benefits
- SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program)
- Cash Assistance
- Welfare Policy
- New York State Government

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Cash Assistance: Welfare, Temporary Assistance, Financial Aid

- Rejection Code: Denial Reason, Reason for Rejection, WMS Code
- NYS Welfare Management System (WMS): Welfare System, Government Assistance System
- Government Assistance: Public Benefits, Social Services, Aid Programs

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identify common reasons for Cash Assistance and SNAP application rejections.
- Analyze trends in rejection rates over time.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of application processes and identify areas for improvement.
- Inform policy decisions related to public assistance programs.
- Investigate disparities in rejection rates across different age groups.
- Develop targeted interventions to reduce unnecessary denials.

title: 2016-17 Physical Education - PE Space
ufd: This dataset provides details on physical education (PE) spaces in Manhattan schools during the 2016-2017 school year. It includes information about the location of the PE spaces, such as the borough, geographical district, and school name, as well as the type and size of the space. Key columns include `location_name` (the name of the school), `grade_level` indicating the grades served at the school, `room_function` describing the purpose of the space (e.g., gymnasium, outdoor yard), and `square_feet` specifying the size of the space. The dataset also indicates whether the space is shared with other schools and whether it's used for purposes other than PE. Researchers and education officials can use this data to analyze the availability and characteristics of PE spaces across different schools and districts. This information can be valuable for resource allocation, facility planning, and ensuring equitable access to physical education resources for students.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details physical education (PE) spaces in Manhattan schools during the 2016-2017 school year. It includes location information (borough, district, school name), space type (gymnasium, yard), and size (square feet). The data also indicates shared use and alternative uses of the PE spaces.

Related Topics:

- Grade Level: School level, education stage, student age

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the distribution of PE resources across Manhattan schools.
- Identify schools with limited or inadequate PE spaces.
- Evaluate the utilization of PE spaces for purposes other than physical education.
- Support resource allocation and facility planning for PE programs.
- Compare PE space availability across different grade levels.

title: Pharmaceutical and Syringe Drop-Off Locations in NYC
ufd: This dataset provides locations in New York City where residents can safely dispose of unwanted pharmaceuticals and syringes/sharps. The data includes the borough, neighborhood (NTA name), site type (pharmaceutical or syringe/sharps drop-off), and the name and address of the drop-off location.  The dataset also contains the zipcode and borough code for each location. Phone numbers and hours of operation are available for some locations. This information can be used to find the nearest and most convenient disposal site.  Researchers could use this data to analyze the accessibility of disposal sites across different neighborhoods.  The dataset also includes DSNY (Department of Sanitation) zones and districts for internal tracking purposes.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset catalogs locations in New York City where individuals can safely dispose of unwanted medications and syringes/sharps. It includes details such as borough, neighborhood, site type (pharmaceutical or syringe/sharps), name, address, and contact information (where available) for each drop-off location. The data also contains administrative information like zipcode, borough code, and DSNY zones/districts.

- Borough: NYC borough (e.g., Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens)

title: NYC Parks Structures
ufd: The NYC Parks Structures dataset contains information about structures located within New York City parks, broadly defined as assemblies of materials forming constructions for occupancy or use. Each row represents a single structure and includes data maintained by NYC Parks, NYC DoITT, and NYC Planning. Key fields include the Building Identification Number (BIN), Borough, a flag indicating the presence of a public restroom, and the year of construction. The dataset also provides identifiers from various agencies, such as the DoITT ID and GIS property number. Additional details include ground elevation, roof height, and a textual description of the structure. This dataset can be used to analyze the distribution and characteristics of structures within NYC parks, identify locations with public restrooms, or study the age and physical attributes of park buildings. Updated weekly, this dataset offers a comprehensive view of the built environment within NYC's park system.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The NYC Parks Structures dataset provides detailed information about structures located within New York City parks. It includes attributes like Building Identification Number (BIN), borough, presence of public restrooms, and year of construction. The dataset also contains identifiers from various agencies and physical characteristics of the structures, offering a comprehensive view of the built environment within NYC's park system.

Related Topics:

- Study the age and physical attributes of park buildings.

title: DCM_StreetNameChanges_Points
ufd: This dataset contains information about honorary street name changes in New York City, represented as points on a map. Each entry corresponds to a specific location, identified by geographic coordinates and the borough it's located in. The dataset specifies whether the location is a corner, intersection, or park. Key columns include the `honor_name`, which is the honorary street name, and `lleffect_dt`, the date the street name change went into effect. The data also includes identifiers related to the introduction of the street name change, such as `intro_year`, `intro_month`, and `intro_num`. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of honorary street names across the city, track the history of street name changes, or identify areas with a high concentration of honorary designations. This information can be valuable for understanding community priorities and memorialization efforts within different neighborhoods.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides a comprehensive record of honorary street name changes in New York City, pinpointed by geographic coordinates. It includes details such as the honorary name, effective date, borough, and location type (corner, intersection, park). The data also contains information about the introduction of the street name change, including the year, month, and number.

title: Position Schedule
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of full-time active positions within the Mayoralty of the city government, as published on June 30, 2020. It includes details about each position, such as the agency code and name, the specific office within the Mayoralty (ua_name), and the title code and name. Key columns include `title_code_name`, which describes the job title (e.g., "ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT TO THE MAYOR"), and the corresponding minimum and maximum salaries (`minmum_salary`, `maxmum_salary`) for that position. The dataset also indicates the number of positions (`positions`) available for each title. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze salary ranges across different roles within the Mayoralty, understand the distribution of positions across various offices, and track changes in staffing and compensation over time, as the dataset is updated twice a year.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details full-time active positions within the Mayoralty of a city government as of June 30, 2020. It includes information on agency, office, job title, and salary ranges for each position. The dataset also specifies the number of positions available for each title code.

- Identify potential areas for cost savings or resource reallocation within the Mayoralty.

title: 2015 - 2018 Demographic Snapshot Pre- K For All
ufd: This dataset provides a demographic snapshot of students enrolled in Pre-K for All sites from 2015 to 2018. It includes information on student enrollment and race/ethnicity demographics, broken down by site. Each row represents a specific Pre-K site and year, identified by a unique `site_id` and `site_name`. The dataset includes the total enrollment (`total_enrollment`) for each site, along with counts (`*_1`) and percentages (`*_2`) for different racial groups (Asian, Black, Hispanic, White) and gender (female, male). Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze trends in Pre-K enrollment and demographic changes over time. This information can be valuable for understanding the diversity within the Pre-K for All program and informing decisions related to resource allocation and program development.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains demographic information about students enrolled in Pre-K for All sites from 2015 to 2018. It includes enrollment numbers and race/ethnicity breakdowns for each site, identified by a unique ID and name. The data allows for analysis of enrollment trends and demographic shifts within the Pre-K for All program.

title: NYC REACH Members
ufd: This dataset provides information on healthcare providers participating in the NYC Regional Electronic Adoption Center for Health (REACH) program. It includes details such as the provider's first and last name, practice name, primary specialty (like Internal Medicine, Pediatrics, or Family Medicine), and the site name. The practice's location is specified by borough, mailing address, and zip code. All listed organizations are classified as "Small Practice." This dataset can be used to locate REACH-affiliated healthcare providers in New York City, identify providers by specialty and borough, or analyze the distribution of healthcare services across different locations. Researchers and healthcare administrators can leverage this data to understand the REACH network and improve healthcare access.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: 2007 - 2008 School Progress Reports - All Schools
ufd: This dataset contains school progress reports for all schools in the 2007-2008 academic year. It includes information such as the school's district, name, principal, and the type of progress report used (ESMS or HS). Key columns include `overall_grade` and `overall_score`, which provide an overall assessment of the school's performance. The `peer_index_` column indicates a school's demographic makeup relative to its peers. Other columns break down the overall score into environment, performance, and progress categories, each with a corresponding score and grade. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze school performance, identify areas for improvement, and compare schools based on various factors. The data also includes information about school support organizations and federal accountability status.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset provides school progress reports for the 2007-2008 academic year, encompassing all schools and their performance metrics. It includes overall grades and scores, broken down by environment, performance, and progress categories. title: Cooking Gas Consumption And Cost (2010 - May 2025)
ufd: This dataset contains monthly cooking gas consumption and cost information for housing developments in New York City, spanning from 2010 to May 2025. The data is broken down by borough and development name, allowing users to compare gas usage across different locations. Key columns include `development_name`, `borough`, `revenue_month` (the month the revenue was recorded), `current_charges` (the gas charges for the period), and `vendor_name` (the utility company providing the gas). You can use this dataset to analyze trends in gas consumption, identify potential cost savings, and evaluate the impact of energy efficiency initiatives in public housing. The dataset also includes meter information and identifiers like `umis_bill_id` and `rc_code` for more granular analysis. The `funding_source` column indicates that the developments are federally funded.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides monthly cooking gas consumption and cost details for New York City housing developments from 2010 to May 2025. The data is organized by borough and development name, including information on gas charges, vendor, and meter details. It allows for analysis of gas usage trends and cost variations across different locations.

title: Property Valuation and Assessment data Tax Classes 2,3,4
ufd: This dataset contains property valuation and assessment data for tax classes 2, 3, and 4 in New York City. It includes real estate assessment data used for calculating property taxes and determining eligibility for exemptions and abatements. Key columns include 'bble' (borough, block, and lot), 'boro' (borough code), 'block' and 'lot' (identifiers for real estate location), and 'year4' (the year of assessment). The dataset also contains information on current and new assessed values for land ('cur_fv_l', 'new_fv_l') and total property ('cur_fv_t', 'new_fv_t'), as well as assessed values and exemptions. Users can analyze this data to understand property valuation trends, assess the impact of exemptions, and evaluate property tax policies. The data is collected and entered by city employees such as property assessors and exemption specialists.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed property valuation and assessment information for tax classes 2, 3, and 4 in New York City. It encompasses real estate assessment data crucial for property tax calculation and exemption/abatement eligibility. Key data points include property identifiers (borough, block, lot), assessment years, and current/new assessed values for land and total property.

title: Encroachments and Defacements
ufd: This dataset contains information on encroachments and defacement complaints reported to 311 in New York City. Each row represents a single complaint, identified by a unique complaint ID and service request number. Key details include the type of complaint (e.g., defacement), the borough where it occurred, and the street address. The dataset also provides information on initial inspections, including the date and results (pass/fail). Furthermore, it tracks the dates of order mailing, follow-up inspections, and when the complaint was closed. Researchers and city planners could use this data to analyze trends in complaints, identify problem areas, and evaluate the effectiveness of inspection and remediation efforts. The data spans across the five boroughs, offering a comprehensive view of these issues across the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details encroachments and defacement complaints reported to 311 in New York City. It includes information on complaint types, borough locations, street addresses, and inspection results. The data also tracks key dates related to order mailing, follow-up inspections, and complaint closure.

title: Bikes in Buildings Requests
ufd: This dataset contains information on bicycle access requests to office buildings in New York City, as mandated by the Bicycle Access to Office Buildings Law. The data includes details about each request, such as the request ID, tenant name, and the floor they occupy. Location information is provided through columns like `tenantbuildingnumber`, `tenantstreetname`, `tenantcity`, `tenantpostcode`, and `tenantborough`. The dataset also includes the owner's name and address. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze trends in bicycle commuting, monitor the implementation of the law, and identify areas where bicycle access infrastructure may need improvement. The data spans 100 requests, with unique identifiers for each.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details bicycle access requests submitted by tenants of office buildings in New York City, as required by the Bicycle Access to Office Buildings Law. title: Buildings Selected for the Heat Sensor Program (HSP)
ufd: This dataset contains information on buildings selected for New York City's Heat Sensor Program (HSP). HPD designates 50 class "A" multiple dwellings with heat violations and complaints for participation in a program requiring installation of heat sensors every two years beginning in July 2020. The dataset includes details such as the building's address (borough, number, street, postcode), the total number of units, and the program start date. Location information is further specified by community board, council district, and census tract. The current status of each building in the program is also provided. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze the effectiveness of the HSP, identify areas with high rates of heat violations, and track building participation over time.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details buildings participating in New York City's Heat Sensor Program (HSP), which targets multiple dwellings with heat violations. It includes building addresses, unit counts, program start dates, and location details like community board and census tract. The data also tracks the current status of each building's participation in the program.

Related Topics:

title: 2021 Arts Data Report
ufd: This dataset contains information collected through the Annual Arts Education Survey, focusing on student participation and access to arts education in schools. Each row represents a unique voter ID, linked to a specific school district number (q0_dbn). The dataset includes numerous columns (q16_c1_r1, q16_c1_r2, etc.) that likely represent responses to survey questions, potentially detailing the amount of time dedicated to different art forms or activities. Note that the provided dataset is truncated; the full dataset is available as an Excel file. Researchers and educators can use this data to analyze trends in arts education, identify disparities in access, and advocate for increased arts funding and programming. The 'section' column appears to be an identifier, though its specific meaning is not clear from the provided context. Due to the high number of columns with similar naming conventions, understanding the survey instrument is crucial for effective analysis.
sfd:

This dataset presents findings from the Annual Arts Education Survey, detailing student involvement and availability of arts education within schools. Each entry corresponds to a unique voter ID connected to a school district. The data encompasses responses to survey questions, potentially quantifying time allocated to various art forms.

title: License Revocations, Suspensions, Surrenders, and Reinstatements
ufd: This dataset contains information on licenses issued by the Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP) that have been revoked, suspended, or surrendered, as well as licenses that have been reinstated. Each row represents a specific event (revocation, suspension, surrender, or reinstatement) for a given license, meaning a single license can appear multiple times in the dataset. Key columns include the DCA license number, the business name, the industry the business operates in, the type of event (e.g., suspended, revoked), the date of the event, and the current status of the license (active or inactive). You can use the DCA License Number to link this dataset to other DCA datasets. This dataset is useful for understanding the lifecycle of business licenses, identifying trends in license revocations or suspensions across different industries, or researching the history of a specific business license. Please note that the dataset reflects data as of July 21, 2023, and an updated version is in progress.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details actions taken against business licenses issued by the NYC Department of Consumer and Worker Protection (DCWP), including revocations, suspensions, surrenders, and reinstatements. Each record represents a specific event affecting a license, identified by its DCA License Number. The data includes information on the business name, industry, event type, event date, and license status, providing a historical view of license activity.

title: Blood pressure checks on NYC HealthMap
ufd: This dataset provides locations in New York City where individuals can access free blood pressure checks. The data includes locations that offer blood pressure checks at self-serve kiosks or by pharmacy staff. Key columns include `service_type`, indicating whether the check is self-serve or performed by staff, `input_1_facilityname` for the name of the facility offering the service (e.g., Rite Aid, CVS), and `input_1_address` along with `input_1_borough` and `input_1_zipcode` for location details.  Latitude and longitude coordinates (`latitude2`, `longitude2`) are also provided for precise mapping.  The dataset can be used by the public to find convenient locations for free blood pressure monitoring. It also includes identifiers such as BBL (`output_bbl`) and BIN (`output_bin`) for linking to other city datasets. Researchers and public health organizations can use this data to analyze access to blood pressure monitoring services across different neighborhoods in NYC.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: Summary of Syringe Data in NYC Parks
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed summary of syringe data collected in New York City parks, offering insights into public safety and environmental health. It includes records of syringes found, detailing whether they were collected from the ground or a kiosk. Key columns include `collected_date` and `time_of_day` to track when the syringes were found, `location` to specify the park, and `ground_syringes` and `total_syringes` to quantify the issue. The `gispropnum` and `omppropid` columns provide unique identifiers for the park properties. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to identify high-risk areas, monitor the effectiveness of syringe collection programs, and allocate resources for public safety initiatives. The data also allows for analysis of trends over time and across different park locations. This information can help inform strategies to reduce syringe litter and improve the safety and cleanliness of NYC parks.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains records of syringes found in New York City parks, including details on collection date, location, and quantity. It distinguishes between syringes collected from the ground versus kiosks. The data can be used to assess public safety and environmental health related to syringe litter in NYC parks.

Related Topics:
- Public Health
- Environmental Health

- Substance Use

Applications and Use Cases:

title: Upcoming contracts to be awarded (CIP)
ufd: This dataset provides information on upcoming Capital Improvement Projects (CIP) for schools in the Bronx that are nearing the design completion phase and will soon be available for bidding. Each row represents a specific project, identified by its unique project design number and name. Key details include the geographic district where the project is located, a description of the work involved (e.g., exterior masonry, window replacements), the estimated project cost, and the project category (e.g., electrical, accessibility). The dataset focuses on projects currently in the design phase. This information can be valuable for contractors and construction companies looking for upcoming bidding opportunities in the Bronx school system. It allows users to identify projects that align with their expertise and resources, and to prepare for the bidding process.
