title: DSNY Waste Characterization 2017 - Main Sort Results
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed characterization of New York City's waste stream, based on a 2017 study by the Department of Sanitation (DSNY). The study hand-sorted waste samples into 70 different material categories, offering insights into the composition of residential, school, and NYCHA waste. Key columns include "material," specifying the type of waste, "material_group," which categorizes materials (e.g., Paper, Plastic, Metal), and percentage columns showing the composition of different waste fractions. The "dsny_diversion_summary" column indicates how the waste is managed (e.g., recycling, composting). Researchers, policymakers, and waste management professionals can use this data to understand waste patterns, evaluate recycling program effectiveness, and inform strategies for waste reduction and diversion. The data also includes location information, specifying whether the data is citywide or specific to Brooklyn.
sfd:

title: 1_4MilePoints
ufd: This dataset is related to the Walk to a Park initiative by NYC Parks, focusing on access to recreational areas for city residents. It includes geographic data representing areas within a 1/4-mile or 1/2-mile walking distance of parks and open spaces. The key column, `the_geom`, contains MultiPolygon coordinates defining these accessible areas. This dataset can be used to analyze the coverage of parks in the city, identify underserved areas, and potentially inform urban planning decisions related to recreational resources. Comparing this data with census information can help estimate the number of New Yorkers who live within walking distance of a park. The dataset also considers properties not under NYC Parks jurisdiction but provide recreational value. This information is current as of the publication date and more details about the initiative can be found on the NYC Parks website.
sfd:

It uses MultiPolygon coordinates (`the_geom`) to define these accessible areas. The data includes both NYC Parks properties and other recreational spaces, providing a comprehensive view of park access.

title: Invoices for Open Market Order (OMO) Charges
ufd: This dataset contains invoice information related to Open Market Orders (OMO) submitted to the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) by private contractors. Each row represents a single invoice and includes details such as the invoice ID, sequence ID, OMO number, and invoice status. Key columns include the invoice date, billing amount, payment amount, sales tax, and administrative fees. Researchers and analysts can use this data to understand the financial aspects of OMOs, track invoice statuses, and analyze trends in billing and payment amounts. The dataset also includes charge amounts and dates of transfer, providing a comprehensive view of the invoicing process. This data can be valuable for identifying potential cost savings, improving invoice processing efficiency, and ensuring transparency in HPD's financial transactions with private contractors. The `invoiceid` column serves as a primary key for the dataset.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides detailed invoice information for Open Market Orders (OMO) submitted to the NYC Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) by private contractors. Each record represents an individual invoice and includes financial details such as billing amount, payment amount, sales tax, and administrative fees. The data allows for tracking invoice statuses, analyzing financial trends, and understanding the invoicing process related to OMOs.

title: Cash Assistance Recipients in NYC (Historical)
ufd: This dataset provides a historical record of cash assistance recipients in New York City on a monthly basis, spanning from 1996 to 2004. It includes the total number of recipients, offering insights into the trends and changes in public assistance over time. Key columns include "year" and "month" to specify the time period, and "total_cash_assistance_recipients" to show the number of individuals receiving aid. The dataset also calculates "monthly_percent_change" and "yearly_percent_change," enabling users to analyze the rate of change in recipients. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to understand the impact of policy changes, economic conditions, and demographic shifts on the need for public assistance. This information can be valuable for forecasting future needs, allocating resources, and evaluating the effectiveness of social programs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains monthly records of cash assistance recipients in New York City from 1996 to 2004. It tracks the total number of recipients and calculates monthly and yearly percentage changes. The data offers insights into trends in public assistance over time, enabling analysis of factors influencing aid needs.

title: Vision Zero Base Report
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the safety records and service offerings of for-hire vehicle (FHV) businesses regulated by the NYC Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC). It includes information on various industry sectors such as livery, luxury limo, and black car services. Key columns include the license number, the business name (`base_does_business_as`), the areas they serve (`serving_areas`), and the year the base opened (`year_base_opened`). The dataset also indicates whether the business offers green taxi service, on-demand service, or book-ahead service. Furthermore, it contains details on safety-related aspects such as participation in Vision Zero training and the use of vehicle safety technology. Researchers, policymakers, and the public can use this data to identify FHV businesses with strong safety records, understand industry trends, and make informed transportation choices. Each entry also links to a downloadable PDF report for more detailed information.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on for-hire vehicle (FHV) businesses regulated by the NYC Taxi and Limousine Commission (TLC). It includes details on business characteristics like service types (livery, limo, black car), service areas, and safety features. The data can be used to analyze industry trends, assess safety records, and inform transportation choices.

title: Tax Liability By AGI Range
ufd: This dataset provides insights into New York City's tax liability across different income ranges, broken down by AGI deciles. It shows the number of tax filers/payers in each income bracket, along with the total and average personal income tax (PIT) liability for each group. Key columns include "income_group," which categorizes taxpayers into income deciles, "total_nyc_pit_liability," representing the total tax liability for each decile, "avg_pit_liability," showing the average tax liability per taxpayer in each decile, and "number_of_tax_payers," indicating the number of individuals in each income group. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze the distribution of tax burden across income levels in NYC. It can also be used to understand the relationship between income and tax contributions, and to evaluate the impact of tax policies on different income groups. The dataset contains 11 rows, each representing an income decile.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details New York City personal income tax (PIT) liability, segmented by adjusted gross income (AGI) deciles. It presents the number of tax filers, total PIT liability, and average PIT liability for each income group. The data allows for analysis of tax burden distribution across income levels in NYC.

Related Topics:

title: Energy and Water Data Disclosure for Local Law 84 2016 (Data for Calendar Year 2015)
ufd: This dataset contains energy and water consumption data for buildings in New York City for the year 2015, as required by Local Law 84. It includes privately owned buildings over 25,000 square feet and city-owned buildings over 10,000 square feet. Key columns include `property_name`, `address_1`, `city`, `postcode`, and various metrics related to energy and water usage. The `primary_property_type_self` and `primary_property_type_epa` columns provide classifications of the building type. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze energy and water consumption patterns across different building types and locations in NYC. The dataset also allows for identifying potential areas for improvement in energy efficiency and water conservation. Furthermore, it can be used to track the progress of the city's sustainability initiatives.
sfd:

title: Agency Performance Mapping Indicators – Annual (Historical Data)
ufd: This dataset contains historical key performance indicators for various New York City agencies, offering insights into city government operations. The data is broken down by geographic unit, such as community district or police precinct, allowing for localized analysis. Key columns include "agency" indicating the responsible city entity, "geographic_unit" and "geographic_identifier" specifying the location, and "indicator" describing the performance metric (e.g., Hate Crimes, Resolved Consumer Complaints). Fiscal year columns (fy2011-fy2019) provide the performance values for each indicator over time. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this dataset to track trends in agency performance across different geographic areas, identify areas needing improvement, and assess the effectiveness of city programs. The data spans from fiscal year 2011 to 2019, offering a longitudinal perspective on city services.
sfd:

title: Citywide Mobility Survey - Vehicle 2022
ufd: This dataset provides details on vehicles included in the Citywide Mobility Survey (CMS) for 2022. It includes information on vehicle characteristics at the household level. Each record represents a vehicle, identified by a `vehicle_id` and associated with a `hh_id` (household ID). Key details include the `year` the vehicle was manufactured and the `fuel_type` it uses. The `vehicle_num` indicates the vehicle's order within the household's vehicles. The `hh_weight` column provides a statistical weighting factor for each household, useful for ensuring the survey results are representative of the population. Researchers and urban planners can use this data to analyze vehicle trends, understand fuel consumption patterns, and model transportation behavior within the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The 2022 Citywide Mobility Survey (CMS) Vehicle dataset contains detailed information about vehicles at the household level. Each record represents a single vehicle, identified by a unique vehicle ID and linked to a household ID. Key attributes include the vehicle's manufacturing year, fuel type, and its order within the household's vehicle fleet. The dataset also includes a household weight for statistical analysis.

title: 2019 Green Taxi Trip Data
ufd: This dataset contains trip details from green taxis in 2019. Each row represents a single taxi trip, including pickup and drop-off times, locations, trip distance, and fare information. The dataset includes the vendor ID, pickup and drop-off locations identified by taxi zone IDs, and the number of passengers. Key financial details such as fare amount, extra charges, MTA tax, tip amount, and total amount are also provided. You can use this dataset to analyze green taxi trip patterns, calculate average fares, or explore the relationship between trip distance and cost. The `store_and_fwd_flag` indicates if the trip data was temporarily stored in the vehicle before being sent to the vendor.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

Each record represents a single trip, capturing pickup and drop-off locations, timestamps, trip distance, and fare breakdowns. It includes vendor IDs, taxi zone IDs for location, passenger count, and financial details like fare, taxes, tips, and total amount.

title: Local Law 18 Pay and Demographics Report - Agency Report Table
ufd: This dataset provides a snapshot of New York City government employee pay and demographics for the year 2018. It breaks down employee counts by agency, job category (EEO-4), pay band, race, ethnicity, and gender. Each row represents a grouping of employees sharing these characteristics. Key columns include `agency_name`, indicating the specific city agency, `eeo_4_job_category`, which categorizes the type of work performed, and `pay_band`, showing the salary range for the group. The dataset also includes `race`, `ethnicity`, and `gender` to provide a demographic breakdown. Researchers, policymakers, and city residents can use this data to analyze pay equity, diversity within city government, and workforce composition across different agencies and job categories. Note that employee counts fewer than 5 are masked for privacy.
sfd:

title: Local Law 83 – FY 2020-2022 Historical Ethnic and Community Media Agency Ad Spend by Agency
ufd: This dataset provides a historical record of New York City agency advertising spending, specifically focusing on ethnic and community media (ECM). It covers fiscal years 2020-2022. Key columns include `fiscal_year`, indicating the year the data pertains to; `agency_name` and `agency_acronym`, identifying the specific city agency; `ecm_spend_1`, representing the agency's spending on ethnic and community media; and `total_ad_spend`, showing the agency's overall advertising expenditure.  Researchers, journalists, and city government observers can use this dataset to analyze trends in city agency advertising, assess the allocation of resources towards ethnic and community media, and compare spending across different agencies.  Note that the `ecm_spend` column has a high null fraction (over 50%). The dataset offers insights into how the city government communicates with diverse communities and manages its advertising budget.

title: Street Network Changes
ufd: This dataset provides information on street network changes in New York City, including one-way conversions and reversals, two-way conversions, and street closures. It covers all five boroughs and specifies the streets affected by these changes, using columns like 'on_street', 'from_st', and 'to_street' to indicate the location. The 'type_of_change' column describes the type of street modification, while 'new_direction' indicates the resulting direction of traffic flow. The 'completion_date' column tells you when the change was implemented.  Researchers, urban planners, and residents can use this data to understand how the city's street network has evolved, plan routes, and assess the impact of these changes on traffic patterns. Please note that this dataset does not include temporary closures due to construction or special events.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
This dataset details permanent street network modifications in New York City, including one-way/two-way conversions, reversals, and street closures. It specifies the location of changes using street names and provides information on the type of change, new traffic direction, and completion date. The dataset covers all five boroughs and excludes temporary closures.

**Related Topics:**
- Urban Planning
- Transportation Engineering
- Traffic Management
- Street Network Analysis
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- New York City Infrastructure

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Street Network Changes: road modifications, street alterations, traffic pattern changes
- One-Way Conversion: one-way street implementation, unidirectional traffic change
- Two-Way Conversion: two-way street implementation, bidirectional traffic change
- Street Closure: road closure, street blockage, traffic obstruction
- Traffic Direction: flow of traffic, direction of travel, traffic orientation
- Completion Date: implementation date, effective date, date of change

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Analyzing the historical evolution of NYC's street network.
- Planning efficient transportation routes for vehicles and pedestrians.
- Assessing the impact of street changes on traffic flow and congestion.
- Identifying areas with frequent street modifications.
- Integrating street network data with other urban datasets for comprehensive analysis.
- Developing GIS applications for navigation and urban planning.

title: FRESH Food Stores Zoning Boundaries
ufd: This dataset contains boundaries where zoning and discretionary tax incentives are available for the development, expansion, and renovation of grocery stores and supermarkets. It includes geographic boundaries represented in the `the_geom` column, which contains MultiPolygon coordinates defining the incentive areas. The dataset also provides the `shape_leng` and `shape_area` columns, representing the length and area of the shapes. The `name` column describes the type of incentive available in the area. This data could be used by developers, city planners, or grocery store chains to identify potential locations for new stores or renovations that could benefit from these incentives. Understanding the spatial distribution and types of incentives can inform strategic investment decisions and promote access to fresh food in underserved communities.
sfd:

This dataset delineates geographic areas within a city where zoning regulations and tax incentives are in place to encourage the development, expansion, or renovation of grocery stores and supermarkets. It includes spatial data defining the boundaries of these incentive zones, along with attributes describing the type of incentive and the area's size. The data is useful for identifying potential locations for grocery store development that could benefit from these incentives.

- Informing real estate investment decisions related to grocery store development.

title: 2020-2021 09222021 LL93 Student Discipline Annual Report - ALL
ufd: This dataset provides insights into student discipline in temporary housing for the 2020-2021 school year. It includes information on removals, suspensions, and expulsions, as well as interventions by principals and superintendents. Each row represents a specific school, identified by its system code and location name, along with its location category (e.g., Elementary, High School). Key columns include `total_removals_suspensions` and `expulsions`, which quantify disciplinary actions. The `administrative_district_code` indicates the district the school belongs to. Researchers and policymakers can use this data to analyze disciplinary trends, identify schools with high rates of removals or suspensions, and evaluate the effectiveness of different intervention strategies. The data can also be used to understand the relationship between student discipline and administrative involvement.

title: Outdoor Swimming Pool Attendance
ufd: This dataset contains attendance records for New York City's outdoor swimming pools. title: 311 Customer Satisfaction Survey
ufd:
This dataset contains results from NYC311 Customer Satisfaction (CSAT) surveys, which gather feedback on the performance of 311 call takers. The surveys are offered after calls to 311 during specific campaigns and are sent via email and text message in multiple languages. Each row represents an individual survey response, with personally identifiable information removed.

Key columns include the year of the survey, the specific campaign it was part of, and the language in which the survey was taken. The dataset also captures overall satisfaction, wait time satisfaction, and satisfaction with the agent's customer service, job knowledge, and answers provided. Researchers and city planners can use this data to understand customer satisfaction trends, identify areas for improvement in 311 services, and assess the impact of different campaigns on customer perception. The data spans from 2020 to 2023, offering a view into how customer service is perceived over time.

title: Dog Runs
ufd: This dataset contains information about dog runs located throughout New York City. Each row represents a specific dog run and includes details such as its unique object ID, system code, and geographic coordinates. The 'system' column provides a unique identifier for each dog run, while 'gispropnum' may refer to a related GIS property number. Location information is captured in columns like 'communityboard', 'councildistrict', 'precinct', 'zipcode', and 'borough', allowing users to understand the dog run's placement within the city. The 'the_geom' column stores the geometry of the dog run, enabling spatial analysis and mapping. This dataset can be used by dog owners to find nearby dog runs, by city planners to analyze the distribution of recreational resources, or by researchers studying urban park usage.

- Borough: City District, County (in NYC context)

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identifying dog run locations for pet owners.
- Analyzing the distribution of dog runs across different neighborhoods.
- Mapping dog runs using spatial analysis tools.
- Planning new dog run locations based on population density and existing resources.
- Researching park usage and recreational resource allocation in urban environments.

title: Bureau of Fire Prevention - Certificates of Fitness (Historical)
ufd: This dataset provides a historical record of premise-based Certificates of Fitness (COF) issued by the Bureau of Fire Prevention. Note that this dataset is no longer updated. It includes information on the type of certificate (cof_type), such as "FIRE AND EMERGENCY DRILL CONDUCTOR" or "COQ - REFRIGERATION ENGINEER," and the name of the certificate holder (holder_name). Each record also contains the expiration date (expires_on) and the address of the premise (prem_addr) for which the certificate is valid. The dataset includes the building identification number (bin), street number, and street name for the premise. Researchers and analysts interested in historical fire safety compliance, certificate trends, or geographic distribution of specific certificate types may find this dataset useful. Due to public safety concerns, COFs for hazardous materials and non-premise based COFs are excluded.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains historical records of premise-based Certificates of Fitness (COF) issued by the Bureau of Fire Prevention. It includes details on the certificate type, holder name, expiration date, and premise address. The dataset provides insights into historical fire safety compliance and the distribution of specific certificate types.

Related Topics:
- Fire Safety
- Public Safety
- Regulatory Compliance
- Building Permits
- Historical Data Analysis
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Certificate of Fitness (COF): Fire safety certificate, competency license, permit
- Bureau of Fire Prevention: Fire department, fire marshal's office, fire prevention bureau
- Premise-based: Location-specific, site-specific, building-related
- Expiration Date: Validity period, end date, expiry
- Holder Name: Certificate holder, licensee, responsible party
- Building Identification Number (BIN): Building ID, property ID, structure identifier

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze historical trends in certificate types and expiration rates.
- Map the geographic distribution of specific certificate types across a city.
- Identify potential areas of non-compliance based on expired certificates.
- Research the effectiveness of fire safety regulations over time.
- Support urban planning and risk assessment initiatives.

title: DSNY - Snow Priority Designation
ufd: This dataset provides information on snow priority designations for streets in New York City, as determined by the Department of Sanitation (DSNY). It includes details about the location of street segments, their snow removal priority, and physical characteristics. Key columns include 'borough' and 'district', which specify the administrative area, 'streetname', indicating the name of the street, and 'snowpriority', which designates the level of priority for snow removal. The 'roadwaytype' column classifies the type of road. The 'line' column contains the geographic coordinates defining the street segment. This data can be used to understand snow removal planning and prioritization in NYC, analyze resource allocation for snow removal, or assess the impact of snow events on different areas of the city. Researchers, city planners, and residents can use this dataset to gain insights into how the city manages snow removal operations.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details snow removal priorities for streets in New York City, as designated by the Department of Sanitation (DSNY). It includes information on street location, snow removal priority level, and roadway characteristics. Key attributes include borough, street name, snow priority, roadway type, and geographic coordinates.

Related Topics:

title: 2022 Annual Sustainability Project Grant
ufd: This dataset contains information on the 2022 Annual Sustainability Project Grants awarded by the NYC Department of Education. It lists the schools that received grants, identified by their name and DBN (Department of Buildings number), along with the borough they are located in. A key aspect of the data is the "grant_category", which specifies the type of sustainability project funded, such as Gardening & Outdoor Learning, Green Team Supports, Sustainability Education Programming, or Demonstration Solar Installation. Researchers and educators can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of sustainability grants across different boroughs and project categories. City planners and policymakers can leverage this information to understand the types of sustainability initiatives being implemented in schools and to inform future grant programs. The dataset provides insights into the DOE's investment in school sustainability projects and their alignment with citywide sustainability goals.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details the 2022 Annual Sustainability Project Grants awarded by the NYC Department of Education. It includes information on recipient schools, identified by name and DBN, their borough, and the specific "grant_category" of their funded sustainability project. The data provides insights into the distribution of sustainability grants across NYC schools and the types of projects being supported.

title: Board of Standards and Appeals (BSA) Action Portal
ufd: This dataset provides an index of actions from the Board of Standards and Appeals (BSA) spanning from 1916 to 1997. It includes information on the premise address (number and street), borough, block, and lot, offering a geographical context for each action. Key columns like 'community_board' and 'council_district' provide insights into the administrative divisions associated with each case. The 'calendarnumber' serves as a unique identifier for each BSA action. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze historical trends in BSA actions, understand the types of cases addressed in different boroughs, and potentially correlate these actions with other urban development datasets. The dataset also includes latitude and longitude coordinates for spatial analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset catalogs actions taken by the Board of Standards and Appeals (BSA) in New York City from 1916 to 1997. It provides details on the location of each action, including address, borough, block, and lot. This historical record allows for analysis of urban development trends and BSA decision-making over time.

title: Capital Projects Dashboard - Citywide Schedule History and Variance
ufd: This dataset provides a historical record of citywide capital projects, including their schedules and any variances. Each row represents a snapshot of a project's data at a specific reporting period. Key columns include the managing agency, the project's unique ID (`pid`), the agency's project name, and the current phase of the project (e.g., Design, Construction, Close-out). The dataset also tracks completion dates, distinguishing between forecasted and actual dates. The `variance_day` column indicates the difference in days between the current completion date and the completion date reported in the previous period. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze project timelines, identify potential delays, and understand the reasons behind forecast changes. This information can be valuable for improving project management and resource allocation across city agencies. The data spans from May 2023 to May 2025, with reporting periods provided in the `reporting_period` column.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains historical data on city government capital projects, capturing their schedules and variances over time. Each record represents a project snapshot at a specific reporting period, detailing key information like managing agency, project ID, name, and current phase. It tracks both forecasted and actual completion dates, along with the variance in days compared to the previous reporting period.

Related Topics:
- City Planning
- Project Management
- Government Spending
- Infrastructure Development
- Urban Development
- Public Works

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Capital Projects: Infrastructure projects, public works, construction projects
- Project Variance: Schedule deviation, timeline difference, delay
- Reporting Period: Time interval, data snapshot, reporting cycle
- Managing Agency: City department, government agency, responsible entity
- Completion Date: Finish date, end date, target date

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze project timelines and identify potential delays.
- Understand the reasons behind forecast changes in project completion dates.
- Improve project management and resource allocation across city agencies.
- Track the performance of different city agencies in managing capital projects.
- Identify trends in project variances and develop strategies to mitigate delays.
- Evaluate the effectiveness of project management practices.
- Forecast future project completion dates based on historical data.

title: Directory Of DHS Contacts
ufd: This dataset provides a directory of contact information for various departments within the Department of Homeless Services (DHS). It includes department names, phone numbers, and occasionally comments providing additional instructions or contact information. Location addresses, postcodes, borough, latitude, and longitude are included, primarily pointing to the main DHS office in Manhattan. The dataset also contains geographic information such as community board, council district, census tract, Building Identification Number (BIN), Borough Block Lot (BBL), and Neighborhood Tabulation Area (NTA). This information could be used to contact specific departments within DHS, understand the geographic location of DHS services, or analyze the distribution of DHS contacts across different areas. Researchers or individuals seeking assistance from DHS can use this dataset to find the appropriate contact information for their needs.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains contact information for departments within the New York City Department of Homeless Services (DHS). It includes department names, phone numbers, addresses, and geographic identifiers. The data allows users to find specific DHS contacts and understand the geographic distribution of DHS services, though most locations point to the main Manhattan office.

title: CommonPlace
ufd: The CommonPlace dataset compiles points of interest across New York City, as identified by various city agencies. This dataset includes the location of each point of interest, represented by coordinates in the `the_geom` column, along with identifiers like `segmentid` and `placeid`. You can find out which agency (`source`) contributed the data for each point. The `boroughcode` indicates the borough in which the point is located, while `facility_domains` and `facility_type` provide information about the type and number of facilities at that location. The `sosindicator` may indicate the state of a system or process at the location. This dataset could be used to analyze the distribution of different types of facilities across the city, identify areas with a high concentration of points of interest, or track changes in the location and characteristics of these points over time using the `created_date`.
sfd:
**Dataset Overview:**
The CommonPlace dataset provides a comprehensive inventory of points of interest throughout New York City, as reported by various city agencies. Each record includes geographic coordinates, unique identifiers, and details about the facility type, responsible agency, and borough location. This dataset is valuable for understanding the distribution and characteristics of various facilities and points of interest across the city.

**Related Topics:**

- Public Services
- New York City
- Location Data

**Concepts and Synonyms:**
- Points of Interest: POI, amenities, facilities, locations
- City Agencies: Government departments, municipal authorities, source
- Geographic Coordinates: Latitude/Longitude, the_geom, location
- Borough: County, district, area, boroughcode
- Facility Type: Amenity type, service category, facility_domains

**Applications and Use Cases:**
- Analyze the spatial distribution of specific facility types across NYC boroughs.
- Identify areas with a high concentration of points of interest.
- Map and visualize the locations of facilities managed by different city agencies.
- Track the creation and modification dates of points of interest to understand urban development patterns.
- Combine this dataset with other datasets (e.g., demographics, crime statistics) to explore correlations between points of interest and other urban characteristics.

title: DOF: Cooperative Comparable Rental Income – Queens – FY 2009/2010
ufd: This dataset provides information on cooperative rental income for properties in Queens, New York, specifically for fiscal years 2009 and 2010. It includes details on comparable rental properties used by the Department of Finance (DOF) to value condominiums and cooperatives as if they were regular rental buildings. Key columns include the borough-block-lot identifier (`queens_cooperatives_comparable_properties_boro_block_lot`), address information, neighborhood, building classification (e.g., walk-up or elevator), total units, and year built. Financial data such as gross square footage, estimated gross income, and gross income per square foot are also included. Researchers and real estate professionals can use this data to analyze rental income trends, property values, and building characteristics in Queens neighborhoods. The dataset can also be used to understand the DOF's valuation methods for cooperatives and condominiums.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains cooperative rental income data for properties in Queens, New York, for fiscal years 2009 and 2010. It details comparable rental properties used by the Department of Finance (DOF) for valuation purposes. The data includes property characteristics, location information, and financial details like gross income and square footage.

title: Lobbyists' Fundraising and Political Consulting Reports
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the world of lobbying and political consulting within New York City. It contains information reported by lobbyists, individuals, and organizations hired to influence government officials, as legally required by the city's administrative code. Each record represents a fundraising or political consulting report, identified by a unique `report_id`, and includes the `filing_year` and `filing_period` for the report. Key details include the `entity_name` of the lobbying firm or organization, their contact information (`street_address`, `city`, `state`, `zip`, `phone`), and the names of the `principal_last_name` and `principal_first_name`. The dataset also specifies the `target_office` (e.g., Mayor, City Council Member) and the `candidate_last_name` and `candidate_first_name` involved. Researchers, journalists, and government watchdogs can use this data to track lobbying activities, identify influential firms, and analyze campaign finance trends in New York City. The `lobbyist_employees` column lists the individuals working as lobbyists.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details lobbying and political consulting activities reported in New York City, as mandated by law. It includes information on lobbying firms, their clients (principals), targeted government offices, and involved candidates. The data encompasses details like entity names, contact information, filing periods, and the names of lobbyists and principals.

Related Topics:

title: Broadband Adoption and Infrastructure by Zip Code
ufd: This dataset provides a detailed look at broadband adoption and infrastructure across New York City, broken down by zip code. It includes key metrics such as home and mobile broadband adoption rates, percentages of residents without internet access, and classifications of connectivity levels. The dataset also contains information on the availability of public computer centers, workstations, and Wi-Fi hotspots, as well as data on commercial fiber infrastructure. Researchers, policymakers, and community organizations can use this data to identify areas with low broadband adoption, assess the digital divide, and inform strategies for improving internet access and digital literacy. The columns 'home_broadband_adoption' and 'mobile_broadband_adoption' represent the adoption rates, while 'no_internet_access_percentage' indicates the proportion of the population without internet. Furthermore, data on infrastructure like 'public_wi_fi_count' and 'commercial_fiber_max_isp' can help evaluate the availability of internet resources in different areas.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information on broadband adoption and internet infrastructure in New York City, organized by zip code. It includes metrics on home and mobile broadband adoption rates, the percentage of residents without internet access, and the availability of public internet resources. title: Local Law 44 - Projects
ufd: This dataset contains information on housing development projects in NYC, as reported by the HPD (Housing Preservation and Development) under Local Law 44. Each row represents a unique project, identified by `projectid` and `projectname`. Key details include the `programname` under which the project was developed, the `startdate` and `projectedcompletiondate`, and the number of housing units: `counted_rental_units`, `counted_homeownership_units`, and `totalprojectunits`. The dataset also provides information on the `borrowerlegalentityname`, `generalcontractorname`, and whether Davis-Bacon wage requirements (`isdavisbacon`) apply. Researchers, city planners, and developers can use this data to analyze housing trends, track project timelines, and assess the impact of different housing programs. The `commercialsquarefootage` column allows for analysis of mixed-use developments.
sfd:

title: Section_ZoningMapIndex
ufd: This dataset provides a sectional index grid for New York City zoning maps, which are essential for understanding land use regulations. Each row represents a section of the city, identified by a unique `objectid` and `section` number. The `the_geom` column contains the geographic boundaries of each section as a MultiPolygon, while `shape_area` and `shape_len` provide the area and perimeter of the section. Researchers, urban planners, and developers can use this dataset to determine which zoning map applies to a specific area of the city. This allows users to quickly reference the relevant zoning regulations for a particular location. The dataset includes 39 rows and 5 columns, with geographic data represented in the `the_geom` column. The zoning maps themselves show the boundaries of zoning districts and are regularly updated to reflect changes approved by the City Planning Commission and City Council.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains a sectional index grid for New York City zoning maps, providing geographic boundaries and identifiers for each section. It includes the `objectid`, `section` number, geometry (`the_geom`), area (`shape_area`), and perimeter (`shape_len`) for each zoning map section. This allows users to quickly identify the relevant zoning map for a specific location within New York City.

Related Topics:
- Urban Planning

- New York City Government

Concepts and Synonyms:

- `shape_len` (Perimeter of Section)

Applications and Use Cases:

- Overlaying zoning map sections with other geographic data to analyze land use patterns.
- Developing tools and applications for urban planning and development.

title: Athletic Facilities
ufd: This dataset provides information on athletic facilities in New York City parks, including permitted and designated sports facilities. It contains 100 rows and 45 columns. Key columns include borough, communityboard, and councildistrict, which provide location information for each facility. The dataset also includes boolean indicators for various sports such as adult baseball, adult football, basketball, and bocce, indicating whether the facility supports these activities. Other important columns are department, gispropnum, and featurestatus. Researchers and city planners can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of athletic facilities across different boroughs and community districts. The data can also help in understanding the availability of specific sports facilities and their current status (active, inactive, or temporarily closed).
sfd:

title: 2013 - 2018 Demographic Snapshot Borough
ufd: This dataset provides a demographic snapshot of student enrollment in New York City public schools, broken down by borough, from the 2013-14 school year through 2017-18. It includes total enrollment figures alongside enrollment numbers for specific grades, from pre-kindergarten through 12th grade. The dataset also details the gender and race/ethnicity composition of the student body in each borough. Key columns include "borough" to identify the location, "year" for the school year, "total_enrollment" for the overall number of students, and columns for each grade level to show enrollment distribution. Researchers, policymakers, and education advocates can use this data to analyze enrollment trends, understand demographic shifts in NYC schools, and inform decisions related to resource allocation and educational equity. The data allows for comparisons between boroughs and across different school years.
sfd:

title: DSNY Special Waste Drop-off Sites
ufd: This dataset provides locations for DSNY Special Waste Drop-Off Sites in New York City. Each record includes the address, borough, city, and zip code of the drop-off location. The dataset also contains computed region codes. Key columns include 'address' for the physical location and 'boro' indicating the borough. This information can be used to find the nearest special waste drop-off site. For detailed information on hours of operation, accepted materials, and procedures, refer to the provided link.

title: School Districts
ufd: This dataset contains geographic boundaries and related information for school districts in New York City. Each record represents a single school district. The `schooldist` column provides a unique identifier for each district. The `shape_leng` and `shape_area` columns describe the perimeter and area of the district's boundaries, respectively, offering insights into the district's spatial extent. The `the_geom` column stores the geometric representation of the school district boundary. This dataset can be used to visualize school district boundaries, calculate spatial statistics, or analyze relationships between school districts and other geographic features. Researchers, city planners, and education advocates can use this data to understand the spatial distribution of school districts and their characteristics.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides geographic boundaries and attributes for school districts within New York City. It includes a unique identifier for each district, along with measurements of their perimeter and area. The dataset also contains the geometric representation of each school district's boundary, enabling spatial analysis.

Related Topics:
- Education
- Urban Planning
- Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- New York City
- School Zones

Concepts and Synonyms:
- School District: Education district, school zone, administrative school unit
- Geographic Boundary: Spatial extent, polygon, shapefile, geodata
- Spatial Analysis: Geographic analysis, location intelligence, mapping
- Shape_Leng: Perimeter, boundary length
- Shape_Area: Area size, district size

Applications and Use Cases:
- Visualizing school district boundaries on a map.
- Calculating spatial statistics related to school district size and shape.
- Analyzing the relationship between school districts and demographic data.
- Identifying school districts that overlap with other geographic features (e.g., parks, transportation routes).
- Supporting school districting and rezoning efforts.

title: Bridge Hold Location Stipulations
ufd: This dataset identifies locations in New York City that have a "Bridge Hold" stipulation, meaning they are within 100 feet of a bridge structure. It includes 100 rows of data with 15 columns. The dataset provides the borough, street names (on, from, and to streets), and specific location names associated with these stipulations. You can use this data to understand where bridge-related construction or maintenance might require special attention or permits. Key columns include `boroughname`, `onstreetname`, `fromstreetname`, `tostreetname`, `inspectiondistrict`, and `maintenancesector`, offering a detailed view of the affected areas. The `stipulationfulltext` column provides the exact text of the bridge hold stipulation. This dataset could be valuable for urban planners, construction companies, and city agencies involved in infrastructure projects.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details locations in New York City subject to "Bridge Hold" stipulations, indicating proximity to bridge structures. It contains 100 rows and 15 columns, specifying borough, street names (on, from, and to), and location names associated with these stipulations. The data allows users to identify areas where bridge-related construction or maintenance may require special considerations.

Related Topics:
- Bridge Infrastructure
- Urban Planning
- Construction Permits
- New York City
- Transportation Infrastructure
- Infrastructure Maintenance

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Bridge Hold: Stipulation, Restriction, Proximity to Bridge
- Borough: City District, County
- Street Names: On Street, From Street, To Street, Intersection
- Inspection District: Area Code, Zone
- Maintenance Sector: Region, Sub-area
- Stipulation Text: Regulation Details, Restriction Description

Applications and Use Cases:
- Identifying areas requiring special permits for construction near bridges.
- Planning infrastructure projects considering bridge proximity restrictions.
- Analyzing the spatial distribution of bridge-related stipulations in NYC.
- Supporting maintenance and inspection activities for bridge infrastructure.
- Informing urban planning decisions related to bridge infrastructure.

title: Independent Budget Office: NYC COVID 19 Spending by Date - Citywide and by Agency
ufd: This dataset contains a daily summary of citywide and agency-specific COVID-19 related spending in New York City. The data spans from March 10, 2020, through June 29, 2021. The key columns include the date, total citywide spending, and spending broken down by various agencies such as the Administration for Children's Services, Department of Social Services, and Department of Education. Each agency has its own column indicating the amount of spending attributed to it on a given date. Researchers, journalists, and government analysts can use this dataset to analyze the financial impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on different city agencies and to track overall city spending during that period. The dataset offers insights into how resources were allocated across different sectors during the crisis. Note that the dataset is no longer being updated.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides a daily record of COVID-19 related spending in New York City from March 10, 2020, to June 29, 2021. It details both citywide spending and spending allocated to specific city agencies. The data allows for analysis of the financial response to the pandemic across different sectors of the city government.

Related Topics:
  - COVID-19 Pandemic
  - New York City
  - Government Spending
  - Public Finance
  - Budget Allocation
  - Emergency Response
  - City Agencies

  - City Agencies: Government departments, municipal services, public sector organizations
  - Daily Spending: Daily expenditures, daily costs, daily outlay
  - Financial Impact: Economic effect, monetary consequences, budget implications
  - Budget Allocation: Resource distribution, funding allocation, expenditure assignment

Applications and Use Cases:
  - Analyze the financial impact of COVID-19 on specific NYC agencies.
  - Track overall city spending during the pandemic.
  - Compare spending patterns across different agencies.
  - Identify trends in resource allocation during the crisis.
  - Evaluate the effectiveness of financial responses to the pandemic.
  - Create visualizations of city spending data.
  - Research the economic impact of COVID-19 in New York City.

title: Local Law 44 - Building
ufd: This dataset contains building-level information reported by the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD) under Local Law 44. It includes details on buildings receiving city financial assistance, such as their address, number of stories, and square footage. Key columns include `projectid` for identifying specific projects, `buildingid` for unique building identification, `borough_code` and `boroid` for location, and `reportingconstructiontype` to indicate if it's new construction or preservation. The dataset also provides counts of rental and homeownership units (`countedrentalunits`, `countedhomeownershipunits`). Researchers, urban planners, and developers can use this data to analyze housing development trends, assess the impact of city-funded projects, and understand the distribution of different types of housing across the city. The `basesquarefootage` and `stories` columns can be used to analyze building sizes and density.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset provides building-level details for projects receiving financial assistance from the New York City Department of Housing Preservation and Development (HPD). The data includes information on building characteristics like address, number of stories, square footage, and the type of construction (new or preservation). It also contains counts of rental and homeownership units within these buildings.

Related Topics:

- Real Estate

- Affordable Housing

- Construction Type: reportingconstructiontype, new construction, preservation, rehabilitation
- Housing Units: countedrentalunits, countedhomeownershipunits, rental units, homeownership units
- Building Size: basesquarefootage, stories, square footage, building height

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze housing development trends in NYC.
- Assess the impact of city-funded housing projects.
- Understand the distribution of rental and homeownership units.
- Analyze building sizes and density in different boroughs.

- Evaluate the effectiveness of housing policies and programs.

title: Palantir Contract List (January 2011 to June 2017)
ufd: This dataset provides a list of contracts awarded to Palantir Technologies by New York City government agencies between January 2011 and June 2017. It includes details such as the agency that awarded the contract, a description of the contract's purpose, the procurement method used, and the contract value. The start and end dates of each contract are also provided. Key columns include "agency," indicating the specific city department involved, and "contractvalue," representing the monetary value of the agreement. Researchers, journalists, and government watchdogs can use this dataset to analyze city spending on Palantir's services, understand the types of services the city contracts for, and assess procurement practices. The data can also be used to track the duration and value of contracts over time.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details contracts awarded to Palantir Technologies by New York City government agencies from January 2011 to June 2017. It includes information on the awarding agency, contract description, procurement method, contract value, and contract start and end dates. This data allows for analysis of city spending on Palantir's services and procurement practices.

Related Topics:

- Investigate the types of services the city contracts for from Palantir.
- Track the duration of contracts awarded to Palantir.
- Assess the transparency of the city's procurement process.
- Identify potential conflicts of interest.

title: Fee Charges
ufd: This dataset contains information on fees assessed to properties by the New York City Housing Preservation and Development (HPD). Each row represents a specific fee charge, identified by a unique `feeid`. Key details include the property's location, specified by `boro` (borough), `housenumber`, `streetname`, and `zip` code, as well as `block` and `lot`. The type of fee is described by `feetype` (e.g., "INSPECTION FEE") and `feesourcetype` indicates the origin of the fee (e.g., "Complaint"). The `feeamount` column shows the amount of the fee.  The `feeissueddate` and `doftransferdate` columns provide information on when the fee was issued and transferred. Researchers and city planners can use this data to analyze fee trends, identify areas with high fee incidence, and understand the financial impact of HPD fees on property owners.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details fees charged to properties by the New York City Housing Preservation and Development (HPD). It includes information on the fee type, amount, issuance date, and property location (borough, house number, street name, zip code, block, and lot). The data allows for analysis of fee trends and their impact on property owners.

Related Topics:
- Housing
- Urban Development
- New York City
- Property Assessment
- Municipal Finance
- Code Enforcement

Concepts and Synonyms:
- HPD Fees: Housing Preservation and Development fees, property charges, municipal levies
- Fee Type: Fee category, charge type, assessment description (e.g., "INSPECTION FEE")
- Fee Source: Fee origin, charge source, reason for fee (e.g., "Complaint")
- Property Location: Address, borough, block and lot, geographic identifier
- Fee Amount: Charge value, monetary assessment, cost of fee

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze the distribution of HPD fees across different boroughs and neighborhoods.
- Identify properties with recurring fees and investigate potential underlying issues.
- Evaluate the financial impact of HPD fees on property owners and tenants.
- Track trends in fee types and amounts over time.
- Assess the effectiveness of HPD's fee structure in promoting property maintenance and compliance.
- Develop predictive models to forecast future fee incidence based on property characteristics and historical data.

title: Bus Delays April2020 994 - July 1, - December 31, 2019
ufd: This dataset contains information about school bus delays reported by bus companies for the first half of the 2019/2020 school year. It includes the name of the vendor, the school affiliation (e.g., Pre-K, Charter, Public), the month the delay occurred, and the call count, which likely represents the number of calls related to the delay. The data is subject to data entry errors as it is self-reported by the bus companies. Researchers and school administrators can use this data to analyze trends in bus delays, identify problematic vendors, and understand how delays impact different types of schools. The 'month' column provides a temporal dimension, allowing for analysis of delays over time. Note that vendor name and school affiliation have a high percentage of missing values.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details school bus delays reported by bus companies during the first half of the 2019/2020 school year. It includes vendor names, school affiliations (Pre-K, Charter, Public), the month of the delay, and a call count, presumably representing delay-related calls. The data is self-reported and may contain data entry errors.

Related Topics:

Applications and Use Cases:
- Analyze trends in school bus delays over time.
- Identify vendors with frequent or significant delays.
- Compare delay patterns across different school types (e.g., Public vs. Charter).
- Investigate the relationship between call count and delay severity.
- Assess the impact of bus delays on student attendance and academic performance (requires merging with other datasets).
- Evaluate the quality and completeness of self-reported data from bus companies.

title: Small Business Administration (SBA) Size Standards Table
ufd: This dataset provides a comprehensive reference for understanding small business size standards as defined by the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA). It links industry descriptions based on the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) to specific size standards. Key columns include `naics_industry_description`, which provides a textual description of the industry sector, and `naics_codes`, the corresponding NAICS code for that industry. The dataset also specifies size standards in terms of both `size_standards_in_millions_of_dollars` and `size_standards_in_number_of_employees`, offering two different metrics for determining if a business qualifies as "small". Researchers, entrepreneurs, and policymakers can use this data to understand eligibility requirements for SBA programs, analyze industry size distributions, or assess the impact of size standards on different sectors. The data was updated based on the Office of Management and Budget's modifications effective January 1, 2012.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) size standards for various industries, linking North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) codes and industry descriptions to specific size standards. Size standards are provided in both millions of dollars and number of employees. This data is based on updates effective January 1, 2012.

Related Topics:
- Small Business Administration (SBA)
- NAICS Codes
- Industry Size Standards
- Business Regulations
- Economic Policy
- Entrepreneurship

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Size Standards: Small business size limits, eligibility criteria
- NAICS Codes: North American Industry Classification System, industry codes
- SBA: Small Business Administration, US SBA
- Industry Description: Sector definition, business activity description
- Revenue Threshold: Sales limit, dollar-based size standard
- Employee Count: Workforce size, number of employees

Applications and Use Cases:
- Determining eligibility for SBA loan programs.
- Analyzing the distribution of small businesses across different industries.
- Assessing the impact of size standards on industry competition.
- Researching the economic effects of SBA policies.
- Developing tools for businesses to determine their size classification.

title: Youth Risk Behavior Survey (Middle School)
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the health risk behaviors of middle school students in New York City, collected through the Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS). The data includes prevalence estimates, lower and upper 95% confidence intervals for various health-related behaviors. Key columns include the survey type ("YRBS (Middle School)"), the year the survey was conducted (e.g., 2018), and prevalence rates for behaviors such as smoking, alcohol consumption, and physical activity.  Specifically, the dataset contains estimates for the percentage of students who have smoked at least once, ever had a drink of alcohol, and are physically active. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to monitor trends in adolescent health behaviors, identify areas of concern, and develop targeted interventions to promote healthier lifestyles among young people. Note that some estimates may need to be interpreted with caution due to large relative standard errors.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains health risk behavior prevalence estimates for middle school students in New York City, derived from the Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS). It includes data on smoking, alcohol consumption, and physical activity, along with confidence intervals. The data spans multiple years, allowing for trend analysis of adolescent health behaviors.

Related Topics:
- Adolescent Health
- Public Health
- Behavioral Health
- Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS)
- Epidemiology
- Health Statistics

Concepts and Synonyms:
- Prevalence: Rate, proportion, percentage
- Health Risk Behaviors: Risky behaviors, unhealthy habits, health-related behaviors
- Youth Risk Behavior Survey (YRBS): YRBS, student health survey
- Confidence Intervals: CI, margin of error, uncertainty
- Middle School Students: Adolescents, young people, youth

Applications and Use Cases:
- Monitoring trends in adolescent health risk behaviors over time.
- Identifying areas of concern and prioritizing public health interventions.
- Evaluating the effectiveness of health promotion programs.
- Comparing health risk behaviors across different demographic groups (if available in the dataset).
- Supporting research on the determinants of adolescent health.

title: NYCHA Customer Contact Centers
ufd: This dataset provides information on NYCHA (New York City Housing Authority) customer contact centers. It includes details such as the name of the center, its address (address_1 and address_2), city, state, and zip code. You can also find the phone number, days of operation, and hours for each center. The dataset further provides geographic information, including latitude and longitude, as well as community board, community council, census tract, BIN, BBL, and NTA codes. This data could be used to locate the nearest NYCHA customer contact center, determine its hours of operation, or analyze the geographic distribution of these centers across the city.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains information about New York City Housing Authority (NYCHA) customer contact centers. It includes location details such as address, city, state, and zip code, as well as contact information like phone number and hours of operation.   - Map NYCHA resources and services.
  - Identify areas with limited access to NYCHA customer service.

title: NYC Benefits Platform: Benefits and Programs Multilingual Dataset
ufd: This dataset contains information on over 80 health and human services programs available to NYC residents. The data is available in eleven languages to improve accessibility. Each row represents a specific benefit or program, identified by a unique ID and program code. Key details include the program name, the government agency responsible, the category it falls under (e.g., Housing, Child Care), and the population it serves. Researchers, developers, and city planners can use this data to build resources like websites or directories to help residents discover benefits they may be eligible for. The dataset also specifies the type of page (e.g., Benefit, Program, Service) where the information is presented. This comprehensive resource is updated regularly with the latest eligibility requirements and application dates.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: WiredNYC – All Buildings Data
ufd: This dataset provides insights into the wired infrastructure of buildings in New York City, collected through the WiredNYC survey. Although building-specific address data is anonymized, the dataset reveals valuable information about connectivity and infrastructure at the borough level. Key details include the building's borough, certification class (e.g., Platinum, Gold, or Not certified), and the number of carriers available. The dataset also specifies the types of connections present (coax, fiber, satellite), the distribution of fiber within the building, and the number of ISPs available. Researchers and city planners can use this data to understand the digital infrastructure landscape across NYC boroughs. This information can help identify areas with strong or weak connectivity, inform decisions about infrastructure investments, and support initiatives to improve internet access for residents and businesses.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
The NYC BigApps WiredNYC dataset provides anonymized building-level data on wired infrastructure across New York City boroughs. It includes information on building certification, available carriers and ISPs, connection types (coax, fiber, satellite), and fiber distribution. This data can be used to analyze connectivity and digital infrastructure at the borough level.

- Analyze broadband availability and digital equity across NYC boroughs.
- Identify areas with limited internet access and inform infrastructure investment decisions.
- Evaluate the impact of building certification on connectivity options.
- Compare the wired infrastructure of different boroughs.
- Support research on the relationship between digital infrastructure and economic development.

title: Inclusionary Housing Properties
ufd: This dataset contains information about properties involved in New York City's Inclusionary Housing Program, which aims to create and preserve affordable housing in areas undergoing new development. Each row represents a specific property, detailing its address, borough, and geographic identifiers like BBL, BIN, zip code, council district, community district, census tract, and neighborhood tabulation area. Key columns include `total_ih_floor_area`, `transferred_ih_floor_area`, and `remaining_ih_floor_area`, which provide insights into the floor area associated with inclusionary housing. The `property_type` column indicates whether a property is a "Generating Site," a "Compensated Development," or "Both." Researchers, urban planners, and developers can use this dataset to analyze the distribution of affordable housing, understand the impact of the Inclusionary Housing Program, and identify potential areas for future development. The dataset also includes latitude and longitude coordinates for mapping and spatial analysis.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:

title: DCLA Cultural Institutions Group Funding
ufd: This dataset contains information on funding provided to cultural institutions in New York City. Specifically, it details the operating and energy support given to members of the Cultural Institutions Group (CIG). The dataset includes the name of the cultural institution, the fiscal year for which the funding was allocated, the amount of operating support provided, and the amount of energy support provided. It covers fiscal years 2018, 2019, and 2020, and includes over 30 different institutions. This data could be used to analyze trends in cultural funding, compare support levels across different institutions, or assess the impact of funding on the city's cultural landscape. Researchers, city planners, and cultural organizations can use this information to understand the financial support system for cultural institutions in NYC.
sfd:

title: DCM_ArterialsMajorStreets
ufd: This dataset, part of the Digital City Map (DCM) series, focuses on arterial highways and major streets in New York City. It provides a digital representation of the city's street network, derived from the official City Map. Key attributes include the borough, route name (e.g., "2 Avenue"), route type (e.g., "Major Streets"), and a more specific route subtype. The `the_geom` column contains the geographic coordinates defining the street's path as a MultiLineString. This dataset could be used for urban planning, transportation analysis, or for visualizing and analyzing street characteristics across the city. Please note that updates to this dataset are temporarily paused as the data is moved to a new mapping format; refer to the provided link for more information.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset represents arterial highways and major streets in New York City, derived from the official City Map. It includes attributes like borough, route name, route type, and route subtype for each street segment. The dataset also contains geographic coordinates (`the_geom`) representing the street's path.

title: NYC Drinking Water Tank Inspections and Audits Compliance Results
ufd: This dataset contains information on NYC building drinking water tank inspections and audit compliance results. It includes data reported to the NYC Health Department through self-reported annual inspections or identified during field observations. Key columns include the building identification number (`bin`), address information (`house`, `street_name`, `zip_code`, `borough`), and details about the inspection or audit (`activity_type`, `activity_year`). The dataset also provides information on violations, including the `violation_code`, `law_section`, and `violation_text`, along with the `compliance_year` and `date_of_occurrence`. Researchers and public health officials can use this data to analyze compliance rates, identify areas with frequent violations, and track the effectiveness of drinking water tank oversight programs. Building owners can use this data to understand common violations and ensure compliance with regulations.
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset details inspections and compliance audits of drinking water tanks in NYC buildings, as reported to the NYC Health Department. It includes building identification, location information, inspection details, and any violations found. The data spans self-reported annual inspections and field observations, providing insights into compliance with water tank regulations.

Related Topics:

title: Campaign Financial Analysis
ufd: This dataset provides a financial analysis of election campaigns. It includes information on campaign finance for the 2001 election cycle. Key columns include candidate names (`cand_name`), candidate IDs (`cand_id`), the office they were running for (`office`), and their borough district (`boro_dist`). Financial data includes contribution counts (`cntns_no`), net contributions (`net_cntns`), match amounts (`match_amt`), and public fund payments (`pubfnd_pmt`). Researchers and campaign finance analysts can use this data to understand campaign funding patterns, identify top donors, and analyze the financial health of different campaigns. The dataset also indicates whether a candidate's term ended (`termnd`).
sfd:
Dataset Overview:
This dataset contains financial details of election campaigns for the 2001 election cycle. It includes candidate information such as name, ID, office sought, and borough district. Financial data covers contributions, match amounts, and public fund payments. This data can be used to analyze campaign finance trends and the financial status of individual campaigns.
